('12', 0, 1, 2, 39) 1. TO THE COLONIAL BORN INDIAN
('12', 0, 2, 3, 70) Those of our Colonial born friends who have not read the special contribution 1 to this journal on the Native Industries Exhibition in Durban, and [sic] published last week, we trust, will hasten to read it and ponder over it.
('12', 0, 2, 4, 297) It is written by one who is himself an idealist and who knows thoroughly what he is writing about.
('12', 0, 2, 5, 396) He is, moreover, a friend and fellow worker in the Indian cause.
('12', 0, 2, 6, 461) Our contributor’s remarks are therefore worthy of careful consideration by every Indian whose life mould has not yet been cast or, if it is already cast, does not give real satisfaction.
('12', 0, 2, 7, 648) Our future in South Africa depends largely upon the conduct of those who are born in this country and to whom India is merely a geographical expression.
('12', 0, 2, 8, 801) We associate ourselves with the remarks of our contributor that “lolling on stools in lawyers’ offices” is no “useful ambition”.
('12', 0, 2, 9, 930) A moment’s thought ought to convince our friends that a nation cannot be built out of clerks or even merchants.“Back to the land” is General Botha’s advice even to the Europeans who, after all, do follow many useful occupations.
('12', 0, 2, 10, 1159) The world lives on its farmers and those who are indispensable to farmers, e.g., carpenters, shoemakers, black smiths, masons, bricklayers, tailors, barbers, etc.
('12', 0, 2, 11, 1322) It is a sad fact that very few Colonial−born Indians are found willing enough to learn or take up these truly noble (because useful) professions.
('12', 0, 2, 12, 1468) We all live upon the great industry of the Natives and Indians engaged in useful occupations in this country.
('12', 0, 2, 13, 1578) In this sense they are more civilized than any of us, not excluding European non producers, inhabiting this continent.
('12', 0, 2, 14, 1697) Every speculator may leave the country; every lawyer may shut down his office, every merchant may wind up his business; and yet we should live comfortably on this land endowed by nature with a beneficent climate.
('12', 0, 2, 15, 1910) But if the great Native races were to stop work for a week, we should probably be starving.
('12', 0, 2, 16, 2002) It must, then, be a privilege for us to be able to copy their productive industry and their ability as matters of useful handicraft.
('12', 0, 2, 17, 2135) We assure our friends that, even if all the
('12', 0, 3, 18, 2179) 1 The witer had praised the Natives’ industry, manual skill and intelligence which were in the evidence at the exhibition.
('12', 0, 3, 19, 2302) He felt that Colonial born Indians had no desire to be useful, that education would merely serve to produce clerks among them and that practical training in agriculture or a useful trade was the best way to equip them for public service as well as for life.
('12', 0, 3, 20, 2560) Indian Opinion, 8 7 1911.
('12', 1, 0, 1, 2586) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 1, 1, 2, 2626) galling disabilities which we labour under in South Africa were to be removed at a stroke the pen, our condition would in no wise be satisfactory until our Colonial born friends direct their undoubted ability and energy in the channels pointed out in the contribution we have drawn attention to.
('12', 1, 2, 3, 2922) Indian Opinion, 15 7 1911
('12', 1, 3, 4, 2948) 2. INDIA’S SORRY PLIGHT
('12', 1, 4, 5, 2972) The news that we have had of a complete settlement is satisfying.
('12', 1, 4, 6, 3038) A campaign which called forth such sacrifices could have had only one result.
('12', 1, 4, 7, 3116) [Yet] reflecting over the outcome, one is moved to sorrow at our unfortunate state here.
('12', 1, 4, 8, 3205) Things are so bad that it would seem an edifice had rotted and lay about in ruins.
('12', 1, 4, 9, 3288) If you still see a vestige of form[about it], it is then due to its solid foundations.
('12', 1, 4, 10, 3375) People have been enfeebled in body and mind, and economically.
('12', 1, 4, 11, 3438) Extreme poverty prevails all around.
('12', 1, 4, 12, 3475) There is a [Gujarati] saying about the idle barber who keeps himself busy shaving wooden seats; likewise you must have also heard the one about “the weak husband who is brave with his wife”.
('12', 1, 4, 13, 3666) Sin is the fruit of the tree of poverty.
('12', 1, 4, 14, 3707) The economic situa tion has greatly deteriorated.
('12', 1, 4, 15, 3757) People ask in despair how they can make a living.
('12', 1, 4, 16, 3807) Here you will [of course] say that agriculture is the best of all.
('12', 1, 4, 17, 3874) But that is for men who are patient and of a steady temperament.
('12', 1, 4, 18, 3939) People are in an abject state because of wranglings over affairs of caste, and unhealthy rivalry in regard to commu nal dinners and social customs; [people’s] tendency to be satis fied with the earnings of a few hours’ work, say four, six, eight or ten hours; and to waste the rest; such misguided contentment, the terror of the plague, etc.
('12', 1, 4, 19, 4281) Education, which is believed to be a means for promoting happiness has become instrumental in bringing about the worst state of misery.
('12', 1, 4, 20, 4417) The strain of learning leaves one a physical wreck.
('12', 1, 4, 21, 4469) The methods of learning are such that they wholly wear one out in body, in mind, and financially.
('12', 1, 4, 22, 4567) Add to this the burden of [keeping up] status in society.
('12', 1, 4, 23, 4625) By the time a man is mature and knowing and tries to hold his head high, he is weighed down with the responsibilities of family.
('12', 1, 5, 24, 4754) We find these reflections in a letter by a certain experienced and educated Indian of South Africa to another.
('12', 1, 5, 25, 4865) The correspondent has
('12', 2, 0, 1, 4887) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 3
('12', 2, 1, 2, 4926) given a faithful and vivid picture of conditions in India.
('12', 2, 1, 3, 4985) We thought it necessary to cite these views and comment on them for the benefit of readers.
('12', 2, 1, 4, 5077) A patriot’s first duty is to know the state of his country.
('12', 2, 1, 5, 5137) Having done so, his next duty is to search for a remedy.
('12', 2, 1, 6, 5194) This done, his third duty is to give effect to the remedy.
('12', 2, 1, 7, 5253) The state of the country is as set forth above.
('12', 2, 1, 8, 5301) One cannot question that description.
('12', 2, 1, 9, 5339) Once the remedy is know, it is up to the readers to put it into practice.
('12', 2, 1, 10, 5413) Our function is to help them to discover the remedy.
('12', 2, 2, 11, 5466) In the very process of setting forth the country’s sorry plight, the correspondent mentioned some of the reasons.
('12', 2, 2, 12, 5580) Let us consider them further.
('12', 2, 2, 13, 5610) Starvation is not a cause of misery.
('12', 2, 2, 14, 5647) It is itself misery.
('12', 2, 2, 15, 5668) The contentment men find in service is not a cause of degradation; it is degradation in itself.
('12', 2, 2, 16, 5764) Wranglings over affairs of caste, hypocrisy, unhealthy rivalries, the terror of the plague—these are not causes of a fallen state; they constitute that state.
('12', 2, 2, 17, 5923) [In fact] there is a single cause for all these.
('12', 2, 2, 18, 5972) We have forsaken our duty.
('12', 2, 2, 19, 5999) We have forgotten God and we worship Satan.
('12', 2, 2, 20, 6043) A man’s duty is to worship God.
('12', 2, 2, 21, 6075) Telling one’s beads is no symbol of that worship; neither is going to mosque or temple., nor saying the namaz 1 or the gayatri 2. These things are all right as far as they go.
('12', 2, 2, 22, 6251) It is necessary to do the one or the other according to one’s religion.
('12', 2, 2, 23, 6323) But by themselves they are no indication of one’s being devoted to god in worship.
('12', 2, 2, 24, 6406) He alone truly adores god who finds his happiness in the happiness of others, speaks evil of none, does not waste his time in the pursuit of riches, does nothing immoral, who acquits himself with others as with a friend, does not fear the plague or any human being.
('12', 2, 2, 25, 6672) Such a one will not, for fear of his caste, give communal dinners; if he is young, he will not, for fear of his men of his caste, marry before he is old enough or until he feels the need for it, and, if a father, he will not, for fear of men of his caste, ruin his son’s and daughter’s future.
('12', 2, 2, 26, 6966) Such a one will not pause, in deciding on any course of action, to think of what any individual or community would think of it.
('12', 2, 2, 27, 7094) He will only ask himself: ‘What will God within me say of this deed of mine?’ The upshot of all this is that all of us, whether Hindus, Muslims, Parsis or Christians, have forsaken our true religion.
('12', 2, 2, 28, 7294) If this view is right, what we need is not remedies against the plague or revolt against the British rule; neither big associations with theirostentatious ways of doing things, nor societies
('12', 2, 3, 29, 7485) 1 The Islamic prayer 2 The Rigvedic hymn to the Sun God
('12', 3, 0, 1, 7541) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 3, 1, 2, 7581) nor meetings; neither will it be any use to keep looking at one another., waiting to act till others give us the lead.
('12', 3, 1, 3, 7700) One thing alone is needful; all of us, having learnt our duty; must presevere in it till the moment of death.
('12', 3, 1, 4, 7810) If this view is right, we need help from none save God.
('12', 3, 1, 5, 7866) We can then do our duty in the midst of a conflagration, can still do it even if placed on the edge of a sword.
('12', 3, 1, 6, 7978) The worst then that can happen is that we lose our mortal bodies.
('12', 3, 1, 7, 8044) Why fear this?
('12', 3, 1, 8, 8059) Fear will not keep the body alive.
('12', 3, 1, 9, 8094) It will perish, when the appointed hour comes.
('12', 3, 1, 10, 8141) If we do our duty in this manner, so easy if only we will think of it, we shall know the rest as we go on.
('12', 3, 1, 11, 8248) The first need of a man lost in a thick wood at night is light.
('12', 3, 1, 12, 8312) He may then bide without fear till he finds the road.
('12', 3, 1, 13, 8366) When he does find it, he will take it straightaway.
('12', 3, 1, 14, 8418) If he finds any institutions on the way, he will use them as bridges for crossing rivers and streams.
('12', 3, 1, 15, 8520) If the bridges are in disrepair, he will examine them with the aid of the light and call attention to the cracks of other defects.
('12', 3, 1, 16, 8651) This light of duty is easy for anyone to acquire and once it is acquired, the way will be found forthwith; even a child will admit that.
('12', 3, 2, 17, 8788) [From Gujarati]
('12', 3, 3, 18, 8804) Indian Opinion, 15 7 1911
('12', 3, 4, 19, 8830) 3. LETTER TO MAGANLAL GANDHI Monday night [July 17, 1911] 1
('12', 3, 5, 20, 8890) MAGANLAL,
('12', 3, 6, 21, 8900) Your letter regarding the trust and other matters came to hand only today.
('12', 3, 6, 22, 8975) It will be better if you address your letters to the Farm hereafter.
('12', 3, 6, 23, 9044) I propose going to Johannesburg only once a week, that is, on Monday.
('12', 3, 7, 24, 9114) 1 The Somali, by which Chhaganlal Gandhi sailed from India, was first expected to arrived at Durban on july 15, 1911, according to the German East African Line advertisement in Indian Opinion, 15 7 1911. A news item appearing in the Gujarati section the same week, however, mentions that the boat would arrive on july 18, 1911, instead.
('12', 3, 7, 25, 9451) Acually she arrived on July 20, 1911, Indian Opinion 22 7 1911. From Gandhiji’s letter of July 12, 1911 to Maganlal Gandhi (p.123), it is clear that he has heard from Chhaganlal Gandhi but is awaiting a cable from him, presumably about his arrival.
('12', 3, 7, 26, 9700) It was therefore, on a Monday following July 12, 1911, that this letter was written, that is, on July 17, 1911. On this Monday, it was still believed that s.s.
('12', 3, 7, 27, 9860) Somali would arrive on July 18, 1911. Thus it is that Gandhiji says later in the letter that Chhaganlal and the others must have arrived by the time Maganlal got this letter.
('12', 4, 0, 1, 10035) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 5
('12', 4, 1, 2, 10074) The arrangement about the Library is all right.
('12', 4, 1, 3, 10122) Do not order books for the present.
('12', 4, 1, 4, 10158) It is better just to collect money.
('12', 4, 1, 5, 10194) I also think it is no longer necessary to keep a separate account of the profits from the store.
('12', 4, 1, 6, 10291) If the matter cannot be settled just now, we shall dispose of it when I go there [next].
('12', 4, 1, 7, 10380) Please make a note of this.
('12', 4, 1, 8, 10408) And now to the main part of your letter.
('12', 4, 1, 9, 10449) With a little reflection, you will be able to see that the question who should send out whom just does not arise.
('12', 4, 1, 10, 10563) When Phoenix is really in difficulties, there will be no question of sending out or retaining anybody.
('12', 4, 1, 11, 10666) He alone will stay on there who has got into the true spirit.
('12', 4, 1, 12, 10728) The problem then will be whether anyone will stay at all.
('12', 4, 1, 13, 10786) No salaries are paid today, but only a kind of maintenance allowance.
('12', 4, 1, 14, 10856) Who will remain, prepared to have this reduced, to face extreme suffering and live on plain bread—that will be the problem.
('12', 4, 1, 15, 10980) This means that the problem will not arise.
('12', 4, 1, 16, 11024) We shall know then who the true mother is and who the false.
('12', 4, 1, 17, 11085) The doubt that has occurred to you is pointless.
('12', 4, 1, 18, 11134) And so are your fears about the children.
('12', 4, 1, 19, 11176) India, being a land of virtue, has sports of wickedness.
('12', 4, 1, 20, 11233) So also, other countries, though lands of sin, have oases by way virtuous spots.
('12', 4, 1, 21, 11314) We are, however, doing our work with our eyes fixed on India.
('12', 4, 1, 22, 11376) Where is the room, then, for any question about the children?
('12', 4, 1, 23, 11438) Phoenix will have, and has, a constitution which will enable all children who so desire to visit India.
('12', 4, 1, 24, 11542) And how can anyone say that [the spirit of] Phoenix will remain confined to Phoenix alone?
('12', 4, 1, 25, 11633) Wherever the aims of Phoenix are present, there you will have Phoenix.
('12', 4, 1, 26, 11704) Do you forget that we are all preparing ourselves for India?
('12', 4, 1, 27, 11765) Should you and your children, however, lay down their lives for India in Phoenix itself, what harm will there be?
('12', 4, 1, 28, 11879) If we live in Phoenix as we would in India, there will be only this difference between India and Phoenix: we shall have adopted the virtuous practices of India and eschewed the evils that obtain there to day.
('12', 4, 1, 29, 12088) Is this anything to be sorry about?
('12', 4, 1, 30, 12124) I shall write more on hearing from you.
('12', 4, 1, 31, 12164) If you consider my atman 1 to have great power, yours, too., has it.
('12', 4, 1, 32, 12233) There is no difference between us in respect of our atmans.
('12', 4, 1, 33, 12293) The moment you rid yourself of whatever in you is foreign to the nature of the atman—timidity, doubt, irresolution, etc.—we are equals, The
('12', 4, 2, 34, 12433) 1 The individual self which neither does nor suffers anything
('12', 5, 0, 1, 12495) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 5, 1, 2, 12535) only difference lies in the fact that I have, with great effort, got rid of many of my defects.
('12', 5, 1, 3, 12631) If you make the bid with a determined mind, you, too will be able to cleanse yourself of all such defects and more.
('12', 5, 1, 4, 12747) Chhaganlal, Anandlal, Jamnadas 1 and others may possibly be there before this letter reaches you.
('12', 5, 1, 5, 12845) I for one am very glad that they are all coming; You ask to have a test; but that you cannot have from me.
('12', 5, 1, 6, 12952) When the time is ripe, you will get it without asking for it.
('12', 5, 1, 7, 13014) Readiness is all.
('12', 5, 1, 8, 13032) It does not seem likely that any member [of the party coming] will have difficulty in landing.
('12', 5, 1, 9, 13127) All the same, I have made the necessary recommendation 2 to the office.
('12', 5, 2, 10, 13199) Blessings from MOHANDAS [PS.] I hope a copy of the Trust Deed will be in your hand next week.
('12', 5, 2, 11, 13293) It is only a draft.

('12', 5, 6, 17, 13617) The news lacks confirmation.
('12', 5, 6, 18, 13646) But if it is true, it is nothing surprising.
('12', 5, 6, 19, 13691) They could not very well suppress my translations 4 of Ruskin’s Unto This Last and not suppress I.O. which either in the English or the Gujarati columns re echoes those views more or less forcibly.
('12', 5, 6, 20, 13889) If the paper is suppressed, my first thought is that I must accept the challenge and go to India at the earliest possible moment.
('12', 5, 6, 21, 14019) This may alter our or my plans.
('12', 5, 6, 22, 14051) It is evident that sooner or later the Andamans must be my home.
('12', 5, 6, 23, 14116) And why not?
('12', 5, 6, 24, 14129) That home should be as sweet as any other if it be purchased with duty done.

('12', 7, 1, 2, 16379) 5. LETTER TO HARILAL GANDHI
('12', 7, 2, 3, 16407) [LAWLEY,] Ashadh Vad O [July 25, 1911] 1
('12', 7, 3, 4, 16448) HARILAL, There should have been a letter from you from India.
('12', 7, 3, 5, 16510) You met Chi.
('12', 7, 3, 6, 16523) Chhaganlal there, and he is now already here.
('12', 7, 3, 7, 16569) I do hope there will be one by next mail.
('12', 7, 3, 8, 16611) Chhaganlal has brought news that Revashankerbhai advised you to join some commercial class in Bombay, deprecating [the idea of your going to] Ahmedabad.
('12', 7, 3, 9, 16764) Chhaganlal also told me that you, on the other hand, continued to prefer Ahmedabad, up to the time he left.
('12', 7, 3, 10, 16872) I still consider Ahmedabad to be better.
('12', 7, 3, 11, 16913) It serves our purpose better.
('12', 7, 3, 12, 16943) Though English may be less easy to learn in Ahmedabad, Gujarati, Sanskrit, etc., can certainly be done well there.
('12', 7, 3, 13, 17058) I personally do not like Bombay at all.
('12', 7, 3, 14, 17098) You may, however, do what you think best.
('12', 7, 3, 15, 17140) I see from Chanchi’s letter that Manilal 2 is suffering from a serious illness.
('12', 7, 3, 16, 17220) Please try if you can to persuade him to come here.
('12', 7, 3, 17, 17272) Let him and Bali both come.
('12', 7, 3, 18, 17300) Open air and nutritious but simple food is the only remedy for a tuberculosis patient.
('12', 7, 3, 19, 17387) Please write to Chanchi not to expect regular letter from me.
('12', 7, 3, 20, 17449) The burden on me at present is especially heavy, I go to Johannesburg only on Mondays.
('12', 7, 3, 21, 17536) This is how things go on: physical labour on the farm up to 10 a.m.; teaching work at the school from 1.00 to 4.30 p.m.; meal at 5.30 p.m.
('12', 7, 3, 22, 17675) and office and other correspondence at night.
('12', 7, 3, 23, 17721) As I do everything single handed, I have no time left and I do writing work till late at night.
('12', 7, 3, 24, 17817) It is 9.45 p.m.
('12', 7, 3, 25, 17833) now as I write this and I have more letters to write yet.
('12', 7, 3, 26, 17891) Mr. & Mrs. John, Rambhabhai 3, Mrs. Phillips, Mr. K. Naidoo and his wife are at the Farm.
('12', 7, 3, 27, 17981) There are five boys and two girls in my school.
('12', 7, 3, 28, 18029) But as they all belong to different standards, even these few are too many.
('12', 7, 3, 29, 18105) I am still on saltless diet.
('12', 7, 3, 30, 18134) I personally feel better for it and as for Ba, it appears her very life has been saved.
('12', 7, 3, 31, 18222) So far as I can see, she is a

('12', 10, 1, 2, 22453) 8. AN AGREEMENT [July 29, 1911] 1
('12', 10, 2, 3, 22487) Articles of Agreement between Lower House and Upper House.
('12', 10, 2, 4, 22546) Lower House is to proceed to Europe on a sacred pilgrimage to the members of his family during the month of August next.
('12', 10, 2, 5, 22667) Lower House is not to spend any money beyond necessaries befitting the position of a simple living poor farmer.
('12', 10, 2, 6, 22779) Lower House is not to contract any marriage tie during his absence.
('12', 10, 2, 7, 22847) Lower House shall not look lustfully upon any woman.
('12', 10, 2, 8, 22900) Lower House is to travel 3rd class whether by sea or land.
('12', 10, 2, 9, 22959) Lower House may, if the exigencies of his business in Johannesburg permit it,visit India with Dr. Mehta.
('12', 10, 2, 10, 23064) In the event of his so doing he will travel the same class as Dr. Mehta.
('12', 10, 2, 11, 23137) Lower House will not tarry long in London or any other place, save the homes of the members of the family.
('12', 10, 2, 12, 23244) The consideration for all the above tasks imposed by Lower House on himself is more love and yet more love between the two Houses ≈ such love as, they hope, the world has not seen.
('12', 10, 2, 13, 23425) In witness whereof the parties hereto solemnly affix their signatures in the presence of the Maker of all this 29th day of July at Tolstoy Farm.

('12', 13, 1, 2, 28362) 11. RECEPTION TO MR. KALLENBACH
('12', 13, 2, 3, 28394) Mr. Kallenbach had intended to slip away from Johannesburg quietly and without any demonstration from the Indian community.
('12', 13, 2, 4, 28518) But God willed otherwise.
('12', 13, 2, 5, 28544) As soon as it became known that Mr. Kallenbach was to leave for Europe, leading passive resisters began to discuss among themselves the desirability of “doing something’.
('12', 13, 2, 6, 28715) They felt that the owner of Tolstoy Farm, who had done so much for them in his own inimitable way, could not be allowed to leave unhonoured by the community.
('12', 13, 2, 7, 28873) It was by an accident that the day of Mr. Kallenbach’s departure became known.
('12', 13, 2, 8, 28952) The time was short.
('12', 13, 2, 9, 28972) But subscriptions were at once raised.
('12', 13, 2, 10, 29011) It was decided to present him with an illuminated address, enclosed in a solid silver casket.
('12', 13, 2, 11, 29105) The ideas was incongruous enough.
('12', 13, 2, 12, 29139) Mr. Kallenbach, who had given up most of his luxuries, and had taken to a simple life on Tolstoy Farm where he entirely shared the life of poor passive resisters, often drinking and eating with them, using a verandah as his chair and his lap for a dinner table, to be presented with a solid silver casket!
('12', 13, 2, 13, 29445) Where was be to keep it?
('12', 13, 2, 14, 29470) That was no concern of the enthusiastic admirers.
('12', 13, 2, 15, 29520) So the address was illuminated and a silver casket ordered and prepared.
('12', 13, 2, 16, 29593) At practically the last minute, Mr. Kallenbach was informed that he was to be presented with an address.
('12', 13, 2, 17, 29698) Mr. Kallenbach laughed.
('12', 13, 2, 18, 29722) “What have I done?
('12', 13, 2, 19, 29741) You owe me nothing, and if you do, I do not wish to collect my debt just yet.” This happened on Saturday when he was on his way to the Farm.
('12', 13, 2, 20, 29882) He was to leave on Monday.
('12', 13, 2, 21, 29909) 1 But the determined men who had done duty as pickets would not have ‘no’ for an answer.
('12', 13, 2, 22, 29998) Mr. Kallenbach said; “I cannot receive any public acknow ledgment.” His interviewers said; “You must.” Thus they parted, Mr. Kallenbach thinking the storm had blown over.
('12', 13, 2, 23, 30169) But on Monday morning, on his way from Lawley, Mr. Kallenbach was picketed and intercepted by a zealous band, headed by Mr. Thambi Naidoo, who had all run from Vrededorp to Canada, a distance of five miles, to meet him in his own compartment.
('12', 13, 2, 24, 30412) Others met him at Fordsburg sta tion.
('12', 13, 2, 25, 30450) What could Mr. Kallenbach do against such determination.
('12', 13, 2, 26, 30507) He had to yield.
('12', 13, 2, 27, 30524) Passive resistance (love) and picketing were once more triumphant.
('12', 13, 2, 28, 30591) Mr. Kallenbach hurreid to the Rev.
('12', 13, 2, 29, 30626) Phillip’s Hall.
('12', 13, 2, 30, 30642) Imam Abdul Kadir Bawazeer presided.
('12', 13, 2, 31, 30678) He related Mr. Kallenbach’s services
('12', 13, 3, 32, 30715) 1 July 31, 1911
('12', 14, 0, 1, 30731) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 15
('12', 14, 1, 2, 30771) in a few well chosen words.
('12', 14, 1, 3, 30799) Mr. Thambi Naidoo read the address which is as follows.
('12', 14, 2, 4, 30855) Mr. Easton 2, on behalf of the Cantonese Club, presented him with the complete works of Carlyle in a beautiful silver mounted case, and Mr. Morarji with the works of Ruskin in a similar case on behalf of the Hindu Association.
('12', 14, 2, 5, 31082) Mr. Kallenbach then, in the course of his reply, said that he did not consider his friends, who had done him so singular an honour, owed him anything at all.
('12', 14, 2, 6, 31240) It was he who was the debtor.
('12', 14, 2, 7, 31270) It was a mater of privilege to him to be able to do what he did during the struggle that lasted five years.
('12', 14, 2, 8, 31378) And he did it for his own sake.
('12', 14, 2, 9, 31410) He sincerely believed that he had gained much through the struggle.
('12', 14, 2, 10, 31478) At the end of it he found himself a better and stronger man.
('12', 14, 2, 11, 31539) He assured his hearers that it was through the struggle that he had overcome many of his prejudices and his weaknesses.
('12', 14, 2, 12, 31659) If ever again the struggle was revived, he was prepared to do what little he could and he knew that whatever he did in such a struggle he would be the gainer.
('12', 14, 2, 13, 31818) After giving renewed thanks for the gifts, Mr. Kallenbach resumed his seat amid applause.
('12', 14, 2, 14, 31908) Mr. Cachalia, was absent, being obliged to go to Warmbaths to attend a sick friend.
('12', 14, 2, 15, 31992) Mr. Ritch, Mrs. Vogl, Miss Schlesin and Mr. Isaac 3 supported the Chair on the platform.
('12', 14, 2, 16, 32081) At the station there was representative gathering of Indians besides his European friends to see Mr. Kallenbach off.
('12', 14, 2, 17, 32198) In order to gain experience and still further to simplify his life and to discipline himself, Mr. Kallenbach travelled 3rd class by the train, much to the surprise of his many friends who had always seen him enjoy all “the good things of life”.
('12', 14, 2, 18, 32443) Mr. Kallenbach is travelling 3rd class on the steamer also.
('12', 14, 2, 19, 32503) All the settlers on Tolstoy Farm were at Lawley station to see Mr. Kallenbach off.
('12', 14, 3, 20, 32586) 1 For the text, vide “Address to H. Kallenbach”.
('12', 14, 3, 21, 32635) 31 7 1911. 2 Martin Easton; Acting Chairman, Chinese Association and Quinn’s successor to that office; associated himself with Gandhiji’s protest against the racial discrimination implied in the Union Immigrant’ Restriction Bill; vide “Telegram to Secretary to Minister of Interior”, 18 3 1911. 3 Gabriel I. Isaac; English Jew and jeweller; a practising vegetarian associated with the Johannesburg vegetarian restaurant; sometime member of Phoenix settlements; travelled collecting subscriptions and advertisements for Indian Opinion and was ever ready to be of use to the journal and to Gandhiji; in 1908 offered to become nominal owner of satyagrahis; shops, following the Government’s policy of auctioning their goods; in June, 1909, was sent by Gandhiji to Delagoa Bay to assist satyagrahis being deported to India; vide “Johannesburg Letter”, 31 8 1908. He went to jail as a satyagrahi during the Great March of 1913.

('12', 15, 2, 3, 33762) 12. MR. KALLENBACH
('12', 15, 3, 4, 33781) Our readers will be glad to possess a portrait, which we issue this week as a supplement, of Mr. H. Kallenbach whom they best know as the owner of Tolstoy Farm, of which he gave the free use to passive resisters families and which is still being used for the purpose.
('12', 15, 3, 5, 34049) Mr. Kallenbach is leaving for Europe principally for sake of meeting the many members of his family in Germany and expects to return within six months.
('12', 15, 3, 6, 34201) Our readers will recollect that, when both Mr. Gandhi and Mr. Polak were absent, Mr. Kallenbach acted as the Honorary Secre tary of the British Indian Association—a most critical time in the history of the struggle.
('12', 15, 3, 7, 34417) Indian Opinion, 5 8 1911
('12', 15, 4, 8, 34442) 13. TUBERCULOSIS
('12', 15, 5, 9, 34459) We invite the special attention of our Natal Indian readers to Dr. Murison’s 1 letter to Mr. Gandhi on the campaign that he, with the assistance of Dr. Adams, the specialist, is conducing in the Durban Borough against tuberculosis.
('12', 15, 5, 10, 34691) This fell disease is no respecter of persons and affect all the communities residing in Durban.
('12', 15, 5, 11, 34787) If its pro gress is not arrested in time, it is difficult to estimate the damage it may cause to precious human lives.
('12', 15, 5, 12, 34906) It is then only proper that Mr. Jameson and his Committee should seek and command the co oper ation of all the communities in their endeavour to root out the disease.
('12', 15, 5, 13, 35073) At the desire of Mr. Jameson a small Indian Committee has been already formed to render the necessary assistance to his Committee to assist ourselves.
('12', 15, 5, 14, 35224) But the establishment of the Committee is not enough.
('12', 15, 6, 15, 35278) 1 Dr. Murison, Medical Officer of Health, Durban.
('12', 15, 6, 16, 35328) During the 1904 plague, Gandhiji found him “sympathetic and ready to help”; vide “The Plague Peg”, 16 7 1904 & “From Pillar to Post”, 30 7 1904. On July 10, 1911 he wrote in reply to Gandhiji’s of July 4, 1911 (not available), suggesting that an Indian Committee and about twenty volunteers co operate with Durban Health Department’s anti tuberculosis campaign so that the Borough bye laws for the prevention of infectious diseases might not be invoked.
('12', 15, 6, 17, 35782) Indian Opinion, 5 8 1911.
('12', 16, 0, 1, 35808) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 17
('12', 16, 1, 2, 35848) We have no doubt that Dr. Murison ought to be besieged by Indian volunteers who would place themselves at his disposal to do inspection and visiting work.
('12', 16, 1, 3, 36003) They may become angels of mercy in the truest sense of the term.
('12', 16, 1, 4, 36068) We feel sure that the work that Dr. Murison expect (and rightly) from us can only be performed by volunteers and not paid workers.
('12', 16, 1, 5, 36199) Who can reason with our consumptives except our lea ders?
('12', 16, 1, 6, 36257) Dr. Adams preaches the gospel of open air, first and last, in the treatmentof this disease.
('12', 16, 1, 7, 36349) It will require all the ability and persuasive powers of those whom the people trust before the latter will adopt the treatment which is so incredibly 1 simple and yet, unless it is under stood, so difficult of adoption.
('12', 16, 1, 8, 36570) Those who are afraid of catching cold if they breathed the fresh but cold air of the fields rather than the hot but contaminated and carbon loaded atmosphere of a stuffy room are not to be easily persuaded that their salvation—freedom from consumption—lies in breathing pure and invigorating fresh air even as we drink pure and health giving water rather than poisoned water vomited by others.
('12', 16, 1, 9, 36964) We trust that every influential Indian will have his name registered is a volunteer worker in the crusade of the Durban Corporation against tuberculosis.

('12', 19, 1, 9, 42892) Your bearing at the station pleased all.
('12', 19, 1, 10, 42933) Your having forgotten the cheque book was a most natural thing in that rush.
('12', 19, 1, 11, 43010) The wonder really is that you put in so much work that morning with so much self possession and forget only the cheque book.
('12', 19, 1, 12, 43135) You know our mutual canon of interpretation: ‘not to put an unfavourable construction upon a man’s writing or action so long as a favourable one is possible’.
('12', 19, 1, 13, 43294) You were hurt at my simple remark about the charge of your not being the same whether I was with you or not.
('12', 19, 1, 14, 43403) I have not in my wildest dreams suspected you of having withheld anything from me.
('12', 19, 1, 15, 43486) Indeed one of the binding links between us is my invisible belief in your absolute and natural frankness with me.
('12', 19, 1, 16, 43600) All I said and still say was and is that when several people bring a charge against us, we should proceed to examine ourselves upon the assumption that there is some truth in the charge.
('12', 19, 1, 17, 43787) We need not jump to the conclusion that it is baseless.
('12', 19, 1, 18, 43843) Our friends often know us better than we do ourselves.
('12', 19, 1, 19, 43898) The reason is that all of us being not perfect do things unconsciously of which we are not witnesses but our friends are.
('12', 19, 1, 20, 44020) There was no rebuke ever meant when I made the remark, much less any mistrust.
('12', 19, 1, 21, 44099) Have I made myself understood!
('12', 19, 1, 22, 44130) It hurts me to think that I should have even unwillingly hurt you on the day of your departure.

('12', 22, 1, 2, 48669) 17. THE STORM GATHERING
('12', 22, 2, 3, 48693) Thoreau went to gaol for the sake of those who did not belong to his race.
('12', 22, 2, 4, 48768) So many Mr. Ritch go to gaol for the sake of us who do not wear the same skin as he does.
('12', 22, 2, 5, 48858) For he has received a notice to the effect that in allowing Indians to remain on the Stands registered in his name in Krugersdorp, he is committing a criminal offence.
('12', 22, 2, 6, 49026) 1 We know that Mr. Ritch is not likely to give up the Stands on account of the notice.
('12', 22, 2, 7, 49113) The authorities know well that Mr. Ritch is a trustee holding the Stands in question for his Indian wards.
('12', 22, 2, 8, 49220) Mr. Ritch does not allow them to remain on his stands.
('12', 22, 2, 9, 49275) They (the Indians) remain on their own.
('12', 22, 2, 10, 49315) That is the real position, although, in the eyes of the law, Mr. Ritch is the owner and no other.
('12', 22, 2, 11, 49413) Klerksdorp Indian have been threatened.
('12', 22, 2, 12, 49453) 2 In Roodepoort a prosecution has already taken place and an appeal is pending.
('12', 22, 2, 13, 49533) 3 Now the compliment has been paid to Krugersdorp.
('12', 22, 2, 14, 49584) Evidently the autho rities imagine that Indians will abandon their stores and their stock immediately they take action.
('12', 22, 2, 15, 49704) Mr. Neser 4 (and he ought to know) has informed South Africa that the Government have stayed their hand only because of this being the Coronation year and that actual proceedings will be take next year.
('12', 22, 2, 16, 49907) Mean while, therefore, we fancy the Government are sharpening their weapons.
('12', 22, 2, 17, 49984) The notice served on Mr. Ritch is a clear call to the Indians to show of what stuff they are
('12', 22, 3, 18, 50077) 1 Ritch was the owner of certain Stands occupied by Indian in the mining area of Krugersdorp which had been declared “Proclaimed Areas” under the Gold Law, Act 35 if 1908. On August 3, 1911 the Public prosecutor, Krugersdorp, sent him a notice warning him that he was contravening section 130 of Act 35 of 1908 and was liable to criminal prosecution.
('12', 22, 3, 19, 50428) He was directed to ask his Indian tenants to vacate.
('12', 22, 3, 20, 50481) Indian Opinion, 12 8 1911. 2 Vide “Extract from Letter to Maud Polak” 5 4 1911. 3 At Roodepoort, one Alfred Tamblin was charged under Section 130 of the Gold Law of 1908 for subletting a mining stands to two Asiatics, Ahmed Khan and Abdulla Khan.
('12', 22, 3, 21, 50728) His counsel argued that under the old Gold Law, an owner had the right to sublet his stand to coloured persons and that under section 77 of the present Gold Law, Coloured persons were entitle to acquire rights to stands, but the case was remanded.
('12', 22, 3, 22, 50976) Subsequently a Krugersdorp magistrate found Tamblin guilty and sentenced him.
('12', 22, 3, 23, 51054) On appeal, the Transvaal Division of the Supreme Court of South Africa acquitted Tamblin and ruled that the Asiatics in question we protected by section 77 of the new Gold Law.
('12', 22, 3, 24, 51231) Indian Opinion 24 6 1911 & 2 9 1911 4 Member of Union Parliament.
('12', 23, 0, 1, 51297) 24 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 23, 1, 2, 51338) We have no doubt that if for no other reason, seeing that Mr. Ritch may himself have to go to gaol, the Indians affected by the notice will remain firm and show once more to the Government that, unless they carry with them the Asiatic communities their laws adversely affecting them must remain a dead letter.

('12', 27, 1, 2, 58403) 22. INDIANS SUPPORT MR. RITCH
('12', 27, 2, 3, 58433) An important meeting 1 of the British Indian Association was held at the Hamidia Society’s Hall on Sunday evening last.
('12', 27, 2, 4, 58553) Mr. Cachalia was in the chair.
('12', 27, 2, 5, 58584) Invitations were sent all over the province.
('12', 27, 2, 6, 58629) A telegram was received from Klerksdorp regretting absence but accep ting the decision of the meeting.
('12', 27, 2, 7, 58732) Representatives attended from Krugersdorp, Rooderpoort, etc.
('12', 27, 2, 8, 58793) Messrs Ritch, Quinn, and Isaac were also present.
('12', 27, 2, 9, 58843) At the invitation of Mr. Cachalia, Mr. Gandhi explained the effect of the proposed action of the authorities.
('12', 27, 2, 10, 58953) The proceedings were earnest and the meeting showed determination to go through the impending storm.
('12', 27, 2, 11, 59054) Mr. Gandhi explained that he had Mr. Ritch’s authority for stating that he (Mr. Ritch) was prepared to stand by the community and incur the risk of imprisonment should it be necessary in making good the trust he had undertaken on behalf of those whose properties were registered in his name.
('12', 27, 2, 12, 59346) After full discussion, the following resolutions were unanimously passed:
('12', 27, 3, 13, 59420) This meeting of British Indians thanks Mr. Ritch for his presence thereat, and for his magnanimous offer to help the community even to the extent of suffering imprisonment in connection with notices issued by the authorities under the Gold Law and in connection with landed property registered in his name, but held by him in trust for member of this community.
('12', 27, 3, 14, 59782) Proposed by Mr. Dadoo (Krugersdorp), and seconded by Mr. Ahmed Khan (Roodepoort).
('12', 27, 4, 15, 59864) This meeting resolves to resist to the utmost the attempt being made to oust Indian merchants from their possessions and businesses, and to suffer imprisonment and other trials during the threatened campaign against them in respect of the Gold Law and the Townships Amendment Act of 1908. Proposed by Mr. Ismail Amod Moola, seconded by Mr. Amod Moosajee and supported by Mr. E. G. Coovadia.
('12', 27, 5, 16, 60255) 1 Held to consider the notice served on Ritch by the public prosecutor, Krugersdorp; vide “The Storm Gathering”, 12 8 1911. 2 Ebrahim Saleji Coovadia; well known Johannesburg merchant and some time Treasurer, Hamidia Islamic Society; acting Chairman, British Indian Association, 1909 and 1910 (Vol. IX p.
('12', 27, 5, 17, 60560) 252 fn and Vol. X. p.
('12', 27, 5, 18, 60582) 268 fn) repeatedly suffered imprisonment as a satyagrahi in 1908 and 1909; in June, 1909 was elected member of the proposed Transvaal Indians’ deputation to India, but was arrested immediately after; vide “Speech at Mass Meeting”, 16 6 1909.
('12', 28, 0, 1, 60824) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 29
('12', 28, 1, 2, 60864) This meeting authorizes the Chairman to send a respectful representation to the Government, enclosing copies of the foregoing resolutions, and urging them to alter the above mentioned laws, so as to reassure the Indian Community and to protect its member in their legitimate occupations.
('12', 28, 1, 3, 61152) Proposed by Mr. A.M. Vaja seconded by Mr. A. A. Karodia and supported by Mr. H. Mal and Mr. M. S. Nana.
('12', 28, 1, 4, 61256) It was also decided to start collecting subscriptions in aid of this struggle.

('12', 28, 3, 6, 61361) 23. AN IMPORTANT DECISION
('12', 28, 4, 7, 61387) Mr. Ritch as well as the British Indian Association of the Transvaal are to be congratulated on their respective decisions as evidenced by the report of the meeting 1 of the Association, published in another column.
('12', 28, 4, 8, 61603) Mr. Ritch, by his generous action, has put the finishing touch to the many services he has so selflessly rendered to the community.
('12', 28, 4, 9, 61735) His action has increased tenfold the responsibility of British Indians in the Transvaal.
('12', 28, 4, 10, 61824) We can only deserve execration from every right minded man if, after allowing Mr. Ritch to go to gaol we though sheer cowardice, avoid the prospect of imprisonment our selves.
('12', 28, 4, 11, 62000) It is therefore but meet that the Association passed the second resolution, committing the community to defend the interests that are in jeopardy, even to the extent of suffering imprisonment or whatever more may be in store for it.
('12', 28, 4, 12, 62233) The third resolution enables Mr. Cachalia to bring the two very important resolutions to the notice of the Government.
('12', 28, 4, 13, 62352) Mr. Cachalia has not allowed any time to lapse.
('12', 28, 4, 14, 62400) And we must now await the decision of the Government.
('12', 28, 4, 15, 62454) We hope that wise counsels will prevail among the member of the Union Cabinet, and that they will avert what promises to become a national calamity.
('12', 28, 4, 16, 62603) Indians are not to be expected to allow their interests to be played “ducks and drakes” with.
('12', 28, 4, 17, 62697) The result of any attempt to force matters on the part of the Government can therefore only be (a) repetition of the unseemly spectacle of a mightly Government setting all its machi nery in motion to crush a small low abiding community, endea vouring to hold on to its own.

('12', 29, 0, 1, 63024) 30 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 29, 1, 2, 63065) 24. AN EDUCATION SCANDAL
('12', 29, 2, 3, 63090) Formerly, Indian girls attended the ordinary Government Schools for girls in Durban.
('12', 29, 2, 4, 63175) Some years ago, Indian girls were prohi bited from attending these schools and provision was made for their attendance at the Higher Grade Indian School.
('12', 29, 2, 5, 63329) Promise was made that the girls would receive separate education from the boys.
('12', 29, 2, 6, 63409) Notwith standing the promise, the Government tried the experiment of mixing boys and girls, and failed.
('12', 29, 2, 7, 63513) In theory we are quite in favour of boys and girls receiving education together, But, in practice, it is impossible to ignore deep rooted habits or prejudices.
('12', 29, 2, 8, 63673) Experience has shown that Indian parents, as a rule, will not allow their daughters to mingle with boys at a school or elsewhere.
('12', 29, 2, 9, 63803) And, whenever a forcible mixture takes place, the result “Let them”, shouts the unthinking reformer.
('12', 29, 2, 10, 63904) “They will soon be at home if left alone” But the parents will not wait for the process.
('12', 29, 2, 11, 63993) They are not reformers and they will not allow experiments to be made at their children’s expense.
('12', 29, 2, 12, 64092) Nor is there any dreadful hurry for pressing forward the reform.
('12', 29, 2, 13, 64157) There is already a deadlock.
('12', 29, 2, 14, 64186) From an attendance of thirty girls, it fell to below ten through the stupid zeal of the reformer in the Education Department.
('12', 29, 2, 15, 64312) At present, we understand, even the few parents who had held out in the hope of separate accommodation being provided have withdrawn their girls.
('12', 29, 2, 16, 64458) The Government need not be surprised if they find themselves being suspected of anti Indian prejudice in not conceding the request of the Congress and the Indian parents concerned to give facilities for the separate education of Indian girls.
('12', 29, 3, 17, 64701) Indian Opinion, 19 8 1911
('12', 29, 4, 18, 64727) 25. FOR INDIAN PARENTS
('12', 29, 5, 19, 64750) We confess to a sneaking regard for many of General Hertzog’s pronouncements.
('12', 29, 5, 20, 64828) His remarks on education and national conser vation, 1 which we have copied elsewhere from Johannesburg papers,
('12', 29, 6, 21, 64940) 1 Speaking at Newlands Government school on August 12, Hertzog had criticized the present system of education which was based on cramming and examinations and benefited only those who aspired to become advocates and doctors; the remaining 97 per cent of the population was left to suffer.
('12', 29, 6, 22, 65229) He had stressed the importance of character training, technical education and the mother tongue.
('12', 29, 6, 23, 65326) Indian Opinion, 19 8 1911.
('12', 30, 0, 1, 65353) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 31
('12', 30, 1, 2, 65393) are worthy of perusal and careful consideration by Indian parents and Indian youths.
('12', 30, 1, 3, 65478) There is a tendency among us to Anglicize our children as if that was the best way of educating them or fitting them for real service to the Empire.
('12', 30, 1, 4, 65627) We do not think that the wisest Englishmen desire that we should lose our nationality—that is our hereditary training—or that we should “ape” them.
('12', 30, 1, 5, 65775) General Hertzog has, we think, shown most clearly that the Dutch will be in danger of losing their nationality if Dutch children received their education through the medium of any other language but Dutch.
('12', 30, 1, 6, 65981) How true are his remarks that children, forgetting their own vernacular, are found lacking in respect for their parents.
('12', 30, 1, 7, 66102) “Honour thy father and thy mother” is equally the commandment of Jesus with Mahomet, Zoroaster and the Vedas.
('12', 30, 1, 8, 66212) Those, therefore, who are so indifferent to their mother tongue, no matter how humble it may be are in danger of forgetting a universal religious principle.
('12', 30, 1, 9, 66369) If General Hertzog’s remarks are true of Dutch for Dutch children, how much more so they are of Indian languages for Indian children.
('12', 30, 1, 10, 66503) Millions of Indians in India, although they may not be able to sign their own names, know the spirit of the great epics, Mahabharata and Ramayana, which play a part in our national life that very few other similar works do.
('12', 30, 1, 11, 66727) We decline to believe that our children can be taught these epics through.
('12', 30, 1, 12, 66802) English translations, however accurate they may be.
('12', 30, 1, 13, 66854) We consider it to be impossible for us to exist an independent, self respecting human beings if we forget the poetry of the race to which we belong.
('12', 30, 1, 14, 67003) We can never learn it through a foreign tongue.
('12', 30, 1, 15, 67051) But some of us labour under the delusion that we may pick up our mother tongue in later life.
('12', 30, 1, 16, 67145) All we can say is that such persons do not know what they are saying.
('12', 30, 1, 17, 67215) General Hertzog has well said that the true purpose of education is not to pass examinations but to mould the character of our children.
('12', 30, 1, 18, 67352) And character cannot be moul ded by making a child unlearn or neglect its past, and pass year in mastering a foreign tongue.
('12', 30, 1, 19, 67477) A moment’s reflection must convince anyone that the adoption of any such course is false economy; it is a criminal waste of capital inherited from our forefathers.
('12', 30, 2, 20, 67641) Indian Opinion, 19 8 1911

('12', 31, 2, 3, 67737) August 20, 1911
('12', 31, 3, 4, 67753) MY DEAR HENRY, I am without a letter from you this week.
('12', 31, 3, 5, 67810) I suppose you were busy with the Congress work.
('12', 31, 3, 6, 67858) Why did you send the wire to Prof.
('12', 31, 3, 7, 67893) Gokhale 1 regarding I.O.?
('12', 31, 3, 8, 67919) If there was any truth in the information, we would have heard in the natural course.
('12', 31, 3, 9, 68005) When the prohibition comes, I do not think we want any fuss about it.
('12', 31, 3, 10, 68075) You will not expect long letters from me just now.
('12', 31, 3, 11, 68126) I am absorbed in the children and my mind is generally occupied with thoughts about making myself as capable as I can be as their teacher.
('12', 31, 3, 12, 68265) And so when I sit down at the last moment to write the weekly mail, my mind is a blank.
('12', 31, 3, 13, 68353) I hope that you have still enough money to go on with.
('12', 31, 3, 14, 68408) I do not want you to have to send me a cable.
('12', 31, 3, 15, 68454) I hope to send you more if not the whole of the balance in a fortnight’s time.
('12', 31, 3, 16, 68533) With love to you all, BHAI

('12', 51, 1, 20, 113291) God alone knows whether the illness was brought on by the beans and salt or was due to some other cause.

('12', 52, 8, 16, 114433) MY DEAR LOWER HOUSE, Kennedy did come last Sunday.

('12', 52, 8, 18, 114521) He may come again.
('12', 52, 8, 19, 114540) We discussed many things ≈ abstract and otherwise.
('12', 52, 8, 20, 114591) It was only at night that he opened discussion on your relations.
('12', 52, 8, 21, 114657) He showed me your letter to me.
('12', 52, 8, 22, 114689) From you we went on to what should be man’s duty in his dealings with friends and fellow beings generally.
('12', 52, 8, 23, 114796) He agreed that the safest course was not to analyse friends even as a son does not analyse his mother or a husband his wife.
('12', 52, 8, 24, 114921) Both simply love one another.
('12', 52, 8, 25, 114951) I do not think he knows what he proposes doing on your return.
('12', 52, 8, 26, 115014) And for my part I would wish that you would not think of your future relations either.
('12', 52, 8, 27, 115101) Let them grow themselves.
('12', 52, 8, 28, 115127) The only thing one may think of is oneself.

('12', 54, 3, 26, 119111) 41. GERMISTON INDIANS
('12', 54, 4, 27, 119133) Indians of Germiston have done well in deciding to oppose the illegal Notice served on the Indians Stand holders in the Germiston Location, by the Town Council of that anti Asiatic stronghold.
('12', 54, 4, 28, 119326) 2 According to Law 3 of 1885, all Asiatics should live in Bazaars or Locations.
('12', 54, 4, 29, 119406) It is true that the law is inoperative as there is no penalty clause for residing outside Locations.
('12', 54, 4, 30, 119507) But it is a notorious that in most
('12', 54, 5, 31, 119542) 1 British author Lowes Dickinson 2 Indian Stand holders in the Georgetown Municipal Location had been notifi ed by the Town Council to have their licences endorsed, which would prohibit them from trading in the Location, alternatively to quit.
('12', 54, 5, 32, 119786) They wrote to the Town Clerk protesting that the Council had no right to ask for such endorsement of licences and that Law 3 of 1885, as amended, protected their tenure.
('12', 54, 5, 33, 119956) Indian Opinion, 23 9 1911.
('12', 55, 0, 1, 119983) 56 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 55, 1, 2, 120024) of the Transvaal towns there are Locations provided for Asiatics and most of these places are occupied by them.
('12', 55, 1, 3, 120136) The Germiston Location is one of them.
('12', 55, 1, 4, 120175) There is no law to prevent Indians from trading in such Locations.
('12', 55, 1, 5, 120242) Consequently several Indians hold trade licences in the Location in question.
('12', 55, 1, 6, 120320) This the Town Council cannot bear.
('12', 55, 1, 7, 120355) It is not at all concerned as to how they are to live if they may not trade, nor is it concerned that the residents of the Location are not in any way competing with European traders in Germiston.
('12', 55, 1, 8, 120552) In the Town Coun cil’s estimation, it is an offence for an Indian to trade at all.
('12', 55, 1, 9, 120635) Now the Council is powerless by direct and fair means to prevent the Indians of the Location from trading.
('12', 55, 1, 10, 120742) So it has resorted to the Notice above adverted to.
('12', 55, 1, 11, 120794) The Council thinks that, as Indians do not possess any leases, it could summarily eject them from their holdings.
('12', 55, 1, 12, 120908) It should be remembered that the Indians have built at their own expense substantial buildings on their Stands.
('12', 55, 1, 13, 121020) Their eviction from the Locations must, as very properly pointed out by the Stand holders in their letter to the Council, mean virtual ruin to them.
('12', 55, 1, 14, 121169) Happily the Indians have decided to ignore the Council’s Notice, and we doubt not that the Notice will remain a dead letter unless the Council proposes still further to stultify itself by acting up to it.
('12', 55, 1, 15, 121374) The Notice serves to show what a precarious existence it is for our countrymen in South Africa.
('12', 55, 2, 16, 121470) Indian Opinion, 23 9 1911
('12', 55, 3, 17, 121496) 42. A SHOCKING CASE We have already printed in these columns a representation addressed by the Natal Indian Congress to the Minister of the Interior regarding the forfeiture of two deposits of £100 each on behalf of certain two Indians who claimed their right of residence in the Province.
('12', 55, 3, 18, 121786) 1 The immigration laws of Natal provide that, if a man, who
('12', 55, 4, 19, 121846) 1Two minors, sons of Saued Ahmed of Durban and M.M. Nathalia of Verylam, respectively, arrived at Durban on May 15 but wre restrained from disembarking by the Principal Immigration Officer, who held that one was above sixteen and that it had not been satisfactrorily proved in the case of the other that the was in fact the son of his father.
('12', 55, 4, 20, 122189) The two traders then deposited £100 each against permission to land pending appeal to the Chief Magistrate, who on May 23 ruled, in the case of Sayed Ahmed’s son, that the official’s discertion regarding the boy’s age was beyond appeal.
('12', 55, 4, 21, 122426) In the second case, he ruled that Nathalisa’s evidence was insufficient.
('12', 55, 4, 22, 122499) If a certificate were producted later about boy’s parentage, he would gladly permit landing.
('12', 55, 4, 23, 122592) He observed that the law dealt some what harshly with Nathlia and recommended the rtefund of the deposit, .
('12', 55, 4, 24, 122700) The boys left for India by the first avialable boat.
('12', 55, 4, 25, 122753) Indian Opinion, 9 9 1911.
('12', 56, 0, 1, 122779) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 57
('12', 56, 1, 2, 122819) deposits £100 and lands in order to prove his claim, fails to prove it to the satisfaction of a Magistrate, he may forfeit the deposit.
('12', 56, 1, 3, 122955) Thus the forfeiture is not a legal result of any such failure.
('12', 56, 1, 4, 123018) It is optional for the Minister to declare such deposits as forfeited, In the two cases before us, the boys in question never made deposits themselves.
('12', 56, 1, 5, 123170) But apart from that, it was never proved conclusively that the boys had not the right of residence in Natal.
('12', 56, 1, 6, 123279) On the contrary, in one case the Magistrate showed much sympathy.
('12', 56, 1, 7, 123345) We could understand forfeiture in glaringly bad cases where deceit has been practised.
('12', 56, 1, 8, 123432) In these cases fraud has not been even so much as whispered.
('12', 56, 1, 9, 123493) The only construction that can be placed upon the action of the Government is that they intend, by a policy of confiscation, to defeat the right of Indian residents.
('12', 56, 1, 10, 123659) If such is its deliberate policy, we think that General Botha’s statement that there is no intention to injure the interests of Indians lawfully resident in South Africa must be set down asinsincere.
('12', 56, 1, 11, 123859) We hope, however, that General Smuts will favourably consider the Congress’s representation and order a refund of the deposits.

('12', 56, 6, 16, 124102) The insects about me tell me that I should not do such night work not that I should put up a perforated screen to ward off the insects.

('12', 56, 6, 18, 124270) I have your letter and the report of the interview with Maude.
('12', 56, 6, 19, 124333) I am not surprised that Maude has impressed you.
('12', 56, 6, 20, 124382) He is a true man.
('12', 56, 6, 21, 124400) But his reasoning is bad.
('12', 56, 6, 22, 124426) Modern civilization has had its trial thousands of years ago.
('12', 56, 6, 23, 124488) It was tried at the time of the Tower of Babel and found wanting.
('12', 56, 6, 24, 124554) It was tried in India and failed.
('12', 56, 6, 25, 124588) It is again on its trial and is already tottering.
('12', 56, 6, 26, 124639) What trial can it want?
('12', 56, 6, 27, 124663) What does it propose doing?
('12', 56, 6, 28, 124691) It either rejects the divinity or seeks to find it outside of ourselves.
('12', 56, 6, 29, 124764) In both of these systems, it is hopelessly wrong.
('12', 56, 6, 30, 124814) His rejection of the doctrine of non resistance to evil takes away everything from the praise he bestows on Tolstoy.
('12', 56, 6, 31, 124931) If Tolstoy was the greatest reformer of his age in Europe, he owed it to his doctrine of non resistance[sic].
('12', 56, 6, 32, 125041) The illustration he takes is far fetched.

('12', 59, 1, 3, 129749) PRANJIVAN MEHTA
('12', 59, 2, 4, 129765) Aso Sud 2 [September 24, 1911] 1
('12', 59, 3, 5, 129798) DEAR SHRI PRANJIVAN, I have not yet replied to your three letters.
('12', 59, 3, 6, 129865) Since you were to go to India, why should I have written [ to you] in England?
('12', 59, 3, 7, 129944) As regards the mail to India, well, the old position continues.
('12', 59, 3, 8, 130008) So it is not possible to write regularly.
('12', 59, 3, 9, 130050) Even today I write without knowing when the post will be cleared.
('12', 59, 3, 10, 130116) I am not writing anything to Manilal 2 now.
('12', 59, 3, 11, 130160) I enclose his last letter.
('12', 59, 3, 12, 130187) I have [already] written to him saying that he may come when he wants to.
('12', 59, 3, 13, 130261) I have also written to Phoenix about him.
('12', 59, 3, 14, 130303) I don’t think I shall be able to go there myself.
('12', 59, 3, 15, 130353) I shall therefore ask him to come over.
('12', 59, 3, 16, 130393) I feel he will gain some experience here.
('12', 59, 3, 17, 130435) As to his going to Fiji, I have written to him plainly that he should not.
('12', 59, 3, 18, 130510) Even if he goes, I think he will regret it.
('12', 59, 3, 19, 130554) There was no one waiting at Fiji just to hand him money.
('12', 59, 3, 20, 130611) He has made a great mistake in converting his paper into a daily.
('12', 59, 3, 21, 130677) As it is, there is no worth in it.
('12', 59, 3, 22, 130712) The types are bad, the paper is bad and so is the substance.
('12', 59, 3, 23, 130773) He doesn’t have capable helpers in Mauritius.
('12', 59, 3, 24, 130819) How then can a proper newspaper be brought out?

('12', 65, 3, 10, 142833) 50. THE FOOL AND HIS BROTHERS
('12', 65, 4, 11, 142863) PREFACE
('12', 65, 5, 12, 142871) We reproduce this tale 1 from a most devout piece of writing by that great man the late Tolstoy.
('12', 65, 5, 13, 142968) We do not provide a literal translation of the tale; but we have attempted a free rendering of it so as clearly to bring out its significance.
('12', 65, 5, 14, 143111) This tale is far superior to the one we have already published.
('12', 65, 5, 15, 143175) 2 It has also been commended by several European writers.
('12', 65, 5, 16, 143233) All that is told in it is not only very plausible, but what is more, such things keep happening even now in obscure places.
('12', 65, 5, 17, 143357) One should not assume that such events are improbable because they do not find a place in recorded history.
('12', 65, 5, 18, 143465) The reader will see Tolstoy’s intention for himself as the chapters succeed one another.
('12', 65, 5, 19, 143554) The story is written in a style which makes it as interesting as its teaching is lofty.
('12', 65, 5, 20, 143642) If our readers fail to find our version as interesting as we ourselves found the English translation, the fault should be attributed to us and not to the story itself.
('12', 65, 5, 21, 143810) We have substituted Indian names for Russian lest the latter detract from the interest of the story.
('12', 65, 6, 22, 143911) [From Gujarati]
('12', 65, 7, 23, 143927) Indian Opinion , 7 10 1911

('12', 68, 4, 13, 149500) 53. THE IMMIGRATION CASE
('12', 68, 5, 14, 149525) The Gerber case 3 decided by Sir John Buchanan at Cape Town is one of considerable importance, and, although it refers to a Russian Jew, it has a bearing on British Indian immigrants.
('12', 68, 5, 15, 149709) It appears that this immigrant had £20 in his possession, had paid his own passage, was in good health, had been convicted of no crime and was an efficient workman.
('12', 68, 5, 16, 149874) The Jewish Minister testified that he was a good Yiddish scholar.
('12', 68, 5, 17, 149940) And yet the Immigration Officer treated him as a prohibited immigrant, because, in his opinion, his educational attainments did not come up to his requirements.
('12', 68, 5, 18, 150101) We know that the Jews in South Africa are not labouring under any particular disabilities, but the silent and insidious opposition against them now and then comes to the surface, as in the present case.
('12', 68, 5, 19, 150304) Had Mr. Gerber been an immigrant from any other part of Europe, and had he belonged to a different denomination, he would probably not have
('12', 68, 6, 20, 150444) 1 A Gujarati literary form resembling a ballad.
('12', 68, 6, 21, 150492) This one was chosen for publication by Chhaganlal Gandhi who also wrote a preface to it which Gandhiji commended; vide “Letter to Chhaganlal Gandhi”, 29 8 1911. 2The heroine; one among many labourers employed by the King Siddharaja of Gujarat to dig a lake, she successfully resisted his improper attentions.
('12', 68, 6, 22, 150801) 3 Jack Gerber, a Russian Jew, came to South Africa to join his brother but he had left his permit behind.
('12', 68, 6, 23, 150907) He was restrained from disembarking on grounds of deficient education although he satisfied the conditions for entry.
('12', 68, 6, 24, 151025) The Cape Provincial Court ruled that Gerber was entitled to land and that Immigration officials’ decisions were justiciable.
('12', 68, 6, 25, 151150) Indian Opinion, 14 10 1911.
('12', 69, 0, 1, 151178) 70 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 69, 1, 2, 151219) been subjected to the harsh treatment that was his lot at the hands of the Immigration Officer.
('12', 69, 1, 3, 151315) What, however, has happened to him happens to scores of Indians from month to month, and nothing is heard of it.
('12', 69, 1, 4, 151428) We know that it is the settled policy of the Union Government to restrict Asiatic immigration, but it can be, and should be, no part of the policy of restriction to turn away men who are fully entitled under the immigration laws of the Union.
('12', 69, 1, 5, 151671) In other words, we claim that intending immigrants, irrespective of their race or colour, should have the law liberally interpreted in their favour, and equally liberally administered.
('12', 69, 1, 6, 151856) We welcome the judgment of Sir John Bucha nan as showing that the courts, at any rate, will not, as a rule be influenced by current prejudices and will not hesitate to interpret laws in favour of human liberty, and we hope that the punishment awarded to the Government in making them pay the costs of the application will serve as a deterrent in the future.

('12', 80, 3, 10, 173801) 63. TRIUMPH OF SATYAGRAHA
('12', 80, 4, 11, 173827) During Diwali, some Hindus burst crackers.
('12', 80, 4, 12, 173870) The Durban police went into a huff over this.
('12', 80, 4, 13, 173916) A leading Hindu gentleman was arrested.
('12', 80, 4, 14, 173956) They all decided not to let the matter rest at that.
('12', 80, 4, 15, 174009) It reached the ears of Mr. Dawad Mahomed and Mr. Parsee Rustomjee.
('12', 80, 4, 16, 174076) They hurried off to the Mayor, and argued that, after all, the whites also exploded crackers during Christmas.
('12', 80, 4, 17, 174187) Why then should the Hindus [they asked] not do so during their festivals?
('12', 80, 4, 18, 174261) Why should they have to take special per mission for this purpose?
('12', 80, 4, 19, 174328) No one seeks such permission during Christmas.
('12', 80, 4, 20, 174375) “If, in spite of this, you wish to harass Hindus for ex ploding crackers, we shall also join them in this as a mark of sym pathy.
('12', 80, 4, 21, 174505) You may then arrest anyone that you like.” The matter is not serious and the victory 2 not much of a triumph.
('12', 80, 4, 22, 174615) The significance of the event, however, is great.
('12', 80, 4, 23, 174665) Because we boldly came forward to suffer the conseqences of doing what was right, we had, it transpired, nothing to suffer and our self respect was preserved.
('12', 80, 4, 24, 174824) This is satyagraha.
('12', 80, 4, 25, 174844) Another, more significant, feature of this case is the fact that a Muslim and a Parsi rushed to help in a matter which concerned Hindus alone.
('12', 80, 4, 26, 174987) The outcome was indeed happy.
('12', 80, 4, 27, 175017) If the right course is
('12', 80, 5, 28, 175040) 1 Vide “Letter to Maganlal Gandhi”, after 18 5 1911. 2 The Mayor’s decision permitting Hindus to explode crackers during Diwali was publicized through handbills.

('12', 81, 1, 2, 175271) followed in one case, it is bound to happen that it will be adopted on other occasions as well.
('12', 81, 1, 3, 175367) If one knot in a tangled piece of sting can be unravelled, the other too can easily be undone.
('12', 81, 1, 4, 175462) How can Hindus, Muslims, Parsis and Christians all be united?
('12', 81, 1, 5, 175524) Mr. Mahomed and Mr. Rustomjee have provide the answer.
('12', 81, 1, 6, 175579) If Muslims come forward to sympathize with Hindus in what concerns the latter alone, if Hindus do the same and if both these communities act in this manner towards Parsis, will there be anyone so bereft of reason as to seek to come in the way of affection developing among them?
('12', 81, 1, 7, 175858) Let people’s religions be different.
('12', 81, 1, 8, 175895) You worship a Being—a single Entity—as Allah and another adores Him as Khuda.
('12', 81, 1, 9, 175973) I worship Him as Ishwar.
('12', 81, 1, 10, 175998) How does anyone stand to lose [by this arrangement]?
('12', 81, 1, 11, 176051) You worship facing one way and I worship facing the other.
('12', 81, 1, 12, 176110) Why should I become your enemy for that reason?
('12', 81, 1, 13, 176158) We all belong to the human race; we all wear the same skin; we hail from the same land.
('12', 81, 1, 14, 176246) When the facts are as simple as that, it will be nothing but folly and short sightedness to bear implacable enmity towards one another.
('12', 81, 1, 15, 176382) The moderns make a key which will open many kinds of locks.
('12', 81, 1, 16, 176442) They call it the “master key”.
('12', 81, 1, 17, 176473) Likewise, satyagraha is the master key to our innumerable hardships.
('12', 81, 1, 18, 176542) How much could be achieved if only all the Indians would use that key!
('12', 81, 1, 19, 176613) Satyagraha is not a difficult term to understand.
('12', 81, 1, 20, 176663) It only means adherence to truth.
('12', 81, 1, 21, 176697) Whatever else the ethical life may mean, it cannot be ethical if it is not based on truth.
('12', 81, 1, 22, 176788) Truth is easy enough to follow once we know its meaning.

('12', 83, 4, 12, 180166) 65. LETTER TO G.K. GOKHALE
('12', 83, 5, 13, 180193) JOHANNESBURG, October 30, 1911
('12', 83, 6, 14, 180224) DEAR MR. GOKHALE, I have to thank you for your long cablegram with reference to the Congress Presidentship muddle.
('12', 83, 6, 15, 180339) I was sorry to hear about your illness.
('12', 83, 6, 16, 180379) Will you never be able to travel outside India and England?
('12', 83, 6, 17, 180439) British statesmen do; why cannot Indian statesmen?
('12', 83, 6, 18, 180490) If you could possibly pay a brief visit to South Africa, it would not be now a ques tion of your courting imprisonment, but it would still serve a double purpose.
('12', 83, 6, 19, 180653) It would bring the people here nearer to India, and it would give me the privilege of so nursing you as to restore you to health.
('12', 83, 6, 20, 180783) In my opinion, we have at Tolstoy Farm, as also at Phoenix, convenience enough for patients like you.
('12', 83, 6, 21, 180885) I am quite sure that I can anticipate Mr. Kallenbach’s warm welcome to you at Tolstoy Farm, and, of course Phoenix you could treat as your own home.
('12', 83, 6, 22, 181034) The first intimation I had of my name being seriously discussed in connection with the Congress Presidentship was a telegram from the Natal Indian Congress, advising me that it had received an invitation for me to preside at the forthcoming session, and urging me strongly to accept the invitation.
('12', 83, 6, 23, 181333) My reply 1 was in the negative.
('12', 83, 6, 24, 181365) I, at the same time, enquired about the name of the sender of the invitation.
('12', 83, 6, 25, 181443) Much to my surprise, the names sent were those of yourself, the All India Moslem League, Mr. Petit, Mr. Natrajan, Mr. Natesan, Mr. S. Bose and
('12', 83, 7, 26, 181586) 1 Not available
('12', 84, 0, 1, 181602) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 85
('12', 84, 1, 2, 181642) Mr. Malviya 1. The inclusion of your name and that of the All India Moslem League gave the cablegram an importance which made me waver in my decision, and I felt that, if you who knew my views so well also wished me to preside, there must be some special reason for the invitation.
('12', 84, 1, 3, 181924) The news was received by me at the Farm.
('12', 84, 1, 4, 181965) I travelled to Johannesburg, and the people at Durban confirmed the telegrams through the telephone and simply insisted upon my accepting the invitation 2. To them, it was a unique honour to the Indians of South Africa and an equally unique opportunity of bringing the South African Indian case still more prominently to the notice of the Indian public.
('12', 84, 1, 5, 182319) Had I not been so foolishly egotistical, I should certainly have doubted the correctness of the message that was sent to me from Durban.
('12', 84, 1, 6, 182456) Before, however, I had had reason to doubt the accuracy of the message, I had allowed the Durban Congress to accept the invi tation, but I felt that I should send my own cablegram 3 independently to you, which I did.
('12', 84, 1, 7, 182673) Three or four days later I received from Durban a letter confirming the telegraphic messages, which, however, included a copy of a letter from Reuter, which put a different interpretation upon the cable.
('12', 84, 1, 8, 182877) It seems to me that, during the time that I was in Cape Town, Mr. Polak, who was in Durban, had arranged for a code address covering the names given above.
('12', 84, 1, 9, 183033) Advice was evidently given to all these parties of the code address, and Mr. Bose of Calcutta made use of it.
('12', 84, 1, 10, 183143) In deciphering the cable, therefore, our people at Durban read the cable to mean that it was sent by all the six parties,but Reuter’s letter, which was sent to the Congress at the time the code address was registered, shows that the code word might mean, according to circumstances, one or all the names.
('12', 84, 1, 11, 183448) In this instance, if my interpre tation is correct, the code indicator must be read to mean only “Mr.
('12', 84, 2, 12, 183550) 1 Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya (1861 1946); “patriarch” of the Indian National Congress; editor of The Hindustan, 1887 9, The Indian Union, 1889 92 and The Abhyudaya, 1907 9; member of Provincial Legislative Assembly, 1902 12, Imperial Legislative Council, 1910 20 and Indian Legislative Assembly, 1924; associated with the Congress since 1886; he was elected President of the 1909 Lahore session and the 1918 Delhi session; Vice Chancellor from 1919 to 1940, of Benares Hindu University which he had founded in 1916; President Hindu Mahasabha, 1923 5; attended Round Table Conference, London, 1931 2. Gandhiji was his guest on the occasion of the founding of Benares Hindu University, when Malaviya used “lovingly to explain...
('12', 84, 2, 13, 184278) like an elder brother the various view points of the different parties”.
('12', 84, 2, 14, 184351) and in 1924, used to read out the Bhagawat to Gandhiji during his 21 day fast.
('12', 84, 2, 15, 184430) 2 Vide “Mr. Gandhi and the Indian National Congress”, 30 9 1911. 3 Not available
('12', 85, 0, 1, 184511) 86 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 85, 1, 2, 184552) Bose”, as the cablegram was from Calcutta.
('12', 85, 1, 3, 184595) So reading it, I concluded that the so called invitation was no invitation at all, but that it was merely an enquiry to know whether the Natal Indian Congress could spare me.
('12', 85, 1, 4, 184770) Probably, had Mr. Bose known my whereabouts precisely, and that cablegrams addressed to me simply “Gandhi” would reach me, he would have cabled to me, when of course there would have been no fuss, and I should have simply answered that I could not accept the honour; but the mischief has already been done, and the over enthusiastic people at Durban even authorized Reuter to publish the news.
('12', 85, 1, 5, 185164) Your cable in reply to my second cable 1, informing me that the decision had yet to be made, confirmed my interpretation of the cable.
('12', 85, 1, 6, 185299) The rest you know.
('12', 85, 1, 7, 185318) I can only hope that the decision at Allahabad will be against my nomination 2 .
('12', 85, 1, 8, 185399) I may receive it tomorrow.
('12', 85, 1, 9, 185426) This is being dictated on the 29th, Sunday.
('12', 85, 1, 10, 185470) I could not very well occupy the presidential chair, and conceal the views which I hold so strongly on many questions that are debated year after year at the National Assembly, and I am fully aware that an expression of those views on the Congress platform might not only be unacceptable to our leaders but might even place them in a false position, which I should be the last person to desire to do.
('12', 85, 1, 11, 185871) I am also aware that my views are likely to be considered immature and based on insufficient data, also that I may myself change them, and, however strongly I may dissent from any of these three propositions, I think that all those who differ from me have a perfect and reasonable right to enunciate them.
('12', 85, 1, 12, 186177) It seems to me that, just now, I can best serve the cause, that is as dear to me as it is to the Congress, by simply serving the South African Indian cause, and, if an opportunity offers itself of going to India, to serve my countrymen in an independent capacity, if not, unofficially under the guidance of a leader like you, from whom I have derived inspi ration.
('12', 85, 1, 13, 186542) Though our views differ, I know, on many matters, my regard for you and for your character as I have pictured it to myself remains the same as before.
('12', 85, 3, 14, 186693) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
