('12', 86, 3, 4, 187092) MY DEAR LOWER HOUSE, It is on Sunday night I am writing this thought it is dated for Monday.
('12', 86, 3, 5, 187185) I am fairly tired and not in the mood to write.
('12', 86, 3, 6, 187233) Thank God I am not to preside at the Congress.
('12', 86, 3, 7, 187280) It would have been a most frightful thing, had I been obliged.
('12', 86, 3, 8, 187343) A remarkable incident happened at the Farm during the week.
('12', 86, 3, 9, 187403) We were making very fair headway with the fence.
('12', 86, 3, 10, 187452) One day when I was not at that work, Desai came and informed me that someone had torn up the fence.
('12', 86, 3, 11, 187552) This is the analysis of my mind.
('12', 86, 3, 12, 187585) The thought could not have occupied more than a second.
('12', 86, 3, 13, 187641) ‘Some evil minded person has done it.
('12', 86, 3, 14, 187679) I must inform police.’ ‘You coward.
('12', 86, 3, 15, 187715) Your philosophy is skin deep.
('12', 86, 3, 16, 187745) No, the police must not be informed either for your or my sake.
('12', 86, 3, 17, 187809) The fence should be re put and someone must sleep near it, if necessary.’ Thus resolved I went down to the fence myself.
('12', 86, 3, 18, 187930) I found that the probability was that the fence was torn up by cattle.
('12', 86, 3, 19, 188001) Anyhow we fixed the poles much more strongly than before.
('12', 86, 3, 20, 188059) I took with [me] plates and nails to fix on to the poles.
('12', 86, 3, 21, 188117) No one slept there and there has been no further interruption.
('12', 86, 3, 22, 188180) The incident, however, touched me deeply and set me thinking as to the right course of conduct.
('12', 86, 3, 23, 188276) The most prominent idea that forced itself on me was that we, if we were to carry out the ideals we hold were unfit to hold more land than we actually used.
('12', 86, 3, 24, 188433) The corollary is not that we should give up the land (though even that may not be quite so farcical as one may imagine) but that we should fence only so much as we wanted and used and no more.
('12', 86, 3, 25, 188626) Then we should be able to overtake any damage with much greater ease.
('12', 86, 3, 26, 188696) I discuss this only to show you how my mind is working and how more and more introspective I am becoming daily.
('12', 86, 3, 27, 188808) This does not in any way alter my plans during your absence.
('12', 86, 3, 28, 188869) I shall go through the programme as we have mapped it.
('12', 86, 3, 29, 188924) Fencing will be finished.
('12', 86, 3, 30, 188950) I have accepted the tender of Stewarts and Llyods for £ 72 odd for erecting a windmill.
('12', 86, 3, 31, 189038) I have described to you the whole thing I think.
('12', 86, 3, 32, 189087) They will send an erector in the course of the week.
('12', 87, 0, 1, 189140) 88 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 87, 1, 2, 189181) I have also told John that he might buy four oxen for which money will be advanced to him.
('12', 87, 1, 3, 189272) It may mean £ 30. I feel that it is much better to let the natives feel that here they may depend upon the fairest treatment.
('12', 87, 1, 4, 189398) And I have no doubt that if it proceeds from the heart and is uniform, continuous and not from affectation, it will bless both the parties.
('12', 87, 1, 5, 189538) Anyhow just now I am generous as your steward.
('12', 87, 1, 6, 189585) Of course John has to repay before the year is out.
('12', 87, 1, 7, 189637) I am letting Basella too do pretty much as he likes.
('12', 87, 1, 8, 189690) I see that I can get much more satisfactory work that way.
('12', 87, 1, 9, 189749) We had a very busy Sunday.
('12', 87, 1, 10, 189776) A party of 13 came, all but two unexpected.
('12', 87, 1, 11, 189820) These were Miss Schlesin and Gordon.
('12', 87, 1, 12, 189857) The others were Indians.
('12', 87, 1, 13, 189882) Poor Mrs.Gandhi, she may foam and fret afterwards.
('12', 87, 1, 14, 189933) But just on such occasions she is at her best.
('12', 87, 1, 15, 189980) I note that you are seriously affecting the lives of your people there.
('12', 87, 1, 16, 190052) Your telling me that they love me now more and more flatters me, but it ought not to.
('12', 87, 1, 17, 190138) They love me as they see me through your glasses.
('12', 87, 1, 18, 190188) However, of this when we meet.
('12', 87, 1, 19, 190219) Of course, you will continue your practice as long as you find it necessary.
('12', 87, 1, 20, 190296) But I do say that it would be unwise to take precautions beforehand on the basis of Kennedy leaving you for certain.
('12', 87, 1, 21, 190413) In your place I should simply let the future take care of itself.

('12', 87, 1, 23, 190575) Whereas if you leave the future in the lap of the gods, you will find your course much smoother and certainly far more natural.
('12', 87, 1, 24, 190703) With love to you and all to whom you have introduced me,
('12', 87, 2, 25, 190760) Yours sincerely, UPPER HOUSE [PS.] I can report nothing about Call.

('12', 88, 0, 1, 190918) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 89
('12', 88, 1, 2, 190958) 67. THE £3 TAX 1
('12', 88, 2, 3, 190975) Recent events have shown that there is a great deal of confusion in regard to the question of who is liable to pay the £3 tax under Act 17 2 of 1895. The Law Department seems to have decided that an Indian who has re indentured or entered into a civil contract of service under the Masters and Servants Act, which he is entitled to do under Clause 3 of Act 19 of 1910, is liable to pay the tax of £3 for the period of his re indenture or contract of service.
('12', 88, 2, 4, 191434) The clause in the Act runs:
('12', 88, 3, 5, 191462) The payment of arrears of licence money, due under Act No.
('12', 88, 3, 6, 191521) 17, 1895, by any Indian, shall be suspended during the period of a re indenture or contract of service for a term of not less than two years, and in the event of his return to India at the expiration of such contract or indenture, payment of arrears shall be waived.
('12', 88, 3, 7, 191788) In order to get at the true meaning of this clause, it is necessary to go back a few years.
('12', 88, 3, 8, 191880) In the year 1905 it was found that a great many ex indentured Indians were not paying the £3 tax, for the simple reason that they were too poor to do so 3. Consequently an Act
('12', 88, 4, 9, 192056) 1This article and “A Breach of Faith”, pp.
('12', 88, 4, 10, 192099) 186 7, seem to have been occasioned by the summons served on one Devaragulu, under civil contract with a Durban Indian, for non payment of arrears due to the £3 tax.
('12', 88, 4, 11, 192265) When the Magistrate’s attention was drawn to Clause 3 of Act 19 of 1910, he suspended the order for payment and adjourned the case sine die.
('12', 88, 4, 12, 192406) Similar summonses had been served on about 21 Indians then under re indenture.
('12', 88, 4, 13, 192485) On September 16, 1911, a meeting of Indians held at Parsee Rustomjee’s house in Durban formed the Anti £3 Tax League to fight for repeal of the tax.
('12', 88, 4, 14, 192634) Indian Opinion, 9 9 1911 & 23 9 1911. Vide also Appendix “Summary of the Protector’s Report”, 11 11 1911. 2 This was passed soon after Natal became a self governing colony in 1893; vide “Statement Presented to Constitution Committee”, 29 5 1906. It did not envisage payment of the £3 tax by women.
('12', 88, 4, 15, 192932) 3 Vide “Indentured Indians”, 22 4 1905. The hardships of Indians who were obliged to pay the tax came to light from time to time; vide, for instance, “The Poll Tax”, 17 3 1906. In 1911, at Stanger, a woman hawker was sent to prison for two weeks for failure to pay this tax owing to extreme poverty.
('12', 88, 4, 16, 193232) Indian Opinion, 8 7 1911. The Indian Immigration Law of 1891 fixed the wages of indentured Indians at 16s.
('12', 88, 4, 17, 193339) per month for the first year, rising to 20s.
('12', 88, 4, 18, 193384) per month for the fifth year (Vol. I, pp.
('12', 88, 4, 19, 193426) 215 6), while the wage for a Native worker in the Rand mines about the year 1901 was 45s.
('12', 88, 4, 20, 193516) per month and Native labour was unobtainable even at that price; Gandhiji had always therefore argued that the Indian labourers’ savings from which they paid the tax could not have been very considerable.
('12', 88, 4, 21, 193721) Maud Polak, in a letter to the Colonial Office (C.O. 477) mentions a Natal planter who testified before a South Afican Commission that “only 6 per cent.
('12', 88, 4, 22, 193874) of ex indentured Indians could afford to pay the £3 tax”.
('12', 89, 0, 1, 193932) 90 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 89, 1, 2, 193973) was passed which prohibited any person from employing or letting land to an ex indentured Indian who could not produce his £3 licence for the current year.
('12', 89, 1, 3, 194129) A contravention of this Act meant a fine of £5 to the employer.
('12', 89, 1, 4, 194193) It also provided that an employer could pay the £3 and deduct the amount from the wages of the Indian.
('12', 89, 1, 5, 194296) In this way it was thought to force the Indians to pay the £3 tax or leave the country.
('12', 89, 1, 6, 194384) Later on in the same year, another Act was passed which entitled an Indian who was subject to the payment of the tax to re indenture for a term of not less than two years.
('12', 89, 1, 7, 194556) This was not possible before.
('12', 89, 1, 8, 194586) He could also regain the privilege of being sent back to India which he had forfeited by paying the £3 tax.
('12', 89, 1, 9, 194694) The Prime Minister of Natal, in moving the second reading of this bill, said that
('12', 89, 2, 10, 194776) the bill had been brought in so as to enable the Indian who might not be able to pay the £3 tax upon his freedom from indenture to reindenture.
('12', 89, 2, 11, 194920) There might well be times when an ex indentured Indian would not be able to pay the £3 tax, and it was only fair that he should be allowed to reindenture.
('12', 89, 2, 12, 195075) It was not only that the right was given to him to re indenture, but he would become entitled to the passage back to India, which he would otherwise have forfeited by not availing himself of it at the conclusion of his previous indenture.
('12', 89, 2, 13, 195314) So here it is quite clear that it was intended that an Indian who entered into a contract of re indenture had not to pay the tax.
('12', 89, 2, 14, 195444) But this inducement was not sufficient.
('12', 89, 2, 15, 195484) At the end of 1909, the planters were crying out for more Indian labour and the Government of India had threatened to stop immigration to Natal.
('12', 89, 2, 16, 195629) What was to be done?
('12', 89, 2, 17, 195650) In the Legislative Council, the Hon.
('12', 89, 2, 18, 195687) Mr. Baynes pointed out that
('12', 89, 3, 19, 195715) the £3 residential fee was a severe condition upon Indians, including the poll tax.
('12', 89, 3, 20, 195799) It was a fact that the number of Indians leaving the Colony was greater than those coming into it.
('12', 89, 3, 21, 195898) He thought they should prevent this exodus of labour.
('12', 89, 3, 22, 195952) The Colonial Secretary, in moving the second reading of Amendment Bill, stated that
('12', 89, 4, 23, 196036) representations had been received both from the Indians themselves and from the magistrates to the effect that the licence of £3 was unable to be paid, and the Government felt that the obligations would be met if the licence were removed so far as Indian women were concerned and that was the object of the present measure.
('12', 89, 4, 24, 196360) The Indian Immigration Commission had inquired into the matter, and had recommended the course now proposed.
('12', 89, 4, 25, 196469) Sir Liege Hulett supported the Bill and said that it was never intended that the £3 tax should apply to women and girls.
('12', 89, 4, 26, 196590) But, on the motion of Mr. Kirkman, an amendment was passed giving magistrates discretion to relieve any Indian women from the payment of licence
('12', 90, 0, 1, 196735) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 91
('12', 90, 1, 2, 196775) To the same Bill Mr. Clayton moved a new clause in regard to the payment of arrears, quoted at the commencement of this article, which was passed into law.
('12', 90, 1, 3, 196931) This law was passed in January, 1910 and in April of the same year a circular 1 was issued from the Colonial Secretary’s Office, Maritzburg, printed in English, Hindi and Tamil, to the effect that Indian men and women who should have taken out the £3 licence, but had not done so, could re indenture for not less than two years or enter into a civil contract for not less than two years, and while under contract or indenture, the licence money would not be claimed, and should they return to India, they would not be made to pay the licence money due 2. Reviewing the above facts, it is not possible to come to any other conclusion than that it was never intended that ex indentured Indians would have to pay the £3 tax during the time of their re indenture or contract of service.
('12', 90, 1, 4, 197714) This review is made for the special purpose of clearing up any doubt there may be as to the intention of the legislature regarding the payment of the tax during re indenture.
('12', 90, 1, 5, 197889) The tax itself we have always fought against, tooth and nail 3, and we shall continue to do so until this pernicious and unjust law is wiped off the Statute book.
('12', 90, 2, 6, 198052) Indian Opinion , 11 11 1911
('12', 90, 3, 7, 198080) 1 Vide “The £ 3 Tax Again”, 30 4 1910. 2 The confusion appears to have been caused by this circular which was sent round among Natal Indians in April, 1910, before the formation of the Union.
('12', 90, 3, 8, 198272) This emanated from the Colonial Secretary’s Office but the Protector’s Department provided Hindi and Tamil translations.
('12', 90, 3, 9, 198393) While Clause 3 of the Act exempted re indentured Indians from “arrears” of the £3 tax, the English circular mentioned “licence money due”and the translations probably suggested exemption from current payments as well.
('12', 90, 3, 10, 198611) Aiyer (footnote 2, p.162) brought the issue to the notice of The Natal Mercury which, in an article published on November 8, 1911, opposed the interpretation as contained in the circular produced by Aiyer with that of the Union law officers who argued that the interpretation would depend upon the wording of the statute which they held made re indentured men liable to payment of the current tax.
('12', 90, 3, 11, 199009) Indian Opinion, 11 11 1911. 3 Natal Indians had always objected to the £3 tax on indentured Indians who had become free men on the ground that the tax was not a source of revenue but a measure designed to drive the Indian out after his term of indenture and that it was repugnant to British constitutional traditions.
('12', 90, 3, 12, 199327) For Gandhiji’s views on indenture and the 1895 Bill, vide “Speech at Public Meeting”, 26 9 1896. 9.

('12', 91, 1, 2, 199468) 68. FAMINE IN INDIA
('12', 91, 2, 3, 199488) We refer to the famine as “Famine in India” though Gujarat and Kathiawar [alone] are affected.
('12', 91, 2, 4, 199583) If a part of the body is injured, the whole is injured; in the same way, a famine in Gujarat is a famine in India.
('12', 91, 2, 5, 199698) We gather from letters and newspapers from India that this year’s famine will be much worse than any in the past.
('12', 91, 2, 6, 199812) Men and cattle are both dying off.
('12', 91, 2, 7, 199847) The last rains, it seems, have failed.
('12', 91, 2, 8, 199886) One has actually to see the conditions to realize that they are beyond description.
('12', 91, 2, 9, 199970) Even a day’s starvation makes us irritable.
('12', 91, 2, 10, 200014) If we do not get the food we are used to, there is no limit to the anger we vent upon the cook or the lady of the house.
('12', 91, 2, 11, 200135) Suppose, instead, that for eight months we have had almost nothing to eat.
('12', 91, 2, 12, 200210) The body is reduced to a skeleton.
('12', 91, 2, 13, 200245) The belly almost touches the back.
('12', 91, 2, 14, 200280) One can stand up only if helped by someone else.
('12', 91, 2, 15, 200329) If we can visualize this for ourselves and suppose further that hundreds of thousands are in this state, we shall then have some idea of the conditions that obtain in India.
('12', 91, 2, 16, 200503) How can we help?
('12', 91, 2, 17, 200520) The first way is to restrain our luxurious ways, our pretensions, our pride and our sharp practices and crave God’s forgiveness for the sins we have committed.
('12', 91, 2, 18, 200680) After this, if we feel that our minds have been purified, we may pray to God for relief for India in this cruelty inflicted on her.
('12', 91, 2, 19, 200812) If we proceed in this manner, money can be saved.
('12', 91, 2, 20, 200862) We can use this money to provide relief to the famine stricken.
('12', 91, 2, 21, 200926) We are ready to accept money from those who cannot themselves send it, and to do so on their behalf.
('12', 91, 2, 22, 201027) Already, we are in correspondence with a generous person who has come forward with the money he is willing to spend for this purpose.
('12', 91, 2, 23, 201161) The money sent by us we shall pass on to this gentle man or to some public body of standing and publish the receipts.
('12', 91, 2, 24, 201279) The important thing is not how to send the money but how to collect it.
('12', 91, 2, 25, 201351) It is our belief that the money sent by those who have made their minds simple and pure as we have suggested, will bear worthy fruit, as good seeds do; of this there can be no doubt.
('12', 91, 3, 26, 201534) [From Gujarati]
('12', 91, 4, 27, 201550) Indian Opinion , 11 11 1911
('12', 92, 0, 1, 201578) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 93
('12', 92, 1, 2, 201618) 69. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('12', 92, 2, 3, 201651) TOLSTOY FARM, LAWLEY STATION, TRANSVAAL, November 11, 1911
('12', 92, 3, 4, 201710) MY DEAR LOWER HOUSE,
('12', 92, 4, 5, 201731) If you still think that you should send my letter about Aylmer Maude to him, you may do so.
('12', 92, 4, 6, 201823) I can fully appreciate your difficulties about even keeping to two meals and a saltless and vegetableless diet.
('12', 92, 4, 7, 201935) Your experience about your cousin is disconcerting.
('12', 92, 4, 8, 201987) Your des cription of it does credit to your heart.
('12', 92, 4, 9, 202038) You are there in the midst of the subtlest temptation.
('12', 92, 4, 10, 202093) The people you want to serve may uncons ciously be your death traps.
('12', 92, 4, 11, 202162) Your very abstemiousness ≈ the leaving off of salt, etc., may surround your life with romance and a halo and may then be itself a temptation.
('12', 92, 4, 12, 202304) Yes, the path of those who want to think and live right is narrow like the edge of a sword.
('12', 92, 4, 13, 202396) They may not only not swerve an inch from the path, they may not even lift their fixed gaze from their goal.
('12', 92, 4, 14, 202505) I have seen acrobats rope walkers in India.
('12', 92, 4, 15, 202549) They walk on a rope fixed to poles in mid air quite twenty feet or more from the ground.
('12', 92, 4, 16, 202638) They walk with a bamboo stretched along their outstretched arms and their gaze steadily in front of the other end.
('12', 92, 4, 17, 202753) They may not go away a hair’s breadth from their path.
('12', 92, 4, 18, 202808) Well, that of spiritual rope walkers is a millionfold more difficult.
('12', 92, 4, 19, 202878) Happily, they have also correspondingly greater strength.
('12', 92, 4, 20, 202936) You are one of those spiritual rope walkers.
('12', 92, 4, 21, 202981) In The Song Celestial, Krishna says: “A good man must think of ME (God) performing every function of life.” It is too true.
('12', 92, 4, 22, 203105) When there is no witness, He is the most vigilant and active in noting our lapses if also our merits.
('12', 92, 4, 23, 203207) Our merits count for nothing.
('12', 92, 4, 24, 203237) For that is what we owe.
('12', 92, 4, 25, 203262) Our lapses simply swell the heavy debit side.
('12', 92, 4, 26, 203308) Beware then; think of the articles of our agreement, and God willing you will be safe.
('12', 92, 4, 27, 203395) I know that I am addressing myself to a condition which existed one month ago and which, if it is existent at the time I am writing this, may have made a big alteration in your life.
('12', 92, 4, 28, 203578) But I have very great faith in you enough to know that you cannot fall.
('12', 92, 4, 29, 203650) Stewarts and Lloyds have not yet sent the material.
('12', 92, 4, 30, 203702) They will next week.
('12', 92, 4, 31, 203723) Fencing is steadily progressing.
('12', 92, 4, 32, 203756) Desai and Albrecht attend
('12', 93, 0, 1, 203782) 94 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('12', 96, 5, 15, 210464) 73. A BREACH OF FAITH
('12', 96, 6, 16, 210486) Apart from the legal effect of the £3 Tax Act, it is necessary to examine the bearing of the cirucular 3 we referred to in these columns last week.
('12', 96, 6, 17, 210634) There are cases when legal quibbles have to be deliberately set aside.
('12', 96, 6, 18, 210705) The £3 tax episode is, in our opinion, distinctly such a case.
('12', 96, 6, 19, 210768) The late Natal Govenment bound themselvels through their circular to exempt the Indins who re indentured themselves from the payment of the tax altogether.
('12', 96, 6, 20, 210924) We consider that the English text bears only that construction and no other.
('12', 96, 6, 21, 211001) But the translations, if anything, are still more binding on the Government in that the people acted upon them.
('12', 96, 6, 22, 211113) The Government must apply the simple rule of interpretation, viz., the meaning of the circular is the meaning that the men concerned reasonably gave to it.
('12', 96, 6, 23, 211269) Now there can be no doubt whatsoever as to what meaning the men gave.
('12', 96, 6, 24, 211339) So much for the circular and its effect.
('12', 96, 6, 25, 211380) The Union Government are using the force of the tyrant in seeking to interpret and enforce the Act in question in defiance of the circular.
('12', 96, 6, 26, 211520) We contend that the Acts of the late Government are binding on them, if they are to retain the respect of the inhabitants of South Africa, no matter whether they are poor Indians or highly placed
('12', 96, 7, 27, 211716) 1Vide “Letter to Dr. Pranjivan Mehta”, 22 10 1911. 2Vide “Letter to Dr. Pranjivan Mehta”, 22 10 1911. 3Vide “The £3 Tax”, 11 11 1911.
('12', 97, 0, 1, 211850) 98 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 97, 1, 2, 211891) Europeans.
('12', 97, 1, 3, 211902) It is a distinct breach of faith for them to override the circular and now want to exact £3 per year from the poor, deluded re indentured men.
('12', 97, 1, 4, 212045) Our appeal to the present members of the Ministry is, perhaps, specially appropriate.
('12', 97, 1, 5, 212131) They insisted on and succeeded in getting accepted the interpretation 1 of the Vereeniging Treaty which they, the weaker party, placed upon it.
('12', 97, 1, 6, 212275) Let General Botha beware lest, in the hour of triumph 2, he forget the lesson of the past and now steam roller poor, ignorant men into subjection.
('12', 97, 2, 7, 212422) Indian Opinion , 18 11 1911

('12', 97, 6, 25, 213308) 1 The reference is to the Boers’ insistence, after the War, on their right to interpret the word “Native” in clause 8 of the Vereeniging Treaty so as to deny the franchise to the Indians.
('12', 97, 6, 26, 213496) At that time Lord Milner allowed the Boers thus to interpret the clause which, however, only put off “the question of granting the franchise to Natives” “until after the introduction of self government”; but Indians were willing to forgo the right of political franchise as well ; vide “Petition to Natal Legislature”, 10 6 1903, “Statement Presented to Constitution Committee”, 29 5 1906, “Letter to The Outlook” and “London”, 27 8 1909. 2 Botha’s hour of triumph is a reference to how, within five years’ of losing the Boer War, the Dutch, under the Het Volk, had won the peace.
('12', 97, 6, 27, 214077) As Gandhiji put it at the time (Vol. VI, pp.
('12', 97, 6, 28, 214122) 343 4 & 357 8), “in defeat, the Dutch had truly won”.
('12', 97, 6, 29, 214176) Also, they were able subsequently to turn the Union of 1909 to their advantage, that is, to promote the interests of the Dutch language and those of the poor among themselves.

('12', 99, 5, 9, 216494) 76. AN UNFORTUNATE ANSWER
('12', 99, 6, 10, 216520) Mr. Harcourt’s reply on the £3 tax question is most un fortunate 2. If it represents the settled policy of the Union Government, they are in for a big battle, not of words but of action.
('12', 99, 6, 11, 216707) The free Indians owe it as a duty to themselves and to their poor brethren to act so as to secure repeal of the obnoxious levy.
('12', 99, 6, 12, 216835) With the stoppage of theintroduction of indentured labour from India the last vestige of justification for the levy ceases.
('12', 99, 6, 13, 216959) The Imperial Government cannot so easily be allowed to shirk their obvious duty.
('12', 99, 6, 14, 217040) If the levy is wrong, neither the Royal sanction nor the determination of the Union Government can make it right.
('12', 99, 6, 15, 217154) The sooner the Natal Indian Congress makes the position clear as to the steps to be taken by the Indian community the better it will be for all concerned.
('12', 99, 6, 16, 217309) The iniquitous tax must be removed at any cost.
('12', 99, 6, 17, 217357) Indian Opinion , 25 11 1911

('12', 99, 7, 22, 217837) He added that, while immigration of indentured Indians to Natal had ceased, the South African Government was not prepared to repeal the £3 tax.

('12', 100, 1, 2, 218050) 77. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('12', 100, 2, 3, 218083) November 26, 1911
('12', 100, 3, 4, 218101) MY DEAR LOWER HOUSE,
('12', 100, 4, 5, 218122) Today is Sunday.
('12', 100, 4, 6, 218139) I came into Town last night as I have to go with Cachalia today to Krugersdorp to make collections for the Polak deputation.
('12', 100, 5, 7, 218264) Call too is in Town.
('12', 100, 5, 8, 218285) He came in yesterday morning.
('12', 100, 5, 9, 218315) Call will not stay long at the Farm I fear.
('12', 100, 5, 10, 218359) He does not like anybody on the Farm except myself.
('12', 100, 5, 11, 218411) He cannot bear the sight of children (Indian).
('12', 100, 5, 12, 218458) He considers that no one on the Farm knows how to eat, sit, walk, run or stand.
('12', 100, 5, 13, 218538) The slightest thing upsets and irritates him.
('12', 100, 5, 14, 218584) I do not let the children go near him.
('12', 100, 5, 15, 218623) When he eats, the children are not to be near him.
('12', 100, 5, 16, 218674) He has the kitchen verandah all to himself.
('12', 100, 5, 17, 218718) I have withdrawn the night school from the school room and it is held in the kitchen room.
('12', 100, 5, 18, 218809) Special food has been brought for him.
('12', 100, 5, 19, 218848) Of course the above condition shows disease.
('12', 100, 5, 20, 218893) He tells me these things quite freely.
('12', 100, 5, 21, 218932) I am now seeing whether Call could be placed elsewhere.
('12', 100, 5, 22, 218988) If he had all the conditions agreeable to him, he is likely to recover quickly.
('12', 100, 5, 23, 219068) Beyond good, non stimulating food, fresh air and good surroundings, he needs nothing more.
('12', 100, 5, 24, 219159) Call’s condition shows how bad we must all be.
('12', 100, 5, 25, 219206) Call’s bad points come to the surface because the poor man has lost control over himself.
('12', 100, 5, 26, 219296) But Call at his worst seems to be an angel and certainly a good man compared to what we should be if we lost control over ourselves and the worst in us had full play.
('12', 100, 5, 27, 219463) The inner man must be in harmony with the outer.
('12', 100, 5, 28, 219512) We ought to be able to think and feel as we act.
('12', 100, 5, 29, 219561) That is, if I act politely towards you, I ought to feel that also.
('12', 100, 5, 30, 219628) Do I always think and feel well of people when I act well with them?
('12', 100, 5, 31, 219697) I am afraid it is not always thus.
('12', 100, 5, 32, 219732) To that extent that I fail, I am a liar.
('12', 100, 5, 33, 219773) And yet I must not act otherwise.
('12', 100, 5, 34, 219807) I must continually try to eradicate feelings and thoughts which are contrary to my actions as they ought to be.
('12', 100, 5, 35, 219919) Then I should be a wholly truthful man.
('12', 100, 5, 36, 219959) May you and I have the privilege of becoming such men.
('12', 100, 5, 37, 220014) I am full of thoughts on this matter which if I had the time I should put down in this letter but I must close.
('12', 100, 5, 38, 220126) Your remarks on your niece are good.
('12', 100, 6, 39, 220163) 1 Vide “Letter to Dr. Pranjivan Mehta”, 8 5 1911.

('12', 101, 7, 19, 221479) We must then await the reply from the Prime Minister.
('12', 101, 7, 20, 221533) Then there should be a petition to Parliament next year, and, if Parliament rejects the petition, there should be an appeal to the Imperial Government by the Congress aided by the other Associations in South Africa.
('12', 101, 7, 21, 221749) Finally the refusal to pay the tax!
('12', 101, 7, 22, 221785) Then, undoubtedly, the Congress should undertake to feed the wives and families of those who may be impri soned.

('12', 101, 7, 24, 221975) For this purpose, either you will have to be in Durban

('12', 104, 3, 15, 226167) Deliverance is possible even at the end of the present life.
('12', 104, 3, 16, 226228) Once we are firmly convinced of this, we must take up the quest.
('12', 104, 3, 17, 226293) There is no reason whatever to believe that anything is right just because it is an established practice or because it was done by our elders.
('12', 104, 3, 18, 226436) Such an attitude is in conflict with belief in the freedom of the soul.
('12', 104, 3, 19, 226508) There is much that is good in the old.
('12', 104, 3, 20, 226547) However, just as there is smoke wherever there is fire, the good in the old is [inevitably] mixed with other things not as good.
('12', 104, 3, 21, 226676) Wisdom consists in distinguishing between the two and drawing out the essential.
('12', 104, 3, 22, 226757) The letter 7 that Cordes has written .
('12', 104, 4, 23, 226796) From the Gujarati original in Gandhiji’s hand: C. W. 5665. Courtesy: Radhabehn Choudhri
('12', 104, 5, 24, 226884) 1 As the last incomplete line in this fragment suggests, the thoughts in this letter appear to have been inspired by a letter from Cordes (Appendix X) at Madras.
('12', 104, 5, 25, 227046) Gandhiji had earlier attempted to wean him from Theosophy, (“Letter to Dr. Pranjivan mehta”, p.
('12', 104, 5, 26, 227142) 65) but unsuccessfully as would appear from Cordes’s letter which sounds like a friendly farewell note.
('12', 104, 5, 27, 227246) The Trust Deed which his letter enclosed was signed and witnessed by Cordes on November 12. Assuming 15 days for the post from Madras to reach South Africa, this letter by Gandhiji, which is possibly addressed to someone in the Phoenix Settlement, of which Cordes had earlier been a member, must have been written some time after November 27, 1911. 2 Literally, “the Supreme God”, a name of Shiva, the God of austerity and self mastery in the Hindu Trinity 3 Literally, “One who lives in Hara”, i.e., in Shiva 4 The Absolute 5 Deliverance from phenomenal existence 6 Sinful action, resulting in degradation and punishment 7 Vide Appendix “Cordes’s Letter to Gandhiji”, 12 11 1911.

('12', 105, 6, 31, 229158) 1As this letter appears to have been sent from Tolstoy Farm, it could only have been written between July 20, 1911, when Anandlal Gandhi arrived in South Africa (“Letter to Maganlal Gandhi”, p.
('12', 105, 6, 32, 229352) 129) and about the middle of January, 1913 when Gandhiji shifted to Phoenix.
('12', 105, 6, 33, 229429) The only references to any “collection” tours by Anandlal Gandhi during this period occur in the Gujarati section of Indian Opinion, 25 11 1911 & 9 12 1912 11. The first mentions that Anandlal has left on a collection tour and the second, which is an extract from a longer item written on December 3, adds that Anandlal Gandhi joined others at Boksburg for collecting subscriptions for the Indian famine fund.
('12', 105, 6, 34, 229839) The reference to the famine (cited already in letters to Dr. Mehta, pp.
('12', 105, 6, 35, 229911) 161, 166 & 183) confirms that this letter belongs to 1911. Writing on a Tuesday Gandhiji says that “Anandlal will leave here at the latest on Saturday” and promises to post some Gujarati articles for Indian Opinion “on Wednesday”.
('12', 105, 6, 36, 230142) It is reasonable to assume, on the authority of the news items, that the letter was written between November 25 and December 3, and the only Tuesday between the two dates is November 28. We learn from the second news item that Anandlal Gandhi actually left on the morning of the 3rd, that is, a Sunday.

('12', 106, 3, 7, 230884) 82. LETTER TO RAOJIBHAI PATEL
('12', 106, 4, 8, 230914) Magshar Sud 8 [November 29, 1911] 1
('12', 106, 5, 9, 230950) DEAR SHRI RAOJIBHAI,
('12', 106, 6, 10, 230971) I have your letter.
('12', 106, 6, 11, 230991) I gather from it that you want to work in Phoenix.
('12', 106, 6, 12, 231042) It is a good idea.
('12', 106, 6, 13, 231061) I shall encourage you, but I doubt if you can stand the strain.
('12', 106, 6, 14, 231125) In Phoenix 1. you will have to observe brahmacharya; 2. you will be under a vow of scrupulous regard for truth; 3. you will have to do chiefly manual labour, that is, work with the hoe and the shovel; 4. if you intend to add to [your] book learning, please forget all about it.
('12', 106, 6, 15, 231403) Whatever addition comes naturally of because circumstances demand it will be welcome; 5. you should make up your mind that our duty is to strengthen character rather than acquire book learning; 6. you should fearlessly oppose injustice from the caste or the family; 7. you should embrace absolute poverty.
('12', 106, 6, 16, 231709) You should think of joining Phoenix only if you would and can do this.
('12', 106, 6, 17, 231780) You should tell yourself that life there will grow harder as the days pass and know that this is for your good.
('12', 106, 6, 18, 231892) Learn to think along these lines if you decide to come over in March.
('12', 106, 6, 19, 231962) Continue to write to me.
('12', 106, 6, 20, 231987) With due regards from MOHANDAS

('12', 107, 0, 1, 232235) 108 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 107, 1, 2, 232277) 83. AN ATTACK ON ASIATIC MORALS
('12', 107, 2, 3, 232309) We reproduced last week the full text of a leading article in The Transvaal Leader on the so called Asiatic invasion of Boksburg in the form of the opening by Mr. Bhyat of a store in that town.
('12', 107, 2, 4, 232503) The Leader of Mr. Cartwright’s time is not the Leader of today.
('12', 107, 2, 5, 232567) It would be difficult to find anything so virulent and offensive to Asiatics as the article in question.
('12', 107, 2, 6, 232672) In the opinion of its writer,
('12', 107, 3, 7, 232702) the Asiatic trader casts his sinister shadow, and, with his primitive mode of existence, his complete indifference to the simplest amenities of life, his Oriental ingenuity and his inferior standard of civilization menaces the future of the European shopkeeper.
('12', 107, 3, 8, 232964) In another place, the writer considers Oriental civilization to be on a “much lower grade”.
('12', 107, 3, 9, 233056) Then, again,
('12', 107, 4, 10, 233069) the European trader cannot much longer keep up the fight against the commercial wiles and the social iniquities of the inscrutable coolie.
('12', 107, 4, 11, 233208) The article ends with the desire
('12', 107, 5, 12, 233241) to protect the European from the unfair competition of the coolie who in so many towns of the Union has established himself at every street corner, bringing with him the unfamiliar habits and dress of Asia.
('12', 107, 5, 13, 233448) In the extracts we have quoted, the reader will not fail to notice how Asiatic morals have been attacked, how their habits and mode of life decried, and how unfavourably the Asiatic civilization has been com pared with the European.
('12', 107, 5, 14, 233681) The ignorant writer has not hesitated to use the word “coolie” in writing of Asiatic traders.
('12', 107, 5, 15, 233775) We are, however, not disposed to quarrel with the writer either for his ignorance or for his sentiments.
('12', 107, 5, 16, 233880) The very civilizaiton he represents makes for ignorance, inasmuch as its exacting demands upon the frail physical frame render it well nigh impossible for any dweller therein to have any but a most superficial knowledge of things in general, and, as those nurtured in it are continuously taught to consider that civilization to be the best, naturally one is prone to look down upon anything that does not satisfy its arbitrary standard.
('12', 107, 5, 17, 234317) And so we find that the writer looks down upon the Asiatic trader with contempt, because he is “indifferent to the simplest amenities of life”.
('12', 107, 5, 18, 234461) The Founder of Chris tianity showed much greater indifference to these amenities and his mode of existence was infinitely more primitive than that of the Asia tic trader, and yet we are quite certain that the writer never intended to
('12', 108, 0, 1, 234695) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 109
('12', 108, 1, 2, 234736) cast any reflection upon Jesus.
('12', 108, 1, 3, 234768) The question, therefore, that we have to address ourselves to is not whether to placate men of the writer’s stamp (and, after all, they represent undoubtedly the majority of the Europeans in South Africa), but whether we must alter our simple mode of life and take over what we consider to be the vices of modern life, in order to retain our foothold in their country.
('12', 108, 1, 4, 235137) Those who have done so know to their cost that they have not, on that account, been able to make themselves more acceptable.
('12', 108, 1, 5, 235262) Their Asiatic origin is still their sufficient condem nation.
('12', 108, 1, 6, 235324) The two systems are struggling to live side by side in South Africa.
('12', 108, 1, 7, 235393) The experiment is interesting.
('12', 108, 1, 8, 235424) We can only hope that, if the Asiatic has faith in himself and in his civilization, he will not lower the latter, and we doubt not that that which has stood the test of ages will come out scatheless in the test it is now undergoing in this sub continent.
('12', 108, 1, 9, 235679) But the handful of Asiatics in South Africa have to remem ber that, if they do not want to disgrace the country of their origin or their system of life, they must thoroughly represent it, and not present a parody of it.
('12', 108, 1, 10, 235899) They must live up to the moral code that has been handed down to them for ages past.
('12', 108, 1, 11, 235984) With them, honesty is not merely the best policy, and on that account only to be observed when it is profitable, but it must be adhered to at all cost and in all circum stances.
('12', 108, 1, 12, 236162) With them, might is not right, but right is always might.
('12', 108, 1, 13, 236220) They can have nothing to do with the doctrine of the survival of the fittest!
('12', 108, 1, 14, 236298) They have to live and let live.
('12', 108, 1, 15, 236330) If they catch the modern craze for competition and adopt the characteristically grasping nature of this vaunted civilization, they will certainly go under.
('12', 108, 2, 16, 236486) Indian Opinion , 2 12 1911

('12', 112, 4, 24, 245526) 86. LETTER TO E. F. C. LANE
('12', 112, 5, 25, 245554) December 7, 1911

('12', 115, 5, 6, 249957) 89. MIXED SCHOOLS AND MORALS
('12', 115, 6, 7, 249986) We gladly make room for Mrs. Wybergh’s spirited contribution 1
('12', 115, 7, 8, 250049) to the Worker on the question of mixed schools.
('12', 115, 7, 9, 250097) The matter was taken up by The Transvaal Leader, and the Education Board has invited Mrs. Wybergh to prove her charges.
('12', 115, 7, 10, 250217) This Mrs. Wybergh has offered to do if her informants, who are teachers, are fully protected.
('12', 115, 7, 11, 250311) There is some hesitation on the part of the Board to give the full protection she naturally asks for.
('12', 115, 7, 12, 250413) We are not just now concerned whether Mrs. Wybergh furnishes the Board with proofs in her possession.
('12', 115, 7, 13, 250515) What we wish to place on record is the fact that The Transvaal Leader and practically the whole of the Johannesburg Press suggest that the system of mixed schools should come to an end, especially for grown up boys and girls.
('12', 115, 7, 14, 250741) It seems to have been taken for granted that, in substance, Mrs. Wybergh’s indictment is true.
('12', 115, 7, 15, 250836) “Rest and be thankful” was Lord John Russell’s motto.
('12', 115, 7, 16, 250890) We admire the wisdom of those Indian parents who instinctively recoiled from the stupid experiments that the Natal Education Department wished to try among us of mixing boys and girls.
('12', 115, 7, 17, 251075) This is essentially an age of innovations and rash experiments.
('12', 115, 7, 18, 251139) Movement is mistaken for progress.
('12', 115, 7, 19, 251174) So long as you move, it does not matter whether you are moving backward or forward.
('12', 115, 7, 20, 251258) The existing order of things must be bad and must, therefore, be improved, says the zealous reformer.
('12', 115, 7, 21, 251360) “Hasten slowly” should be the motto of the real reformer.
('12', 115, 8, 22, 251418) 1In her article, Mrs. Wybergh had said that, whereas in London co education had been dropped as its wrongly conceived ideals had tended to exaggerate instead of equalizing sex differences, in Johannesburg it had been adopted merely to save the expense of separate school buildings for boys and girls.
('12', 115, 8, 23, 251719) She charged that no care had been taken “to guard against the great and obvious dangers”.
('12', 115, 8, 24, 251809) The results of the system were such that she could not record them without rendering herself liable to prosecution.
('12', 115, 8, 25, 251925) The parents seemed to be ignorant of this but conscientious school teachers were at their wits’ end.

('12', 116, 3, 4, 252300) 90. FAMINE IN INDIA
('12', 116, 4, 5, 252320) We have started a Famine Relief Fund.
('12', 116, 4, 6, 252358) 1 Mr. Gajjar has made a beginning.
('12', 116, 4, 7, 252393) We have had several letters from which we learn that a number of Indians are willing to take on [the task of] going round for collections.
('12', 116, 4, 8, 252532) This is our brief appeal to those who have realized how dreadful the famine is.
('12', 116, 4, 9, 252612) Please do not turn away those collecting contributions, saying that you have already paid towards many funds.
('12', 116, 4, 10, 252722) Do not hesitate to send your contribution directly either.
('12', 116, 4, 11, 252781) Those who have money have to contribute towards a variety of funds, but there can be no comparison between a famine Fund and other funds.
('12', 116, 4, 12, 252919) To this Fund, even the poorest Indian can contribute.
('12', 116, 4, 13, 252973) One who lives on coarse roti and ghee may go without ghee for a time and pay the money thus saved into the Famine Relief Fund.
('12', 116, 4, 14, 253100) Such a one should bear in mind that while he gets at least millet roti and ghee, people in the famine areas do not get even roti.
('12', 116, 4, 15, 253230) There is no fodder for cattle and both human beings and cattle have been reduced to skeletons.
('12', 116, 4, 16, 253325) If this is realized by everyone, there is no Indian who cannot make a contribution, however small.
('12', 116, 4, 17, 253424) We admit that there is no charity like that which one dispenses directly, where one can see it being use.
('12', 116, 4, 18, 253530) This is what people do in our country wherever they have not been caught in the wind from the West.
('12', 116, 4, 19, 253630) The villager gives in charity after the fashion of the village.
('12', 116, 4, 20, 253694) He shares his food with any poor person who may call at his home.
('12', 116, 4, 21, 253760) He does not even dream of being able to help those whom he cannot see.
('12', 116, 4, 22, 253831) He knows that even to think of it is pride and is like claiming to be God.
('12', 116, 4, 23, 253906) But we have been caught in the wind from the West.
('12', 116, 4, 24, 253957) It is this which has brought us to this land.
('12', 116, 4, 25, 254003) If people suffer overmuch during a famine, it is due to the Western atmosphere.
('12', 116, 4, 26, 254083) What is our duty at a time like this?
('12', 116, 4, 27, 254121) Our foremost duty is to quit this monstrous atmosphere here and rush to the side of the famine stricken, to live as they do and take
('12', 116, 5, 28, 254254) 1Vide “Famine in India”, 11 11 1911.
('12', 117, 0, 1, 254291) 118 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 117, 1, 2, 254333) them along the right path.
('12', 117, 1, 3, 254360) We may be inclined to do all this, but perhaps lack the requisite strength.
('12', 117, 1, 4, 254436) A man like Vibhishana 1 had to endure the monstrous atmosphere for a long time; what strengthhave we before him?
('12', 117, 1, 5, 254549) There may be others, moreover, who do not feel this way and do not even want to get away from here.
('12', 117, 1, 6, 254649) It is essential that both these types of people must send as much help as they can to the famine stricken.

('12', 120, 1, 2, 259549) 93. THE INIQUITOUS TAX
('12', 120, 2, 3, 259572) We publish elsewhere an instructive letter 1 from the Colonial Secretary addressed to Lord Ampthill’s Committee, and the Union Prime Minister’s Minute to the Governor General, on the Natal £3 tax, exacted from ex indentured men, women and children.
('12', 120, 2, 4, 259821) That the taxing legislation was imposed with the knowledge and consent of the Government of India and of His Majesty’s Government, and that the consent was obtained on a correct representation of facts, does not make it any the less criminal.
('12', 120, 2, 5, 260064) It may be considered very gracious on the part of the Union Government to be ready to consider any specific cases of hardship brought to their notice.
('12', 120, 2, 6, 260215) We venture to think, however, that every case of the exaction of this tax is a specific case of hardship.
('12', 120, 2, 7, 260321) But, apart from that, if, as Mr. Sauer 2 has pointed out, they have watched the law carefully and all complaints have been inquired into, why have they not produced statistics to show in what case and under what circumstances the tax has been remitted?
('12', 120, 2, 8, 260574) Our columns have been full of cases of hardship, especially on women.
('12', 120, 2, 9, 260644) The Government really were bound to waive the tax in respect of women
('12', 120, 3, 10, 260714) 1 Dated November 14, 1911, this was sent by Harcourt, Secretary of State for the Colonies, in reply to paragraph 6 of the SABI Committee’s representation of June 17, 1911 (Appendix VIII), which asked for exemption from the £3 tax for Indian women and children saying that the amending Act of 1910 (Natal Act 19 of 1910) had “but slightly improved the situation”.
('12', 120, 3, 11, 261077) It also drew attention to disparities between decisions of individual magistrates.
('12', 120, 3, 12, 261160) Along with his letter, Harcourt enclosed the copy of a despatch from the Governor General of South Africa containing a minute dated August 22, 1911 from the Union Ministers on the subject.
('12', 120, 3, 13, 261349) The minute, signed by Sauer, said that the £3 tax had been imposed “on grounds of policy, with a view to limiting the free Indian population as much as possible” and that the Ministers considered its repeal inadvisable.
('12', 120, 3, 14, 261569) The minute added that the application of the law in particular cases had been “carefully watched” and all complaints inquired into and that the Ministers were convinced that there had been “no undue harshness in the administration of this law”.
('12', 120, 3, 15, 261814) Commenting on this, Harcourt had observed that the facts had been “correctly represented” in the minute and the legislation had been passed with the full knowledge and consent of the Government of India and of His Majesty’s Government and that he could only accept the Ministry’ decision.
('12', 120, 3, 16, 262103) Indian Opinion, 1612 1911. 2 J. W. Sauer; member of the Cape Legislature and later of the Union Cabinet; fellow passenger with the Transvaal Indian Deputation of 1909 on board s.s.
('12', 120, 3, 17, 262284) Kenilworth Castle; vide “Deputation’s Voyage”, 23 6 1909 Gandhiji who met him during the voyage found him “full of sympathy”; he promised all possible help.
('12', 121, 0, 1, 262441) 122 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 121, 1, 2, 262483) entirely, as has been shown by us by quoting speeches of responsible members of the now defunct Natal Parliament when the amending measure was passed.
('12', 121, 1, 3, 262634) 1 The Minister’s Minute is, we are constrained to say, calculated to blind the Imperial Government to the serious nature of the hardship entailed on those who have to bear the burden.
('12', 121, 1, 4, 262818) We trust that the attention of the Imperial Government will be brought to the almost unanimous condemnation 2 by the South African Press of the wretched treatment meted out to people who have deserved better of those for whom they have slaved for a number of years.
('12', 121, 1, 5, 263084) We think that it was open to Mr. Harcourt to have at least invited the Union Government to consider the new situation that has arisen by reason of the stoppage of recruiting indentured Indian labour for Natal.
('12', 121, 1, 6, 263294) The question of limiting the free Indian population as much as possible does not now arise as witness General Smuts’ own statement made to his Pretoria constituents on the 7th instant:
('12', 121, 2, 7, 263479) If ever Asiatics were introduced here as indentured labourers, there would be revolution.
('12', 121, 2, 8, 263569) That door was closed for ever.
('12', 121, 2, 9, 263600) We note with considerable satisfaction that, in the absence of Lord Ampthill, Lord Lamington has been moving the House of Lords in the matter of the forthcoming legislation.

('12', 122, 8, 10, 265139) Yes, with reference to Obligadoo, we ought to get the charge sheet.
('12', 122, 8, 11, 265207) I want to see the two counts on which he was prosecuted.
('12', 122, 8, 12, 265264) You will see the Prosecutor accepted his plea of guilty on the first count and was satisfied.
('12', 122, 8, 13, 265358) Generally, when a Prosecutor does that, you may depend upon it that he has a very weak case, and, as a matter of fact, this plea of guilty ought never to have been accepted by the Magistr gistrate as a plea of guilty, because the accused has qualified it, saying he was in want of this money and took it.

('12', 123, 4, 10, 267192) 96. WHAT TO EXPECT FROM THE IMPERIAL GOVERNMENT
('12', 123, 5, 11, 267240) The letter (for Downing Street a long one) written to Lord Ampthill’s Committee by the Colonical Office on the petition of the British Indian Association regarding the Transvaal Draft Local Government Ordinance 1 forms sad reading, and if confirmation were wanted, it confirms the opinion held by many passive resisters that it was the strength of passive resistance alone which brought about with General Smuts the Provisional Settlement which should be reduced to legislation during the next two or three months.
('12', 123, 5, 12, 267755) We do not wish to convey the impression that Imperial Government sat with folded arms and that the Union Government were not in any way affected by the representations that were made by the Imperial Government, but what we do wish to convey is that the Imperial Government would not have moved at all in our favour, had it not been for passive resistance.
('12', 123, 5, 13, 268111) Mr. Harcourt’s letter of the 23rd November last, says in so many words that the Imperial Government will not intervene on our behalf even in order to secure redress of tangible grievances.
('12', 123, 5, 14, 268300) The fact that some thing—it does not matter to them whether it is just or unjust—has been done before is sufficient reason for them to reject any approach
('12', 123, 6, 15, 268455) 1 For the sections of the Ordinance affecting Asiatics and the BIA’s petition, vide Appendix “Transvaal Draft Local Government Ordinance, 1911: Extracts Affecting Asiatics”, 10 6 1911.
('12', 124, 0, 1, 268640) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 125
('12', 124, 1, 2, 268681) on behalf of British Indians in order to undo an admitted wrong.
('12', 124, 1, 3, 268746) We need not have been told that the municipal franchise was taken away from us by a previous Ordinance, nor that most of the clauses in the proposed Draft Ordinance were virtually a re enactment of old provisions.
('12', 124, 1, 4, 268960) It did not strike Mr. Harcourt that it was quits the proper thing for the British Indian Association to have drawn attention to such re enactment, especially in the new circumstances arising from the Union of South Africa, and there can be no reason why Mr. Harcourt could not have pressed for a revision of a vicious policy at an opportune time like that of the impending passage of the Draft Ordinance in question.
('12', 124, 1, 5, 269377) It grieves us to find Mr. Harcourt as representing the Imperial Government concurring with the Union Ministers in their policy of shuffle.
('12', 124, 1, 6, 269516) He and they insult our intelligence when they tell us that we could have no ground for complaint because the clauses regarding the issue of licences are of a general character.
('12', 124, 1, 7, 269693) They must know as well as we do that, in the vast majority of cases, such general clauses have been in administration made applicable only to Asiatics.
('12', 124, 1, 8, 269845) A passage, however, in Mr. Harcourt’s letter dealing with the matter wherein the deprivation of the right of appeal to a court of law is referred to as a hardship supplies a ray of hope that something may be done in this direction.
('12', 124, 1, 9, 270077) It is wonderful how in an important communication dealing with weighty matters the most trifling and contemptible arguments have been seriously taken up in answer to our complaints.
('12', 124, 1, 10, 270259) Mr. Harcourt, for instance, justifies the deprivation of the right of Indians, other Asiatics and, for that matter, other Coloured people to be employed in bakeries, etc., on the exploded ground of sanitation.
('12', 124, 1, 11, 270469) He ought to know by this time that the clause in question is purely an attempt to take away the means of livelihood, and an avenue for employment, from honest people.
('12', 124, 1, 12, 270636) Surely the sanitary authorities can be trusted to look after sanitation and to see whether bakers and their employees observe the rules of hygiene.
('12', 124, 1, 13, 270784) We are also gravely told that similar disability in connection with a different matter altogether has been created against female labour.
('12', 124, 1, 14, 270922) The crying grievance regarding tram cars is similarly rejected because it is a “matter of long standing”, as if a crime oft repeated actually became a virtue.
('12', 124, 1, 15, 271081) We are sorry that the Imperial Government, in taking up the attitude as exemplified in Mr. Harcourt’s letter, are abdicating their function of holding the balance

('12', 125, 1, 3, 271559) We could wish that there would be a reversion to the old and fearless attitude of absolute impartiality which at one time ruled at the centre of the Empire when self interest at the centre itself was not in jeopardy.

('12', 125, 3, 5, 271804) 97. A SHAMEFUL ACT
('12', 125, 4, 6, 271823) The brief report of the Nathalia case 1 we published last week has disgusted every member of the community as it disgusted the judges themselves who decided upon this matter.
('12', 125, 4, 7, 271998) It is enough to make one despair of the utility of law courts if the judges cannot right a wrong that they themselves acknowledge.
('12', 125, 4, 8, 272129) The late Mr. Leonard used to say and hold that there was no wrong without a legal remedy.
('12', 125, 4, 9, 272219) It is this comfortable delusion which reconciles some of the otherwise best minds to the practice of a profession which has very few redeeming features.
('12', 125, 4, 10, 272372) This case on Nathalia, a young lad, cannot be allowed to rest where the Natal judges have left it.
('12', 125, 4, 11, 272471) It is a national scandal that the boy cannot be admitted to the Province in spite of his having produced credentials which would have satisfied any but an autocratic immigration officer who has certainly no time to bring to bear on a case a judicial mind free from bias.
('12', 125, 4, 12, 272742) His very vocation forbids it.
('12', 125, 4, 13, 272772) The fault is therefore not the individual’s but of the legislature that has wickedly saddled a responsibility on him which no ordinary mortal could discharge.
('12', 125, 4, 14, 272931) He is legally called an “Immigration Restriction Officer” appointed to administer a restriction law.
('12', 125, 4, 15, 273032) How could he generally decide in favour of persons whom he is expected to restrict?
('12', 125, 5, 16, 273116) 1 E.M. Nathalia “was sent back to India twice, and on the last occasion had returned with documents that were required to show that he was the son of the father he sought to join” in Natal.
('12', 125, 5, 17, 273306) The Immigration Restriction Officer was, however, not convinced and refused the boy permission to land.
('12', 125, 5, 18, 273410) The judge remarked that “the officer never seemed to be able to believe that a boy was the son of his father”, but would not interfere because the officer had full authority.
('12', 125, 5, 19, 273585) Indian Opinion, 23 12 1911.
('12', 126, 0, 1, 273613) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 127
('12', 126, 1, 2, 273654) To prevent an appeal from his decisions is to deny justice.
('12', 126, 1, 3, 273714) And that the late Natal legislature succeeded in doing.
('12', 126, 1, 4, 273770) We trust that the matter will be taken to a higher court and thoroughly thrashed out.
('12', 126, 1, 5, 273856) It will be a discredit to the community to which the lad belongs if we allow him to be sent back.
('12', 126, 1, 6, 273954) The community must make it a point of honour to protect the boy, who, we are satisfied, is the son of the person who claims him as such.
('12', 126, 2, 7, 274091) Indian Opinion , 30 12 1911
('12', 126, 3, 8, 274119) 98. THE NEW YEAR
('12', 126, 4, 9, 274136) At the close of a year we are apt to look back on the way we have come and it is a good thing if we are able to find something over which we can rejoice.
('12', 126, 4, 10, 274290) What has happened during this year that can be said to have affected the Indian community?
('12', 126, 4, 11, 274381) The first week of January brought the welcome news from Calcutta that the Government of India had decided to issue a notice in April prohibiting the further emigration of indentured Indians to Natal from July 1. 1 This decision was carried out; and now we have seen the last of indentured Indian immigration to these shores.
('12', 126, 4, 12, 274706) It is impossible at this time to say what the effect will ultimately be, but we have good reason to believe that many employers of Indian labour have awoke to the necessity of treating their work people with some consideration and providing them with decent housing accommodation.
('12', 126, 4, 13, 274987) We hope to see more improvements as time goes on, including the establishing of schools for Indian children living on the estates.
('12', 126, 4, 14, 275118) This, however, does not blind us to the many evils of the indenture system, and we have not forsaken our ideal of freedom for all.
('12', 126, 4, 15, 275249) This will come in time when the people themselves are ready for it.
('12', 126, 4, 16, 275317) Better treatment and healthier conditions, which are now being offered as inducements to re indenture, will in the course of time lead to freedom of contract between labourers and employers.
('12', 126, 4, 17, 275508) The year opened with the Transvaal passive resistance struggle at white heat.
('12', 126, 4, 18, 275586) In March the Immigrants’ Restriction Bill 2 was published and our readers will remember its fate 3. Then followed the lengthy

('12', 131, 5, 5, 284615) 104. SMALLPOX IN JOHANNESBURG

('12', 131, 6, 10, 284922) But our crime consists in the Indians concerned having concealed the outbreak.
('12', 131, 6, 11, 285001) The whole community will have to suffer for the crime of an individual.
('12', 131, 6, 12, 285073) Happily the leaders are whole heartedly co operating with Dr. Porter 2 in stamping out the disease.

('12', 131, 6, 15, 285509) Passive resistance can be as effectively applied within as without.
('12', 131, 6, 16, 285577) Only, when it has to be applied within it is far more difficult.
('12', 131, 6, 17, 285642) But then a real passive resister will not—cannot flinch in the face of difficulties, however serious they may be.
('12', 131, 6, 18, 285756) It is a common charge against us that we are an insanitary people and without scruples when it is a matter of cheating authorities by way of concealing diseases or misleading them.

('12', 132, 3, 4, 286602) 105. INTERVIEW TO “THE EVENING CHRONICLE”
('12', 132, 4, 5, 286644) [JOHANNESBURG, January 15, 1912] 1
('12', 132, 5, 6, 286679) An Evening Chronicle man interviewed Mr. Gandhi on the questions of trading licence, the smallpox outbreak, etc.
('12', 132, 6, 7, 286792) Asked as to the particular objections to the Municipal Ordinance 2, Mr. Gandhi replied: The objections we take to the draft Ordinance are to the control being given to Municipalities over a certain class of trading licences, without even the right to appeal; 3 to the reimposition of the disqualification as to the municipal franchise; 4 and to the qualification as to Indians and other Asiatics being engaged in bakeries, etc.
('12', 132, 7, 8, 287220) The first and third of these are innovations; the second is an old grievance, 6 but I think the British Indians are bound to protest against it each time it is revived or reasserted in legislative form.
('12', 132, 7, 9, 287423) Indians naturally hope that some day or other a prejudice, which has little justification, will die out, and having that as their goal it is felt that they cannot allow renewed attempts to perpetuate discriminating legis lation to pass by without protest.
('12', 132, 8, 10, 287679) [QUESTION:] And the provision for Asiatic bazaars, 7 Mr. Gandhi—are these not

('12', 141, 0, 1, 306789) 142 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 141, 1, 2, 306831) 113. THE NEW IMMIGRATION BILL
('12', 141, 2, 3, 306861) The Union Immigration Bill which is partly intended to satisfy the Transvaal Indian passive resisters is now out.
('12', 141, 2, 4, 306975) It is in some respects a better bill than that of the last year.
('12', 141, 2, 5, 307040) But it does not quite fulfil the promise made by General Smuts.
('12', 141, 2, 6, 307104) General Smuts has undertaken not to disturb the existing legal status throughout South Africa in any general bill designed to meet passive resisters.
('12', 141, 3, 7, 307254) The existing legal position is among other things that, at any rate at the Cape and the Transvaal, domicile and the rights of minor children and wives of non prohibited immigrants are dependent on a decision of the highest tribunal of justice; that British Indians of the Transvaal passing the ordinary simple education test can easily enter the Cape or Natal; and that Indians of Natal have until lately received certificates of domicile as a matter of right upon proving domicile.
('12', 141, 3, 8, 307737) Under the New Bill the Immigration Officer constitutes the highest court of justice to consider the rights of domiciled Asiatics and their wives and children; educated Indians of the Transvaal have to pass the stiffer test under the new Bill on entering the Cape or Natal and the Natal Indians will be unable to demand certificates of domicile as a matter of right.
('12', 141, 3, 9, 308103) 2 Now these are new disabilities which passive resisters cannot be expected to accept.
('12', 141, 3, 10, 308190) We hope, however, that these points arean oversight and that General Smuts will rectify the defects in Committee.
('12', 141, 3, 11, 308304) The Free State difficulty is being met with as was suggested last year.
('12', 141, 3, 12, 308376) 3 Only care will have to be taken that an Indian finding his way to the Free State as an educated immigrant is not called upon under Section 8 of Chapter XXXIII of the Free State Constitution to make any declaration contemplated by it.
('12', 141, 3, 13, 308612) If these points are cleared up, we fancy that passive resisters will be completely met.
('12', 141, 4, 14, 308700) 1 Vide “Letter to E. F. C. Lane”, 29 4 1911. 2 “A Notice to Every Indian”, published in the Gujarati columns of Indian Opinion, 3 2 1912 said: “Indians residing in Natal or the Cape who do not possess proper certificates of domicile are advised not to leave their Provinces for the time being”.
('12', 141, 4, 15, 308995) 3 Vide “Interview to Cape Argus”, before 30 3 1911 and “Letter to E. F. C. Lane”, 7 4 1911.
('12', 142, 0, 1, 309087) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 143
('12', 142, 1, 2, 309128) There still remain general objections by Natal 1 and the Cape.
('12', 142, 1, 3, 309191) They will be legitimately able to complain of the new education test, and at least be entitled to some guarantee that a certain number of educated Indians from India will be permitted to pass the education test.
('12', 142, 1, 4, 309403) The Bill even then will leave many things from an Asiatic standpoint in an unsatisfactory condition.
('12', 142, 1, 5, 309504) Restriction on interstate immigration will be a cause of great grievance.
('12', 142, 1, 6, 309578) 2 And the disabilities of lawful residents as to ownership of landed property, etc., in the Transvaal or the Free State must be a menace to the well being of Indians and other Asiatics, who, after all, form part of the South African nation that is in process of formation.
('12', 142, 2, 7, 309851) Indian Opinion ,3 2 1912
('12', 142, 3, 8, 309876) 114. LATE MR. ABDOOLLA HAJEE ADAM
('12', 142, 4, 9, 309910) One of the greatest figures in the Indian community of Natal is no more.
('12', 142, 4, 10, 309983) Mr. Abdoolla Hajee Adam Jhaveri 3, of the well known firm of Dada Abdoola and Co., breathed his last on Monday last, at the age of 58 leaving a widow, together with the whole Indian communityand not a few of his European friends to mourn after him.
('12', 142, 4, 11, 310232) With the deceased was linked the political as also the commercial life of the Indians of Natal.
('12', 142, 4, 12, 310328) He was one of the first independent Indian settlers of Natal, having almost immediately followed the late Mr. Abobaker Amod 4. Mr. Abdoolla Hajee Adam, together with his partners,
('12', 142, 5, 13, 310508) 1 A meeting of the Natal Indian Congress held on February 4 passed resolutions protesting against: (a) the Union immigration bill and the wide powers vested under it in the administration; (b) the discretion vested in the Immigration Officer to decide the highly technical question of domicile and that of marriage and parentage.
('12', 142, 5, 14, 310838) The meeting demanded the right of Natal Indians to permanent domiciliary certificates issued by the Government.
('12', 142, 5, 15, 310950) It protested against the education test, the restriction on interprovincial immigration and the rescinding of domiciliary rights of Natal Indians who could prove three years’ residence in the Province.
('12', 142, 5, 16, 311152) 2 Vide “Letter to E. F. C. Lane”, 29 1 1912 and telegrams to the Private Secretary to the Minister of the Interior, 30 1 1912 & 1 2 1912. 3 He invited Gandhiji to South Africa in 1893 to represent his case to an English lawyer.
('12', 142, 5, 17, 311380) 4 Abubaker Amod Zaveri; one of the early Indian settlers in the Transvaal, a leading merchant of “silk and fancy goods” and the only Indian to own landed property in the Transvaal.
('12', 142, 5, 18, 311561) He sent indentured Indians in distress back to India in his ships free of charge and even helped them with food and money en route.
('12', 142, 5, 19, 311693) The transfer, on his death, of his property, which was acquired before Law 3 of 1885 came into force, to his heirs became the subject of much controversy and legislation.
('12', 143, 0, 1, 311864) 144 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 143, 1, 2, 311906) probably owned the largest Indian business throughout South Africa during the last decade of the past century.
('12', 143, 1, 3, 312017) His firm had at one time probably no fewer than fifteen branches, their transactions with England, Germany and India running into thousands of pounds sterling.
('12', 143, 1, 4, 312177) He was the first Indian to have gone in for ship owning in South Africa, he having bought the Courland and the Khedive.
('12', 143, 1, 5, 312297) Mr. Abdoolla Hajee Adam’s political ability was as great as his business talent.
('12', 143, 1, 6, 312378) He was the President founder of the Natal Indian Congress.
('12', 143, 1, 7, 312437) His oratorical powers in his own mother tongue were of no mean order.
('12', 143, 1, 8, 312507) Though his knowledge of English was all picked up, he could carry on with ease a sustained argument in English.
('12', 143, 1, 9, 312619) He used to surprise his European friends by his resources in argument and apt illustrations which he used to draw upon for enforcing his point.
('12', 143, 1, 10, 312763) He headed many a deputation to the Natal Government, especially during the late Sir John Robinson’s 1 premiership.
('12', 143, 1, 11, 312878) Though he was ailing, he took a most active and prominent part in the boycott of the Coronation celebrations when he spoke to the crowds that surrounded him with his old fire.
('12', 143, 1, 12, 313054) No memoir of Mr. Abdoolla Hajee Adam would be complete that did not refer to his religious zeal.
('12', 143, 1, 13, 313151) His greatest pleasure in life was probably to engage in a religious and philosophical discussion.
('12', 143, 1, 14, 313249) He lost no opportunity of placing before his arguers the beauties of the religion of the holy Prophet of Arabia.
('12', 143, 1, 15, 313362) We tender our condolences to the late Mr. Abdoolla Hajee Adam’s family.
('12', 143, 2, 16, 313434) Indian Opinion , 3 2 1912
('12', 143, 3, 17, 313460) 115. NEW IMMIGRATION BILL 2
('12', 143, 4, 18, 313488) SUMMARY OF IMPORTANT CLAUSES AND COMMENTS
('12', 143, 5, 19, 313530) The Bill will apply to the entire Union of South Africa.
('12', 143, 6, 20, 313587) SECTION 3
('12', 143, 7, 21, 313597) The Governor General is empowered to appoint an Immigration Board to help the Government.
('12', 143, 8, 22, 313687) 1 (1839 1903); first Prime Minister and Colonial Secretary of Natal, 1893 7. 2 For extracts from the Bill in English, vide Appendix Extracts from Immigrants’ Restriction Bill (1912) and Orange Free State Constitution”, 3 2 1912.
('12', 144, 0, 1, 313916) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 145
('12', 144, 1, 2, 313957) COMMENT
('12', 144, 2, 3, 313965) We may demand that our people should be represented on this board.
('12', 144, 3, 4, 314032) SECTION 4(A)
('12', 144, 4, 5, 314045) A person, who is unable to write out 50 words, to the satisfaction of the Immigration Officer in the language which he chooses,will be prohibited from entering the Union.
('12', 144, 5, 6, 314216) COMMENT
('12', 144, 6, 7, 314224) These may include the Arabic and the Sanskrit languages.
('12', 144, 6, 8, 314281) Even so the clause is severe.
('12', 144, 6, 9, 314311) The Transvaal [Indians], however, cannot protest against it; but Natal and the Cape should protest.
('12', 144, 6, 10, 314411) Also, we cannot hope that this clause will be amended.
('12', 144, 6, 11, 314466) But an arrangement can be made to ensure the entry of a specified number of educated Indians to meet our needs.
('12', 144, 7, 12, 314578) SECTION 4(C)
('12', 144, 8, 13, 314591) If a foreign Government sends any [adverse] information about a person, he shall be prevented from entering [the Union]
('12', 144, 9, 14, 314711) COMMENT
('12', 144, 10, 15, 314719) This section appears to be meant for agitators.
('12', 144, 11, 16, 314767) SECTION 5 (f) & (g)
('12', 144, 12, 17, 314787) A person who wants to enter [the Union] by virtue of his [pre War] domiciliary rights and whose wife and children also wish to enter [by virtue of his right of entry] should prove their rights to the satisfaction of the [Immigration] Officer.
('12', 144, 13, 18, 315030) COMMENT
('12', 144, 14, 19, 315038) Everyone should oppose this section.
('12', 144, 14, 20, 315075) There is a similar section in the Natal [law].
('12', 144, 14, 21, 315122) The Government now intends to introduce this in the Cape and the Transvaal [laws].
('12', 144, 14, 22, 315205) Even a satyagrahi cannot accept this section.
('12', 144, 14, 23, 315251) We should certainly be given the right to appeal to courts of law [against the official’s decisions]
('12', 144, 15, 24, 315352) SECTION 6
('12', 144, 16, 25, 315362) A prohibited immigrant is liable to three months’ imprison ment.
('12', 144, 16, 26, 315427) There is no [provision for a] fine.
('12', 144, 16, 27, 315463) And he can be deported.
('12', 145, 0, 1, 315487) 146 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 145, 1, 2, 315529) SECTION 7
('12', 145, 2, 3, 315539) If an Indian from one Province of the Union wishes to proceed to another, he must pass a fresh [dictation] test.
('12', 145, 3, 4, 315652) COMMENT
('12', 145, 4, 5, 315660) Under this section it may happen that a few educated Indians from Natal or the Cape may occasionally enter the Transvaal; but it will be very difficult for educated Indians from the Transvaal to go Natal or Cape.
('12', 145, 4, 6, 315873) For, instead of the existing test which is relatively easy, they will have to pass the new test which is more severe.
('12', 145, 4, 7, 315991) Everyone concerned should oppose this section.
('12', 145, 4, 8, 316038) This can never be acquiesced in.
('12', 145, 4, 9, 316071) Even the satyagrahis cannot afford to remain silent [on this point]
('12', 145, 5, 10, 316139) SECTION 8
('12', 145, 6, 11, 316149) No prohibited immigrant can carry on trade or own land in the Province [where his residence is unlawful], or in any part of the Union.
('12', 145, 7, 12, 316284) COMMENT
('12', 145, 8, 13, 316292) The effect of the section will be that a Cape Indian, who does not have the right to reside in Natal, cannot own land or carry on trade in that Province.
('12', 145, 9, 14, 316446) SECTION 23
('12', 145, 10, 15, 316457) The onus of proving that one is not a prohibited immigrant will lie on the [intending immigrant].
('12', 145, 11, 16, 316555) COMMENT
('12', 145, 12, 17, 316563) All such laws contain a similar section.
('12', 145, 13, 18, 316604) SECTION 25 (I)
('12', 145, 14, 19, 316619) The Government reserves powers to issue temporary permits on such conditions as it may choose.
('12', 145, 15, 20, 316714) COMMENT
('12', 145, 16, 21, 316722) Under this section the Government can permit the entry of persons whose services it considers essential.
('12', 146, 0, 1, 316827) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 147
('12', 146, 1, 2, 316868) [SECTION 25(II)] 1
('12', 146, 2, 3, 316887) The [Immigration] officer, in his discretion, may issue to any person who fears that he may forfeit his [domiciliary] right, a permit entitling him to return [to the Province or the Union] after a specified period.
('12', 146, 3, 4, 317102) COMMENT A similar offensive section is contained in the Cape law, but it is a new one for Natal.
('12', 146, 3, 5, 317199) It is not obligatory on one to take out this permit; but the poor may be [imprisoned and] sorely harassed [if, on their return, they are unable to establish their domiciliary right].
('12', 146, 3, 6, 317382) Natal should vehemently oppose this section.
('12', 146, 3, 7, 317427) The satyagrahis may do so too; but it cannot be asserted just yet that they should fight.
('12', 146, 3, 8, 317517) One does not forfeit one’s right if one does not take out this permit and one can leave Natal after making [other] careful arrangements.
('12', 146, 4, 9, 317654) SECTION 28(I) &(II) Act 36 of 1908 (the second Asiatic Act) will not apply to those, who enter (the Union) after passing the [dictation] test.
('12', 146, 4, 10, 317797) But they will nevertheless be subject to Sections 7 & 8 of the Orange Free State Laws 2.
('12', 146, 5, 11, 317886) COMMENT Under this section, an Indian who has passed the test gets an unqualified right to reside in all the four Provinces [of the Union].
('12', 146, 5, 12, 318026) He will not have to register himself.
('12', 146, 5, 13, 318064) He cannot, however, own land in his own name in the Transvaal.
('12', 146, 5, 14, 318127) In the Orange Free State, he cannot own land, neither can he carry on trade or farming.
('12', 146, 5, 15, 318215) Satyagrahis cannot ask for more than this.
('12', 146, 5, 16, 318258) Another campaign, and that on a big scale, should, however, be launched to secure the rights to own land, etc.
('12', 146, 5, 17, 318369) For this it is essential that Indians should acquire the requisite strength.
('12', 146, 5, 18, 318446) That will take time.
('12', 146, 5, 19, 318467) We have still much to learn and to suffer yet.
('12', 146, 5, 20, 318514) This law contains 29 sections in all, but it is unnecessary to summarize the rest.

('12', 147, 8, 9, 319612) DEAR SHRI RAOJIBHAI,
('12', 147, 9, 10, 319633) I have your letter.
('12', 147, 9, 11, 319653) I have not changed my mind but, in view of our father’s refusal to permit you to go to Phoenix, it is my duty to say ‘No’ to you.
('12', 147, 9, 12, 319783) You have a like duty.
('12', 147, 9, 13, 319805) If, however, your father wants you to do something that is positively wrong, I can take you into Phoenix to help your escape that.
('12', 147, 9, 14, 319936) When placed in a moral dilemma, one is bound to hold one’s peace if parents forbid one to follow a certain line of action; if pressed, however, to do something sinful, one should refuse to obey.
('12', 147, 9, 15, 320131) Prahladji’s is the only example that can be
('12', 147, 10, 16, 320175) 1 Vide “A Note”, on or after 2 2 1912. 2 A meeting of the Cape Indians held on February 4 passed unanimous resolutions on the lines suggested in the telegram.

('12', 147, 10, 20, 320591) It gives the rest of the letter under Phagan Sud 2 (corresponding to February 20 in 1912).
