('12', 148, 0, 1, 320802) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 149
('12', 148, 1, 2, 320843) cited in this connection.
('12', 148, 1, 3, 320869) One may, moreover, submit to any amount of physical suffering at the bidding of one’s father.
('12', 148, 1, 4, 320963) As for suffering to the self, there can be none.
('12', 148, 1, 5, 321012) You can conform to [the requirements of] morality while engaged in business.
('12', 148, 1, 6, 321089) That will be education for you and a preparation for the kind of life that you wish to live.
('12', 148, 1, 7, 321182) You will be, moreover, rendering a service to others through your business if you can practise absolute honesty in your dealings.
('12', 148, 1, 8, 321312) You should accept a fixed price from every customer, one which would permit a reasonable margin of profit.
('12', 148, 1, 9, 321419) You ought not to sell articles which you would not use yourself.
('12', 148, 1, 10, 321484) You should be civil to the customers, [though] you need not flatter them in order to promote sales.
('12', 148, 1, 11, 321584) If you have any assistance, you should treat them as if they were your brothers.
('12', 148, 1, 12, 321665) All this should be easy enough.
('12', 148, 1, 13, 321697) You should not feel that, by being in business, you will be exposing yourself to temptations; it is not as if your took to busi ness in order to make dishonest gains.
('12', 148, 1, 14, 321864) You will be joining business merely in deference to your father’s order, so that your should find it quite easy to maintain uprightness.
('12', 148, 1, 15, 322001) You say that you are not in love with money.
('12', 148, 1, 16, 322046) One may feel unhappy in a situation which one dislikes, but one will not corrupted.
('12', 148, 1, 17, 322130) I do not think Prahladji found it in any way difficult to live as a devotee of Vishnu in the midst of rakshasa 1; for he utterly disliked the rakshasa way of life.
('12', 148, 1, 18, 322294) One can be true to one’s pledge even when made to sit on the shuli 2. A true pledge is the one that is kept even at such moment.
('12', 148, 1, 19, 322423) If uprightness has become natural to us, has become a part of our being, it can certainly be kept, and it is the duty of us all to cultivate it to that extent.
('12', 148, 1, 20, 322583) I pray that your may succeed in your noble aspiration.
('12', 148, 2, 21, 322638) With due regards from MOHANDAS

('12', 149, 4, 6, 323262) The meeting expresses its disapproval of the Bill as it stands, and authorizes the President and Secretary, on behalf of the whole Anglo British Indian community, to petition Parliament, and to take such further, or other,steps as may be necessary to bring about the modification of the Bill in the particulars and on the lines suggested in the President’s address, members of the meeting indivi dually promising their strenuous support and assistance wherever possible.

('12', 152, 1, 2, 327604) 122. THE IMMIGRATION BILL
('12', 152, 2, 3, 327630) The Natal Indian Congress and the Cape British Indian Union have lost no time in holding public meetings 1 to protest against the Immigration Bill that was to have been read second time last Thursday.
('12', 152, 2, 4, 327831) The resolutions 2 ought to command acceptance.
('12', 152, 2, 5, 327878) The Bill designed not only to carry out the policy of almost entire Asiatic exclusion, but, if it is passed in its present form, it will very largely interfere with vested rights, and Asiatics generally will find themselves at the mercy of Immigration Officers.
('12', 152, 2, 6, 328140) General Botha’s declaration 3 made in England, and repeated elsewhere: that the Union Government do not desire to molest the resident Asiatic population of South Africa, will be falsified.
('12', 152, 2, 7, 328329) It is more an Asiatic Expulsion Bill than an Immigration Consolidation Bill, as its authors have entitled it.
('12', 152, 2, 8, 328439) The rights of residence of domiciled Asiatics and those of their wives and children are very seriously threatened, and the movement of educated Asiatics as between Natal and the Cape as also the Transvaal on the one hand and the Cape and Natal on the other, is to be considerably restricted by the new Bill.
('12', 152, 2, 9, 328747) So that not a single section of the Asiatic community has been left untouched.
('12', 152, 2, 10, 328826) Moreover Natal and the Cape have a special grievance in that educated Indians of the status of clerks and assistants will be practically prohibited immigrants under the arbitrary education test now proposed.
('12', 152, 2, 11, 329034) The remarks 4 of The Star in its leading article of the
('12', 152, 3, 12, 329090) 1 Vide 4th footnote of “The New Immigration Bill”, 3 2 1912 and “Resolu tions at Meeting of Cape British Indian Union”, 4 2 1912. 2 Ibid 3 General Botha, who was visiting England in connection with the Imperial Conference, made a Press statement in London on May 23, 1911, expressing gratification over the Provisional settlement of May 20. Reuter further reported that “he was sure that the Indians would do their part to help the Government to make things as pleasant as possible for them.
('12', 152, 3, 13, 329582) They could be fully assured that the Government entertained no hostility towards them, but must always remember that the Government was determined not to admit more, except as provided in the agreement.
('12', 152, 3, 14, 329785) He hoped that the Indians both in Africa and in India would realize that Mr. Smuts had great difficulty in obtaining the concessions he had already made.” 4 The Star, commending the education test prescribed under the Transvaal Immigrants’ Restriction Act of 1907 (which judged the ability of a would be immigrant to write and sign, in any European language, an application for permission to enter the Colony) condemned the Bill as going “beyond the bounds of either equity or expediency” and said that the education test prescribed under it gave “the most arbitrary power” to Government officials.
('12', 152, 3, 15, 330384) That there was a Board of Appeal
('12', 153, 0, 1, 330417) 154 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 153, 1, 2, 330459) 31st ultimo on this portion of the Bill are very apposite.
('12', 153, 1, 3, 330518) Let us hope that the timely protest of the Natal Indian Congress and the British Indian Union will receive a sympathetic hearing from the Govern ment, and an ugly situation that must otherwise inevitably arise be avoided.
('12', 153, 2, 4, 330740) Indian Opinion, 10 2 1912
('12', 153, 3, 5, 330766) 123. FIRST INSTALMENT OF FAMINE RELIEF FUND 1
('12', 153, 4, 6, 330812) We have sent Dr. Pranjivandas Mehta a cheque for £100, being our first instalment towards the Famine Relief Fund.
('12', 153, 4, 7, 330926) Any suggestions by contributors have also been forwarded to Dr. Mehta.
('12', 153, 4, 8, 330997) Dr. Mehta is not unknown among the Indians here.
('12', 153, 4, 9, 331046) His intention is to visit the famine areas and have his own contribution expended on the spot.
('12', 153, 4, 10, 331141) We feel, therefore, it is only through him that the best use can be made of the collections.
('12', 153, 4, 11, 331234) 2 Equally, the instructions which we have received or may receive in future about the disbursement of the money received for specific purposes or in specific areas can be best implemented through him.
('12', 153, 4, 12, 331435) This would also seem to be the right occasion to clarify some points which have been raised about the famine fund that is being collected.
('12', 153, 4, 13, 331574) To contribute to this fund we have started and to entrust us with its utilization as has been done is one method.
('12', 153, 4, 14, 331688) We have also received some instructions for disbursements independently of the Indian Opinion fund; to have the money thus sent through us is another method.
('12', 153, 4, 15, 331846) Those who intend to send money anywhere on their own may do so.
('12', 153, 4, 16, 331910) Our only aim must be to see that those who realize the seriousness of the famine do send help to the home country.
('12', 153, 4, 17, 332025) There can be no question of anyone taking special credit to himself.
('12', 153, 5, 18, 332094) was of no use for the reversal of the decision of an “arbitrary officer—possibly with anti Semitic tendencies”, after many days, would be no recompense for the loss of money and the inconvenience caused.
('12', 153, 5, 19, 332298) There was no provision in the Bill that the language selected by the immigration officials would be one of those commonly spoken in the immigrant’s country or among his race.
('12', 153, 5, 20, 332473) This, said The Star, was “Hertzogism run riot” and enabled “a satellite Minister of Justice to exclude an Englishman because he cannot pass a fifty words’ test in the Taal”.
('12', 153, 5, 21, 332647) Indian Opinion, 10 2 1912. 1 Vide “Famine in India”, 11 11 1911 & 9 12 1911. 2 The subject of the famine figured often in Gandhiji’s letters to Dr. Mehta; vide 24 9 1911, 10 10 1911 & 11 11 1911.
('12', 154, 0, 1, 332843) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 155
('12', 154, 1, 2, 332884) We know that ours is a modest fund.
('12', 154, 1, 3, 332920) The leaders [of the community] may, if they are prepared to assume the responsibility, undertake collection on a larger scale; it would do them credit if they did so.
('12', 154, 1, 4, 333087) If no collection on any large scale is to be undertaken, we believe every Indian ought to give his mite to our fund.

('12', 154, 4, 7, 333246) 124. LETTER TO E. F. C. LANE
('12', 154, 5, 8, 333275) February 15, 1912
('12', 154, 6, 9, 333293) DEAR MR. LANE,
('12', 154, 7, 10, 333308) I am still awaiting the promised reply 1 in connection with the Immigration Bill.

('12', 156, 3, 5, 337198) [ENCLOSURE]
('12', 156, 4, 6, 337210) STATEMENT FOR COUNSEL’S OPINION Counsel’s opinion is requested on the following points arising out of the Immigration Bill now before the Union Parliament: 1. Section 5, 1 sub sections (f) and (g) exempt from the prohibition clause wives and minor children of lawful immigrants and domiciled residents, as also domiciled persons themselves, who satisfy an Immigration Officer as to their rights whether as wives and children or as domiciled residents.
('12', 156, 4, 7, 337662) Does this Clause remove the ordinary jurisdiction of the courts of law?
('12', 156, 4, 8, 337734) And, if it does not, to what extent, if any, is the jurisdiction of the courts ousted [?] Will the decisions of Immigration Officers be subject to Appeal in the same manner as those of magistrates’ courts?
('12', 156, 4, 9, 337940) Is the exemption clause in any way affected by Section 7 2?
('12', 156, 4, 10, 338000) 2. Several British Indians are today in Natal or the Cape by reason of their having passed the education tests under the immigration laws of the respective Provinces.
('12', 156, 4, 11, 338167) In what way are they protected under the Bill?
('12', 156, 4, 12, 338214) Do they become both domiciled and entitled to reside in their respective Provinces by reason of their having entered them by passing the education test, or are they protected only because their rights have not been taken away specifically by the Bill?
('12', 156, 4, 13, 338466) 3. What is the position of those who entered Natal or the Cape by passing the education test, but who are at present temporarily absent from their respective Provinces?
('12', 156, 4, 14, 338635) 4. The present laws provide for the protection of the rights of those who are domiciled in the respective Provinces, but the Bill protects the rights of those only who are both domiciled and entitled to reside in the Union or any Province.
('12', 156, 5, 15, 338875) 1 Vide 4th and 5th footnotes of “Letter to E. F. C. Lane”, 29 1 1912; also Appendix “Extracts from Immigrants’ Restriction Bill (1912) and Orange Free State Constitution”, 3 2 1912. 2 Vide 6th footnote of “Letter to E. F. C. Lane”, 29 1 1912.
('12', 157, 0, 1, 339118) 158 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 157, 1, 2, 339160) What is the exact meaning of the additional, if any, restriction imposed by the clause underlined?
('12', 157, 1, 3, 339259) 5. Section 7 says that the person referred to therein may at any time be required to pass that (that is, the education) test.
('12', 157, 1, 4, 339385) Could a man who has once, after the passing of the Bill, passed the education test, be challenged again, although he may prove that he has passed the test?
('12', 157, 1, 5, 339541) Is a person who passes the test under the Bill liable to be examined again upon passing from one Province to another, although he may be in a position to prove that he has already, upon entering the Union, passed the test?
('12', 157, 1, 6, 339764) 6. Section 25 of the Bill gives the Minister discretion to issue a permit to any person who is lawfully resident in the Union desiring to absent himself therefrom.
('12', 157, 2, 7, 339928) What will be the position of those who fail to take out such permits?
('12', 157, 2, 8, 339998) Will it be enough protection for them if, rather than take out these permits, they, for instance, appear before a Notary Public, make a declaration as to their residence and then leave, and, on return, submit the declaration filed in the protocol of the Notary in proof of their right of domicile and residence?
('12', 157, 2, 9, 340310) 7. Section 28 of the Bill, sub section 2: those who enter the Free State by passing the education test are subject in all respects to the provisions of Articles 7 and 8 of Chapter 33 of the Orange Free State Constitution.

('12', 158, 1, 2, 341437) 126. THE £3 TAX 1
('12', 158, 2, 3, 341455) The judgment 2 given by a full bench of the Supreme Court, which appears in another column, would show that every Indian who has entered into a period of re indenture or contract of service under the provisions of Act 19 of 1910 is liable to pay the annual licence of £3 for the current year.
('12', 158, 2, 4, 341748) This means that all those who were induced to re indenture by reading the Government’s circular issued in April, 1910, have been cruelly deceived .3 Whatever the intention of the Act may have been, the fact remains that perhaps thousands of Indians have entered into fresh contracts of service, fully believing that they would be relieved thereby from both arrears and current payments.
('12', 158, 2, 5, 342135) Not only did the poor ignorant people believe this, but the Government departments also acted upon that interpretation.
('12', 158, 2, 6, 342255) Some months ago the Law Department seems to have issued instructions to prosecute all those who had not paid the current licence.
('12', 158, 2, 7, 342385) A test case 4
('12', 158, 3, 8, 342399) was brought before the Umlazi Court in which it was decided that, during the existence of the contract of service, payment should be
('12', 158, 4, 9, 342532) 1 Vide “The £3 Tax”, 11 11 1911. 2 On February 9, 1912, the National Division of the Supreme Court dismissed N. Mudaly’s appeal against the Lower Tugela Divison Magistrate’s decision declaring Mudaly liable to the payment of the ú3 tax.
('12', 158, 4, 10, 342769) The appellant argued that Act 19 of 1910 protected him from this payment since he had entered into a contract of service on the expiry of his indenture.
('12', 158, 4, 11, 342922) Indian Opinion, 17 2 1912. 3 In its letter of November 18, 1911, to the Secretary for Justice, the Natal Indian Congress had referred to the circular of April 1910, issued by the Protector of Immigrants in a number of Indian languages (footnote 2 on p.
('12', 158, 4, 12, 343175) 181) and claimed freedom for re indentured Indians and others who had entered into civil contracts from payment of the current licence fee.
('12', 158, 4, 13, 343315) It also proposed to agitate for the abolition of the tax altogether.
('12', 158, 4, 14, 343384) It suggested that the Government might levy a genuine revenue tax thus compensating itself for the losses.
('12', 158, 4, 15, 343491) Indian Opinion, 2 12 1911. In his reply of February 2, 1912, the Acting Secretary for the Interior asked for more information about the re indentured men who had been prosecuted for non payment of the licence fee.
('12', 158, 4, 16, 343705) 4 Vencatachale Naik was brought before the Umlazi Court some time during November, 1911, charged with the non payment of the £3 fee.
('12', 158, 4, 17, 343838) The Magistrate decided that the current licence fee should not be demanded from him—presumably because he had entered into a civil contract.
('12', 158, 4, 18, 343979) Following this some “forty to fifty summonses” which had been issued were withdrawn.
('12', 158, 4, 19, 344064) The Umlazi case was cited by the Natal Indian Congress in its letter of February 17, 1912 to the Acting Secretary for the Interior.

('12', 159, 0, 1, 344223) 160 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 159, 1, 2, 344265) suspended.
('12', 159, 1, 3, 344276) Consequently forty or fifty summonses which had been issued were withdrawn.
('12', 159, 1, 4, 344352) The Government seems to have decided to abide by that decision, for nothing further was heard of it.
('12', 159, 1, 5, 344453) Now, it appears, the Magistrate of Lower Tugela Division has given his decision to the effect that the Current licence must be paid, and the Supreme Court has upheld that decision.
('12', 159, 1, 6, 344634) This brings the matter to a head and we shall shortly see what the intention of the Government is.
('12', 159, 1, 7, 344733) If the Minister of Justice has a spark of humanity in him, he will at once instruct the Courts not to prosecute, for he knows well enough that many if not all of the people affected by the judgment have been trapped into fresh contracts of service by the inducements held out in the late Natal Government’s circular.
('12', 159, 1, 8, 345050) We understand that already the machinery of the law is being set in motion and that summonses are being issued.
('12', 159, 1, 9, 345162) There is also an element of farce about the whole business.
('12', 159, 1, 10, 345222) We happen to know that, if a free Indian who has managed to escape payment of the tax wishes to return to India, no one will prevent his going, even though he may owe arrears amounting to twenty pounds.
('12', 159, 1, 11, 345425) Yet this same Government rewards the man who has been inveigled into a contract of re indenture by making him pay ú3 per annum so long as he is willing to slave away for the benefit of planters and other employers!
('12', 159, 1, 12, 345640) Surely it does not need a very wise man to see both the absurdity and injustice of such procedure?
('12', 159, 1, 13, 345739) On the same page as the judgment will be found a letter from the Secretary for the Interior in reply to the Natal Indian Congress’s letter of November last, which was addressed to the Minister of Justice.
('12', 159, 1, 14, 345944) The Congress requested that all those who had acted upon the words of the circular should be relieved from payment, Now, after waiting three months, what is the result?
('12', 159, 1, 15, 346113) The Minister of Justice, whose depart ment was responsible for the issue of summonses against these poor Indians, ignores the request and sends the letter to the Department for the Interior which asks of the Natal Indian Congress a question which the Minister of Justice was better able to answer .
('12', 159, 1, 16, 346412) In fact, when inquiry was made at the Court from which the summonses were issued, the information was refused and the advice given to obtain such information through the Secretary for Justice!
('12', 159, 1, 17, 346605) So we have the spectacle of a great Government using its tremendous power to tyrannize over poor defenceless Indians—men and women who have given their very life blood in making Natal a
('12', 160, 0, 1, 346791) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 161
('12', 160, 1, 2, 346832) prosperous country.
('12', 160, 1, 3, 346852) It is the duty of the Natal Indian Congress to boldly defend these poor people.
('12', 160, 1, 4, 346932) Whatever reply it chooses to send to the Minister for the Interior, it must at all costs see to it that those who are helpless shall not seek in vain for succour.

('12', 162, 1, 2, 351370) 128. LETTER TO CHANCHALBEHN GANDHI
('12', 162, 2, 3, 351405) [LAWLEY, ] Maha Vad 0 [February 18, 1912] 1
('12', 162, 3, 4, 351449) CHANCHAL,
('12', 162, 4, 5, 351459) I had a letter from you after many months.
('12', 162, 4, 6, 351502) I should like you to be less lazy about writing letters.
('12', 162, 4, 7, 351559) I can very well understand your natural desire to be with Chi.
('12', 162, 4, 8, 351622) Harilal.
('12', 162, 4, 9, 351631) I do not at all wish to come in your way in this.
('12', 162, 4, 10, 351681) Live, both of you, as you wish and do what you like.
('12', 162, 4, 11, 351734) I can have but one wish: you should be happy and remain so.
('12', 162, 4, 12, 351794) Personally, I do not like your giving Kanti 2 Mellin’s Food.
('12', 162, 4, 13, 351855) I think it a sin to use any foreign goods in India, and the use of food products is all the more distasteful to me now.
('12', 162, 4, 14, 351975) I cannot help feeling that all such products are polluted.
('12', 162, 4, 15, 352034) Even when they do not contain animal fat, alcohol, etc., I have noticed that they are not entirely free from contamination by them, since foreigners do not object to the use of these.
('12', 162, 4, 16, 352218) We should know that our children grew well enough in the olden days without these foreign foods; hence my advice is that we too should do without them.
('12', 162, 4, 17, 352370) Wheat, well roasted, ground fine and mixed with a little gur and water will serve the same purpose as Mellin’s Food.
('12', 162, 4, 18, 352487) We can prepare a number of things to replace it.
('12', 162, 4, 19, 352536) It is easy to see that your presence there and that of Rami and Kanti must be a great comfort to Chhabalbhabhi 3. Personally I don’t se how Ba or I can get away from here just now.
('12', 162, 4, 20, 352717) Manilal is here at present.
('12', 162, 4, 21, 352745) He will leave in the middle of Phagan 4. Jamnadas, too, is here.
('12', 162, 4, 22, 352810) I am busy at present with the affairs of the school.
('12', 162, 4, 23, 352863) There are 25 pupils, eight of them Muslims, two Parsis and the rest Hindus.
('12', 162, 4, 24, 352939) Among the last, five are from Madras and one from Calcutta, and the rest are Gujaratis.
('12', 162, 4, 25, 353027) Jamnadas and others help with the reaching.

('12', 164, 2, 3, 354677) February 20, 1912
('12', 164, 3, 4, 354695) DEAR MR. GREGOROWSKI,
('12', 164, 4, 5, 354717) I thank you for your letter.
('12', 164, 4, 6, 354746) I shall await your opinion with very considerable interest.
('12', 164, 4, 7, 354806) I quite agree that the draft is an awful humbug, and one of the ways I can fight it successfully is to get your valuable opinion.
('12', 164, 4, 8, 354936) It would not do for me to use your last year’s opinion 1, as there are some new points at least in the present Bill, and as I have to use your opinion both here and in London in support of the contentions I have already advance, in so far, of course, as your views are in agreement with mine.
('12', 164, 4, 9, 355229) I, therefore, hope that you will give me your opinion on all the points I have raised without referring to last year’s opinion, except in so far as you may use it for comparing the present Bill with last year’s draft 2.
('12', 164, 6, 10, 355449) Yours sincerely,

('12', 166, 7, 12, 358432) 133. MISREPRESENTATION
('12', 166, 8, 13, 358455) We publish in another column the reply of the Colonial Office to the representation made by Lord Ampthill’s Committee in the Nathalia case 3. Mr. Harcourt has been given to understand that the new Bill now before the Union Parliament will prevent “a recurrence of such a case”.
('12', 166, 8, 14, 358733) Mr. Harcourt, therefore, declines to take any action in the matter.
('12', 166, 8, 15, 358801) Mr. Harcourt’s statement that the new Bill will preclude a recurrence of such a case proves the hardship of the case.
('12', 166, 9, 16, 358919) 1 The reference is to Section 25(2).
('12', 166, 9, 17, 358956) 2 The reference is to Section 28. 3 For details of the case, vide “A Shocking Case”, 23 9 1911, “A Shameful Act”, 30 12 1911 and 4th footnote of “Letter to E. F. C. Lane”, 15 2 1912. The SABI Committee, London, wrote to the Colonial Office on January 19, 1912, regarding the inability of the Natal Courts to interfere in Nathalia’s case.
('12', 166, 9, 18, 359294) The Colonial Office reply, dated February 5, 1912, said: “Mr. Harcourt understands that the recurrence of such a case is precluded by the terms of the Immigration Bill now before the Union Parliament and he does not propose to take any action in the matter.” Indian Opinion, 9 3 1912.
('12', 167, 0, 1, 359579) 168 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 167, 1, 2, 359621) obviously based his letter on information given to him by the Union Ministers.
('12', 167, 1, 3, 359700) Now, everybody who knows anything of the new Bill knows that, in its present form, it does nothing of the kind.
('12', 167, 1, 4, 359812) It simply exaggerates the existing evil.
('12', 167, 1, 5, 359853) The Nathalia tragedy was possible because the Immigration Officer had autocratic powers.
('12', 167, 1, 6, 359942) These are further increased by the new Bill.
('12', 167, 1, 7, 359987) If in cases such as this, wherein misrepresentation can be easily exposed, the Union Government do not hesitate to misrepresent matters to the Imperial Government, who can tell what misrepresentations they have made in matters which will never see the light of day?
('12', 167, 1, 8, 360253) Mr. Harcourt’s refusal to intervene in the individual case of the boy Nathalia is not easy to understand.
('12', 167, 1, 9, 360359) The injustice is admitted.
('12', 167, 1, 10, 360386) Surely he could, therefore, ask the Union Government, we shall not say, to exercise mercy, but to undo the mischief done by their own officers.
('12', 167, 1, 11, 360530) Nathalia’s sacrifice on the altar of an anti Asiatic policy will rankle in the breast of every Indian in South Africa.
('12', 167, 1, 12, 360649) If we cannot act more decisively it does not show that we feel the injustice any the less for it; we simply betray our weakness.
('12', 167, 1, 13, 360778) But neither the Imperial Government nor the Union Government dare trade upon our weakness with impunity.
('12', 167, 1, 14, 360883) A community that has once wielded the weapon of passive resistance may be relied upon to do so again on due occasion.

('12', 167, 3, 16, 361026) 134. MRS.
('12', 167, 3, 17, 361036) JUSSAT’S CASE
('12', 167, 4, 18, 361050) If Mrs. Jussat is deported, 1 the Transvaal British Indian Association, the Hamidia Islamic Society and, to some extent, all the Indians in South Africa will lose face.
('12', 167, 5, 19, 361219) 1 Ebrahim Mahomed Jussat, a registered Transvaal resident, had two wives, Rasool in Standerton and Fatima in India.
('12', 167, 5, 20, 361335) When Rasool left him, he wanted to bring Fatima to South Africa.
('12', 167, 5, 21, 361400) The Barberton Magistrate disallowed Fatima’s claim to entry on the ground that, since Rasool had already acquired domicile as Jussat’s wife, his first wife could not also claim entry.
('12', 167, 5, 22, 361584) Fatima’s appeal to the Transvaal Bench of the Supreme Court was dismissed on February 13, 1912, by Justice Wessels who, in his judgment, referred to his earlier ruling in Adam Ismail’s case (footnote 1 on p.
('12', 167, 5, 23, 361792) 120 and “Johannesburg”, pp.
('12', 167, 5, 24, 361820) 122 3) that a Muslim could bring in only one wife and this, in Jussat’s case, was Rasool whom he had not divorced.
('12', 167, 5, 25, 361935) Indian Opinion, 24 2 1912.
('12', 168, 0, 1, 361962) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 169
('12', 168, 1, 2, 362003) The Government’s reply 1 to Mr. Cachalia is entirely unsatis factory.
('12', 168, 1, 3, 362073) It only goes to prove that no assurance by the Government can be relied on.
('12', 168, 1, 4, 362149) The law is the last word.
('12', 168, 1, 5, 362175) General Smuts had clearly said that, notwithstanding Justice Wessels’ judgment, he would grant relief in cases of hardship.
('12', 168, 1, 6, 362299) 2 The community can only interpret this to mean that, whenever anyone can establish that he has contracted a second marriage in conformity with the law of his religion and wants to bring in his second wife, he should not be prevented from doing so.
('12', 168, 1, 7, 362548) General Smuts writes that there are no extraordinary facts about this case [which would warrant interference by the Government].
('12', 168, 1, 8, 362677) What extraordinary facts does he require?
('12', 168, 1, 9, 362719) It is a fact important enough for us that Mrs. Jussat is a legally married wife of Mr. Jussat.
('12', 168, 1, 10, 362814) What does Mr. Jussat propose to do?
('12', 168, 1, 11, 362850) Will he let his wife be deported and himself stay on in the Transvaal, without a word of protest, for the sake of his wretched belly?
('12', 168, 1, 12, 362984) What do his friends propose to do?
('12', 168, 1, 13, 363019) Will they look on, bangles on wrists, 3 while the police deport Mrs. Jussat, in this awful manner, for no fault of hers?
('12', 168, 1, 14, 363140) What does the Association propose to do?
('12', 168, 1, 15, 363181) Does its duty end with sending telegrams and letters?
('12', 168, 1, 16, 363235) Does the Hamidia Islamic Society intend to sit still?
('12', 168, 1, 17, 363289) Will not its office bearers realize that Islam is being insulted?
('12', 168, 1, 18, 363355) The issue is not whether Mr. Jussat is poor or rich, good or bad.
('12', 168, 1, 19, 363421) He brought his wife in and the Government has made ready to push her out.
('12', 168, 1, 20, 363495) That is [tantamount to] pushing us all out.
('12', 168, 1, 21, 363539) Let not Natal or the Cape feel that they do not have a similar law in those Provinces We hope that Mrs. Jussat is a brave woman and that, if deported,

('12', 171, 3, 13, 369028) 138. MR. RUTHNUM PATHER
('12', 171, 4, 14, 369052) The appearance in our midst of another young Natal born Indian barrister, fresh from his successful career as a student in England, 2 is an indication that the rising generation of Indians are a force to be reckoned with.
('12', 171, 4, 15, 369274) Mr. Ruthnum Pather, who was born and brought up in Durban and attended the Higher Grade Indian School, said, at the reception given in his honour, that he looked forward with pride to the prospect of sharing the community’s sufferings, prosperity and happiness.
('12', 171, 4, 16, 369536) The first of these he will certainly have a full opportunity of sharing; the second depends on what he considers to be prosperity; and the last is an illusive phantom which, if pursued, is never gained, but is rather found in duty faithfully done.
('12', 171, 4, 17, 369784) Mr. Pather rightly boasts of the ancient civilization of India; and it is well if he keeps this before his mind, for, although we do not wish to disparage

('12', 175, 1, 2, 375375) passive resister, I have just finished the account, of which I give you herewith a full summary 1. You will see, on the expenditure side, “Farm Capital Account”.
('12', 175, 1, 3, 375537) This represents the expense of erecting dwellings on Mr. Kallenbach’s farm 2. The bulk, if not the whole, of it is returnable by Mr. Kallen bach, in terms of the grant of the use of his farm to passive resisters, on its being vacated.
('12', 175, 1, 4, 375772) The item for Indian Opinion has been explained in the previous account rendered in my public letter 3 to the hon’ble Mr. Gokhale.
('12', 175, 1, 5, 375902) The item “Relief” includes all disbursements made to indigent families of passive resisters and all other help given to them or to their families.
('12', 175, 1, 6, 376049) All the other items speak for themselves.
('12', 175, 1, 7, 376091) As to the receipt column, all I need remark upon is that the funds received from Rangoon and London were entirely earmarked for relief purposes, and certain items from India were so earmarked by Mr. Petit.
('12', 175, 1, 8, 376297) All these instructions have been strictly followed.
('12', 175, 1, 9, 376349) There are some items in the receipt column included under the heading “Local” which are not, strictly speaking, contributions, but which are either refunds or receipts for disbursements specially made.
('12', 175, 1, 10, 376551) It also includes boarding expenses paid by the parents of the boys attending the farm school.
('12', 175, 1, 11, 376645) But for the willing assistance rendered free of charge by many a volunteer, the timely assistance of Mr. Kallenbach, and, above all, the readiness with which passive resisters’ families fell in with the idea of going to the farm, the expenses would have been much greater.
('12', 175, 1, 12, 376918) Before quitting this subject of accounts, I would like to add also that the expenditure shown in the account takes no note of hundreds of pounds raised locally and disbursed by local committees, nor of private collections of which our countrymen will probably never know anything.
('12', 175, 1, 13, 377199) The financial sacrifice made by the community during the struggle which has extended over a period of four years has been very considerable, and it has been my agreeable experience to notice that those who have continuously gone to gaol for the sake of their and their country’s honour have been also the men who have cheerfully spent most in aid of the struggle.
('12', 175, 1, 14, 377563) You will observe that there is already a deficit, and I am obliged to fall back upon such resources as are available to me to meet it.
('12', 175, 1, 15, 377698) It commenced nearly three months ago.

('12', 176, 1, 4, 378117) Most of the passive resisters’ families have withdrawn from the farm, and their husbands or bread winners have found for themselves means of earning a livelihood, but they all understand that, in the event of a revival of the struggle, they are to return to the farm.
('12', 176, 1, 5, 378385) Though the Union Parliament is still sitting, and the Immi gration Bill, designed to give effect to the terms set forth in the corres pondence 1 that passed last year between General Smuts and myself, has been read a first time, it is difficult to say whether the struggle will be entirely closed this year.
('12', 176, 1, 6, 378693) The Bill itself is open also to certain objections from the passive resistance standpoint, as it is also from a general standpoint.
('12', 176, 1, 7, 378825) 2 In my opinion, it does not entirely carry out the agreement 3, but I have great hope that, so far as objections in terms of the agreement are concerned, the Bill will be amended.
('12', 176, 1, 8, 379006) If it is not in any vital particular, the struggle will most assuredly be revived.
('12', 176, 1, 9, 379089) But there is also some ground for the fear that the Bill may not be passed during the current session at all, in which case the farm will, in all pro bability, have to be continued.
('12', 176, 1, 10, 379271) As you know, the struggle has centred round the racial bar in the Transvaal immigration legislation, and we have consistently opposed it from the very commencement.
('12', 176, 1, 11, 379436) So long as the Transvaal persists in treating Asiatics as prohibited immigrants because they are Asiatics, so long will the struggle continue.
('12', 176, 1, 12, 379579) Once that bar is removed, and details into which I need not go, are settled in accordance with the written undertaking, passive resisters will have achieved their purpose.
('12', 176, 1, 13, 379751) How many and who will actually be able to enter the Transvaal or the Union, as the case may be, is a matter on which passive resisters, as such, have not laid any stress.
('12', 176, 1, 14, 379922) The number of entrants and the, manner of entry will largely depend upon the general behaviour of the community here and the demand made by India.

('12', 177, 0, 1, 380523) 178 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 177, 1, 2, 380565) establishment of a school at the farm, which is being conducted by me, assisted until recently by Messrs Medh and Desai, two staunch passive resisters, and assisted at present by a cousin 1 of mine.
('12', 177, 1, 3, 380764) The pupils number twenty five, and the desire is not to admit more than fifty.
('12', 177, 1, 4, 380843) No day scholars are accepted, and all must remain on the farm.
('12', 177, 1, 5, 380906) The parents of most of the boys pay £1.10s.
('12', 177, 1, 6, 380950) per month for their sons’ board.
('12', 177, 1, 7, 380983) The amounts so received are credited in the passive resistance account.
('12', 177, 1, 8, 381055) No school fees are charged.
('12', 177, 1, 9, 381083) Manual training is combined with mental but the greatest stress is laid on character building.
('12', 177, 1, 10, 381178) No corporal punishment is inflicted, but every endeavour is made to draw out the best that is in the boys by an appeal to their hearts and their reason.
('12', 177, 1, 11, 381331) They are allowed to take the greatest freedom with their teachers.
('12', 177, 1, 12, 381398) Indeed, the establishment is not a school but a family, of which all the pupils are persuaded, by example and precept, to consider themselves a part.
('12', 177, 1, 13, 381548) For three hours in the morning, the boys perform some kind of manual labour, preferably agricultural, of the simplest type.
('12', 177, 1, 14, 381672) They do their own washing, and are taught to be perfectly self reliant in everything.
('12', 177, 1, 15, 381758) There is, too, attached to the school a sandal making class, as also a sewing class, the latter under the supervision of Mrs. Vogl, who so successfully organized the Indian Bazaar 2, held under the auspices of the Indian Women’s Association last year.
('12', 177, 1, 16, 382010) I need hardly mention that Mrs. Vogl’s work is a labour of love.
('12', 177, 1, 17, 382075) No paid servants are kept on the farm in connection either with the school or the kitchen.
('12', 177, 1, 18, 382166) Mrs. Gandhi and Mrs. Sodha, assisted by two or three of the pupils, who are changed every week, attend to the whole of the cooking.
('12', 177, 1, 19, 382298) Non smoking, non drinking and vegetarianism are obligatory on the farm.
('12', 177, 1, 20, 382370) Mental training is given for three and a half hours at least, consisting of the vernaculars of the respective scholars, English, Arithmetic, and so much of history and geography as may arise from the lessons in English or in the vernacular.
('12', 177, 1, 21, 382611) The medium of instruction is chiefly the vernaculars, which are Gujarati, Hindi and Tamil.
('12', 177, 1, 22, 382702) The Tamil tuition, I am sorry to say, is of a very elementary character, there being no good Tamil teacher available.
('12', 177, 1, 23, 382820) One hour in the evening is devoted to giving the scholars some idea of their respective religions, and, to that end,
('12', 177, 2, 24, 382937) 1 This was Jamnadas Gandhi who possibly taught Gujarati.
('12', 177, 2, 25, 382994) After the departure of Medh and Desai on March 21, 1912, Gandhiji got Jamnadas over to help him with the school; vide “Letter to Chanchalbehn Gandhi”, 18 2 1912 and “Letter to Manilal Gandhi”, 6 4 1912. 2 Vide “Address to Mrs. Vogl”, 15 11 1911.
('12', 178, 0, 1, 383240) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 179
('12', 178, 1, 2, 383281) lessons are read from the Mahomedan, Hindu and Zoroastrian Scriptures.
('12', 178, 1, 3, 383352) Readings from the last have been recently suspended, as two Parsee lads who were at the school have just left it.
('12', 178, 1, 4, 383466) The classification according to religion to the date of writing this is sixteen Hindus and nine Mahomedans, and the classification according to race is eighteen Gujaratis, six Tamils and one from North India.
('12', 178, 1, 5, 383675) All the boys attend throughout the hour when the respective readings are given.
('12', 178, 1, 6, 383755) An attempt is made to inculcate in them the spirit that they are first Indians and everything else after that, and that, while they must remain absolutely true to their own faiths, they should regard with equal respect those of their fellow pupils.
('12', 178, 1, 7, 384004) The life on the farm is reduced to the utmost simplicity.
('12', 178, 1, 8, 384062) The school is in the nature of an experiment.
('12', 178, 1, 9, 384108) Though therefore, it may be too sanguine to expect the boys to remain, when they grow up, agriculturists and simple livers, it may not be too much to hope that they will carry into their daily dealings, when they enter upon the battle of life, some of the lessons they are now learning.
('12', 178, 1, 10, 384395) The question will be asked how the school is to be continued.
('12', 178, 1, 11, 384457) It is my desire, so long as I am in South Africa, to continue to devote myself to this work, and not to revert to legal practice, which has been entirely suspended for some time.
('12', 178, 1, 12, 384636) 1 I should still take my share in what may be called purely political work, which here really is that of making a desperate attempt to earn one’s livelihood with honour and dignity.

('12', 180, 4, 7, 386680) 145. LOCATIONS AND DISEASE
('12', 180, 5, 8, 386707) In his evidence before the Tuberculosis Commission the other day Dr. Thornton, Medical Officer of Health for the Cape Province, is reported to have said: “Municipal Locations were very bad.
('12', 180, 5, 9, 386897) With some exceptions, the huts rarely passed any kind of inspection, and very few municipalities gave anything in return for the revenue from the Locations.” Other evidence given before the Commission goes to prove that the “civilizing” policy of the more “enlightened” nations has meant death and destruction to the Native people of this country.
('12', 180, 5, 10, 387245) Before the adoption by them of European habits and customs, tuberculosis was practically unknown amongst the Natives.
('12', 180, 5, 11, 387363) One mission station is specially mentioned as being comparatively immune from the disease, owing to the conditions of life approximating to those in the Native Kraal.
('12', 180, 5, 12, 387530) All this is a serious indictment of the system under which a simple living, pastoral people is brought from its natural surroundingsinto the crowded and unhealthy conditions prevailing in towns and Locations.
('12', 180, 5, 13, 387739) It shows, so far as the health of the people in concerned, that they suffer severely for the doubtful privilege of becoming acquainted with modern life.
('12', 180, 5, 14, 387892) We will not for the moment discuss the wider and much more important question of morals, except to say that we believe that the effect upon the people of congregating in crowded areas is the worst possible.
('12', 180, 5, 15, 388099) Anyone who has visited a Location, whether Native or Indian, must be impressed with the utter hopelessness of such places.
('12', 180, 5, 16, 388222) The shameful neglect of the roadways, the utter absence of proper drainage, and the wretched condition of the buildings, all show at once
('12', 180, 6, 17, 388360) 1 The Minister replied telegraphically on April 9: “.
('12', 180, 6, 18, 388414) no intention of abandoning Immigration Bill” (S. N. 5644), confirming the, same by a letter dated April 9; S. N. 5645.
('12', 181, 0, 1, 388533) 182 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 181, 1, 2, 388575) that his is a Location—a place where Coloured people are condemned to spend their days as outcasts.
('12', 181, 1, 3, 388675) It is whispered that it is “dangerous” to go there alone at night; avoid it as you would a plague spot.
('12', 181, 1, 4, 388779) The dust carts and scavengers of the municipality give it a wide berth and share in the general antipathy towards such unholy places.
('12', 181, 1, 5, 388913) Rents and rates are regularly collected, but the money goes into the coffers of the municipality.
('12', 181, 1, 6, 389011) If a new Location is to be laid out, it is considered economical to utilize ground recently used as a dumping ground for night soil and dead horses.
('12', 181, 1, 7, 389160) Is there any wonder that Locations are hotbeds of tuberculosis and other dangerous diseases?
('12', 181, 1, 8, 389253) We understand that the Johannesburg Town Council had decided to “tackle” the question of Native Location, and that they are going to make a “big effort” to solve the question of housing the Natives.
('12', 181, 1, 9, 389452) This is how they propose to do it: All the people who are at present living where they please are to be rounded up into a huge compound, where they will be compelled to live, whether they like it or not.
('12', 181, 1, 10, 389656) A fence is to be erected around the Location, and the “inmates” (suggestive term) are to enter through the gateway, which will be under police guard.
('12', 181, 1, 11, 389806) At a certain hour the gates will be closed, and opened again in time to allow the Natives to get to work for their European masters.
('12', 181, 1, 12, 389939) A well known Johannesburg citizen gave it as his opinion that the scheme would be a great success, not only from a public health point of view, but also from a police point of view.
('12', 181, 1, 13, 390121) Now, as for the public health point of view, we are quite certain that the public referred to is the white public and not the public which is to receive the special advantage of living in this municipal compound ; and we think that Dr. Thornton will agree with us.
('12', 181, 1, 14, 390386) And what, pray, is the “police point of view”?
('12', 181, 1, 15, 390433) We think we can guess, but, as there can be no certainty about it, we will content ourselves by merely suggesting that, by segregating all the blacks, it will then be an easy matter to keep a watchful eye upon the white criminal class which is known to congregate in the cities.
('12', 181, 1, 16, 390712) But to return to our main point, we would ask all fair minded and far seeing people not to ignore the warning contained in the evidence given before the Tuberculosis Commission that to increase Locations is to multiply disease and death.
('12', 181, 2, 17, 390950) Indian Opinion, 6 4 1912

('12', 182, 1, 2, 391016) 146. LETTER TO MANILAL GANDHI
('12', 182, 2, 3, 391046) [LAWLEY] Chaitra Vad 5 [April 6, 1912] 1
('12', 182, 3, 4, 391087) MANILAL,
('12', 182, 4, 5, 391096) I have your letter.
('12', 182, 4, 6, 391116) I do not mind your writing to me about Virji 2
('12', 182, 5, 7, 391163) and Sam.
('12', 182, 5, 8, 391172) Of course you do right to let me know whenever you notice shortcomings.
('12', 182, 5, 9, 391244) Personally, however, I would rather you noted people’s virtues than their faults.
('12', 182, 5, 10, 391326) The latter, all of us are full of, so that we would do well to find out people’s virtues and think of only these.
('12', 182, 5, 11, 391440) It is possible to form this habit.
('12', 182, 5, 12, 391475) So long, however, as you have not succeeded in doing so, do not hesitate to tell me of whatever faults you see [in people].
('12', 182, 5, 13, 391599) If things are what you represent them to be, I too feel that they are both wasting their time.
('12', 182, 5, 14, 391694) About the press, too, your criticism may be justified.
('12', 182, 5, 15, 391749) But turn your mind to the counsel in the Gita: “What is apariharya—that for which one has no remedy—one must resign oneself to.” If you do your duty, you will feel contented.
('12', 182, 5, 16, 391924) The world will go its ways in spite of our having done our duty.
('12', 182, 5, 17, 391989) How can we prevent that?
('12', 182, 5, 18, 392014) Even to think that we can would be conceit.
('12', 182, 5, 19, 392058) I have with me what your Carlyle says on this.
('12', 182, 5, 20, 392105) Only recently I read in it some profound observations, which I shall reproduce for your benefit some other time.
('12', 182, 5, 21, 392218) Mr. West and others are coming here.
('12', 182, 5, 22, 392255) This may possibly make you feel a little more nervous still.
('12', 182, 5, 23, 392316) But you should not be afraid.
('12', 182, 5, 24, 392346) Mr. West’s coming here is all to the good.
('12', 182, 5, 25, 392389) It was necessary for him to meet me.
('12', 182, 5, 26, 392426) Do not let anything disturb your studies.
('12', 182, 5, 27, 392468) On Monday, we have sports for the children.
('12', 182, 5, 28, 392512) We got the parents to donate prizes.
('12', 182, 5, 29, 392549) Fifty other people will also attend.
('12', 182, 5, 30, 392586) I wish you were here on an occasion like this.

('12', 182, 6, 32, 392865) The only year in which Gandhiji spent the months of April and May on Tolstoy Farm was 1912. Furthermore West, referred to in paragraph 3, arrived at Tolstoy Farm on April 10, 1912 and stayed up to May 7, 1912 recuperating from an illness.

('12', 183, 6, 8, 393617) I have just seen a newspaper cutting containing a letter from the Acting Secretary for the Interior addressed to the Secretary of the Chamber of Commerce, in which the following passage occurs:
('12', 183, 7, 9, 393811) The object of the draft Bill is not to use the dictation test as a means of permitting the entry of Asiatics into the O.F.S., but to use it to exclude them, so that, under the provisions of the draft Bill, the territory of the Free State will be actually better protected against the entry of Asiatics than it is under the provisions of Chapter 33 of the Free State Law Book.

('12', 184, 1, 2, 395259) 148. LETTER TO MANILAL GANDHI
('12', 184, 2, 3, 395289) [LAWLEY, ] Chaitra Vad 11 [April 13, 1912] 1
('12', 184, 3, 4, 395334) MANILAL,
('12', 184, 4, 5, 395343) Your letter.
('12', 184, 4, 6, 395356) Since Mrs. Pywell 2 and others took all that trouble over you, it is not surprising that you should have been so deeply moved.
('12', 184, 4, 7, 395483) Your undisciplined ways have been causing me much concern.
('12', 184, 4, 8, 395542) I should like you to make every effort to submit yourself to discipline.
('12', 184, 4, 9, 395615) I saw your photograph.
('12', 184, 4, 10, 395638) Your out and out English dress is not of a kind to please me.
('12', 184, 4, 11, 395700) Even the collar starched?

('12', 187, 4, 11, 401406) 151. LETTER TO “SPORTING STAR”
('12', 187, 5, 12, 401437) [THE EDITOR SPORTING STAR JOHANNESBURG
('12', 187, 6, 13, 401476) SIR,] You have been good enough to invite my opinion on the suggestion made by “Recorder” in your issue of the 20th instant as to some provision being made for the admission of Asiatics to the Wanderers Ground.
('12', 187, 6, 14, 401687) I offer my opinion not without some hesitation, for I feel that Recorder’s suggestion is not practicable, to say the least of it.
('12', 187, 6, 15, 401817) I recognize the purity of his motives, but, if I may venture to deal with his suggestion on its merits, I must say that the proposed division between higher and lower class Asiatics is, or should be, totally unacceptable, if only because it is impossible to make such distinctions in matters such as those to which “Recorder” refers.
('12', 187, 6, 16, 402151) I hardly think that it is character or education that counts in determining the question of admission to a sporting ground.
('12', 187, 6, 17, 402275) I should not suppose that any such distinction is made in respect of Europeans.
('12', 187, 6, 18, 402355) All that can be reasonably expected is that those who apply for admission be suitably and cleanly dressed.
('12', 187, 6, 19, 402462) Nor will the suggestion that a portion of certain stands be set aside for Asiatics meet with general favour.
('12', 187, 6, 20, 402571) It is one thing to put us on our honour, and expect us to occupy certain parts only; it is quite another to say that we may go to certain parts, and to no other.
('12', 187, 6, 21, 402733) I am not blind to the unfortunate prejudice that exists in South Africa against Asiatics and Coloured
('12', 188, 0, 1, 402835) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 189
('12', 188, 1, 2, 402876) people.
('12', 188, 1, 3, 402884) But I do feel that, as long as that preju dice is allowed to influence the deliberations of a Sporting Committee, so long it is better that we do not have any right of entry at all, than that such right should be recognized in a limited and niggardly spirit.

('12', 188, 3, 5, 403181) 152. WHAT IS A WIFE?
('12', 188, 4, 6, 403202) Mr. Jordan 1, the Johannesburg Magistrate, has presented us with a clear cut issue.
('12', 188, 4, 7, 403286) In the case of an Indian wife who entered the Transvaal together with her husband, he has decided that she is a prohibited immigrant, as her marriage cannot be recognized by the Courts of South Africa by reason of her husband having married more than one wife.
('12', 188, 4, 8, 403547) 2 Mr. Jordan has gone further than Sir John Wessels.
('12', 188, 4, 9, 403600) The latter left us in a state of suspense.
('12', 188, 4, 10, 403643) Under the learned Judge’s decision in Mrs. Jussat’s case 3, it was just possible that one wife of a Mahomedan who had married more than one wife could come.
('12', 188, 4, 11, 403800) But Mr. Jordan lays it down clearly that, if a man was married to more than one wife whilst the first wife was alive, all the wives become prohibited immigrants.
('12', 188, 4, 12, 403962) Indeed, we consider Mr. Jordan’s judgment to be more honest, if it is also more drastic.
('12', 188, 4, 13, 404051) If this magisterial decision is allowed to stand unchallenged, the position of Indians with more wives than one will become most precarious.
('12', 188, 4, 14, 404192) Those concerned are bound to obtain the decision of the highest tribunal of justice.
('12', 188, 4, 15, 404277) Indeed, the matter cannot even rest with the Supreme Court.
('12', 188, 4, 16, 404337) In the event of an adverse decision by that august body, the community will have to seek a clear declaration from the Imperial Government as to their attitude.
('12', 188, 4, 17, 404497) The question is one of honour, and it will have to be
('12', 188, 5, 18, 404551) 1 H. H. Jordan; a Johannesburg Magistrate, in whose Court Gandhiji was sentenced for the first time on December 28, 1907. 2 The reference is to the case of Hassin Mahomed’s wife.
('12', 188, 5, 19, 404730) Hassin Mahomed, a registered Asiatic, had married in India in 1895. In 1905, Hassin Mahomed took a second wife as sanctioned by Muslim law but later divorced her.
('12', 188, 5, 20, 404893) His first wife was prohibited entry into the Transvaal by Magistrate Jordan who disallowed her claim to enter as a domiciled Asiatic’s wife on the ground that polygamous marriages were not valid in South Africa.
('12', 188, 5, 21, 405105) He declared her a prohibited immigrant as she could not pass the education test under the Transvaal Immigrants’ Restriction Act.
('12', 188, 5, 22, 405234) Indian Opinion, 4 5 1912. 3 Vide “Mrs. Jussat’s Case”, 9 3 1912.

('12', 189, 3, 5, 405460) 153. THE JOHANNESBURG SCHOOL
('12', 189, 4, 6, 405489) So the Executive of the Provincial Council has decided not to give the Indian community a separate school for the education of Indian children.
('12', 189, 4, 7, 405633) In the absence of any valid reason why such a school should not have been sanctioned, we are constrained to ascribe the refusal to anti Asiatic prejudice on the part of the Executive.
('12', 189, 4, 8, 405817) The School Board had recommended the establishment of the school.
('12', 189, 4, 9, 405883) There was ample precedent for granting the Indian request.
('12', 189, 4, 10, 405942) The promoters had guaranteed the rent of the school and guaranteed a large attendance too.
('12', 189, 4, 11, 406033) In our opinion the fact that the Coloured schools of Johannesburg did not provide any facility for teaching the children their vernaculars was sufficient justification for granting the Indian demand.
('12', 189, 4, 12, 406233) The state could make little use of Indian youths who did not know their own vernaculars.
('12', 189, 4, 13, 406322) But we know that the self styled state does but want its Indian population, whom it regards as an evil, to be got rid of at the first opportunity.
('12', 189, 4, 14, 406469) However, we must frankly confess that we do not mind this decision—we rather welcome it; we are now put upon our mettle.
('12', 189, 4, 15, 406590) A community that jealously guards its will not allow them to be neglected because an outside body refuses to help it.
('12', 189, 4, 16, 406708) The English speaking section of the Free State population answered General Hertzog’s intention to starve the English education of their children by opening private schools or finding other facilities for educating their children in a manner they considered best.
('12', 189, 4, 17, 406971) We have no real schools of our own in Johannesburg where a good education may be given to our children.
('12', 189, 4, 18, 407075) We hold that it is the duty of the promoters not to sit still but to open the school and manage it without the help of the state.
('12', 189, 4, 19, 407205) Indeed, if a strong board of management can be formed, we feel sure that the school will better supply our wants by reason of the absence of state interference.
('12', 189, 4, 20, 407366) (At the time of going to press, we have received further corres pondence from Johannesburg which somewhat alters the case.
('12', 189, 4, 21, 407489) But we consider that our main argument still holds good.)

('12', 190, 6, 12, 408365) 155. INDIAN EDUCATION IN NATAL
('12', 190, 7, 13, 408396) “The Indian schools have made much progress during the last few years,” says the Minister of Education for the Natal Province in his Annual Report.
('12', 190, 7, 14, 408544) And that is all he has to say about the education of Indian children.
('12', 190, 7, 15, 408614) He is evidently satisfied at the present condition of affairs where considerably more than £100,000 is spent annually on the education of European children and only a paltry £6,761 on Indian education.
('12', 190, 7, 16, 408816) Anyone not aware of the position which Indians hold in South Africa would naturally ask the reason for such a wide difference between the educational facilities offered to Europeans and Indians.
('12', 190, 7, 17, 409011) The population of Indians exceeds that of Europeans.
('12', 190, 7, 18, 409064) Is it not the duty of the Government to educate its people, to whatever race

('12', 194, 1, 2, 416344) 157. LETTER TO E. F. C. LANE
('12', 194, 2, 3, 416373) LAWLEY, May 31, 1912 DEAR MR. LANE, General Smuts’ speech 1 on the second reading of the Bill leaves, I fear, the question of interprovincial migration in a somewhat unsatis factory state.
('12', 194, 2, 4, 416562) General Smuts appears to meet the objection raised on this point by lax administration rather than by amending the section as it appears in the measure now before Parliament.
('12', 194, 2, 5, 416737) As I have already remarked, this will not satisfy passive resisters.
('12', 194, 2, 6, 416806) I therefore, hope that the measure will be so amended as to leave the rights of Asiatics residing in the other provinces to enter Natal and the Cape in status quo ante.
('12', 194, 2, 7, 416975) I remain, Yours sincerely,
('12', 194, 3, 8, 417002) From a photostat of the typewritten office copy: S. N. 5654
('12', 194, 4, 9, 417062) 158. “AN UNFORTUNATE CASE”
('12', 194, 5, 10, 417089) Under the above sub heading, the following report of a case brought before Mr. J. Y. Gibson, in the First Criminal Court, Durban, appears, in the Natal Advertiser:
('12', 194, 6, 11, 417253) Jadubansi, an Indian woman, was charged with refusing to return to her lawful employer, she being an indentured servant.
('12', 194, 6, 12, 417374) The accused pleaded guilty.
('12', 194, 6, 13, 417402) It was stated that the circumstances of this case were that the woman had served continuous sentences amounting to six months, for a steadfast refusal to return to her employer.
('12', 194, 6, 14, 417580) She had been working on an estate at Stanger, and, in some accident, her baby had been burnt.
('12', 194, 6, 15, 417674) She had come to Durban to make complaint to the Protector and had since refused on every occasion to comply with her indenture.
('12', 194, 6, 16, 417802) Argument arose as to whether continual successive punishment could be awarded for the same offence, and it was pointed out by Mr. Gibson that section governing such cases provided that each successive refusal to comply with an order of the Court was separately punishable.
('12', 194, 6, 17, 418075) His Worship said that it seemed an unfortunate thing that a woman could thus be punished time after time for a matter wherein she had shown a particular aversion from some especial place of employment.
('12', 194, 6, 18, 418277) It was stated that the woman was willing
('12', 194, 7, 19, 418318) 1 Vide Appendix “Smuts’ Speech on I. R. Bill (1912) in Union Parliament”, 30 5 1912.
('12', 195, 0, 1, 418403) 196 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 195, 1, 2, 418445) to work elsewhere, if she could get a transfer, and Mr. Gibson adjourned the case for a week, Jadubansi meanwhile being sent to the Protector to see what could be arranged.
('12', 195, 1, 3, 418618) We have something to add to the above report, as we have been brought into close touch with the woman concerned who, early in April, came to Phoenix and related her story in detail.
('12', 195, 1, 4, 418800) In the first place, the woman had not been working on an estate, at Stanger, but was indentured to a farmer down the South coast whose name it is not necessary to mention for the moment.
('12', 195, 1, 5, 418987) We learn from the report that Jadubansi’s child had been burnt.
('12', 195, 1, 6, 419051) It was not only burnt, but burnt so severely that it died; and the woman accuses her employer of delibe rately refusing to attend to the wounds, after having first put on ban dages, with the result that they stank.
('12', 195, 1, 7, 419266) The woman’s duties in her master’s house kept her away from the child from 5 a.m.
('12', 195, 1, 8, 419348) to 7 p.m., with the exception of two short intervals for breakfast and dinner.
('12', 195, 1, 9, 419427) Consequently the child had to be left alone.
('12', 195, 1, 10, 419472) After a fortnight’s terrible sufferings, the child was sent to the hospital where it died a few days afterwards.
('12', 195, 1, 11, 419585) After the death of her child, Jadubansi tells of great hardships, including the refusal of her employer to give her food for three days, forcing her to grind mealies in a hand mill, ill treatmentby kicking, and the withholding of wages.
('12', 195, 1, 12, 419822) The total wages received in the course of a year, she states, was nine shillings.
('12', 195, 1, 13, 419904) We took Jadubansi to the Protector of Indian Immigrants, laid the information before him, and left her in his charge, pending inquiries into her grievances.
('12', 195, 1, 14, 420061) The matter was referred to the employer who flatly denied that he neglected the child, and accused the mother of neglect.
('12', 195, 1, 15, 420183) The doctor at the hospital reported the death of the child, but did not consider its condition to be so bad as to warrant special mention.
('12', 195, 1, 16, 420322) We have these conflicting statements and we lay them before the public for them to judge which is the more likely: that a mother, whose child gets accidentally burnt, should wilfully neglect it, and refuse to nurse it, or that the employer should seek to shield himself from the consequences of serious charge.
('12', 195, 1, 17, 420633) And what is the position of the doctors in such matters?
('12', 195, 1, 18, 420690) They are employed by the Indian Immigration Trust Board, which consists of planters and farmers, 1 and
('12', 195, 2, 19, 420793) 1 Indian Opinion editorials had more than once demanded that Indians should be represented on such boards and in the SABI Committee’s representation of June 17, 1911 to the Colonial Office, Polak had made a similar request; vide Appendix “S. A. B. I. Committee’s Letter to Colonial Office”, 17 6 1911.
('12', 196, 0, 1, 421095) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 197
('12', 196, 1, 2, 421136) one can easily imagine that the doctors are not over anxious to report cases which reflect upon employers.
('12', 196, 1, 3, 421243) So we must not place much importance on the non report of the bad condition of the child.
('12', 196, 1, 4, 421333) It is a crying scandal that these medical men are not under the control of the Government.
('12', 196, 1, 5, 421424) We are very much afraid that many a gruesome tragedy lies hidden because of this.
('12', 196, 1, 6, 421506) And what of the employer?
('12', 196, 1, 7, 421532) Jadubansi states that, in one room which is a part of stable, four Indians—two men and two women—and four Natives had to cook their food together.
('12', 196, 1, 8, 421679) Of the Indians, two were married and the others not.
('12', 196, 1, 9, 421732) But they all had to sleep in the same room.
('12', 196, 1, 10, 421776) Some months before, inspector Waller, of the Protector’s Department, visited the place and saw these conditions.
('12', 196, 1, 11, 421889) He ordered the employer to make alterations, which instructions, evidently, were not carried out.
('12', 196, 1, 12, 421987) Thus we see that the employer is not a man who is careful over the welfare of his Indians and that is putting it very mildly.
('12', 196, 1, 13, 422113) Well, to continue the story, the Protector tried to persuade the employer to transfer the woman elsewhere as it was clear that, for some reason, she did not wish to remain with him.
('12', 196, 1, 14, 422295) But the employer refused, and it seems that it was not possible for the Protector to carry his protection any further, and the officers of the law arrested Jadu bansi and she was sent to prison for desertion.
('12', 196, 1, 15, 422504) After serving a month in prison and again refusing to return to her employer, the latter seems to have given up all hope of getting her to return and so he has given his consent to her being shipped back to India where she wished to go and from whence, she alleges, she was forcibly brought against her will, a recruiting agent in India having deceived her.
('12', 196, 1, 16, 422862) If half of this woman’s story be true, it is indeed “an unfortu nate case”.
('12', 196, 1, 17, 422938) It must be considered unfortunate, too, by supporters of the indenture system, that such cases are brought to light.
('12', 196, 1, 18, 423055) Even one such case condemns the whole system, because it shows what horrible things are possible in the outlying districts.
('12', 196, 1, 19, 423179) We have to thank the Magistrate, Mr. Gibson, for having prevented the further punishment of this poor woman.
('12', 196, 2, 20, 423288) Indian Opinion, 1 6 1912
('12', 197, 0, 1, 423313) 198 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 197, 1, 2, 423355) 159. HEALTH OF INDENTURED INDIANS
('12', 197, 2, 3, 423389) The evidence of the Protector of Indian Immigrants, given before the Tuberculosis Commission, brings to mind once again the fact that, in matters of health, as in some other matters, he is powerless to protect the people under his charge.
('12', 197, 2, 4, 423628) The Protector is a Government servant, independent of the Immigration Trust Board and is therefore in a position to act independently without interference by its mem bers.
('12', 197, 2, 5, 423800) Not so the sanitary inspectors and medical officers, appointed to look after the conditions of the barracks and the health of the occupants.
('12', 197, 2, 6, 423941) They are employed by the Trust Board, and, therefore, and under the thumb of the employers.
('12', 197, 2, 7, 424033) We maintain that it is impossible for these officers to do their duty under such conditions.
('12', 197, 2, 8, 424126) In answer to questions by the Tuberculosis Commission regarding the ground surrounding some of the Indian barracks, which was in filthy condition with slop water and refuse lying about, Mr. Polkinghorne 1
('12', 197, 3, 9, 424331) said that there was a sanitary inspector who was supposed to look after these things.
('12', 197, 3, 10, 424417) Of course, we can quite understand that a sanitary inspector, at any time, is looked upon by employers as a troublesome nuisance.
('12', 197, 3, 11, 424547) His faultfindings mean increased expenses and less profits.
('12', 197, 3, 12, 424607) The consequence is, in many cases, that the much needed improvements are not even suggested by these officers because they know that it will only bring a hornet’s nest about their ears.
('12', 197, 3, 13, 424793) Naturally, they will let matters slide rather than create trouble for themselves and make their position untenable.
('12', 197, 3, 14, 424909) So far back as 1908, Protector, in his annual report, called attention to this matter.He said that, in his opinion, the high death rate among indentured Indians working in the coast districts of Natal was due in no small measure to this state of affairs, and as a kind of protest against the scandal, he asked for no reports from, the medical officers.
('12', 197, 3, 15, 425262) The Immigration Trust Board consists of seven members elected by employers of indentured Indians, with the Protector and one other member nominated by the Government.
('12', 197, 3, 16, 425429) Referring to the constitution of the Board, the protector said in his report:“In no other Colony, introducing Indian immigrants, is there any such Board of Employers, and I am strongly of opinion that such a constituted Board should not in any way have any power to deal with, or in any way influence, the
('12', 197, 4, 17, 425735) 1 J. A. Polkinghorne, Protector of Indian Immigrants, Natal
('12', 198, 0, 1, 425795) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 199
('12', 198, 1, 2, 425836) treatment of the indentured Indians in the Colony.” We quite agree with Mr. Polkinghorne, and we think that he might have brought this matter a little more forcibly to the notice of the Tuberculosis Commission.
('12', 198, 2, 3, 426047) Indian Opinion, 22 6 1912
('12', 198, 3, 4, 426073) 160. MRS.
('12', 198, 3, 5, 426083) VOGL’S BAZAAR 1
('12', 198, 4, 6, 426099) Mrs. Vogl, whose name and work our readers have now become thoroughly acquainted with, has an insatiable ambition.
('12', 198, 4, 7, 426214) As will be seen from Miss Schlesin’s letter 2 to the ladies in India, Mrs. Vogl is organizing, under the auspices of the Indian Women’s Association, another Bazaar larger scale than before.
('12', 198, 4, 8, 426404) The last Bazaar was successful, both financially and socially.
('12', 198, 4, 9, 426467) But Mrs. Vogl, thinks that the funds should be considerably augmented if the Nagappen memorial is to be worthy of the cause to which the lamented lad gave his life.
('12', 198, 4, 10, 426632) She thinks, too, that the education work of the Association will receive greater encouragement if Bazaars are held periodically.
('12', 198, 4, 11, 426761) We are sure that the ladies in India will return a liberal response to Miss Schlesin’s appeal, and we hope that those, both here and in England, who are at all interested in Indians in this subcontinent, will take note of the appeal and help the great movement inaugurated by Mrs. Vogl.
('12', 198, 5, 12, 427048) Indian Opinion, 22 6 1912
('12', 198, 6, 13, 427074) 1 Vide “Address to Mrs. Vogl”, 15 11 1911. 2 Miss Schlesin, who was the Honorary Secretary of the Transvaal Indian Women’s Association, in this letter of June 14, had requested that fancy goods and specimens of Indian hand work be sent for the Bazaar to be held towards the end of 1913. She also appealed to all willing Associations in India for help.

('12', 201, 4, 7, 431605) Owing to a shortage of funds for defraying the expenses of our Committee in England and of public work in Johannesburg, a collection has recently been started in the Transvaal.
('12', 201, 4, 8, 431782) It is Sorabji in fact, who has taken this work upon himself.
('12', 201, 4, 9, 431843) Mr. Cachalia also accom panies him sometimes.
('12', 201, 4, 10, 431889) Dulabhbhai Kalyanji, Dayal Parbhu, Manchha Gosai, G. K. Patel, Bhikhubhai Karsanji and Jeram Gosai also go out [with them].
('12', 201, 4, 11, 432013) Mr. Sodha, too, goes round for the collection.
('12', 201, 4, 12, 432060) A sum of about £350 has been collected, including £27.12s.
('12', 201, 4, 13, 432119) received from Vereeniging towards the expenses [of the SABI Committee].
('12', 201, 4, 14, 432191) Soon they will visit other towns for collection.
('12', 201, 4, 15, 432240) But the entire [burden of the] expenses of Lord Ampthill’s Committee should not devolve on the Transvaal alone.
('12', 201, 4, 16, 432352) Natal and the Cape ought to share in them.
('12', 201, 4, 17, 432395) The Committee functions in the interests of all parts of South Africa, and all the Indians should share in its expenses.

('12', 202, 1, 2, 433634) 165. SPEECH AT DURBAN FAREWELL TO PILGRIMS
('12', 202, 2, 3, 433677) [June 29, 1912]
('12', 202, 3, 4, 433693) The Ottoman Cricket Club organized a function on Saturday [June 29] night at the same place [Mr. Rustomjee’s residence].
('12', 202, 3, 5, 433814) About 200 to 300 persons were present.
('12', 202, 3, 6, 433853) Mr. Gandhi was requested to take the chair and he said: I came here to honour the Haj Pilgrims.
('12', 202, 3, 7, 433949) I had no intention of presiding over this function.
('12', 202, 3, 8, 434001) However, two of the office bearers of the Club urged me to take the chair.
('12', 202, 3, 9, 434076) I gladly complied after they had promised, in return, to join in the satyagraha movement if it were started again.
('12', 202, 3, 10, 434191) It has indeed become my sole occupation to seek out people willing to go to goal for the country’s sake.
('12', 202, 3, 11, 434296) I wish the mem bers of this club, too, would equip themselves to become satyagrahis and be ready to go to goal when the occasion arises.
('12', 202, 3, 12, 434433) Why should we fight shy of goal?
('12', 202, 3, 13, 434466) Students of the school attached to Tolstoy Farm walked to Wightrust seven miles away.
('12', 202, 3, 14, 434552) On the way, they came upon streams and bathed in them.
('12', 202, 3, 15, 434607) When they were arrested [for trespassing], they admitted to having done wrong.
('12', 202, 3, 16, 434686) On being told that they could be sent to gaol, they said that they would prefer going to gaol to being let off.
('12', 202, 3, 17, 434798) At this, the authorities responsible for arresting them released them.
('12', 202, 3, 18, 434869) The point is that, instead of being afraid of gaol, we should become courageous and learn to fight in defence of truth.
('12', 202, 3, 19, 434989) This kind of education is necessary for the Indian community.
('12', 202, 4, 20, 435051) Mr. Gandhi then expressed his heart left happiness at having been able to attend this function to bid farewell to Mr. Dawad Mahomed and other pilgrims and then commenced the business of the meeting.
('12', 202, 5, 21, 435250) In his concluding remarks as chairman, he said: I offer my hearty congratulations to Dawad Mahomed, Mahomed Coovadia 1 Dawad Seedat and Moola on their Undertakin the Haj pilgrimage.
('12', 202, 5, 22, 435432) As a Hindu I am glad of their decision to go on the pilgrimage.
('12', 202, 5, 23, 435496) A true Muslim cannot do Hindus harm.
('12', 202, 5, 24, 435533) A true Hindu cannot do harm Muslims.
('12', 202, 5, 25, 435570) Those who are capable of harming their won Indian brethren are neither true Muslims nor true Hindus.
('12', 202, 5, 26, 435671) I consider any selfless work done in the service of the community as a religious and not a worldly act.
('12', 202, 5, 27, 435775) I accordingly believe the services
('12', 202, 6, 28, 435810) 1 Mahomed Cassim Coovadia; merchant; President of the Durban Anjuman and a trustee of the West Street Mosque
('12', 203, 0, 1, 435919) 204 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 203, 1, 2, 435961) rendered by Mr. Dawad Mahomed by going to gaol 1 will be acknow ledged in the court of God.
('12', 203, 1, 3, 436053) On the other hand, I believe that and ostensibly religious act is not a godly one if not done with a pure heart.
('12', 203, 1, 4, 436166) Secondly, it is repeatedly asserted that there is no unity among Indians.
('12', 203, 1, 5, 436240) 2 But one should not believe that this is really so.
('12', 203, 1, 6, 436293) At the same time we should not shut our eyes to the disunity among us and say that there is none.
('12', 203, 1, 7, 436391) In any case it should be remembered that the cause of our sufferings in South Africa in no disunity but lack of courage.
('12', 203, 1, 8, 436512) I do not wish to say that we are wholly wanting in courage.
('12', 203, 1, 9, 436572) When the Imam Saheb came forward to court imprisonment, who could have predicted that he would be able to bear up with [life in] gaol?
('12', 203, 1, 10, 436707) His offer to go to gaol was a courageous act and it was again due to his courage that he could remain steadfast till the end.
('12', 203, 1, 11, 436833) Our chief need is to be truthful.
('12', 203, 1, 12, 436867) Our motto should be Truth and nothing but the Truth.
('12', 203, 1, 13, 436920) With the aid to Truth we shall be able to cross even oceans of misery.
('12', 203, 1, 14, 436991) No action undertaken with a sincere motive ever goes unrewarded.
('12', 203, 1, 15, 437056) Therefore, work for the community with purity of motive.
('12', 203, 1, 16, 437113) It is not difficult to preserve unity.
('12', 203, 1, 17, 437152) As long as the Muslims do not want to quarrel, Hindus by themselves cannot do so.
('12', 203, 1, 18, 437234) If the Hindus are not spoiling for a fight, Muslims alone cannot bring about one.
('12', 203, 1, 19, 437316) Even if there are a hundred people out to create dissensions as against one who comes forward to promote unity, the hundred will lose and the one will win.
('12', 203, 1, 20, 437472) If that were not so, God’s divinity would be at an end.
