('12', 205, 1, 2, 439954) 168. DR.
('12', 205, 1, 3, 439963) MURISON’S CHARGE
('12', 205, 2, 4, 439980) Dr. Murison is reported to have said before the Tuberculosis Commission that Indians were given to lying and that “it was difficult to find out much of their private life, owing to their habits”.
('12', 205, 2, 5, 440176) In his opinion, “Indians should be put into Locations as well as Natives.” We awaited a public contradiction by Dr. Murison with reference to the charge of lying, and in order to make assurance doubly sure, we wrote, too, to the worthy Doctor, asking whether he had been correctly reported.
('12', 205, 2, 6, 440467) Not having seen any contradiction and not having received a reply from him we assume that he is correctly reported.
('12', 205, 2, 7, 440583) Dr. Murison has proved a conscientious medical officer, and we have often had occasion to congratulate him on his even handed treatment 1 of all classes of the community that came under his notice.
('12', 205, 2, 8, 440781) It is, therefore, not without pain that we are constrained to take exception to the sweeping charge of lying laid by him against a community, which prejudice has already terribly misrepresented in South Africa.
('12', 205, 2, 9, 440992) In the first place, Dr. Murison, as medical officer, would come into contact with the unhealthy rather than with the healthy, and to impute the faults of the unhealthy to a whole body of people is, to say the least of it, highly illogical.
('12', 205, 2, 10, 441232) But is it proper even to charge Indians suspected of suffering from tuberculosis with lying?
('12', 205, 2, 11, 441325) We are quite free to admit that such Indians, like all other classes of patients, in order to avoid segregation and special treatment which they might not understand, would minimize their trouble, or fail to give notice or even mislead officials, but, we trust that, upon reflection, Dr. Murison will find that to charge these people with lying and then, too, to base upon that charge a recommendation for their compulsory segregation in Loca tions is not the proper thing.
('12', 205, 2, 12, 441799) We may remind him that Lord Curzon, when he was Viceroy of India, at a lecture before University students, committed a similar indiscretion, 2 for which he suffered heavily.
('12', 205, 3, 13, 441973) 1 Vide “The Plague”, 7 1 1905. 2 This was at a Convocation address to an Indian University in 1905. While on the subject of the low place assigned to truth in the moral systems of the East, he had said that “craftiness and diplomatic wile have always been held in much repute” in Eastern countries.
('12', 205, 3, 14, 442272) Gandhiji had answered this at length at the time; vide “Oriental Ideal of Truth”, 1 4 1905. 3 The reference is to his resignation following a controversy with Lord Kitchener; vide, however, “Lord Curzon”, 26 8 1905.
('12', 206, 0, 1, 442488) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 207
('12', 206, 1, 2, 442529) lost all the prestige in India that he had previously enjoyed and laid himself open to the justifiable taunt of himself not having hesitated to lie when he thought that the occasion demanded it.
('12', 206, 1, 3, 442724) Zangwill 1 once said that if a Jew committed a crime it was the whole race that committed it; if a Gentile committed a crime, it was the individual only.
('12', 206, 1, 4, 442878) Replace the word “Jew” by “Indian”, and we have the whole ugly truth in nutshell.
('12', 206, 1, 5, 442960) Whenever an Indian does anything that is considered reprehensible, the newspapers do not hesitate to publish it in black type, and some public men do not hesitate to speak from platforms against the whole body of Indians residing in this country.
('12', 206, 1, 6, 443207) We do hope that Dr. Murison will not wish to belong to the category of public men above referred to, and that he will not forfeit the esteem in which he is at present justly held by the Indian community.
('12', 206, 2, 7, 443411) Indian Opinion, 13 7 1912
('12', 206, 3, 8, 443437) 169. THE NEW BROOM
('12', 206, 4, 9, 443456) Mr. Cousins, who has been appointed Acting Immigration Officer for Natal, has signalized his advent by issuing what purports to be a circular—which we give elsewhere—as to the evidence he would require to satisfy him as to the wives of domiciled Indians who might intend to enter the Province of Natal.
('12', 206, 4, 10, 443759) We can only hope that the circular is not dictated from headquarters.
('12', 206, 4, 11, 443829) Nothing could be better calculated to deeply wound Indian susceptibilities than this circular.
('12', 206, 4, 12, 443924) In rejecting the ordinary evidence that was submitted to him, Mr. Cousins stated that he would want unmistakable proof that the husband had no other wife, and that he should have a marriage certificate, which, too, would be accepted only when it was accompanied by proof of identity, 2 and that, if such a certificate were not produced, he would want the certificate of a superior European magistrate bearing the
('12', 206, 5, 13, 444337) 1 Israel Zangwill (1864 1926); Jewish teacher, novelist and playwright; was born and brought up in England; founded and edited Ariel and The London Puck; his works deal mostly with Jewish life and serious social problems; had earlier advocated settlement for Jews within the British Empire and later became a Zionist leader.
('12', 206, 5, 14, 444662) 2 The circular, “addressed to applicants for the admission of their wives”, also stated that the applicant would have to satisfy Cousins that he was lawful resident.
('12', 206, 5, 15, 444828) Indian Opinion, 13 7 1912.
('12', 207, 0, 1, 444855) 208 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 207, 1, 2, 444897) thumb marks of the wife, and to the effect that she was the wife of the applicant, whose identity also must be established by unmistakable means, that the superior officer had personally held an inquiry upon oath as to the date of the marriage, etc.
('12', 207, 1, 3, 445147) 1, and that he was to forward all the original statements declared before him, accompanied by means of identification of both the husband and the wife, and much more along the same lines.
('12', 207, 1, 4, 445335) Thus in a single circular Mr. Cousins has insulted Indian women, has impugned the honesty of Indian magistrates and even judges (for, we presume, he will not accept the testimony of even High Court judges, if they are Indian), and has insulted even European officials because he wants certificates from superior European officers, who, in turn, are insulted by being called upon to send all the records on which they issued the certificate required.
('12', 207, 1, 5, 445785) We should hope that to this extraordinary circular the Government of India will have something to say, that the people of India will not sit still under the unwarranted affront offered to them, and that the Indians of Natal will treat the circular letter as it deserves and will decline to allow their wives to give thumb or any other impre ssions.
('12', 207, 1, 6, 446134) It was one thing to require Indian males to identify themselves when there was a charge 2 of personation and surreptitious entry levelled against them.
('12', 207, 1, 7, 446286) It is another to wantonly insult Indian woman hood.
('12', 207, 1, 8, 446338) Let us hope that the Union Government will have the circular recalled, and that the practice of taking ordinary evidence will be con tinued, and may we suggest to Mr. Cousins that the quality that is required in a public officer is not over zeal in the direction of browbeating those members of the public with whom he comes into contact but that of showing kindly courtesy to all without in any way interfering with the administration of the particular laws which he may have been appointed to administer.
('12', 207, 1, 9, 446845) We cannot believe that the circular in question is required in the interests of the administration, and it
('12', 207, 2, 10, 446952) 1 The circular added that the Magistrate should also declare that: (a) the “facts declared to” by him were correct; and (b) that he had “caused a police inquiry to be made”.

('12', 207, 2, 12, 447319) 2 The charge of surreptitious entry and impersonation had been made repeatedly against Indians since 1906; vide “Influx of Asiatics”, 10 3 1906 & “The Mass Meeting”, 11 9 1906, “Interview to The Tribune”, 20 10 1906 & “Representation to Lord Elgin”, 31 10 1906, “Johannesburg Letter”, 12 10 1907 and Vol. VIII, “Interview to The Star”, 6 1 1908, “Extracts from Blue Book”, 7 3 1908 & “Cape Town Indians”, 11 4 1908.

('12', 208, 3, 4, 447845) 170. INDIAN INTERPRETERS
('12', 208, 4, 5, 447870) Our attention has been drawn to the fact that there is only one interpreter for three Indian languages (Hindustani, Tamil and Telugu) in the Supreme Court (Natal Division).
('12', 208, 4, 6, 448043) This gentleman may be qualified to interpret in these different languages, as it is stated he is, but we contend that it is not possible for one man to give satisfaction when he is called upon to interpret in all these languages with their various dialects in one breath, so to speak.
('12', 208, 4, 7, 448328) The Supreme Court has to decide questions of life and death, and upon the true interpretation of the evidence rests the fate of a prisoner.
('12', 208, 4, 8, 448468) When invited to ask questions, the prisoner is unable to do so as he cannot understand the languages in which the evidence is given.
('12', 208, 4, 9, 448601) Take the case of two Indians, speaking Tamil and Hindustani, tried under one charge.
('12', 208, 4, 10, 448686) A Telugu witness goes into the box and gives his evidence against the two accused.
('12', 208, 4, 11, 448769) The prisoners, not being represented by Counsel, are given the opportunity of cross examining the witness.
('12', 208, 4, 12, 448876) The Tamil man puts a question to the Telugu witness through the interpreter, who gives the answer in Tamil and to the Court in English.
('12', 208, 4, 13, 449012) Although it is desirable that the Hindustani man shall also understand what is going on, we believe, under the present circumstances, the evidence is not interpreted to him.
('12', 208, 4, 14, 449186) The interpreter is supposed to remember the proceedings and give a summary to the accused.
('12', 208, 4, 15, 449277) Even with one language, much will necessarily be missed, but with two prisoners and three Indian languages, the chances of both men being properly informed by the same interpreter are very small.
('12', 208, 4, 16, 449473) One can easily imagine that a man might be condemned to death wrongly in the midst of such a maze.
('12', 208, 4, 17, 449572) We have before called attention to the want of Gujarati inter preters, the large community speaking this language having always to speak in Hindustani before the Court, a language which they have never learnt and which has only been picked up in South Africa.
('12', 208, 4, 18, 449832) The whole question is one of stinginess on the part of the Government.
('12', 208, 4, 19, 449903) Whilst the authorities strain at the gnat of spending a few hundred pounds a year in providing sufficient competent interpreters for the courts, they swallow the camel of spending a million and a quarter over the Union Buildings, an expenditure which has been so
('12', 209, 0, 1, 450166) 210 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 209, 1, 2, 450208) severely criticized by Mr. Merriman and other members of Parlia ment.
('12', 209, 1, 3, 450278) Not until there are competent interpreters for all the Indian languages can it be said that substantial justice is done to Indians.
('12', 209, 2, 4, 450410) Indian Opinion, 13 7 1912
('12', 209, 3, 5, 450436) 171. DOMICILE CERTIFICATES IN NATAL
('12', 209, 4, 6, 450472) Natal Indians are no longer issued fresh domicile certificates.
('12', 209, 4, 7, 450536) Even worse, old certificates, whoever is found to possess them, are taken away and exchanged for new ones only on the production of fresh affidavits.
('12', 209, 4, 8, 450686) This causes the poor Indians much hardship.
('12', 209, 4, 9, 450730) We believe the Congress should fight out the case regarding domicile as it had intended to.
('12', 209, 4, 10, 450822) Meanwhile, those who have old certificates need not surrender them in order to obtain new ones.
('12', 209, 4, 11, 450918) Even if they want new ones, it is unnecessary to produce fresh proof before the official.
('12', 209, 4, 12, 451008) Those who do not have any certificates can leave the country without their having filed affidavits and [generally] strengthened the proofs of residence.
('12', 209, 4, 13, 451161) No one is obliged to keep domicile certificates.
('12', 209, 4, 14, 451210) There should be no difficulty, therefore, in leaving the country after collec ting the proofs [of residence, etc.

('12', 211, 3, 10, 455320) 174. DR.
('12', 211, 3, 11, 455329) MURISON’S LETTER
('12', 211, 4, 12, 455346) We print elsewhere Dr. Murison’s reply 1 to our letter 2 referred to in our columns last week.
('12', 211, 4, 13, 455441) We sympathize with Dr. Murison in his troubles.
('12', 211, 4, 14, 455489) But we venture to think that the worthy Doctor uncons ciously exaggerates the incidents that have come under his notice.
('12', 211, 4, 15, 455610) We take leave to say that the other classes give him much the same trouble that Indian patients do.
('12', 211, 4, 16, 455710) We suggest to Dr. Murison that his work will be no smoother by his flinging charges of lying against a whole community.
('12', 211, 4, 17, 455830) The only remedy is gentle yet firm handling of patients who want to evade his department.
('12', 211, 4, 18, 455920) If Indians suffering from small pox concealed their disease, other Indians helped him to combat the disease.
('12', 211, 4, 19, 456029) No one can deplore more than we do the fact that there should be any disease at all among Indians, or that, having contracted an infectious disease, Indians should, in their ignorance or fear, attempt to conceal it.
('12', 211, 4, 20, 456245) But a serious charge, such as that of lying, can not be sustained because of the painful experiences related by Dr. Murison.
('12', 211, 4, 21, 456370) However, the community must feel thankful to Dr. Murison for his frankness and for his evident desire to serve Indians as well as the others.
('12', 211, 4, 22, 456512) Those of us who claim to be responsible persons must see to it that Dr. Murison receives all the help he may need in order to keep the Borough free from disease and danger, from careless or timid person disregarding or concealing any disease that may be suspected
('12', 211, 5, 23, 456776) 1 Dr. Murison, Medical Officer of Health for the Borough of Durban, in the course of his evidence before the Tuberculosis Commission, had stated that Indians were given to lying.
('12', 211, 5, 24, 456955) On this Gandhiji wrote to Dr. Murison on June 28, 1912, to which the latter replied on July 10, 1912. He maintained that, in matters dealing with public health and sanitation, “it is impossible to obtain truthful replies from this race”.
('12', 211, 5, 25, 457193) Indian Opinion, 20 7 1912. Vide also “Dr. Murison’s Charge”, 13 7 1912. 2 This letter by Gandhiji and also the others in the series are not available.
('12', 212, 0, 1, 457344) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 213
('12', 212, 1, 2, 457385) to be infectious.
('12', 212, 1, 3, 457403) It is no consolation to be able to refute a general charge of lying.
('12', 212, 1, 4, 457472) The real consolation can only be derived from efforts being made to remove the smallest ground for making such a charge.
('12', 212, 2, 5, 457593) Indian Opinion, 20 7 1912
('12', 212, 3, 6, 457619) 175. DR .
('12', 212, 3, 7, 457629) MURISON’S CHARGE
('12', 212, 4, 8, 457646) Dr. Murison’s reply to our letter seeking his explanation regarding the charge of lying he had brought against Durban Indians deserves careful study.
('12', 212, 4, 9, 457796) His explanation certainly does not substantiate the charge of lying against the entire community.
('12', 212, 4, 10, 457894) But we cannot just sit back having put forward this defence.
('12', 212, 4, 11, 457955) We must admit the [individual] instances Dr. Murison has cited.
('12', 212, 4, 12, 458019) For it is true that some Indians habitually conceal [the incidence of infectious] diseases and give false replies to the [inquiries of] officials.
('12', 212, 4, 13, 458166) This habit must go.
('12', 212, 4, 14, 458186) Often men lie out of fear, and fear is the consequence of ignorance.
('12', 212, 4, 15, 458255) If ignorance goes, so will fear.
('12', 212, 4, 16, 458288) And with the passing of fear [the habit of] lying will vanish.
('12', 212, 4, 17, 458351) For instance, if a case of smallpox is declared we might be threatened with we know not what or we might be harassed in hospital; so we conceal [the incidence of] the disease due to ignorance of this kind and the fear arising from it.
('12', 212, 4, 18, 458586) In fect, nobody is going to hang us for it, and if we are spirited enough nobody can harass us in the hospital either.
('12', 212, 4, 19, 458705) Why then should we be afraid?
('12', 212, 4, 20, 458735) More over, by lying we cannot [successfully] conceal a case of smallpox.
('12', 212, 4, 21, 458808) If anything, we should be afraid of telling a lie.
('12', 212, 4, 22, 458859) Suppose we tell a lie and conceal a patient and the matter comes to be known, we may be put to shame, charged and even punished.
('12', 212, 4, 23, 458988) Moreover, if we have concealed a patient, we are likely [afterwards] to be harassed even at the hospital and our relatives may also become involved.
('12', 212, 4, 24, 459137) If we learn to view the matter thus, there should be no cause for fear.
('12', 212, 4, 25, 459209) However, many of those who deceive the authorities are unlikely to read these comments of ours.
('12', 212, 4, 26, 459305) Thus, the responsibility rests solely on the leaders.
('12', 212, 4, 27, 459359) If we are truthful and remain so, and if we wish others also to act; likewise, we can do much.
('12', 212, 4, 28, 459454) It is the duty of the leaders to keep in touch with the poorer section of the community, to point the right path to them now and again and themselves follow it.
('12', 212, 4, 29, 459615) If we do this, there should be no occasion for a single charge against us.
('12', 212, 5, 30, 459690) [From Gujarati]
('12', 212, 6, 31, 459706) Indian Opinion, 20 7 1912

('12', 213, 1, 2, 459774) 176. LETTER TO REGISTRAR OF ASIATICS 1
('12', 213, 2, 3, 459813) July 22, 1912
('12', 213, 3, 4, 459827) [THE REGISTRAR OF ASIATICS PRETORIA
('12', 213, 5, 5, 459863) I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 13th instant.
('12', 213, 5, 6, 459940) In reply, I beg to state that the inconvenience felt by Indians who are waiting in the street outside your office is very considerable.
('12', 213, 5, 7, 460076) As you are aware, many have to wait for a long time, and, apart from anything else, to be standing in the street indefinitely must be extremely fatiguing, as, indeed, those who have been obliged to wait there have so often complained to the British Indian Asso ciation.
('12', 213, 5, 8, 460346) Moreover, they have no protection from the wind, sun or rain, and often, when they are in any considerable number, it is difficult for them to know where they should stand—on the pavement or in the street—as, wherever they stood, they would be causing an obstruction.
('12', 213, 5, 9, 460614) In my humble opinion, as part of the public having to do business in a public office, they are entitled to the same respectable accommodation as is provided in all other public offices.
('12', 213, 6, 10, 460800) M. K. GANDHI Indian Opinion, 3 8 1912
('12', 213, 7, 11, 460838) 1 This was sent in reply to a letter from M. Chamney, Registrar of Asiaitics, dated July 13, which read: “With reference to the interview I had with you on the 11th instant, I shall be obliged if you will put in a written statement regarding the inconvenience to which Indians are put while waiting in the streets outside my office, and setting forth what it is they desire.” Indian Opinion, 3 8 1912. 2 In reply to this, Chamney wrote on July 26: “.
('12', 213, 7, 12, 461289) there is no special accommodation available for the convenience of Asiatics who attend at my Office, nor are there any funds available by which such special accommodation could be furnished at the present time.
('12', 213, 7, 13, 461500) With regard to the sentence which closes your communication.

('12', 215, 4, 5, 463670) 179. THE SETTLEMENT PROLONGED
('12', 215, 5, 6, 463700) The correspondence 1 between the Union Government and Mr. Gandhi forms interesting reading.
('12', 215, 5, 7, 463792) According to it, the Provisional Settlement of last year 2 continues pending the passing of satisfactory legislation which the Government again intend introducing during the next session.
('12', 215, 5, 8, 463980) Meanwhile, six educated British Indians will be permitted to enter the Transvaal Province as if the legislation had already been passed.
('12', 215, 5, 9, 464117) 3 This is all good .
('12', 215, 5, 10, 464138) The correspondence avoids recrudescence of passive resistance on the points in dispute.
('12', 215, 6, 11, 464226) But the indictment of Lord Ampthill, who has been, with tireless zeal, championing our cause, remains unanswered.
('12', 215, 6, 12, 464340) 4 The gravamen of His Lordship’s charge is that, though the letter of the settlement is being kept, the spirit of it— indeed, General Botha’s public declarations 5—require that the resident Indian population is allowed to

('12', 218, 1, 2, 469274) 181. THE BOKSBURG CASE 1
('12', 218, 2, 3, 469299) The result of the judgment 2 in Mr. Bhyat’s case is that trade of
('12', 218, 3, 4, 469365) 1 Amod Moosa Bhyat, a well known Heidelberg merchant who had earlier suffered arrests and financial privation as a passive resister, opened a store in Boksburg on November 6, 1911, in premises registered in L. W. Ritch’s name.
('12', 218, 3, 5, 469592) The Europeans of Boksburg, an East Rand centre which had hitherto allowed no Asiatic to trade in the town, called a meeting on November 8, and protested against the advent of Asiatic competition.
('12', 218, 3, 6, 469788) A few days earlier the East Rand Express had styled Bhyat as an “astute invader” who, with the help of Ritch and his “influential European friends in England”, was forcing a test case and promised that the local whites would fight “to the last ditch”.
('12', 218, 3, 7, 470040) An editorial in Indian Opinion, 4 11 1911, agreed that the “clear cut issue” was whether British Indians could trade or pursue their crafts outside “coolie Locations”.
('12', 218, 3, 8, 470208) The Transvaal leader, too, took up the cry of white self preservation and the European Press spoke of an “Asiatic invasion” and declared that European traders could never compete with the Asiatics with their “primitive mode of existence”, “Oriental ingenuity” and “inferior standard of civilization”.
('12', 218, 3, 9, 470509) This meeting passed three resolutions, demanding that: (a) action should be taken against Bhyat under Section 131 of the Gold Law; (b) the condition under which the leasehold of Ritch’s property was converted into a freehold—that no Coloured person should reside thereon or trade therein—should be enforced; and (c) municipal facilities be denied to Bhyat by the Town Council.
('12', 218, 3, 10, 470886) The Town Council, in its meeting of November 22, 1911, was faced with more extreme amendments to these resolutions and was called upon to instruct the Receiver of Revenue to cancel all existing Asiatic trade licences.
('12', 218, 3, 11, 471104) In its meeting of December 8, the Town Council, however, rescinded its amendments having meanwhile taken legal advice and forwarded the resolutions to the Government.
('12', 218, 3, 12, 471271) Meanwhile, the Mayor and the Chairman of the Committee of the Town Council had met General Smuts in deputation and he assured them that the Government would take immediate steps regarding the stands occupied by Coloured persons in Boksburg.
('12', 218, 3, 13, 471512) On January 12, 1912 the Government served a notice on Ritch through their lawyers asking him to surrender the crown Grant of August 21, 1911 which gave him freehold of the Stands since he had “violated the conditions of Grant by permitting Coloured persons...
('12', 218, 3, 14, 471772) to reside on the Stands”.
('12', 218, 3, 15, 471798) On February 12, 1912, the Supreme Court (Transvaal Division) issued summonses against Ritch and Bhyat following an application by the Government and hearing commenced on June 7. The Minister of Justice had moved the Supreme Court for a declaration that the plaintiff was entitled to the ownership of the said Stand since the defendant had refused to cancel the transfer deed and to deliver up the possession of the Stand.
('12', 218, 3, 16, 472220) Indian Opinion, 4 11 1911 to 13 7 1912. 2 In his judgment Justice Moson declared that Ritch was bound by the conditions under which the Deed of Transfer of Crown land was effected, that is, by the relevant provisions of the Townships Act and the Gold Law.
('12', 218, 3, 17, 472476) The Union of South Africa were therefore entitled to cancel the Deed of Transfer of these 3 Stands and to order Ritch to deliver up possession of all these.
('12', 218, 3, 18, 472633) They were furthermore entitled to eject Bhyat, the second defendant.
('12', 218, 3, 19, 472702) The plaintiff was entitled to the costs of the
('12', 219, 0, 1, 472749) 220 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 219, 1, 2, 472791) British Indian merchants, living within the gold areas, has been rendered not worth a day’s purchase.
('12', 219, 1, 3, 472893) The East Rand Express has already advised the other municipalities to take action similar to thatof Boksburg and force the hand of the Government.
('12', 219, 1, 4, 473040) It is certainly now open to the latter to institute proceedings in respect of landed property in gold areas occupied by British Indian merchants.
('12', 219, 1, 5, 473186) It is, therefore, of the greatest importance that the Bhyat case should be fought to a finish.
('12', 219, 1, 6, 473281) The Union Government assured the Imperial Government that the Town ships Act was not directly aimed at British Indians or other Asiatics, and that there was no clause in it specially affecting them.
('12', 219, 1, 7, 473480) 1 We now see that, if the judgment given by the Transvaal Bench remains unreversed, the Townships Act has to be read in conjunction with the Gold Law, 2 and the combined effect of action.
('12', 219, 1, 8, 473668) Ritch had contended that the original lease, taken out in 1896, contained no provision against Coloured persons occupying the land.
('12', 219, 1, 9, 473800) As for the conditions in which leasehold was converted into freehold (that is, that the Stand should not be transferred to any Coloured person), they had been promulgated by Regulation and could not be enforced against persons of non European descent for, being a differential provision operating against Asiatics only and not Europeans (that is to say, since it was “class legislation”), it required the “previous instruction” of His Majesty under Section 39(a) of the Letters Patent (Transvaal).
('12', 219, 1, 10, 474298) Indian Opinion, 13 7 1912. Vide also Appendix “Union Ministers’ Minutes for Union Government Regarding Townships Amendment Act (1908)”, 16 6 1911 in which Smuts had argued in 1911 that the Townships Act did not bear on such cases.
('12', 219, 1, 11, 474529) 1 Vide Appendix “Union Ministers’ Minutes for Union Government Regarding Townships Amendment Act (1908)”, 16 6 1911. 2 While Law 3 of 1885 did prohibit a Transvaal Asiatic from owning landed property outside Locations, it did not prevent a European from doing so on his behalf whether in perpetual leasehold or freehold.
('12', 219, 1, 12, 474850) In 1905, the Transvaal Supreme Court “definitely recognized these equitable trusts as between nominal European owners and Asiatic virtual owners” (case of Syed Ismail and Another v.
('12', 219, 1, 13, 475032) Jacobs cited by Maud Polak).
('12', 219, 1, 14, 475061) The effect of the Townships Amendment Act and the Gold Law of 1908 was to annul these confirmed rights.
('12', 219, 1, 15, 475165) Under the Townships Act, Part II, Chapter 3, Section 9(1), leaseholds of all Stands in Stands Townships were automatically converted into freehold on the payment of a licence fee.
('12', 219, 1, 16, 475345) The lessor or owner was admittedly not obliged to take out a freehold title.
('12', 219, 1, 17, 475422) If he did so, Section 130 of the Gold Law of 1908, prohibiting the subletting of premises or the residence of Asiatics thereon, came into force.
('12', 219, 1, 18, 475567) Obviously, in cases where the property was held in trust, the Indian could not himself take out a freehold owing to the prohibition on “Coloured ownership”.
('12', 219, 1, 19, 475724) If the nominal European owner did so, he became liable under the Townships Act, Chapter 3, Section 3(1), to criminal prosecution, and his property would become forfeit to the Government, under Sections 130 and 131 of the Gold Law of 1908, which was brought into operation in such cases.
('12', 219, 1, 20, 476011) It happened in cases where the laws were read together.
('12', 219, 1, 21, 476067) That is, he could not then allow a Coloured person other than a domestic servant to reside on Township properties.
('12', 219, 1, 22, 476182) Moreover, when such property passed at
('12', 220, 0, 1, 476221) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 221
('12', 220, 1, 2, 476262) the two Acts is such that the Township Act virtually becomes class legislation 1. Whilst, therefore, it is necessary to take the matter to the highest court of appeal, it is equally necessary for the British Indians in the Transvaal to realize and understand that the courts of justice in matters of this character cannot possibly finally decide the position.
('12', 220, 1, 3, 476622) In the event of the highest court of appeal upholding the decision, they will have to move in order to secure an amendment of both these laws.
('12', 220, 1, 4, 476765) Mr. Bhyat cannot be expected to undertake the burden of appealing.
('12', 220, 1, 5, 476832) The whole community is in duty bound to come to the rescue.
('12', 220, 1, 6, 476892) The decision in this case is of general application.
('12', 220, 1, 7, 476945) We hope, therefore, that British Indians of means will not hesitate to support the proceedings now being taken by giving donations towards the expenses.
('12', 220, 2, 8, 477098) Indian Opinion, 27 7 1912
('12', 220, 3, 9, 477124) the death of the owner to the heirs the conversion of a leasehold into a freehold was made compulsory.
('12', 220, 3, 10, 477227) So much so that, at the death of a nominal European owner, the property of the equitable owner would pass out of his hands.
('12', 220, 3, 11, 477351) As Lord Ampthill said, this was how the Townships Amendment Act (Act 34 of 1908) and the Transvaal Gold Law (Act 35 of 1908) provided “in a subtle and indirect manner” that the same prohibitions and penalties as were prescribed by the Gold Law in ‘proclaimed areas’ shall apply in the case of public Townships also.
('12', 220, 3, 12, 477667) The effect of both these laws was to force, after January 1, 1909, the entire Transvaal Indian population, whether in Townships or in “proclaimed areas”, into Locations.
('12', 220, 3, 13, 477837) The British Government had opposed this policy before and after the Boer War, but had assented to it in 1908. (Lord Ampthill’s letter to the British Press, Indian Opinion, 28 10 1911, Maud Polak’s letter on behalf of the SABI Committee to the Secretary of State for the Colonies, July 29, 1911, C. O. 551/22 and “Mr. Polak’s Statement”, Indian Opinion, 9 12 1911 & 16 12 1911).
('12', 220, 3, 14, 478215) 1 Gandhiji had always objected to class legislation, that is, legislation which sought to place differential restrictions on any minority among British subjects which did not have political franchise.
('12', 220, 3, 15, 478416) As Indians had become members of the Empire by virtue of Queen Victoria’s Proclamation, the constitutions of Natal and the Transvaal (which became self governing in 1893 and 1908, respectively) contained a special provision to the effect that any discriminatory legislation directed against British Indians as a class would require special royal assent.
('12', 220, 3, 16, 478770) For Gandhiji’s references to class legislation, vide, for instance, Vol. VI, “Interview to The Morning Leader”, 20 10 1906 & “A Retrospect”, 29 12 1906.

('12', 223, 1, 2, 481951) 185. SPEECH AT JOHANNESBURG BANQUET TO V. A. CHETTIAR 1
('12', 223, 2, 3, 482007) August 1, 1912
('12', 223, 3, 4, 482022) The worst days of the Indian passive resistance struggle in the Transvaal were recalled last night [August 1], and a warning was given by Mr. Gandhi to the people who voluntarily underwent imprisonment with hard labour at the time, to be in readiness for a possible repetition of their sufferings.
('12', 223, 4, 5, 482320) It was at a banquet given in honour of Mr. V. A. Chettiar, ...
('12', 223, 4, 6, 482383) who is now on the eve of returning to Madras.
('12', 223, 5, 7, 482429) Mr. Gandhi, called upon by Mr. Hosken, as the teacher and prophet of passive resistance, warned his hearers that the great struggle in South Africa was by no means ended.
('12', 223, 5, 8, 482600) It was, he said, only in suspense, and it might be that the community might again be called upon to undergo much suffering.
('12', 223, 6, 9, 482724) Proceeding to propose “The Guests”, Mr. Gandhi paid a warm tribute to Mr. Hosken and other Europeans present, and said it was due largely to them that they were all gathered at that table on terms—might he say—of equality.
('12', 223, 6, 10, 482947) To his mind equality should be a matter of course in every civilized country, and especially in every Christian community; but, labouring as they did under terrible difficulties and terrible prejudices, it was a matter for congratulations when any sort of equality could be attained.

('12', 223, 8, 12, 483262) 186. THE GERMISTON LOCATION
('12', 223, 9, 13, 483290) We publish elsewhere the report of Dr. F. Arnold, the Acting Medical Officer of Health for the Union, on the proposed site for a new Asiatic Bazaar in Germiston.
('12', 223, 9, 14, 483452) The report, in our opinion, is a special pleading for the site chosen by the Town Council.
('12', 223, 9, 15, 483543) Dr. Macnab’s strong remarks have been brushed aside.
('12', 223, 9, 16, 483596) It is true that some of the objections have been withdrawn by Dr. Machab.
('12', 223, 9, 17, 483670) But the main objection—that the Location is to be near a depositing site and a site where anthrax animals have been buried—remains.
('12', 223, 9, 18, 483802) The fact of Dr.
('12', 223, 10, 19, 483818) 1 The banquet was arranged by the Tamil community of Johannesburg on the occasion of Chettiar’s departure for India and was attended by about 300 guests including a number of Europeans sympathetic to the Indian cause.
('12', 223, 10, 20, 484036) Dr. Ross, Rev.
('12', 223, 10, 21, 484051) Doke and Hosken also spoke.
('12', 224, 0, 1, 484079) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 225
('12', 224, 1, 2, 484120) Arnold having laid down certain conditions under which only the site can be passed medically shows, too, that Dr. Macnab’s strictures were quite justified.
('12', 224, 1, 3, 484276) It must not, again, be forgotten that even the very ground where night soil has been deposited is part of the site chosen by the Germiston Municipality.
('12', 224, 1, 4, 484429) No doubt, from a purely scientific standpoint, it is a consolation that this portion of the Location is not to be used for building purposes for some time to come, but, in matters of this character, a favourable medical report cannot become a conclusive answer to the various objections raised.
('12', 224, 1, 5, 484724) An old cemetery, form a medical standpoint, may be a good enough site for habitation, but, from other perfectly justifiable points of view, it may be a totally undesirable site.
('12', 224, 1, 6, 484902) As we have already pointed out, it is a curious circumstance that, for Asiatic Bazaars and Native Locations, Muni cipalities always succeed in finding the most favourable spots near depositing sites.
('12', 224, 1, 7, 485102) All we can say is that the Indians of Germiston decline to remove to this wretched spot, notwithstanding the favourable report given by Dr. Arnold.
('12', 224, 1, 8, 485250) We are aware that they will require to have more than ordinary grit in refusing to remove to this site.
('12', 224, 1, 9, 485354) The Municipality has made it well nigh impossible for them to remain in the old Location, because all trade there is entirely stopped.
('12', 224, 1, 10, 485489) Several buildings have been razed to the ground, and the Municipality have threatened to do likewise with the other buildings, if their owners are caught is the act of trading in the Location.
('12', 224, 1, 11, 485682) We hope that, no matter what difficulties they have to face, the Indians in Germiston will take up a firm stand and decline to fall into the trap prepared by the Municipality.

('12', 229, 1, 2, 495462) 190. MR. TATA’S MUNIFICENCE
('12', 229, 2, 3, 495490) Mr. Ratan Tata has outdone himself.
('12', 229, 2, 4, 495526) At the Sheriff’s meeting 1 held at Bombay on the 31st ultimo and presided over by Sir Jamsetji, it was announced that Mr. Tata had given a third contribution of Rs. 25,000 to the Transvaal passive resistance fund.
('12', 229, 2, 5, 495740) The total given by Mr. Tata there fore amounts to £5,000—a fortune in itself.
('12', 229, 2, 6, 495818) Mr Petit has already cabled to Mr. Gandhi £1,500. Mr. Tata’s munificence shows not only his large heartedness, but also his keen appreciation of the struggle.
('12', 229, 2, 7, 495977) Mr. Tata has laid the passive resisters, as also the whole Indian community of South Africa, under deep obligation.
('12', 229, 2, 8, 496093) He has made the lot of passive resisters easy; and the fact that there are at the back of the struggle such distinguished Indians, encourages those who are engaged in it, and probably brings them nearer their goal.
('12', 229, 2, 9, 496308) The moral effect of such help on those who, from prejudice, are opposed to us, is also obvious.
('12', 229, 3, 10, 496404) Indian Opinion, 10 8 1912
('12', 229, 4, 11, 496430) 191. THE SHERIFF’S MEETING
('12', 229, 5, 12, 496457) A meeting called by a Sheriff in India is equivalent to a meeting called, say, by the Mayor in Durban.
('12', 229, 5, 13, 496560) The term Sheriff has a meaning different from what we understand by it in South Africa.
('12', 229, 5, 14, 496648) The Sheriff’s position is honorary and it is conferred upon the most distinguished citizens in India.
('12', 229, 5, 15, 496750) Those of our readers who do not know India much, will now understand what the public meeting recently held in Bombay and called by the Sheriff means.
('12', 229, 5, 16, 496900) The meeting naturally represented the voice of all the sections of the Bombay public.
('12', 229, 5, 17, 496986) Its resolutions must, therefore, carry weight.
('12', 229, 5, 18, 497033) The meeting very properly took up the whole question of the status of our countrymen settled in the British Colonies.
('12', 229, 5, 19, 497151) East African Europeans want to hound our countrymen out of the British East African Protectorate.
('12', 229, 5, 20, 497249) They donot even realize that, if Indians withdrew from it, the country would soon become a howling wilderness.
('12', 229, 5, 21, 497360) Canada will not allow the wives of
('12', 229, 6, 22, 497395) 1 This meeting, held on August 1, protested against the treatment of Indians in the colonies, particularly in South Africa, East Africa and Canada; approved a memorandum to the Indian government for transmission to the Marquess of Crewe, condemning the continuance of the indentured labour system; and sent a message of encouragement to South African Indians, strongly approving the forthcoming visit of Gokhale to that country.

('12', 230, 1, 2, 497865) domiciled Indians to join their husbands, thus disregarding every canon of decency and fair play.

('12', 230, 1, 4, 498159) The meeting presided over by the Parsee Baronet dealt with all these questions.

('12', 230, 3, 12, 498909) 192. INVALID REGULATIONS
('12', 230, 4, 13, 498934) A Boksburg Indian 1 was defended by Mr. Ritch the other day in the Magistrate’s Court for a breach of municipal regulations, in that he was conducting a compound where Natives were kept as tenants.
('12', 230, 4, 14, 499132) The accused was convicted.
('12', 230, 4, 15, 499159) Mr. Ritch appealed.
('12', 230, 4, 16, 499179) Mr. Gregorowski argued the appeal and the conviction has been set aside, the Court holding that the regulations were ultra vires.
('12', 230, 4, 17, 499309) This is an important decision.
('12', 230, 4, 18, 499340) Many Indians would have been seriously affected if the regulations had been held to be valid.
('12', 230, 5, 19, 499434) Indian Opinion, 10 8 1912
('12', 230, 6, 20, 499460) 1 Moses.
('12', 230, 6, 21, 499469) He was convicted for contravening Section 38 of the Boksburg Public Health Bye laws.
('12', 230, 6, 22, 499554) On appeal being preferred, the judge declared that the bye law was not valid inasmuch as it discriminated as between Europeans and Coloured persons, for which there was no authority in the enabling law, and he set aside the conviction.
('12', 230, 6, 23, 499790) Indian Opinion, 10 8 1912.

('12', 233, 5, 30, 505762) 1 Dr. Porter, Medical Officer of Health, said in the course of an interview: “Judging by past experience, the remedy for such outbreaks lies in the segregation of white and Coloured in the city.

('12', 234, 1, 2, 506268) outbreak of smallpox in Johannesburg.
('12', 234, 1, 3, 506306) So far, Indians appear to have remained immune, but it is none the less their duty to help the authorities by removing all causes that might lead to an outbreak among themselves.
('12', 234, 1, 4, 506485) There is, in that article, the suggestion that we do not conform to the laws of sanitation.
('12', 234, 1, 5, 506577) The best way to meet this charge is, without doubt, that we put our houses in perfect order.

('12', 234, 1, 8, 506997) We feel that Indians residing within that area should at once set about vacating such houses, where they are not capable of proper repair, and they will find that, although it may cost them a little more in rent, the extra cost would be more than made up for in times of panic and by the people themselves keeping better health.

('12', 234, 3, 11, 507470) 196. SMALLPOX IN JOHANNESBURG
('12', 234, 4, 12, 507500) Smallpox has again broken out in Johannesburg.
('12', 234, 4, 13, 507547) Once the disease appears in a large and crowded city like Johannesburg, It is difficult to stamp it out quickly or [even] to check it.
('12', 234, 4, 14, 507682) The news of the outbreak has therefore created a panic and thousands of people rush to get themselves vaccinated against smallpox.
('12', 234, 4, 15, 507813) In order to control the epidemic, however, the chief thing is to prevent the contagion from spreading.
('12', 234, 4, 16, 507916) Stress has therefore been laid on segregating the various communities, and the question of obtaining the necessary powers is also being considered.
('12', 234, 4, 17, 508064) When segregation is being considered, the proposal, needless to say, is bound to include the Indians.
('12', 234, 4, 18, 508166) It will be impossible to raise the issue of racial discrimination if it is proposed to segregate Indians in Locations because of the epidemic.
('12', 234, 4, 19, 508309) It cannot also be denied that our people, more than others, withhold information about [the incidence of] the disease with the result that the contagion spreads further.
('12', 234, 4, 20, 508479) Thus, the outbreak of the epidemic will provide an occasion for some serious suggestions to be made which, we want the Indians to note, it will be
('12', 235, 0, 1, 508626) 236 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 235, 1, 2, 508668) almost impossible to oppose.
('12', 235, 1, 3, 508697) Though the epidemic did not originate this time with Indians and though only a few cases appear to have occurred among them, they should not be any the less careful in the matter.
('12', 235, 1, 4, 508877) Dr. Porter has stated that some of the houses in the central part [of the city], occupied by Indians and others, are so dirty that they should really be burnt down.
('12', 235, 1, 5, 509042) It is the duty of the Indians [concerned] to vacate the houses forthwith and take up residence elsewhere.
('12', 235, 1, 6, 509148) And they should maintain the utmost cleanliness in the new houses.
('12', 235, 1, 7, 509215) Even if this means their having to incur some expenditure, it will be worth while doing so.
('12', 235, 1, 8, 509307) The community should extend its full co operation to the Medical Officer.
('12', 235, 1, 9, 509381) If it shows itself to be negligent, the severest possible measures will be taken against it in the name of the epidemic.

('12', 236, 1, 2, 510109) 198. INTERVIEW TO “THE TRANSVAAL LEADER”
('12', 236, 2, 3, 510150) JOHANNESBURG, August 22, 1912
('12', 236, 3, 4, 510180) Although Mr. M. K. Gandhi is not resident in Johannesburg at the present time, he continues to keep in close touch with public affairs, in so far as they affect his own people.
('12', 236, 3, 5, 510357) Yesterday morning [August 22] a Leader representative had a chat with the one time passive resister, who had trudged in from the farm Tolstoy, where he is now living in comparative retirement.
('12', 236, 4, 6, 510550) When asked whether he had read the various articles published during the past few weeks in connection with the outbreak of smallpox, Mr. Gandhi replied in the affirmative.
('12', 236, 4, 7, 510722) In regard to the suggestion that the Coloured races should be segregated he stated that, although he approved of voluntary segregation, he was opposed to compulsion in any shape or form.
('12', 236, 4, 8, 510909) Segregation would in any case be totally ineffective.
('12', 236, 4, 9, 510963) Even if you kept the Indians in one district, the Eurafricans in another, you could not prevent them intermixing outside in the ordinary course of their business.
('12', 236, 4, 10, 511126) Segregation would not remove the danger of infection.
('12', 236, 4, 11, 511180) You would find that the Indian fruit hawker would, if he came from an area infected with smallpox, carry the disease into other areas.
('12', 236, 4, 12, 511315) During the present outbreak there have been very few Indian cases, and the health officials cannot blame us on this occasion.
('12', 236, 4, 13, 511441) We are only too anxious to help the authorities, but we are opposed to compulsory segregation.
('12', 236, 4, 14, 511536) Dr. Murray gave some very valuable evidence on the point some years ago, when he appeared before the Insanitary Area Expropriation Commission, .
('12', 236, 4, 15, 511681) He stated that any neglect of sanitation that existed among British Indians or the others would not be dealt with successfully by relegating them to inaccessible Bazaars or to places which would not lend themselves to effective control by the Health officials.
('12', 236, 5, 16, 511942) DRASTIC BY LAWS APPROVED
('12', 236, 6, 17, 511967) I fully approve of drastic by laws where the health of the community is concerned.
('12', 236, 6, 18, 512050) I would show no mercy to offenders against such measures.
('12', 236, 7, 19, 512108) [Question ;] Do you approve of the action of the Public Health Committee in applying for the powers of demolition in the case of in sanitary dwellings?
('12', 236, 7, 20, 512260) Yes, I would enforce the law in this respect with the utmost
('12', 237, 0, 1, 512321) 238 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 237, 1, 2, 512363) rigour.
('12', 237, 1, 3, 512371) The proper way of dealing with all classes of the community, European, Asiatic, Eurafrican and Native, is to allow them freedom of movement, subject to a strict supervision as regards health conditions.
('12', 237, 1, 4, 512574) I’ve had close on 20 years’ experience in such matters, and if you were to segregate the Indians and force them to live in Bazaars, say 4 or 5 miles out of town, you would run a big risk of the spread of such diseases as smallpox.
('12', 237, 1, 5, 512805) We as a community have been accused of a desire to hide the outbreak of any disease.
('12', 237, 1, 6, 512890) What would happen if the Indians were cut off for residential purposes from the rest of the population?
('12', 237, 1, 7, 512994) I can assure you that the danger of contagion would be far greater.
('12', 237, 1, 8, 513062) In any case, I am convinced that the Imperial Government would not sanction any class legislation such as a policy of segregation would entail.
('12', 237, 1, 9, 513206) As a race we are only too anxious to obey the laws, and trust that the sanitary by laws which will come into force under the new Municipal Ordinance will be enforced in a firm and just manner.
('12', 237, 2, 10, 513399) The Transvaal Leader, 23 8 1912
('12', 237, 3, 11, 513431) 199. A SPLENDID RECORD
('12', 237, 4, 12, 513454) The subject of this sketch is so well known that it is almost superfluous to explain who and what Mr. Gokhale is.
('12', 237, 4, 13, 513568) South African Indian remember with deep gratitude his continued advocacy of their cause and his sympathy with them in their troubles.
('12', 237, 4, 14, 513702) He will be always remembered as the man who largely brought about the stoppage of recruiting indentured labour in India for Natal.
('12', 237, 4, 15, 513833) Mr.Gokhale’s ener gies have been recently thrown into the introduction of a Bill in the Viceroy’s Council to provide free and compulsory education for every child in India.
('12', 237, 4, 16, 514006) Although unsuccessful, Mr. Gokhale is not the man to be discouraged by failure.
('12', 237, 4, 17, 514086) When he knew that the fate of his Bill was sealed, he made no complaint.
('12', 237, 4, 18, 514159) In his speech before the Coun cil he said: “I know too well the story of the preliminary efforts that were required even in England before the Act of 1870 was passed, either to complain or to feel depressed.
('12', 237, 4, 19, 514367) Moreover, I have always felt and have often said that we of the present generation in India can only hope to serve our country by our failures.” Such is the man as he is today.
('12', 237, 4, 20, 514544) His life has been spent in serving the Motherland, and it is the prayer of millions in India and elsewhere that he may be spared many more years to continue the work he loves so well.
('12', 238, 0, 1, 514728) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 239
('12', 238, 1, 2, 514769) Gopal Krishna Gokhale was born in 1866 at Kolhapur, India.
('12', 238, 1, 3, 514828) His parents were poor, but they sent him to the local college to be educated.
('12', 238, 1, 4, 514906) He was a successful student and took his B. A. course principally at the Eliphinstone College, Bombay, and partly at the Deccan College, Poona.
('12', 238, 1, 5, 515050) After taking his degree, in 1884, he was admitted to membership of the Deccan Education Society.
('12', 238, 1, 6, 515147) The life members of this Society bind themselves to serve in the Fergusson College and in the schools of the Society for a period of twenty years on a monthly salary of 75 rupees.
('12', 238, 1, 7, 515327) For some time Mr. Gokhale lectured on English Literature and Mathematics, but for the greater part of his term of service he filled the chair of History and Political Economy, subjects which he has so thoroughly mastered that he is acknowledged to be an authority on them.
('12', 238, 1, 8, 515600) Such was his devotion and love for the work that, for several years, he devoted all his holidays to the work of collecting funds, travelling incessantly, bearing hardships, and submitting to indignities.
('12', 238, 1, 9, 515804) Mr. Gokhale, though never occupying the position of Principal, was a man of great influence in the conduct of its affairs.
('12', 238, 1, 10, 515927) About the time that he entered the Fergusson College, Mr. Gokhale came under the influence of the late Mr. Justice Ranade 1, and for many years they studied together great world problems, and especially those concerning India.
('12', 238, 1, 11, 516154) In 1887, in compliance with Mr. Ranade’s wish, Mr. Gokhale became the editor of the Quarterly Journal of the Poona Sarvajanik Sabha.
('12', 238, 1, 12, 516287) Subsequently he became Honorary Secretary of the Deccan Sabha.
('12', 238, 1, 13, 516350) He was also for four years one of the editors of the Sudharak, an Anglo Marathi weekly of Poona.
('12', 238, 1, 14, 516447) He was Secretary of the Bombay Provincial Council for a similar period, and when, in 1895, the Indian National Congress held its eleventh session in Poona, Mr. Gokhale was elected as one of its Secretaries.
('12', 238, 1, 15, 516654) In 1897 he was selected, along with other prominent public men of Bombay, to go to England and give evidence before the Welby Commission of Indian Expenditure.
('12', 238, 1, 16, 516814) There, thanks to his excellent training, he was able to stand the severe heckling to which the expert Commissions subjected him, and showed a thorough grasp of principles and mastery of details.
('12', 238, 1, 17, 517009) The character of the man was brought out in connection with some letters which he addressed to the British Press on the plague administration in India.
('12', 238, 1, 18, 517161) When he returned
('12', 238, 2, 19, 517178) 1 1. Mahadev Govind Ranade (1842 1901) ; economist, historian and social reformer; became judge of Bombay High Court in 1893 ; author of Rise of the Maratha Power, Essays in Indian Economics and other books.
('12', 239, 0, 1, 517386) 240 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 239, 1, 2, 517428) to India, he was called upon to substantiate his charges, and, on his friends, who had furnished him with the information, failing to come forward to support him, Mr. Gokhale acted in accordance with the best traditions of public life and offered a generous apology.
('12', 239, 1, 3, 517695) For this gentlemanly act, Mr. Gokhale suffered a great deal of unpopularity in some quarters.
('12', 239, 1, 4, 517789) During 1900 and 1901, Mr. Gokhale was an elected member of the Bombay Legislative Council where he did most useful work.
('12', 239, 1, 5, 517910) In 1902, he was elected a member of the Supreme Legislative Council, which is presided over by the Viceroy of India.
('12', 239, 1, 6, 518027) His first Budget speech came as a revelation to the public.
('12', 239, 1, 7, 518087) Ever since, his speech on the occasion of the Budget has been looked forward to with eager interest.
('12', 239, 1, 8, 518188) His mastery of facts and figures and his detailed knowledge of administrative problems, together with his command of simple, clear, vigorous expression and earnestness of purpose, call forth the admiration of even his opponents.
('12', 239, 1, 9, 518417) Some of the most highly placed officials in India are his personal friends, and even Lord Curzon recognized in Mr. Gokhale ‘a foeman not unworthy of his steel”.
('12', 239, 1, 10, 518578) The Viceroy is reported to have said that it was a pleasure to cross swords with Mr. Gokhale and that Mr. Gokhale was the ablest Indian he had come across, and., in token of his admiration for his ability and character, decorated him with the title of C.I.E. The Servants of India Society was formed by Mr. Gokhale in 1905. Mr. Gokhale believes that the Motherland is greatly in need of men who will devote their lives to willing service, and it is through the medium of this Society that he is training men for the noble work of educating the people of India in matters concerning their physical and moral welfare.
('12', 239, 1, 11, 519194) In the same year Mr. Gokhale went on a mission to England, on behalf of the Bombay Public, and, just before leaving again for India, he received a pressing invitation to become the President of the forthcoming Congress at Benares.
('12', 239, 1, 12, 519425) Mr. Gokhale was not at all well at the time, and would have been excused from the arduous duties, but he at last yielded to the public demand.
('12', 239, 1, 13, 519568) The speech delivered by Mr. Gokhale as President dealt in a masterly manner with Lord Curzon’s administration, the Partition of Bengal, the Swadeshi movement, and the demand of the Indian people for a greater share in the Government of their own country.
('12', 239, 1, 14, 519823) It is not possible this brief outline of Mr. Gokhale’s career, to go further into this and other speeches, but we would recommend readers to obtain a copy of Mr. Gokhale’s published speeches and study them.
('12', 239, 1, 15, 520030) We cannot do better than conclude by quoting the closing lines of the
('12', 240, 0, 1, 520100) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 241
('12', 240, 1, 2, 520141) excellent introduction to Mr. Natesan’s publication, The Speeches of the Hon.
('12', 240, 1, 3, 520219) Mr. G. K. Gokhale, from which we have gleaned the facts for this sketch ;
('12', 240, 2, 4, 520293) Magnanimous by nature, he seldom wounds the feelings of his adversary even when he hits the hardest.
('12', 240, 2, 5, 520394) Identified as he is with the moderate school of political thought, he is far from being a party man.
('12', 240, 2, 6, 520495) Scorning all mere strife, his great anxiety is to unite all parties by the common tie of patriotism.
('12', 240, 2, 7, 520596) Brought up in a school of severe self examination, he is always on the guard against the insidious influences of the partisan spirit, and will not allow his love of his fellow countrymen to be affected by irrelevance distinction.
('12', 240, 2, 8, 520826) Chaste in thought, word and deed, a master of lucid exposition, a speaker who inspires without inflaming, a citizen who is not afraid of strife but loves amity, a worker who can obey as well as command, a solider of progress with invincible faith in his cause—Mr, Gokhale is indeed a perfect Servant of India.

('12', 240, 8, 18, 522007) So far as he could see, therefore, Mr. Gokhale would be able to give two days to Cape Town, one day to Kimberly, from which place an invitation had already been received, and would reach Johannesburg about the 27th October.
('12', 240, 8, 19, 522231) He could give the Transvaal about ten days, most of which time could be passed in Johannesburg.

('12', 243, 4, 11, 527685) 203. DEATH OF MR. HUME
('12', 243, 5, 12, 527708) By the last English mail comes the news of the death of Mr. A.O. Hume 2, who was known as the “Father of the Indian National Congress”.
('12', 243, 5, 13, 527844) We give elsewhere tributes to his memory reprinted from India.
('12', 243, 5, 14, 527907) Real friends of India are so rare that we feel specially grateful to those who have taken pains to understand the peculiar and in many ways unfortunate position of India in the British Empire.
('12', 243, 5, 15, 528100) Too often we find that retired Civil Servants of India are out of sympathy with the Indian people.
('12', 243, 5, 16, 528199) This was not the case with the late Mr. Hume.
('12', 243, 5, 17, 528245) He believed that it was not beneath his dignity to meet Indians on an equal footing.
('12', 243, 5, 18, 528330) He worked side by side with the leaders of the people, encouraging them with his kindly sympathy and urging them on to higher and nobler things.
('12', 243, 5, 19, 528475) We learn that, even though his strength failed him, his enthusiasm never flagged.
('12', 243, 5, 20, 528557) The memory of such noble men renews again our drooping faith in the righteousness of the British people.
('12', 243, 5, 21, 528662) We still hope and trust that England can produce men of the stamp of Mr. Hume—men who will stand up for justice, cost what it may.
('12', 243, 5, 22, 528793) By the death of Mr. A.O. Hume, India has lost a true friend.
('12', 243, 6, 23, 528854) Indian Opinion, 31 8 1912
('12', 243, 7, 24, 528880) 1 He arrived in Durban from India with Mrs. Polak on September 4. 2 Allen Octavian Hume; one of Sir George Trevelyan’s “Competition Wallahs”, was Magistrate of Etawah during the Mutiny; became Secretary to the Government of India in 1870 and did commendable work organizing the Revenue, Agricultural and Commercial departments; author of Old Man’s Hope, The Star in the East, The Rising Tide, etc., the last being on political activity in India.

('12', 244, 1, 2, 529367) 204. RAILWAY TRAVELLING IN THE TRANSVAAL
('12', 244, 2, 3, 529408) We publish in another column the correspondence that has passed between Miss Schlesin and the Railway Administration.
('12', 244, 2, 4, 529526) 1 The question raised by Miss Schlesin is undoubtedly one of very great delicacy, and requires, on her part, a great deal of tact and carefulness.
('12', 244, 2, 5, 529673) It is equally necessary, on the part of the Administration, to use tact and discretion.
('12', 244, 2, 6, 529761) We consider that, in her capacity as Honorary Secre tary of the Indian Women’s Association, Miss Schlesin could take up no other position, consistently with her dignity and with the interests that are under her charge.
('12', 244, 2, 7, 529980) She could not properly leave her co workers, who are travelling with her in a common mission and separate herself from them during the railway journey.
('12', 244, 2, 8, 530132) That would be carrying too far the doctrine of concession to popular prejudice, unreasonable and unreasoned as it is; and we think that Miss Schlesin, in spite of her natural desire to conciliate the Railway Department, is in no way bound by an administration of regulations which is not at all required for the purpose for which the Regulations are intended.
('12', 244, 3, 9, 530492) Indian Opinion, 31 8 1912

('12', 244, 5, 13, 530826) That is exactly what happened the other day to five Indians at Cape Town.
('12', 244, 5, 14, 530900) 2 Mr. Justice Searle, who heard the application of the Indians, said that the case was one of distinct hardship, but he was obliged to carry out the plain meaning of the law, having no discretion.
('12', 244, 5, 15, 531097) All we can say is that there is something very seriously

('12', 247, 1, 2, 536380) 207. MR. AND MRS.
('12', 247, 2, 3, 536398) Mr. and Mrs. Polak received a hearty welcome from the Indians of Durban on their return from India.
('12', 247, 2, 4, 536498) Perhaps this is not the place, owing to Mr. Polak’s intimate connection with this journal, to review his work 1. But, before he takes the editorial reins in his own hands again, it may not be considered out of place to remark upon his public work, apart from his editorial activity which, as our readers are aware, is a labour of love with him.
('12', 247, 2, 5, 536843) Mr. Polak, by his tact, ability and perseverance, has been able to rouse public opinion in India in such a manner that, probably, there is no question which occupies so much attention and commands such unanimous advocacy as the South African Indian.
('12', 247, 2, 6, 537093) His persistent effort has enabled the Hon’ble Mr. Gokhale to achieve the brilliant result he did on the indenture question.
('12', 247, 2, 7, 537217) His advocacy filled the exhausted passive resistance chest 2 and, thanks to his unremitting zeal, the Government of India is posted up with the fullest particulars about our
('12', 247, 3, 8, 537391) 1 Polak arrived in India towards the middle of November, 1911, primarily as a representative of the Transvaal British Indian Association to lay the problems of African Indians before the Indian public.
('12', 247, 3, 9, 537593) Soon after his arrival he received a cable from the Natal Indian Congress authorizing him to represent that body in his dealings with the Indian Government and public organizations.
('12', 247, 3, 10, 537775) He was instructed to lay great stress on the abolition of the £3 Tax.
('12', 247, 3, 11, 537845) Polak addressed many letters and petitions on the subject to the Secretary, Department of Commerce and Industry.
('12', 247, 3, 12, 537958) His other communications to the Government of India dealt with the Transvaal Townships Amendment Act of 1908, the Gold Law, and the Transvaal Government’s refusal to recognize “polygamous marriages” contracted under Muslim Law.
('12', 247, 3, 13, 538186) He also addressed the Calcutta session of the Indian National Congress held between December 26 and 29 on the Indian situation in South Africa (“Mr. Polak at the National Congress”, p.207) and his speech was received with great ovation.
('12', 247, 3, 14, 538423) He also surveyed the South African situation in a speech delivered at the sixth session of the All India Muslim League.
('12', 247, 3, 15, 538543) Other meetings he addressed passed resolutions condemning the treatment of Indians in South Africa and demanded that the Indian Government take steps to end their grievances and abolish the system of indentured labour.
('12', 247, 3, 16, 538762) The memorial that the Sheriff’s meeting (pp.
('12', 247, 3, 17, 538807) 299 300) addressed to the Viceroy was the outcome of Polak’s “stirring speech”.
('12', 247, 3, 18, 538887) Sir Jamsetjee Jeejeebhoy, the chairman of this meeting, entertained Polak at a banquet on August 7 and warmly praised Polak’s services to the African Indians’ cause.
('12', 247, 3, 19, 539053) Vide also “Polak’s Work”, 1 7 1911. 2 While Polak may generally have collected money for the Passive Resistance fund during his tour of India, the reference here is perhaps specifically to the donation of Rs. 25,000 by Ratan Tata announced at the Sheriff’s meeting in Bombay; vide “The Sheriff’s Meeting”, 10 8 1912.

('12', 248, 1, 3, 539423) Mr. Polak could have done little but for the zealous support ungrudgingly given to him by Mrs. Polak.
('12', 248, 1, 4, 539525) Nor has Mrs. Polak’s work been of a neutral character.

('12', 248, 3, 11, 540117) 208. HIS HIGHNESS THE AGA KHAN
('12', 248, 4, 12, 540148) The community has every reason to congratulate itself on the reported decision of His Highness the Aga Khan to visit South Africa.
('12', 248, 4, 13, 540279) His Highness is the High Priest of one of the most important sections of the Mahomedans of India.
('12', 248, 4, 14, 540377) He is the undisputed political leader of Indian Mahomedans, and is a cultured Indian, taking an active and intelligent part in all that concerns the welfare of India.
('12', 248, 4, 15, 540544) As a politician of broad views, he is striving to bring Mahomedans and Hindus more closely together.
('12', 248, 4, 16, 540645) It is said to be due to his efforts that the London Branch of the All India Muslim League has suggested more intimate co operation with the Indian National Congress.
('12', 248, 4, 17, 540811) What is perhaps of most importance to us is, that His Highness has always espoused our cause and spoken out fearlessly on more than one occasion on our behalf.
('12', 248, 4, 18, 540971) It was well, therefore, that the prominent Indian Associations of South Africa should have sent invitations to him and suggested that his visit may synchronize with the Hon’ble Mr. Gokhale’s.
('12', 248, 4, 19, 541163) 1 It would, undoubtedly, be a great thing in every way if we could have both these distinguished visitors at the same time.
('12', 248, 4, 20, 541287) But, whenever His Highness comes, we know that he is sure of a royal welcome from the whole of the Indian community throughout South Africa.
('12', 248, 5, 21, 541428) Indian Opinion, 7 9 1912

('12', 249, 1, 2, 541664) 209. THOU, TOO, BRUTUS!
('12', 249, 2, 3, 541688) Elsewhere our readers will peruse with pain, horror and, no doubt, indignation, the remarks that a Judge of the Natal Bench deemed it necessary to make in the course of his address to the Jury in an Indian murder case.
('12', 249, 2, 4, 541907) His Lordship allowed himself quite gratui tously to argue from the particular to the general.
('12', 249, 2, 5, 542001) In the case in question, it appears that the murdered woman, who was employed on a sugar estate, had two “husbands”.
('12', 249, 2, 6, 542118) In rightly calling such a state of affairs an abomination, the Judge said “it was a common form of abomination amongst these Indians”.
('12', 249, 2, 7, 542253) The context shows that the word “these” is not used to specialize Indians but it is used to empha size the Judge’s opinion that it is Indians he is thinking of and no others in this connection.
('12', 249, 2, 8, 542447) So that the Judge’s sweeping condemnation includes the whole Indian community.
('12', 249, 2, 9, 542526) Evidently, the Jury, being men of the world, knew better.
('12', 249, 2, 10, 542584) In their rider to the verdict of guilty, they drew attention to the fact that on sugar estates “thousands of men were congregated with a very small percentage of women”.
('12', 249, 2, 11, 542754) Those who know the conditions of life on estates wonder that there is any purity of life left among their inmates, and that vio lent crimes are as rare as they are.
('12', 249, 3, 12, 542919) We take leave to say that the Judge does not know the Indian community at all.
('12', 249, 3, 13, 542998) We doubt if he has met with even half a dozen Indian cases of the kind mentioned by him.
('12', 249, 3, 14, 543087) The Judge, in failing even to distinguish between Indians actually undergoing indenture and free Indians, has shown a hastiness of judgment which one rarely associates with the High Court Judge.
('12', 249, 3, 15, 543282) If the learned Judge had cared to probe the truth, he would have found that such cases are not to be found in any numbers among the free Indian population, that they are not of frequent occurrence even among indentured Indians, that, where they do exist, they are really not marriages at all, but that the women, living in such circumstances, are nothing but helpless prostitutes who have fallen a prey to the lust of men; and these consider the few women, whom the law requires to be brought as a sop to conventional mora lity, as their natural prey.
('12', 249, 3, 16, 543834) If the Judge had gone still deeper, he would have discovered that the men were not mere animals when they left India, and that most men, living in their position would have lived like
('12', 250, 0, 1, 544018) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 251
('12', 250, 1, 2, 544059) them; and that, therefore, it was the system that was at fault.
('12', 250, 1, 3, 544123) 1 If the Judge had taken pains to make the inquiry we have suggested, he could have, with advantage, drawn attention to the evil of the system rather than unnecessarily hunt the feelings of Indians by his ill conceived remarks.
('12', 250, 1, 4, 544351) Here there is scope for the activity of our Colonial born friends, and also, though not to the same extent, for the Congress.
('12', 250, 1, 5, 544477) The former can investigate the matter and make a detailed protest showing how utterly baseless the remarks are.
('12', 250, 1, 6, 544589) The latter should promptly address the Department of Justice, drawing attention to the extraordinary summing up of the Judge and courting an inquiry.
('12', 250, 2, 7, 544739) Indian Opinion, 7 9 1912

('12', 255, 6, 7, 556593) Indian Opinion, 14 9 1912
('12', 255, 7, 8, 556619) 211. OURSELVES
('12', 255, 8, 9, 556634) The Trust Deed 3 which we publish in this issue, and which is in course of registration, marks a step forward in our work.
('12', 255, 8, 10, 556757) Mr. Gandhi ceases to be the sole legal owner of the concern known as the International Printing Press, where this journal is printed.
('12', 255, 8, 11, 556891) Nearly eight years ago we migrated to Phoenix, the idea being that the workers might be able to look more to the land for their sustenance than to the proceeds of the sale of Indian Opinion and the advertisements inserted in it.
('12', 255, 8, 12, 557120) During this period we have not given that attention to the land which it was thought we should be able to give, and we have certainly not been able to pay our way by means of agriculture.
('12', 255, 9, 13, 557308) 1 The earlier version makes no reference to Schedule B. 2 Clause 9 and Schedule A were added later.
('12', 255, 9, 14, 557408) 3 Vide the preceding item.
('12', 256, 0, 1, 557435) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 257
('12', 256, 1, 2, 557476) the journal itself has not been self supporting is a widely known fact.
('12', 256, 2, 3, 557548) The assistance received by it from Mr. Tata’s gift of 1909 enabled it to tide over a crisis in its career.
('12', 256, 3, 4, 557655) We have also come to the conclusion that, consistently with our ideals, we could not accept advertisements for paying our way.
('12', 256, 3, 5, 557782) We believe that the system of advertisement is bad in itself, in that it sets up insidious competition, to which we are opposed, 3 and often lends itself to misrepresentation on a large scale; and that, if we may not use this journal for the purpose of supporting us entirely, we have no right to cater for and use our time in setting up advertisements.
('12', 256, 3, 6, 558136) We have always used our discrimination and rejected many advertisements which we could not conscientiously take.
('12', 256, 3, 7, 558249) Our friends and well wishers, who have hitherto extended their support to us, will not, we hope, take it amiss if we discontinue the practice of inserting advertisements.
('12', 256, 3, 8, 558420) The object of issuing this paper is twofold 4: to voice and work to remove the grievances of the British Indians of South Africa, and to do educative work, by publishing matter of an elevating character.
('12', 256, 3, 9, 558624) We hope that our readers will appreciate our position, and continue to give us their support, by subscribing to the paper.
('12', 256, 4, 10, 558747) Indian Opinion, 14 9 1912

('12', 258, 1, 2, 562315) Laughton, in his recent letter 1 to The Natal Mercury already quoted by us, points out that the Immigration Officer, appointed to administer the Natal Immigration Act at Durban, taken upon himself to decide who shall and who shall not immigrate into the Cape Colony, where the law is of a different kind, and where appeal may usually be made, and has, in fact, not seldom successfully been made, to the Supreme Court against decisions of the Immigration Officers appointed under the Provincial statute.
('12', 258, 1, 3, 562818) We are quite sure that, whilst stationed in Natal, Mr. Cousins can exercise no authority whatever under the Cape Immi gration Law, whose interpretation does not fall to our local division of the Supreme Court.
('12', 258, 1, 4, 563028) He has, actually, exercised an authority not vested in him, and in preventing Mr. Laughton’s client—there are other cases of which complaint has been made—from proceeding to his destination in the neighbouring Colony,—from proceeding to his destination in the neighbouring Colony, thereby denying him access to the Courts of that Province, Mr. Cousins would appear to have incurred a serious liability.
('12', 258, 1, 5, 563431) We have reason to believe that suitable action is being taken in the proper quarters.
('12', 258, 1, 6, 563517) It is intolerable that Immigration Officers shouldbe allowed to proceed as though existing Provincial statutes did not, in point of fact, exist, and as if they had been already superseded by a Union measure that may, after all, never mature.
('12', 258, 1, 7, 563759) If anything further were needed to prove to the Imperial Government the impossibility of leaving enormous powers in the hands of apparently irresponsible and certainly arbitrary officials, Mr. Cousins could not have offered a more effective demonstration of the fact.
('12', 258, 2, 8, 564027) Indian Opinion, 14 9 1912
