('12', 259, 0, 1, 564925) 260 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 259, 1, 2, 564967) 214. OURSELVES
('12', 259, 2, 3, 564982) It is more than seven years ago that this journal began to be printed at Phoenix.
('12', 259, 2, 4, 565064) We are now taking a step forward.
('12', 259, 2, 5, 565098) So far the legal proprietor has been Mr. Gandhi, but the ownership is now being transferred to [a board of] Trustees, and the objectives which will govern the management of Phoenix have been precisely laid down.
('12', 259, 2, 6, 565310) We feel this is a step in the right direction and we are sure our readers will feel the same.
('12', 259, 2, 7, 565404) The paper has never been in a position to pay its way.
('12', 259, 2, 8, 565459) It is here needless to go into the reasons for that.
('12', 259, 2, 9, 565512) It, however, needs to be recalled on this occasion that the paper would have been in dire straits if Mr. Tata’s generous help had not been drawn upon to meet its needs.
('12', 259, 2, 10, 565681) When the workers decided to settle in Phoenix and start a journal there, it was expected that the income from it and the land would not only give them enough to live on but also enable them to put by substantial savings, for they were to be the masters of whatever profit might accrue from the enterprise.
('12', 259, 2, 11, 565987) Experience has shown that the assumption was incorrect.
('12', 259, 2, 12, 566043) We realized that the Phoenix way of life could not be reconciled with monetary gain.
('12', 259, 2, 13, 566128) And so, for the last several years, the Phoenix settlement has been worked on that basis.
('12', 259, 2, 14, 566218) Our principal object was that, while living by agriculture, we should give of our best in the service of the people and publish the paper for them.
('12', 259, 2, 15, 566366) We have not so far succeeded in that aim.
('12', 259, 2, 16, 566408) We gave up job work many years ago.
('12', 259, 2, 17, 566444) We now feel that we should also discontinue the practice of publishing advertisements.
('12', 259, 2, 18, 566531) We believed then that advertisements were a good thing to have but on reflection we see that the practice is wholly undesirable.
('12', 259, 2, 19, 566660) Advertisements are inserted by people who are impatient to get rich, in order that they may gain over their rivals.
('12', 259, 2, 20, 566776) They are so much in fashion these days that any and every kind of advertisement is published and paid for.
('12', 259, 2, 21, 566883) This is one of the sorriest features of modern civilization, and for our part we wish to be rid of it.
('12', 259, 2, 22, 566986) If, however, we published non commercial advertisements, which serve a public purpose, free of charge, they would fill the entire number each time, so we shall only accept them against payment.
('12', 259, 2, 23, 567180) Other advertisements, we shall stop publishing forthwith.
('12', 259, 2, 24, 567238) As for advertisements which we
('12', 260, 0, 1, 567269) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 261
('12', 260, 1, 2, 567310) have on hand, we shall try to negotiate with our clients and free ourselves of the commitments.
('12', 260, 1, 3, 567406) We shall then be able to work more on the land and more effectively fulfil the main object of the Trust Deed 1
('12', 260, 2, 4, 567517) which we publish in this issue.
('12', 260, 2, 5, 567549) We believe that the proposed changes will enhance our capacity for public service.
('12', 260, 2, 6, 567632) We also hope that we shall be able to publish worthier and more valuable [reading] matter in the journal.
('12', 260, 2, 7, 567738) It has been our endeavour daily to add to its value as an instrument of moral education.
('12', 260, 2, 8, 567827) There are two, and only two, reasons for its existence: to strive to end the hardships suffered by Indians in this country and to promote moral education.
('12', 260, 2, 9, 567982) The second purpose can be best served by our improving our way of life.
('12', 260, 2, 10, 568054) That is why we are doing our best to eschew the commercial aspects of our work, such as jobbing and advertisements.
('12', 260, 2, 11, 568170) Progressively as we live up to the ideals enumerated in the title deed, we shall be able to give our readers more useful material.
('12', 260, 2, 12, 568301) We want all Indians to help us in this.

('12', 260, 5, 15, 568383) 215. MAHOMEDAN WIVES
('12', 260, 6, 16, 568404) The letter, that we reproduce in another column, from the India Office to the South Africa British Indian Committee, shows that the representations that have been made from time to time, both to the Imperial and Indian Governments, seem to have borne fruit.
('12', 260, 6, 17, 568662) The India and Colonial Offices are, we learn, in consultation on the question of the immigration of Mahomedan wives into South Africa.
('12', 260, 6, 18, 568797) Matters were bad enough when the Fatima and Sukina cases were decided, but Mr. Cousins’ now notorious circular 2, which took occasion also to suggest that Natal Indians were in the habit of introducing women into the Province for immoral purposes, for which there is absolutely no warrant in the past history of the community, has brought them to a crisis.
('12', 260, 6, 19, 569154) They cannot be allowed to remain where they are, nor can the South African Indian community, who are so greatly prejudiced by these horrible judicial and administrative blunders, submit to the insult and humiliation imposed thereby.

('12', 261, 3, 5, 569987) 216. IMMIGRATION AUTHORITIES AGAIN CENSURED
('12', 261, 4, 6, 570031) The appeal of Natha Ooka, 1 before the Cape Provincial Division of the Supreme Court, judgment wherein is reported in another column, has once more afforded to the Court an opportunity of offering its views on the present administration of the immigration laws of the Province and, incidentally, of laws of a like nature in the other Provinces of the Union.
('12', 261, 4, 7, 570389) The Court has once again criticized most strongly the harrying policy adopted by the authorities towards lawful Indian residents of South Africa seeking readmission to their homes in this country, and has thus completely justified the many and bitter complaints that are heard all over the Union against the Government’s repeated breaches of the spirit of the immigration law.
('12', 261, 5, 8, 570766) Only recently the cape Courts had to exclude as prohibited immi grants men domiciled in the Province, and who had been delayed a few days beyond the duration of their permits owing to causes over which they had no control, due partly to the dilatory tactics of the Natal Immigration Officer.
('12', 261, 5, 9, 571058) It will be for the Imperial and Indian Governments to keep such incidents in view when considering the draft legislation that is promised for next session.
('12', 261, 5, 10, 571214) In the case under discussion, the appellant was apparently able to afford the costly luxury of expensive litigation, a privilege denied to the average poor applicant for readmission.
('12', 261, 5, 11, 571397) The legislation that is contemplated ought,
('12', 261, 6, 12, 571441) 1 Natha Ouka, a Cape businessman, left for India in 1906 retaining his partnership in a business in East London.
('12', 261, 6, 13, 571554) On his return in July, 1911, he was prohibited from landing.
('12', 261, 6, 14, 571615) On appeal, Justice Buchanan of the Cape Division of the Supreme Court granted the application with costs and, condemning the Immigration Officer’s action, observed that “more judiciaousness in the administration of the spirit of the Act” would be far better “in such cases” than “the strict letter of the law”.
('12', 261, 6, 15, 571926) Indian Opinion, 28 9 1912. 2 Vide also “More Official Illegality”, 14 9 1912.
('12', 262, 0, 1, 572004) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 263
('12', 262, 1, 2, 572045) in our opinion, to provide a cheap and speedy remedy against official blunders of the type condemned by Sir John Buchanan, and we trust that His Majesty’s Government will make it their business to see that it is provided.
('12', 262, 1, 3, 572267) The so called appeal boards contemplated by this year’s defunct Bill were a sorry farce, and will have to be replaced by very much more efficient machinery if substantial justice is to be done.
('12', 262, 1, 4, 572461) South African Indians cannot afford that their vital rights and most intimate interests should be jeopardized by the high handed autocracy of the “tin Tsars” of the Immigration Department, backed up, as is know, by a Government that pretend to the Imperial authorities a most solicitous concern for the welfare of the Indian community.

('12', 262, 4, 9, 572884) Mr. Gokhale leaves for South Africa today by the s.s.
('12', 262, 4, 10, 572938) Dover Castle, and he is, therefore, due to arrive in Cape Town about the 26th instant.

('12', 262, 4, 15, 573877) 2 Mr. Gokhale’s firmness of principle should endear him the more to Indians in this country, and his example should encourage them, as occasion demands, to do likewise, in the name and for the honour of India.

('12', 263, 2, 3, 574391) [LAWLEY, ] Aso Sud 6 [October 16, 1912] 1
('12', 263, 3, 4, 574433) HARILAL, I have your letter after so many months.

('12', 263, 3, 6, 574527) I have written to Revashankerbhai about your attending the Congress.
('12', 263, 4, 7, 574596) You have not understood the step I have taken regarding Sorabji.

('12', 263, 4, 11, 574909) That is why I would not encourage Medh to be a barrister.
('12', 263, 4, 12, 574967) How then could I ever encourage you [to become one]?
('12', 263, 4, 13, 575020) If I did, all my ideas would go by the board; though, at present, you will not appreciate them.
('12', 263, 4, 14, 575116) We shall discuss them if and when we meet.
('12', 263, 4, 15, 575159) Just now you should only attend to the strengthening of your character in your own way—that is all I want.
('12', 263, 4, 16, 575266) I am sure you will change your ideas in future.
('12', 263, 4, 17, 575314) You have again succumbed to passion in regard to Chanchal.
('12', 263, 4, 18, 575373) I can well understand it.

('12', 264, 1, 2, 576430) 219. MR. GOKHALE’S VISIT
('12', 264, 2, 3, 576455) So far as can be ascertained at present, the following is the Johannesburg programme regarding the Hon.
('12', 264, 2, 4, 576559) Mr. Gokhale’s visit.
('12', 264, 2, 5, 576580) A special train carrying about 500 passengers will leave Park Station at about 10 p.m.
('12', 264, 2, 6, 576667) on the 27th instant, to meet the Diamond Express bringing Mr. Gokhale, at Klerksdorp, at about 2 o’clock in the morn ing.
('12', 264, 2, 7, 576789) The coach that will be specially reserved for Mr. Gokhale and party from Kimberley will be detached from the Express and attached to the special.
('12', 264, 2, 8, 576935) Mr. Gokhale will receive an address at Klerksdorp, and will probably drive through the town.
('12', 264, 2, 9, 577028) The special will leave Klerks dorp on the return journey at about 10 a.m., reaching Potchefstroom about the middle of the day, when there will be a prolonged halt to enable Mr. Gokhale to receive an address from the local community and to drive to the Experimental Farm.
('12', 264, 2, 10, 577299) The special will then proceed to Krugersdorp, where there will be another brief halt to enable the local community to present an address.
('12', 264, 2, 11, 577437) The train will then run to Park without a break, reaching there exactly at 4 p.m.
('12', 264, 2, 12, 577519) Here Mr. Gokhale will be received by (in addition to the Indian community) the Mayor of Johannesburg and other European townsmen.
('12', 264, 2, 13, 577649) The party will then proceed to the platform erected for the occasion at the station where, under the Chairmanship of the Mayor, addressed will be presented.
('12', 264, 2, 14, 577806) The address on behalf of the British Indian Association will be read; the others will be formally handed to Mr. Gokhale, without being read, by the Chairmen of the respective Societies—the Hamidia Islamic Society, the Hindu Community, the Tamil Benefit Society and the Patidar Association.
('12', 264, 2, 15, 578096) In order that the function may be finished within an hour, beyond a speech of welcome by the Chairman of the British Indian Association.
('12', 264, 2, 16, 578233) In order that the function may be finished within an hour, beyond a speech of welcome by the Chairman of the British Indian Association there will be no speeches on behalf of the Reception Committee.
('12', 264, 2, 17, 578433) His Worship the Mayor will then say a few words and call upon the Hon.
('12', 264, 2, 18, 578504) Mr. Gokhale to reply, where after the meeting will disperse with the singing of the National Anthem.
('12', 264, 2, 19, 578605) On the 30th, a meeting of the European Committee will take place at Mr. Hosken’s house to enable Mr. Gokhale to meet the Committee and to discuss the whole Indian question.
('12', 264, 2, 20, 578778) On the 31st, there will be a Banquet at the Masonic Hall.
('12', 264, 2, 21, 578836) Arrangements are also being made to enable the European townsmen to hear Mr. Gokhale.
('12', 264, 2, 22, 578922) The Indian Women’s
('12', 265, 0, 1, 578941) 266 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 265, 1, 2, 578983) Association will give an At Home at a place and time to be appointed.
('12', 265, 1, 3, 579053) Saturday and Sunday Mr. Gokhale will pass at Tolstoy Farm.
('12', 265, 1, 4, 579112) During the week following, he will interview the Ministers, and, immediately afterwards, proceed to Natal.
('12', 265, 1, 5, 579219) Mr. Kallenbach has placed his residence at Mountain View at the disposal of the Indian community, and offices are being engaged for him in town, where he may receive visitors during the day.

('12', 265, 3, 7, 579437) 220. INTERVIEW TO “CAPE ARGUS” 1
('12', 265, 4, 8, 579470) CAPE TOWN, October 22, 1912
('12', 265, 5, 9, 579498) Mr. Gandhi, interviewed by the Argus regarding Mr. Gokhale’s visit, said he had come with the knowledge of the Indian Government, but entirely on his own initiative.
('12', 265, 5, 10, 579664) He considered it his duty as an Imperialist to investigate the whole Indian question in South Africa for himself, and to make the acquaintance of the Union Ministers.
('12', 265, 5, 11, 579831) Mr. Gokhale had not yet settled what position he was going to discuss and what he wanted discussed.
('12', 265, 5, 12, 579931) There were no outstanding questions, but certain standing grievances in the Cape, Transvaal and Natal.
('12', 265, 5, 13, 580034) He (Mr. Gandhi) was not hopeful that Mr. Gokhale’s visit would result in a final settlement of all questions; they were too large to be settled in the course of a single visit by one distinguished legislator.
('12', 265, 5, 14, 580243) He hoped, however, that the visit would result in a better understanding between Euro peans and Indians, and that a better tone would be adopted by the two communities towards each other.
('12', 265, 5, 15, 580431) That certainly was part of the mission that brought Mr. Gokhale here.
('12', 265, 5, 16, 580501) Mr. Gokhale informed him that the feeling in India over the South African Question was very intense and there was no question over which all sections in India were so much agreed as this.
('12', 265, 6, 17, 580689) Indian Opinion, 26 10 1912
('12', 265, 7, 18, 580716) 1 This interview was given soon after Gokhale’s arrival at Cape Town on October 22.

('12', 266, 1, 2, 580841) 221. SPEECH AT CAPE TOWN RECEPTION TO GOKHALE 1
('12', 266, 2, 3, 580889) October 22, 1912
('12', 266, 3, 4, 580906) The Mayor (Mr. Harry Hands) presided .
('12', 266, 3, 5, 580945) Dr. Abdurahman and other leaders of the Asiatic community also occupied seats on the platform.
('12', 266, 4, 6, 581040) The Mayor, in opening the proceedings, said they were met together to extend a welcome to a very distinguished Indian subject of His Majesty the King; a gentleman who was a member of the Council of the Viceroy of India, and who had come to the Union of South Africa, with, he believed, the full consent of the Union Government, to inquire at first hand into an economic difficulty which had arisen in their midst and which their fellow Indian subjects had been feeling for some time.
('12', 266, 4, 7, 581524) He had pleasure in extending to him a warm welcome to the Mother City of South Africa, and ventured to express the hope that the result of his mission would be the solution of the difficulty in a manner satisfactory to all concerned.
('12', 266, 4, 8, 581758) (Applause.) .
('12', 266, 5, 9, 581772) Mr. M. K. Gandhi said the name of Mr. Gokhale was sacred to him; Mr. Gokhale was his political teacher, and whatever he had been able to do in the service of his fellow countrymen in South Africa—of which he claimed to be a citizen—was due to Mr. Gokhale.
('12', 266, 5, 10, 582028) (Cheers.) This South African question was not a new one to him; but they loved him not only for his interest in that question, but because of his life’s work.
('12', 266, 5, 11, 582187) Although he was a candid critic of the Indian Government, he was also a friend to it.
('12', 266, 5, 12, 582273) (Applause.) He thought it a hopeful sign that they had this representative gathering over which the Mayor of the city presided.
('12', 266, 5, 13, 582401) And the hospitality accorded to Mr. Gokhale showed that though there had been hard knocks given between the European and Indian communities, there was not bitterness.
('12', 266, 5, 14, 582568) In every town where these meetings were to be held, the Mayors had signified their intentions to preside.
('12', 266, 5, 15, 582674) Mr. Gokhale had come to help them in bringing the two peoples closer together, and his mission would let them know that behind this country was another, in which the people were watching its representatives in this country.
('12', 266, 5, 16, 582898) They knew His Highness the Aga Khan was expected to arrive some time next year in connection with this same question.
('12', 266, 5, 17, 583016) 2 The British Indian Association had only just received a letter from His Highness, in which he expressed his intention of arriving in South Africa to study the question at first hand, in so far as it affected his countrymen here.
('12', 266, 5, 18, 583247) But he (Mr. Gandhi) wished to utter one word of warning, and it was this: that many of them had, in their ignorance, false expectation that Mr. Gokhale’s visit would act as a
('12', 266, 6, 19, 583422) 1 The reception was held in the City Hall, Cape Town.
('12', 266, 6, 20, 583476) A number of prominent whites were present and addresses were presented by various organizations.

('12', 267, 1, 3, 583740) He hoped his countrymen would not have those expectations, or, if they had them, that they would dismiss them.
('12', 267, 1, 4, 583851) Mr. Gokhale was certainly going to assist them, but they had to remember that there was nothing so valuable as self help.
('12', 267, 1, 5, 583973) (Applause.) They would have to work out their own salvation, and men like Mr. Gokhale and Mr. Schreinger 1 could only point the way to the solution, and make the path easy.

('12', 267, 6, 13, 584529) 1 William Phillip Schreiner (1857 1919); brother of the well known authoress, Olive Schreiner; Gandhiji noted his “sense of justice” and his friendly feeling for Indians; member of Rhodes’ second Ministry, 1898; barrister and sometime leader of the Cape Bar; twice Attorney General; Prime Minister of Cape Colony, 1898 1900. Eric Walker, historian of South Africa, calls him an outstanding champion of federalism.
('12', 267, 6, 14, 584943) In 1909, he vehemently opposed Section 35 of the draft South Africa Act (of Union)which disfranchised Cape Coloureds, went on their behalf to England and persisted in his efforts even after the House of Lords had passed the bill for unification of South Africa; In march, 1911, Gandhiji contemplated consulting him regarding the Union Immigration Bill; vide Vol. X, “Letter to L. W. Ritch”, 4 3 1911 & “Telegram to L. W. Ritch”, 8 3 1911. The Golden Number (1906 14) of Indian Opinion mentions his strenuous fight for justice for the Indian community; became in 1914 High Commissioner for Union of South Africa in England.
('12', 267, 6, 15, 585566) 2 The meeting, arranged for Gokhale, was held in the Town Hall, which “was crowded to its utmost capacity with members of the Indian community and a large sprinkling of Europeans”.
('12', 267, 6, 16, 585747) After the Mayor, who presided, had made a speech of welcome an address was presented to Gokhale on behalf of the Indian community.
('12', 267, 6, 17, 585878) Gokhale himself in this, the first of his public utterances in South Africa, expressed satisfaction that the system of indentured labour in Natal had been stopped, dwelt briefly on the Indian question in South Africa which he said he would like to study from all standpoints before expressing an opinion on it.
('12', 267, 6, 18, 586189) Gandhiji’s memory of this incident must have been a cherished one, for writing of it without notes several years later in Yeravda Jail, he recalls Gokhale’s speech on the occasion “concise, full of sound judgment, firm but courteous which pleased the Indians and fascinated the Europeans”.

('12', 268, 1, 3, 586905) He regarded Mr. Gokhale as a political asset.
('12', 268, 1, 4, 586951) He referred in glowing terms to Mr. Gokhale’s services and sacrifices in the interest of Fergusson College, and in the cause of education.

('12', 268, 3, 13, 588078) 223. SPEECH AT KIMBERLEY BANQUET TO GOKHALE 1
('12', 268, 4, 14, 588124) [October 26, 1912]
('12', 268, 5, 15, 588143) Mr. Gandhi, who was cordially received, said he thought they might well drink the toast the guest of the evening, if what Mr. Oliver, who was good enough to pay them a visit, had playfully said was true, namely, that Mr. Gokhale had brought with him the much needed rain which the parched land of Kimberley required so badly.
('12', 268, 5, 16, 588469) He only hoped that the rain had reached Johannesburg, and not merely Johannesburg, because he lived there, but throughout the whole Union.
('12', 268, 5, 17, 588608) We Indians were supposed to be a superstitious nation, and he had no doubt many of his countrymen would share his (the speaker’s) superstition that Mr. Gokhale had brought with him the much needed rain.
('12', 268, 5, 18, 588811) (Applause.) But he thought there was another reason also why this toast might be commended, both to their European friends, who had been good enough to respond to the invitation issued by the reception committee, as also to his country men, and it was this, that Mr. Oats was good enough to take the guest of the evening, together with his following, over his great mine, and when he took them over those huge pieces of machinery he (Mr. Gandhi) could not help thinking what a great thing it was.

('12', 269, 0, 1, 589678) 270 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 269, 1, 2, 589720) believer in machinery.
('12', 269, 1, 3, 589743) He for one was quite willing to admit that he could have done with Kimberley even had there been no diamonds and no machinery.
('12', 269, 1, 4, 589870) He was no believer in millions and in diamonds, but he realized that he was now before diamond kings and he therefore bowed his head before them.
('12', 269, 1, 5, 590016) One thing struck him forcibly when watching the machinery, and that was that if they as human beings worked so well together as this marvellous piece of machinery, what a happy family they would be.
('12', 269, 1, 6, 590215) Then, indeed, their swords would be beaten into ploughshares, and the lions would certainly lie down with the lambs.
('12', 269, 1, 7, 590332) He also felt that if one nut in that piece of machinery went loose it was possible for the whole machinery to become disjointed, and to carry that analogy to human beings, they had seen so often that one obstreperous man could break up a whole meeting, and one rogue in a family could damage the reputation of that family.
('12', 269, 1, 8, 590655) Similarly, to take the reverse position, if the chief part of the machinery did its work regularly they found the other pieces working in harmony without being disjointed.
('12', 269, 1, 9, 590827) He (Mr. Gandhi) regarded Mr. Gokhale’s mission as a holy one, and it was a matter of pride to him that Mr. Gokhale had been instrumental in bringing about such a happening in Kimberley as a meeting of the most representative Europeans and Indians at a common board.
('12', 269, 1, 10, 591093) He hoped such gatherings would be multiplied.
('12', 269, 1, 11, 591139) As a humble student of the life and teachings of Tolstoy, he felt also that functions like that were unnecessary, and that they sometimes did a great deal of mischief if only by way of interfering with one’s digestion.
('12', 269, 1, 12, 591358) (Laughter.) But although a student of Tolstoy, for the time being he was prepared to reconcile himself to those functions even, if they brought them together, and if they enabled them to know each other better.
('12', 269, 1, 13, 591569) He recalled the magnificent hymn,
('12', 269, 2, 14, 591603) We shall know each other better
('12', 269, 3, 15, 591635) When the mists have rolled away,
('12', 269, 4, 16, 591668) and though they might have their differences they would know each other better when the mists of ignorance had rolled away.
('12', 269, 4, 17, 591792) His distinguished countryman had come to South Africa in order to dispel those mists of ignorance.
('12', 269, 4, 18, 591891) He had come as the brightest jewel that India could present to them.
('12', 269, 4, 19, 591960) He (Mr. Gandhi) knew that he deeply wounded Mr. Gokhale’s susceptibilities whenever he made mention of what he had done, but he (Mr. Gandhi) had to perform a duty, though painful to him.
('12', 269, 4, 20, 592147) There was no one who could tell them so much of Mr. Gokhale as he could about his life in the political arena of India.
('12', 269, 4, 21, 592267) He it was who gave 20 years of his life to the cause of education for a mere pittance.
('12', 269, 4, 22, 592354) Even today Mr. Gokhale lived in poverty, although he could command riches.
('12', 269, 4, 23, 592429) Hundreds of pounds were always at his disposal whenever he wanted them for public institutions.
('12', 269, 4, 24, 592525) A Viceroy of India carried the burden of Empire on his shoulders for five years (unless he was a Lord Curzon, and then held office for seven), and even then had a train of workers to assist him, but
('12', 270, 0, 1, 592724) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 271
('12', 270, 1, 2, 592765) here was a distinguished countryman of his carrying the burden of Empire on his shoulders unaided and unassisted and undecorated.
('12', 270, 1, 3, 592895) True, he carried the C.I.E., but in his opinion he was worth a much better decoration.
('12', 270, 1, 4, 592982) The decoration that Mr. Gokhale loved best was his love for his countrymen, and the approval of his own conscience.
('12', 270, 1, 5, 593098) To those Indians who were educated with Western ideas he had given a lesson in humility and gentleness.

('12', 272, 4, 10, 597359) 226. INTERVIEW TO “THE TRANSVAAL LEADER” 1
('12', 272, 5, 11, 597402) [JOHANNESBURG, October 30, 1912] 2
('12', 272, 6, 12, 597437) The Hon.
('12', 272, 6, 13, 597446) G. Gokhale is being kept busy receiving a constant stream of people of all classes and complexions at the rooms which have been taken for him in Chudleigh’s Buildings.
('12', 272, 6, 14, 597614) He received a representative of The Transvaal Leader between a visit from Mr. Creswell, the Labour leader, and the introduction of a deputation of Parsees.
('12', 272, 6, 15, 597770) While waiting to see Mr. Gokhale, the Leader representative had a chat with Mr. M. K. Gandhi, the local leader of the Indian people, who suggested that there were certain questions about Mr. Gokhale’s mission which he could personally answer and which it would be an advantage to put to him, from the point of view of economizing Mr. Gokhale’s time.
('12', 272, 6, 16, 598120) Mr. Gandhi first of all cleared up the doubt which exists in many people’s minds as to the official character, or otherwise, of Mr. Gokhale’s visit.
('12', 272, 7, 17, 598269) [QUESTION:] Is Mr. Gokhale the formally appointed representative of the Government of India in this matter?
('12', 272, 7, 18, 598377) No, he comes in his private capacity but with the full knowledge and approval of both the Indian and the Imperial Governments.
('12', 272, 7, 19, 598504) Before sailing from England he had interviews with, among others, the

('12', 273, 7, 15, 600379) In further conversation, Mr. Gandhi expressed his belief, which, he said, was also Mr. Gokhale’s belief, that the problem had been virtually narrowed down to the treatment of the Indian population domiciled in the Union.
('12', 273, 7, 16, 600600) As to that, Mr. Gokhale has, I think, come to the general conclusion that the Indians resident here are entitled to civic equality.
('12', 273, 7, 17, 600732) That is to say, their movement within the Union should not be hampered and, under restrictions of a general character applying to the community at large, they should be allowed freedom of trade.
('12', 273, 8, 18, 600927) How about the Free State?

('12', 273, 8, 20, 601097) Personally, I feel that for yet a few years to come the Free State will retain its policy as far as the holding of land and the carrying on of trade are concerned.

('12', 276, 7, 19, 607114) Wherever Mr. Gokhale had gone there had been the spirit of peace.
('12', 276, 7, 20, 607180) He could only hope that the spirit would not vanish with his departure, but would continue and intensify, because there was not, after all, any reason why they should not all live together under the same flag in peace, amity and friendship.

('12', 281, 1, 2, 616139) 238. LETTER TO G. K. GOKHALE
('12', 281, 2, 3, 616168) DAR ES SALAM, December 4, 1912
('12', 281, 3, 4, 616199) DEAR MR. GOKHALE,
('12', 281, 4, 5, 616217) I have just heard that the Indian mail closes within half an hour from now (9.30 a.m.).
('12', 281, 4, 6, 616305) We are in this place for two more days.
('12', 281, 4, 7, 616345) On receipt of cable from Johannesburg to the effect that the case 1 was found at Lourenco Marques and that it was being forwarded to you, I cabled to you at Mahe.
('12', 281, 4, 8, 616508) 2 I hope you received the cable.
('12', 281, 4, 9, 616541) A cable 3 was also sent to Miss Schlesin, asking her to insure the case.
('12', 281, 4, 10, 616614) And now will you forgive me for all my imperfections?
('12', 281, 4, 11, 616668) I want to be a worthy pupil of yours.
('12', 281, 4, 12, 616706) This is not mock humility but Indian seriousness.
('12', 281, 4, 13, 616756) I want to realize in myself the conception I have of an Eastern pupil.
('12', 281, 4, 14, 616827) We may have many differences of opinion, but you shall still be my pattern in political life.
('12', 281, 4, 15, 616921) One word from the quack physician.
('12', 281, 4, 16, 616956) Ample fasting, strict adhe rence to two meals, entire absence of condiments of all kinds from your food, omission of pulses, tea, coffee, etc., regular taking of Kuhne baths, regular and brisk walking in the country (not the pacing up and down for stimulating thought), ample allowance of olive oil and acid fruit and gradual elimination of cooked food—and you will get rid of your diabetes and add a few more years than you think to your life of service in your present body.
('12', 281, 4, 17, 617433) Mr. Kallenbach wishes to be remembered to you.
('12', 281, 6, 18, 617480) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('12', 282, 4, 5, 618082) From a photostat of the typewritten copy: C. W. 4842
('12', 282, 5, 6, 618135) 239. EDUCATION IN VERNACULARS
('12', 282, 6, 7, 618165) For the first time in the history of Indian education in South Africa, Indian languages are now acknowledged as being necessary as a medium of training Indian children in schools.
('12', 282, 6, 8, 618345) One of the condi tions accepted by the Witwatersrand Central School Board, in con nection with the establishment of an Indian school 2 in Johannesburg, is that the Gujarati language “may be taught as a language and used as a medium of instruction”.
('12', 282, 6, 9, 618594) It strikes us as being remarkable that the Education Department in Natal should have been so blind as not to see that the mother tongue is an absolute essential to school training.
('12', 282, 6, 10, 618775) The position now is that not a single Indian school in Natal, under control, gives instruction through the language of the pupils.
('12', 282, 6, 11, 618906) Nor are Indian vernaculars taught as languages to Indians in the schools, except in one or two cases where the teachers kindly give instruction in those languages after school hours to those who specially wish it.
('12', 282, 6, 12, 619120) Mr. Gokhale, in his farewell speech at Pretoria, laid emphasis on the need for teaching Indian vernaculars in school hours.
('12', 282, 6, 13, 619244) He also rightly pointed out that, so long as such instruction is not given, it is a legitimate excuse for the Indian community to ask for the admission of clerks and others so instructed, for the proper keeping of their bookes.
('12', 282, 6, 14, 619472) But most of all we would urge the importance of the study of

('12', 286, 1, 2, 627438) 241. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH December 20, 1912
('12', 286, 2, 3, 627490) MY DEAR LOWER HOUSE,
('12', 286, 3, 4, 627511) I am now reaching Durban.
('12', 286, 3, 5, 627537) Up to Newcastle I had a compart ment all to myself.
('12', 286, 3, 6, 627589) From Maritzburg it became crowded.
('12', 286, 3, 7, 627624) A native friend usurped my seat whilst I was walking along the platform.
('12', 286, 3, 8, 627697) I thought I would walk and risk losing my seat.
('12', 286, 3, 9, 627745) Could not manage two meals yesterday.
('12', 286, 3, 10, 627783) I shall see what happens today.
('12', 286, 3, 11, 627815) The Indian visit fills me ≈ consideration of it in details sends my brain whizzing.
('12', 286, 3, 12, 627899) Why need I think so much about it?
('12', 286, 3, 13, 627934) One step enough for me.
('12', 286, 3, 14, 627958) That step is the patient to whom I am going.
('12', 286, 3, 15, 628003) He drove out the Indian visit from my thought.
('12', 286, 3, 16, 628050) So much of self.
('12', 286, 3, 17, 628067) Now you are in a seesaw.
('12', 286, 3, 18, 628092) Your mind is a spinning top set in motion at its highest.
('12', 286, 3, 19, 628150) Well, the comfort before us all is that we cannot peep into the future and we cannot control all the forces that mould us.
('12', 286, 3, 20, 628273) Only this we know that one of such forces is ourselves.
('12', 286, 3, 21, 628329) So that our duty is done when we have performed to the best of our ability our own part.
('12', 286, 3, 22, 628418) What is your own part?
('12', 286, 3, 23, 628441) To make up your mind for the immediate future and stick to it manfully.
('12', 286, 3, 24, 628513) You have made up your mind.
('12', 286, 3, 25, 628541) Now it remains to stick to the resolution.
('12', 286, 3, 26, 628584) It means your refusing to waste your time even by your mind idly thinking of other projects which might have been better.
('12', 286, 3, 27, 628706) Do your Hindi, fix up Mountain View and Africa Building, wind up your office and do not worry about Call or Geevers or anybody else or anything else.
('12', 286, 3, 28, 628856) For your food, while you need not just now return to the pure fruit diet, you may only take up bread and oil and not milk and ghee.
('12', 286, 3, 29, 628988) Later only may you take these up if they are found necessary.
('12', 286, 3, 30, 629050) Bread should have its trial without ghee and milk.
('12', 286, 3, 31, 629101) That would be a scientific experiment.
('12', 286, 3, 32, 629140) Hope that you will have things not to be kept on the Farm packed up.
('12', 286, 3, 33, 629209) Will you remember that you may not even spend a penny without careful thinking?
('12', 286, 3, 34, 629289) The next year or eighteen months or more are the time of your life.
('12', 286, 4, 35, 629357) Yours sincerely, UPPER HOUSE

('12', 287, 2, 9, 630156) He has suggested that we ought to be content if the legal right was secured.
('12', 287, 2, 10, 630233) He added that if we hoped for reasonable treatment, we should understand the underlying reason for the Europeans’ anxieties and fears.

('12', 288, 5, 12, 632835) I am a lawyer practising in the Transvaal Court, and I have with me a return ticket to Johannesburg.

('12', 290, 1, 19, 638189) This messenger had returned with the permit.
('12', 290, 1, 20, 638234) It was shown to the Immigration Officer’s clerk who then issued me a pass; I was set free.
('12', 290, 1, 21, 638325) Mr. Kallenbach and I disembarked and, having enjoyed the hospitality of the Delagoa Bay Indians, we took the train to Johannesburg the same day.
('12', 290, 1, 22, 638470) I for one have learnt much from the foregoing incident.
('12', 290, 1, 23, 638526) I place it before readers of Indian Opinion hoping that they would know about it, and that they, too, may learn something from it.
('12', 290, 1, 24, 638657) Surely, this has not happened only to me that I should bore readers of Indian Opinion with this rigmarole.
('12', 290, 1, 25, 638764) Let me hope that this question would not occur to them.
('12', 290, 1, 26, 638820) Admittedly, suffering a thousand times more severe has befallen Indians at Delagoa Bay and other ports.
('12', 290, 1, 27, 638924) It is because I know this that I was pained and now write about this incident.
('12', 290, 1, 28, 639003) I would, I suppose, be considered and educated person.
('12', 290, 1, 29, 639058) That is, I would know
('12', 291, 0, 1, 639080) 292 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 291, 1, 2, 639122) what to do.
('12', 291, 1, 3, 639134) Many Europeans know me.
('12', 291, 1, 4, 639158) I would be counted among the “big”, and many would come forward to help me.
('12', 291, 1, 5, 639234) If, in spite of all this, I have had to put up with so much, what must be the plight of other Indians, looked down upon as uneducated and in no wise able to defend themselves?
('12', 291, 1, 6, 639410) I wish Indians in my predicament would be infused with the same zeal that I felt.
('12', 291, 1, 7, 639492) The first step towards our deliverance is the true realization of our condition.
('12', 291, 1, 8, 639573) During my deck journey an Indian, referring to our condition here, expressed the opinion: “We are as ants.
('12', 291, 1, 9, 639680) We must endure this suffering somehow and have done with it.” This I call ignorance.
('12', 291, 1, 10, 639765) We set no store by self respect and are not prepared to defend it.
('12', 291, 1, 11, 639832) ‘Once I get my wages, the whites might call me a coolie, a deck hand might kick me.
('12', 291, 1, 12, 639916) I might be obliged to live in a Location; I might be prevented from owning land and mine might be a dog’s plight.
('12', 291, 1, 13, 640030) But I don’t care.’ Such, generally, is our lot.
('12', 291, 1, 14, 640078) We have submitted to it all along, so the Europeans treat us in this fashion.
('12', 291, 1, 15, 640156) Thus we alone are responsible for our condition.
('12', 291, 1, 16, 640205) That is the lesson to be learnt from this incident.
('12', 291, 1, 17, 640257) Having learnt it, we must apply it in every difficult situation and act accordingly.
('12', 291, 1, 18, 640342) Two things need to be done: one, we must rid the community of its defects which may have brought about the present condition and two, every one of us must fight against injustices perpetrated by the whites.
('12', 291, 2, 19, 640549) MOHANDAS KARAMCHAND GANDHI [From Gujarati]
('12', 291, 3, 20, 640592) Indian Opinion, 28 12 1912
('12', 291, 4, 21, 640619) 244. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('12', 291, 5, 22, 640653) December 26, 1912
('12', 291, 6, 23, 640671) MY DEAR LOWER HOUSE,
('12', 291, 7, 24, 640692) I find that I cannot leave before next week.
('12', 291, 7, 25, 640737) The patients are progressing.
('12', 291, 7, 26, 640767) I am making safe experiments with one of them and it appears to me that he will recover much more rapidly.
('12', 291, 7, 27, 640874) It consists in eliminating milk from the dietary.
('12', 291, 7, 28, 640924) Will you please have those things which have to come here packed slowly?
('12', 291, 7, 29, 640997) I should like to shorten my stay there as much as possible.
('12', 291, 7, 30, 641057) The contents of each case should be noted in a book.
('12', 291, 7, 31, 641110) I have been thinking over your letter.
('12', 291, 7, 32, 641149) I think that we often manufacture sorrows.
('12', 291, 7, 33, 641192) Instead of simply saying to yourself you are
('12', 292, 0, 1, 641237) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 293
('12', 292, 1, 2, 641278) going to Phoenix and then to India, you are thinking in advance what awaits you at these places.
('12', 292, 1, 3, 641375) May you not think thus: ‘I shall go to Phoenix.
('12', 292, 1, 4, 641423) I shall take up work which I can do and no other.
('12', 292, 1, 5, 641473) If I cannot find anything to suit me and Phoenix appals me, I shall leave the place.
('12', 292, 1, 6, 641558) I do not mind admitting defeat.
('12', 292, 1, 7, 641590) I shall go to India.
('12', 292, 1, 8, 641611) I shall try to like it.
('12', 292, 1, 9, 641635) I shall try, too, to find pleasure in the work before me.
('12', 292, 1, 10, 641693) If I still fail, I shall not lose.
('12', 292, 1, 11, 641728) I shall be the gainer for having tried.’ This is a safe attitude and it is the attitude of the average man.
('12', 292, 1, 12, 641836) Why should you worry by trying to know the whole future?
('12', 292, 1, 13, 641893) With love, Yours sincerely, UPPER HOUSE
('12', 292, 2, 14, 641933) From the original: Gandhi Kallenbach Correspondence.
('12', 292, 2, 15, 641986) Courtesy: National Archives of India
('12', 292, 3, 16, 642023) 245. A CATASTROPHE
('12', 292, 4, 17, 642042) We have to thank our stars that the dastardly act of the bomb thrower at Delhi did not prove fatal to Lord Hardinge’s life and that Lady Hardinge had a miraculous escape.
('12', 292, 4, 18, 642213) That in this century, Which is considered an enlightened period in the history of mankind, there are people who believe that assassination can lead to political or other reform is a fact which should make people think and ask whether water passes under the name of progress is real progress.
('12', 292, 4, 19, 642505) We as Indians deplore that this nefarious institution of cold blooded Satanic murder should find its votaries in India.
('12', 292, 4, 20, 642625) We cannot recall instances of the kind in Indian history.
('12', 292, 4, 21, 642683) Assassination for selfish ends is as old as the hills.
('12', 292, 4, 22, 642738) It had its sway in India also long before the introduction, in that land, of Western influence.
('12', 292, 4, 23, 642834) But Political assassination is a recent excrescence in the life of India.
('12', 292, 4, 24, 642908) The mad youth who perpetrated the crime no doubt thought that by striking murders of distinguished men, rulers could be terrorized and an independent Indian could be thereby secured .
('12', 292, 4, 25, 643092) We should decline to share any such independence even if it were attainable, which we doubt.
('12', 292, 4, 26, 643185) We do not believe that good can be brought about by evil.
('12', 292, 4, 27, 643243) The fact is that the idea of securing independence by assassination is chimerical.
('12', 292, 4, 28, 643326) The result can only be greater repression, greater suspicion on the part of the rulers, greater taxation on the people, and consequent increase in the hardships of the poorest in the land.
('12', 292, 4, 29, 643515) In the midst of this darkness we can but pray for India’s
('12', 293, 0, 1, 643573) 294 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 293, 1, 2, 643615) deliverance from the curse of assassination and the return of the few misguided youths to the sane teaching of their forefathers that free dom comes only from self suffering and purification—never by inflicting on others.
('12', 293, 1, 3, 643837) We pray, too, for Lord Haridinge’s quick recovery from the effect of the wound received by him.
('12', 293, 2, 4, 643933) Indian Opinion, 28 12 1912
('12', 293, 3, 5, 643960) 246. LETTER TO G.K. GOKHALE 1
('12', 293, 4, 6, 643990) PHOENIX, NATAL, December 28, 1912
('12', 293, 5, 7, 644024) DEAR MR. GOKHALE,
('12', 293, 6, 8, 644042) Chhaganlal’s son being ill I was obliged to hurry here as soon as we reached Johannesburg.
('12', 293, 6, 9, 644133) The youngster is much better now thanks to the hip baths & partial starvation.
('12', 293, 6, 10, 644212) Many thanks for your letter from Mombasa & cable from India.
('12', 293, 6, 11, 644273) The criticism you cable was expected by us.
('12', 293, 6, 12, 644317) It does not affect me at all.
('12', 293, 6, 13, 644347) The critics have not troubled to study the question.
('12', 293, 6, 14, 644400) Even Mr. Natrajan in his paper says that we have made as good a bargain as we could under the circumstances.
('12', 293, 6, 15, 644509) The fact is that we have made no “bargain”.
('12', 293, 6, 16, 644553) But I must not worry you.
('12', 293, 6, 17, 644579) I value your time and health too much to inflict a long letter on you.
('12', 293, 6, 18, 644650) I replied to your cable early this week.
('12', 293, 6, 19, 644691) I hope that the souvenir case was received in time.
('12', 293, 6, 20, 644743) The Umkazi remained a long time at Beira.
('12', 293, 6, 21, 644785) You were right and I was wrong.
('12', 293, 6, 22, 644817) The foodstuff bought at Johannesburg for our voyage went to the Farm.
('12', 293, 6, 23, 644887) All evidently lost their heads, Miss Schlesin most of all.
('12', 293, 6, 24, 644946) You wanted to know, too, as to who was responsible for the omission to pay our passage.
('12', 293, 6, 25, 645034) Ismail says he knew nothing about it and that he never received Polak’s wire.
('12', 293, 6, 26, 645112) Polak distrusts Ismail.
('12', 293, 6, 27, 645136) Poor Rustomjee was upset when he heard that the passage had to be paid at Beira.
('12', 293, 6, 28, 645217) The omission to give you the diary of your tour was due to Polak’s forgetfulness.
('12', 293, 6, 29, 645299) I admit that all these mishaps were preventable and I could have prevented them had I given them more thought.
('12', 293, 6, 30, 645410) The lessons I have learnt during the tour will not be lost on me.
('12', 293, 7, 31, 645476) 1 Vide also “Letter to G. K. Gokhale”, 4 12 1912.
('12', 294, 0, 1, 645526) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 295
('12', 294, 1, 2, 645567) I hope to shift to Phoenix during the middle of January.
('12', 294, 1, 3, 645624) On my arrival in Johannesburg Miss Sclesin told me that the whole of the passive resistance balance was used up.
('12', 294, 1, 4, 645737) As I have several calls to meet, I took the liberty of adding to the cable a few words asking you to ask Mr. Petit to cable the balance in his hands.
('12', 294, 2, 5, 645887) I hope that you are keeping well.
('12', 294, 2, 6, 645921) I should value all the news you could give me abut your health and the changes made in your dietary, &c.
('12', 294, 2, 7, 646026) If one of the Servants of India could be specially put on S.A. Work arrangements could be made to send him a regular letter every mail about the position here, and a few copies of I.O. for careful distribution.
('12', 294, 2, 8, 646237) You have asked me to write to you regularly about the position.
('12', 294, 2, 9, 646301) But I feel that I ought not to expect you to read such heavy correspondence from fortnight to fortnight .
('12', 294, 2, 10, 646407) The member whom you may appoint could do all that & take you instructions when necessary.
('12', 294, 3, 11, 646497) I remain,
('12', 294, 4, 12, 646507) Your sincerely, M. K. GANDHI [PS.]

('12', 295, 6, 8, 647295) 1 These brief memoranda were made by Gandhiji from day to day on a copy of “Indian Opinion Pocket Diary for 1912” published by the International Printing Press, Phoenix, and advertised for the first time in Indian Opinion, 6 1 1912. It measures 4Ω” x 3Ω” (Crown sexto decimo size).
('12', 295, 6, 9, 647577) Written in Gandhiji’s hand, it contains, for the most part, names of persons he wrote to each day and of those who visited hem at Tolstoy Farm and references to his visits to Johannesburg or to Phoenix.
('12', 295, 6, 10, 647780) While all these notes are in Gujarati, the entries of daily receipts and disbursements, made in single vertical column, are in English.
('12', 295, 6, 11, 647916) These accounts presumably concern the petty cash kept with him at the Farm and include sundry credits and receipts and disbursements on account of the school.
('12', 295, 6, 12, 648075) The punctuation in the Diary is meagre and sometimes misleading.
('12', 295, 6, 13, 648140) Marks of punctuation have been supplied where absolutely necessary.
('12', 295, 6, 14, 648208) In transliterating names of persons from the Gujarati, English spellings have been taken over from advertisements or news items in the Indian Opinion issues for the year or from the English entries in the accounts column.
('12', 295, 6, 15, 648430) As for proper names, which could not be checked with contemporaneous sources, the conventional or phonetic spelling has been used.
('12', 295, 6, 16, 648561) Of the letters mentioned in the Diary, the few that have been traced have been identified by cross references.

('12', 357, 9, 11, 718166) 248. MR. GOKHALE AT THE NATIONAL CONGRESS
('12', 357, 10, 12, 718208) The Hon’ble Mr. Gokhale did not allow grass to grow under his feet before he commenced work in India after his return from the arduous work done by him in this subcontinent.
('12', 357, 10, 13, 718382) He succeeded in having a motion carried in the Congress at Bankipore, advocating the
('12', 357, 11, 14, 718467) 1 A word here is illegible.
('12', 357, 11, 15, 718495) Cf., however, Vol. VIII, p.
('12', 358, 0, 1, 718523) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 359
('12', 358, 1, 2, 718564) total abolition of the system of indenture.
('12', 358, 1, 3, 718608) We trust that before long we shall sea an end to the system.
('12', 358, 1, 4, 718669) Mr. Gokhale is not given to leaving things half done.
('12', 358, 1, 5, 718723) He does thoroughly whatever he undertakes.
('12', 358, 1, 6, 718766) He fights his battles to a finish.
('12', 358, 1, 7, 718801) He is no retreat general.
('12', 358, 1, 8, 718827) We feel sure, therefore, that the cause of the voiceless indentured labourers is safe in his hands.
('12', 358, 1, 9, 718927) Besides speaking directly to his motion, Mr. Gokhale is reported to have devoted his speech to a reply to his critics in India.
('12', 358, 2, 10, 719055) The latter seem to have imagined that Mr. Gokhale had given away some rights and had made a bad bargain.
('12', 358, 2, 11, 719160) Here his critics like Major Silburn charged Mr. Gokhale with having intimidated the people of South Africa.
('12', 358, 2, 12, 719268) Truly, a public man who wishes to obey the voice of his conscience alone has a difficult if not an impossible task before him if he wishes also to please all people.
('12', 358, 2, 13, 719434) With Mr. Gokhale it is well if he pleases the people, but it is well also if he must displease the people or any section of them so long as he pleases the voice from within.
('12', 358, 2, 14, 719608) From Reuter’s condensed summary of his reply to his critics it is difficult to form any accurate opinion about the speech.
('12', 358, 2, 15, 719731) But Reuter has supplied us with an infallible test by saying that Mr. Gokhale endorsed and urged all the demands made by us in South Africa.
('12', 358, 2, 16, 719872) It may be well, therefore, to state them in a few sen tences.
('12', 358, 2, 17, 719934) So far as we know them they are: “Complete legal equality as to immigration throughout the Union, but, whilst we should be, we could be, no party to administrative discremination, we should not oppose it, so long as a certain number of new Indians are permitted annually to enter the Union.
('12', 358, 2, 18, 720225) (2) Our goal is most certainly complete equality in everything, but we do not agitate for disturbing the present political status and we do agitate for the removal of all other legal and administrative disabilities in all the parts of the Union, save the Orange
('12', 358, 3, 19, 720487) 1 According to a Reuter telegram, Gokhale had moved a resolution at Bankipore urging that the system of indenture be abolished altogether.
('12', 358, 3, 20, 720626) He called upon the Government [of India] to prohibit further recruiting.

('12', 363, 1, 2, 730571) There seems to be no limit to the filthiness of deck passengers.
('12', 363, 1, 3, 730636) Even though facilities for bathing are provided on the ship, many of them rarely take a bath.

('12', 363, 1, 21, 732253) Though the passenger is clearly far better off, as far as money goes, than the bank manager, he travels deck class.

('12', 366, 1, 2, 737827) Being unacquainted with the common rules concerning the human body, we often do things which we ought not to, or fall into the hands of selfish and unscrupulous quacks.
('12', 366, 1, 3, 737996) It is surprising but true that we know less of things close by than of those that lie far away.

('12', 367, 4, 13, 741399) 254. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('12', 367, 5, 14, 741433) Wednesday [January 8, 1913] 1
('12', 367, 6, 15, 741463) MY DEAR LOWER HOUSE,
('12', 367, 7, 16, 741484) For me, last night was momentous.
('12', 367, 7, 17, 741518) Let me try to explain.
('12', 367, 7, 18, 741541) I feel that you are accepting my conclusions without being ready to follow them out.
('12', 367, 7, 19, 741626) Such a man dare not risk the unbalancing of his mind in the attempt to follow out somebody else’s conclusions.
('12', 367, 7, 20, 741737) If you had proved for yourself the correctness of the theory of life as I have endeavored to sketch it, if you had an inner conviction, if your belief in future life was unshakable, if you had become sick of the world unto death, if money had no attractions for you, if you were not influenced by your surroundings, if you were longing for poverty and suffering, it would be your duty to attempt to live the new life.
('12', 367, 7, 21, 742155) But you are not any of these things, so I think that you ought not to think of India or work in Phoenix just now.
('12', 367, 7, 22, 742269) I have an inner conviction about the things I have mentioned.
('12', 367, 7, 23, 742331) My conclusions are my own and I ought to risk even the unhinging of my mind in the attempt to live the new life.
('12', 367, 7, 24, 742444) My mistake was in trying to force your pace and thinking that you could not but be right in trying to do right.
('12', 367, 7, 25, 742556) But the trying to do
('12', 367, 8, 26, 742577) 1 The addressee has recorded on this letter: “Mr. Gandhi left on the 9th, Thurs day for Phoenix and he handed this letter to me.”

('12', 368, 1, 2, 742748) right would not have been your act.
('12', 368, 1, 3, 742784) Or the many thoughts that arise in your mind, e.g., about Mr. Alexander 1 , or getting more work or more money, would not find place in your system.
('12', 368, 1, 4, 742933) The fact is, we cannot help ourselves beyond a certain point.
('12', 368, 1, 5, 742995) I feel sure, as I did not up to last night, that your duty is just now to adhere to your practice and your material advancement.
('12', 368, 1, 6, 743124) In doing so, you have to watch yourself.
('12', 368, 1, 7, 743165) You must not abandon the simple life, you must not revert to the rake’s life and pursue your calling as in trust for others.
('12', 368, 1, 8, 743290) Make very little use of your riches for you own comforts and keep poverty and suffering as your goal.
('12', 368, 1, 9, 743392) So doing, you will be more in tune with yourself and it will be possible for you to come to India with a better preparation.
('12', 368, 1, 10, 743517) Instead of India being a preparation, let your practice be it.
('12', 368, 1, 11, 743580) After all it may only mean one year, it may even mean less.

('12', 368, 1, 13, 743687) You cannot prepare in Phoenix for India.

('12', 368, 1, 15, 743783) You will thus test yourself.

('12', 368, 1, 22, 744253) I hope you understand my meaning.
('12', 368, 1, 23, 744287) You will do exactly as you please but in my opinion you would err in thinking of India.

('12', 369, 4, 7, 745095) 256. AN “ACT OF GRACE”
('12', 369, 5, 8, 745118) Last week we printed Mr. Polak’s letter to the Minister of the Interior on the action of the Chief Immigration Officer of Natal regarding two young Indians born in South Africa claiming rights of entry into the Transvaal.
('12', 369, 5, 9, 745340) 3 That letter speaks for itself, and shows in a
('12', 369, 6, 10, 745388) 1 The meeting referred to in the letter was held on this date.
('12', 369, 6, 11, 745451) 2 Ichharam Sooryaram Desai; Gujarati writer, jouranalist and publisher 3 On December 22, 1912, Bhawani Dayal and Devi Dayal, both Transvaal born sons of a domiciled Transvaal resident, arrived in Durban on their way back to the Transvaal.
('12', 369, 6, 12, 745690) They were both accompanied by their wives one of whom had brought her baby with her.
('12', 369, 6, 13, 745775) Although one of the men could have passed the education test and both calimed that they had been in the Transvaal on May 31, 1902, Cousins, the Immigra tion Officer refused them visitors’ permits.
('12', 369, 6, 14, 745972) Polak obtained an affidavit from a respect able Transvaal Indian who vouched for their identity and certified that they had been in the Transvaal on May 31, 1902, but Cousins refused to consider their claim without instructions from the Registrar of Asiatics; he further refused to communicate with the Registrar or to give the applicants visitors’ passes.
('12', 369, 6, 15, 746329) Polak telegraphed the Registrar of Asiatics and asked Goodricke and Laughton, attorneys, to apply for an interdict against Cousins and other parties to prevent removal of applicants, pending consideration of their claims by the Transvaal authorities.
('12', 369, 6, 16, 746580) The interdict from the Supreme Court was obtained, a condition being that applicants should lodge £100 as security.
('12', 369, 6, 17, 746696) Cousins, after considerable delay, went aboard ship and demanded that applicants sign a document authorizing him to keep them under restraint at the Detention Camp and to use the security for their maintenance.
('12', 369, 6, 18, 746907) Polak protested that it was unlawful, but Cousins,
('12', 370, 0, 1, 746958) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 371
('12', 370, 1, 2, 746999) telling manner how high handed the action of the Officer concerned was.
('12', 370, 1, 3, 747071) Mr. Polak addressed a letter to The Natal Mercury also about the same time, in which he dealt not only with the case of two young Indians, but with that of Mr. Gajjar, 1 with which also our readers are familiar.
('12', 370, 1, 4, 747283) Our contemporary has written a very forcible editorial 2 on
('12', 370, 2, 5, 747343) learning that Polak was not yet enrolled as attorney in Natal, had him ordered off ship.
('12', 370, 2, 6, 747432) Under pressure from Cousins, the applicants signed.
('12', 370, 2, 7, 747484) The attorneys had meanwhile communicated with the Judge who declared that Cousins’ action was not intended by his order.
('12', 370, 2, 8, 747605) Although Cousins then issued them visitors’ passes, he still refused to accept their applications for registration.
('12', 370, 2, 9, 747721) Polak then wrote to the Minister of the Interior setting forth the details of this case and requesting that instructions be issued for a “humaner administration” of the immigration laws.
('12', 370, 2, 10, 747908) The Dayal brothers applied directly to the Registrar of Asiatics, Pretoria, who had not yet replied when the period of their visiting passes expired.
('12', 370, 2, 11, 748058) The Immigration Officer refused an extension.
('12', 370, 2, 12, 748104) Meanwhile, the elder brother’s claim to reside in Natal was admitted on grounds of his ability to pass the education test but his proof of marriage was rejected.
('12', 370, 2, 13, 748266) The brothers, therefore, crossed the border accompanied by Polak.
('12', 370, 2, 14, 748332) Although their application for residential rights was under consideration, they were charged as prohibited immigrants and the cases remitted to Pretoria and remanded to January 30. On January 27, however, Polak was notified by the Registrar that the cases had been withdrawn and the brothers’ claims admitted.
('12', 370, 2, 15, 748642) Indian Opinion, 4 1 1913 & 1 2 1913. 1 Gajjar, an Indian merchant from Somerset East in the Cape, had gone to Durban to receive his family coming from India.
('12', 370, 2, 16, 748800) He asked the local magistrate to issue him a visitors’ permit for Natal which the latter in this ignorance of Cape Immigration laws thought unnecessary.
('12', 370, 2, 17, 748953) He was, however, issued a certificate of identity which mentioned his standing in the community.
('12', 370, 2, 18, 749050) On arrival at Durban, Cousins, the Natal Immigration Officer summoned him and discovered that he had neither a visiting pass for Natal nor a permit of temporary absence from the Cape.
('12', 370, 2, 19, 749234) While Cousins issued him a visiting pass for Natal, he ordered Gajjar to stay on in Durban until he had obtained the Minister’s instructions, but refused to allow his family to disembark on the ground that Gajjar was technically a “prohibited immigrant” in both provinces in Natal because he had not got a visiting pass and in the Cape because he had not obtained a permit of absence.
('12', 370, 2, 20, 749619) He was, however, allowed to return home as “an act of grace”.
('12', 370, 2, 21, 749681) Polak then wrote to The Natal Mercury saying, “Such, however, is the ‘humane’ administration of the Immigration Law that Mr. Gokhale was given to understand might be expected when he interviewed the Ministers at Pretoria.
('12', 370, 2, 22, 749903) Are these expectations never to be realized, and is every conceivable occasion to be seized to harass unfortunately placed members of the Indian community?” Indian Opinion, 11 1 1913. 2 In this The Natal Mercury strongly condemned Cousins.
('12', 370, 2, 23, 750143) He apparently laboured, it said, under the impression that he had been placed “to give the public the greatest amount of inconvenience .
('12', 370, 2, 24, 750280) the maximum degree of hardship he can impose”; he was “about the last man for the job” and they did “not intend Natal to rest under the stigma of being a place” where the law was administered according to Cousins’ ideas.
('12', 370, 2, 25, 750501) Indian Opinion, 11 1 1913.

('12', 371, 1, 2, 750570) these cases, which we reproduce in this issue, as also that part of Mr. Polak’s letter which refers to Mr. Gajjar’s case.
('12', 371, 1, 3, 750692) The most painful part of Mr. Polak’s letter is where he says that Mr. Gajjar has been permitted to return to the Cape as an “act of grace”.
('12', 371, 1, 4, 750832) No case—and there have been harsh cases enough—under the Cape Immigration Act has, perhaps, shown in a manner as this has, the cruelty of the section that requires an Indian leaving the Province to take out a permit of absence in a particular form.
('12', 371, 1, 5, 751081) Mr. Gajjar might, but for this precious“act of grace”, have become a prohibited immi grant for the Cape Province although he was armed with a document of identification from the Chief Constable of his town.
('12', 371, 1, 6, 751288) Under the Act, a Cape Indian paying a visit to a sister Province on the strength of a permit issued by that Province may be prevented from returning, if he happened not to know, like the Magistrate at Somerset East, the exact terms of the Cape Immigration Law.
('12', 371, 1, 7, 751549) Justice in Mr. Gajjar’s case has been forced from the Government by the persistent efforts of Mr. Polak, but the Cape Indians ought not to rest until the section in question has been altered and a promise taken from the Government that, pending alteration, the section will not be rigorously enforced.
('12', 371, 1, 8, 751851) So far as the action of the Officer 1 in question is concerned, the public will perhaps feel thankful to know that he has handed over the charge to Mr. Harry Smith, who is, so far as Natal is concerned, an old experienced official possessing the requisite legal knowledge of the people he has to deal with.
('12', 371, 1, 9, 752158) But Mr. Harry Smith’s conduct of his department under the Union Government will be watched by the Indian community with not a little anxiety.
('12', 371, 1, 10, 752300) Whilst we have had to perform the painful duty of severely criticising Mr. Cousins’ administration of the Immigration Act of Natal, 2 we have always felt that we might not have done justice to him by ignoring the fact that he is now a Union Officer, and that probably he has been acting against his own wishes and under orders from the Department of the Interior.
('12', 371, 1, 11, 752664) However, we have not been able to place any such charitable construction upon his action so far as Mr. Gajjar’s case, for instance, was concerned.
('12', 371, 1, 12, 752811) No matter what the orders from the Department of the Interior might be, humane Immigration Officers would always find scope for their humanity in dealing with helpless men and women;

('12', 372, 1, 2, 753119) and we trust that Mr. Harry Smith will exercise, as he has often done before, kindly tact in his dealings with the Indian community.

('12', 372, 3, 4, 753278) 257. GENERAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT HEALTH[ II]
('12', 372, 4, 5, 753319) It is our habit that, at the slightest illness, we rush at once to a doctor, vaidya or hakim.
('12', 372, 4, 6, 753413) 1 And if we do not, we take whatever medicine the barber or our neighbour suggests.
('12', 372, 4, 7, 753497) It is our belief that no sickness can be cured without drugs.
('12', 372, 4, 8, 753559) This, however, is sheer superstition.
('12', 372, 4, 9, 753597) People who suffer from other causes are—and will continue to be— fewer than those who have suffered, and are suffering, because of this superstition.
('12', 372, 4, 10, 753747) If, therefore, we can get to know what constitutes illness, we should be able to take a somewhat balanced view.
('12', 372, 4, 11, 753859) “Darad” 2 means pain.
('12', 372, 4, 12, 753881) “Roga” 3 means much the same.
('12', 372, 4, 13, 753911) It is right to seek a remedy for pain, but it is fultile to take drugs to suppress pain.
('12', 372, 4, 14, 754000) Actually, the result is often harmful.
('12', 372, 4, 15, 754039) Taking medicine has the same effect as my covering up the refuse in my house.
('12', 372, 4, 16, 754117) Refuse which is kept covered will putrefy and cause me harm.
('12', 372, 4, 17, 754178) Moreover, the covering itself may putrefy and add to the refuse.
('12', 372, 4, 18, 754243) I have then to get rid of the refuse which has since formed as well as that which was to begin with.
('12', 372, 4, 19, 754344) This is the fate that befalls people taking drugs.
('12', 372, 4, 20, 754395) But, if one throws out the refuse, the house will become as clean as it was before.
('12', 372, 4, 21, 754479) By giving rise to illness— pain [that is]—Nature, in fact, informs us that there exists impure matter in our body.
('12', 372, 4, 22, 754594) Moreover Nature has provided within the body itself the means of cleansing it, so that, when illness occurs, we should realize that there exists impure matter in the body and that she has commenced her cleansing process.
('12', 372, 4, 23, 754815) I should be thankful to anyone who came forward to remove the refuse from my house.
('12', 372, 4, 24, 754899) So long as he has not done with the cleaning, I might be inconvenienced but I would keep my patience.
('12', 372, 4, 25, 755001) Likewise if I am patient while Nature is cleansing the body, which is my home, it will be well again, and I shall become healthy and so free from pain.
('12', 372, 4, 26, 755153) If I have a cold, I do not have to rush to swallow drugs—sunth 4 [for instance].
('12', 372, 4, 27, 755234) I know that some impure matter has accumulated in a certain part of my body and that Nature
('12', 372, 5, 28, 755326) 1 A vaidya practices the Ayurvedic and hakim the Unani system of medicine.
('12', 372, 5, 29, 755401) 2 Gujarati words for pain, ailment, disease 3 Ibid 4 Ginger, dried and ground, is a much used household remedy.
('12', 373, 0, 1, 755513) 374 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 373, 1, 2, 755555) has stepped in to remove it.
('12', 373, 1, 3, 755584) And so I must let her have her way, so that my body may be cleansed in the shortest possible time.
('12', 373, 1, 4, 755683) If I resist Nature, her task is doubled; she has both to cleanse me and cope with my resistance.
('12', 373, 1, 5, 755780) I can assist Nature, for instance, by getting rid of the effective cause of the impurity, so that more of it does not accumulate.
('12', 373, 1, 6, 755910) That is to say, if I stop eating for the duration of the illness, thus preventing the ingress of further impurity, and if I exercise in fresh air, I shall also start ejecting the impurity through the skin.
('12', 373, 1, 7, 756116) That this is the golden rule for keeping the body free of disease, every one can prove for himself.
('12', 373, 1, 8, 756216) Only, the mind must be kept in a stable state.
('12', 373, 1, 9, 756263) One who reposes true faith in God will always act in this fashion.
('12', 373, 1, 10, 756330) The following [throught] will help in bringing about this state of mind: `Even if I undergo the treatment prescribed by the vaidya or some such person, no one can guarantee that my disease will be got rid of.
('12', 373, 1, 11, 756539) Not all those who put themselves in the hands of a doctor are cured.
('12', 373, 1, 12, 756608) If they were, Mr. Gandhi should not have to write these chapters and all of us would be leading happy lives.’ Experience shows that once the [medicine ] bottle enters a house, it never leaves.
('12', 373, 1, 13, 756801) Countless persons suffer from some ailment or other throughout their lives, go on adding to the drugs one after the other or go on changing their vaidyas and hakims in their search for the one who will cure them; finally, having ruined both themselves and others, they die, a troubled death.
('12', 373, 1, 14, 757093) That famous judge, the late Mr. Justice Stephen, who had lived in India [for a time], once said that doctors introduce herbs, of which they know little, into bodies of which they know even less.
('12', 373, 1, 15, 757288) Doctors say the same thing after attaining due experience.
('12', 373, 1, 16, 757347) Dr. Magendie has said: “Medicine is a great hoax.” A famous doctor, Sir Ashley Cooper, has observed: “The science of medicine is based on mere guess work.” Sir John Forbes has remarked: “Not withstanding the skill of physicians, it is Nature which cures most men of their diseases.” Dr. Baker tells us: “In cases of night fever many more patients die of the drugs than of the disease.” Dr. Froth declares that it is difficult to find a more dishonest profession than that of medicine.
('12', 373, 1, 17, 757832) Dr. Thomas Watson writes: “In the most important matters our profession drifts on a sea of dubious hypotheses.” Dr. Coswell feels that the human race would benefit immeasurably if the entire medical profession was ended.
('12', 373, 1, 18, 758053) Dr. Frank avers that thousands have been killed in hospitals.
('12', 373, 1, 19, 758115) Dr. Mason Good says: “Drugs claim a
('12', 374, 0, 1, 758151) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 375
('12', 374, 1, 2, 758192) heavier sacrifice of human lives than do wars, epidemics and famines.” We find that an increase in the number of doctors is followed in one place after another by a rise in the incidence of disease.
('12', 374, 1, 3, 758391) Large advertisements appear in newspapers which do not accept other advertisements.
('12', 374, 1, 4, 758475) When Indian Opinion used to accept advertisements, its workers had to go about soliciting these from others, but as for drug advertisements, their manufacturers pressed them on the journal and would even tempt [us] with large sums.
('12', 374, 1, 5, 758707) We pay a rupee for medicine which should cost no more than a pie.
('12', 374, 1, 6, 758773) Most manufacturers generally do not let us know what the drugs are made from.
('12', 374, 1, 7, 758851) A drug manufacturer recently brought out a book entitled Secret Medicines, his object being to ensure that people are not misled.
('12', 374, 1, 8, 758981) He reveals therein that the ingredients of sarsaparilla, fruit salt, syrup and other well known patent medicines, for which we pay from three to seven shillings a bottle, cost from a farthing to a penny.
('12', 374, 1, 9, 759185) This means that we pay from 36 to 336 times the actural cost of the medicine.
('12', 374, 1, 10, 759263) The profit to the dealer is thus 3500 to 35000 per cent.
('12', 374, 1, 11, 759320) The reader ought surely to see from all this that it is unnecessary for a patient to rush to a doctor or buy drugs in a hurry.
('12', 374, 1, 12, 759447) But few will so forbear.
('12', 374, 1, 13, 759472) All doctors are not dishonest.
('12', 374, 1, 14, 759503) That every time the drug is harmful, the common man will not admit.
('12', 374, 1, 15, 759571) To such persons, one may say: ‘Forbear as much as you can.
('12', 374, 1, 16, 759630) Do not bother a doctor as long as you can help it.
('12', 374, 1, 17, 759681) If you must call in one, get only a reliable person and, having called him, stick to him.
('12', 374, 1, 18, 759771) Consult another only if he so advises.
('12', 374, 1, 19, 759810) Your disease is not under your doctor’s control.
('12', 374, 1, 20, 759859) If it is given to you to live, you will get well and if, in spite of all that you have done, death comes to you or to your relatives, know that death is no more than a transition.’ The purpose in my writing these chapters is that we might think and act according to this principle.
('12', 374, 1, 21, 760141) In these, I wish to discuss with readers such topics as physiology, air, water, diet, exercise, clothing, water and earth treatment, accidents, child care, the duties of men and women during pregnancy and common ailments.
('12', 374, 2, 22, 760363) MOHANDAS KARAMCHAND GANDHI
('12', 374, 3, 23, 760390) Phoenix
('12', 374, 4, 24, 760398) [From Gujarati]

('12', 375, 1, 2, 760482) 258. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('12', 375, 2, 3, 760516) Saturday [January 11, 1913]
('12', 375, 3, 4, 760544) MY DEAR LOWER HOUSE,
('12', 375, 4, 5, 760565) Just a line to say that I got the message about the fares for the Naidoo boys all right.
('12', 375, 4, 6, 760654) Here we are quite comfortable but I do not know that you could stand this life.
('12', 375, 4, 7, 760734) We were most of us on the verandah sleeping side by side.
('12', 375, 4, 8, 760792) Jeki 1 was next to me.
('12', 375, 4, 9, 760815) We all sat at the same table last night to dine ≈ we were 20. The work is good but hard.
('12', 375, 4, 10, 760904) I have been up since 4.30 a.m.
('12', 375, 4, 11, 760935) and now it is 5.40 a.m.
('12', 375, 4, 12, 760959) I woke up the boys at 5.20 a.m.
('12', 375, 4, 13, 760991) We are in all 23 in one household.
('12', 375, 4, 14, 761026) In the light of what happened at the station, in the light of what is happening here, consider my letter well.
('12', 375, 4, 15, 761137) Over my meal yesterday I could not have taken more than 10 minutes.
('12', 375, 4, 16, 761205) I think I took the least time of all and I did not gulp.
('12', 375, 4, 17, 761262) I have simply found out, I hope, the right food for me.
('12', 375, 4, 18, 761318) One can only die in the attempt to find the truth.
('12', 375, 4, 19, 761369) I am passionately in search of it.
('12', 375, 4, 20, 761404) May you not for the time being follow my career from a distance?
('12', 375, 4, 21, 761469) Poor Mrs. Gandhi and poor you!
('12', 375, 4, 22, 761500) Mrs. Gandhi must have felt simply shocked to see her neat little home turned into a menagerie.
('12', 375, 4, 23, 761595) But she took it all quite calmly.
('12', 375, 4, 24, 761629) Your case is somewhat different.
('12', 375, 4, 25, 761662) She is bound up in my life.
('12', 375, 4, 26, 761690) She is not on the fence.
('12', 375, 4, 27, 761715) You are not bound up in me and you are on the fence.
('12', 375, 4, 28, 761768) All these things should put you on your guard.
('12', 375, 4, 29, 761815) I therefore urge again: do not be hasty, nurse your office in terms of my letter, come to Phoenix whenever you like partly to share my life but not wholly, and you will test yourself.
('12', 375, 4, 30, 761999) Watch me just now not with a friendly eye but a highly critical and fault finding eye.
('12', 375, 4, 31, 762086) Assimilate the joint life as we have lived it hitherto but in my flight now hesitate, watch and wait.
('12', 375, 4, 32, 762188) More when you come here.
('12', 375, 4, 33, 762213) You will observe things for yourself.
('12', 375, 4, 34, 762251) Please understand me.
('12', 375, 4, 35, 762273) I do not want to put you off.
('12', 375, 4, 36, 762303) If you will take the full step in spite of my warnings, I will not stop you.
('12', 375, 4, 37, 762380) With love, UPPER HOUSE

('12', 376, 1, 2, 762571) 259. LETTER TO MANILAL GANDHI
('12', 376, 2, 3, 762601) [Before January 18, 1913] 1
('12', 376, 3, 4, 762629) MANILAL, I have your two letters.
('12', 376, 3, 5, 762663) I will not do anything in haste.
('12', 376, 3, 6, 762696) Ideas ought to come up and great changes must take place in my way of life.
('12', 376, 3, 7, 762772) But I will not do anything that might cause you apprehension.
('12', 376, 3, 8, 762834) It is your duty not to lose hope.
('12', 376, 3, 9, 762868) You can rise only through supreme effort.

('12', 376, 3, 15, 763226) I have other things to say, but there is now no time.
('12', 376, 3, 16, 763280) I have corrected the verse from the shataka.
('12', 376, 3, 17, 763325) Look at it carefully.
