('12', 378, 1, 2, 766660) 262. INDIAN EDUCATION
('12', 378, 2, 3, 766682) In the Natal Provincial Gazette we read the following among the rules framed for the guidance of teachers in the Government schools:
('12', 378, 3, 4, 766815) No Native, Indian or Coloured children are to be admitted to schools other than those specially provided for them.
('12', 378, 4, 5, 766930) No pupils under standard II may be admitted to an Indian School under European teachers.
('12', 378, 5, 6, 767019) No subject not included in the Standard Syllabus for Primary Schools may be taught during ordinary school hours in an Indian School in charge of European teachers.
('12', 378, 6, 7, 767183) No pupil who has passed Standard IV will be allowed to remain at an Elementary Indian School.
('12', 378, 6, 8, 767277) Hitherto there have been no Gazetted rules specifically debarr ing Indian children from entering schools other than those specially established for them.
('12', 378, 6, 9, 767431) But the rules before us have altered all that.
('12', 378, 6, 10, 767478) The Provincial Administration have thrown down the challenge.
('12', 378, 6, 11, 767540) They have made it a matter of law.
('12', 378, 6, 12, 767575) The rules, moreover, hamper Indian education in many other respects.
('12', 378, 6, 13, 767644) Their effect is to prevent the teaching of vernaculars in the Government schools and to prevent our children from receiving other than elementary education in Government schools.
('12', 378, 6, 14, 767823) The duty of Indian parents is obvious.
('12', 378, 6, 15, 767862) They ought to make adequate provision for the education, along national lines, of their own children.
('12', 378, 6, 16, 767964) There should be established our own schools affording our children opportunities to learn their own vernaculars and, through them, their own history.
('12', 378, 6, 17, 768114) It is a serious reflection on us that our children are being brought up without a proper foundation to build character upon.

('12', 380, 1, 2, 770933) 265. PARENTS’ DUTY
('12', 380, 2, 3, 770952) These days many parents think [much] on the subject of what they should do about their boys.
('12', 380, 2, 4, 771045) Among British families, one notices that it is the tradition to make the handsome boy a soldier, the intelligent one a doctor or a barrister, and the dullard a priest.
('12', 380, 2, 5, 771213) There are many exceptions to this rule, a big one being that, in a good family, one member is prepared for public work.
('12', 380, 2, 6, 771333) India is in such a state today that all parents should prepare one of their boys for public work—that is, work in the service of the community.
('12', 380, 2, 7, 771477) Where there is only one boy in the family, this of course does not apply.
('12', 380, 2, 8, 771551) But many families have more than one boy each.
('12', 380, 2, 9, 771598) If they train one of the boys for service to the country, the uplift of the country will become possible in a short time.
('12', 380, 2, 10, 771720) This is a matter worthy of the highest consideration by all parents.

('12', 380, 5, 13, 771831) 266. GENERAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT HEALTH [ III]
('12', 380, 6, 14, 771874) CHAPTER 1. THE HEALTHY STATE
('12', 380, 7, 15, 771903) It is the common belief that, if a person eats and drinks normally, moves about and does not call in the doctor, he is free from illness.
('12', 380, 7, 16, 772041) A little thought will show that this belief is erroneous.
('12', 380, 7, 17, 772099) Nume rous instances come to notice of a person who eats, drinks and goes about and who ignores his ailments in the belief that there is nothing wrong with him.
('12', 380, 7, 18, 772259) In truth, there are very few persons in this world who are entirely healthy.
('12', 380, 7, 19, 772336) An English writer has observed that only he can be called healthy in whose pure body dwells a pure mind.
('12', 380, 7, 20, 772441) Man is not all body.
('12', 380, 7, 21, 772462) The body is merely his abode.
('12', 380, 7, 22, 772492) Moreover, the body, the mind and the sense organs are so closely connected that, if one of them is affected by illness or pain, the others also get out of order.
('12', 380, 7, 23, 772654) The body has been likened to a rose.
('12', 380, 7, 24, 772691) What shows without is the body of the rose, the fragrance is its soul.
('12', 380, 7, 25, 772762) No one would care for a paper rose which does not smell like the real flower.
('12', 380, 7, 26, 772840) The fragrance is the test of the rose, so is
('12', 381, 0, 1, 772885) 382 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 381, 1, 2, 772927) the test of a man his fragrance—the character of his soul.
('12', 381, 1, 3, 772986) We will, moreover, throw away a flower which looks like a rose but has an unpleasant smell.
('12', 381, 1, 4, 773078) Likewise, even if a man’s body appears to be all right, if the soul inhabiting that body tends to bad conduct, his body will hold no fascination for us.
('12', 381, 1, 5, 773231) We thus see that one whose character is unworthy can never be called healthy.
('12', 381, 1, 6, 773309) The body is so closely bound to the soul that one whose body is pure will be pure in mind too.
('12', 381, 1, 7, 773404) In the West a whole tradition has emerged, based on this principle.
('12', 381, 1, 8, 773472) It holds that those whose minds are pure can never be ill and one who is ill can cure himself by cultivating purity of mind.
('12', 381, 1, 9, 773597) this tenet should not be rejected [out of hand].
('12', 381, 1, 10, 773646) It is sound, in fact, but the people of the West who claim to be civilized misuse it.
('12', 381, 1, 11, 773732) The essential thing we have to learn from this tradition is that our mind is a potent means for the preservation of health, and that purity of mind ensures the main tenance of good health.
('12', 381, 2, 12, 773921) This man has a bad temper and is tamasik 1, that man is lethargic.
('12', 381, 2, 13, 773988) A third is deaf.
('12', 381, 2, 14, 774005) All these defects are, in fact, only symptoms of disease.
('12', 381, 2, 15, 774063) Some doctors believe that even faults, such as stealing, are diseases.
('12', 381, 2, 16, 774134) Some wealthy women in England pilfer worthless articles from shops.
('12', 381, 2, 17, 774202) Doctors in that country ascribe this state of mind to a disease termed kleptomania.
('12', 381, 2, 18, 774286) There are a few who are not at peace till they have shed blood.
('12', 381, 2, 19, 774350) This, too, is a disease.
('12', 381, 2, 20, 774375) Arguing along these lines, we can describe only that person as healthy whose body is whole and without defect; whose teeth are sound; who has his ears and eyes; whose nose does not run; who does perspire but whose perspiration does not smell; whose feet and mouth do not give out a bad odour; whose hands and feet can perform common tasks; who is not given to inordinate sexuality; who is neither too fat nor too thin, and whose mind and senses are under control.
('12', 381, 2, 21, 774839) It is no easy matter to achieve or maintain this state of health.
('12', 381, 2, 22, 774905) We do not enjoy such good health because our parents did not.
('12', 381, 2, 23, 774967) A great writer has said that the offspring, if any, of men and women who are fit in every way must surpass their parents.
('12', 381, 2, 24, 775089) If this be untrue, those who hold that the world is progressing must revise their view.
('12', 381, 2, 25, 775177) One who is wholly free from disease has no fear of death.
('12', 381, 2, 26, 775235) The very fact that we all fear death shows that we are not healthy.
('12', 381, 2, 27, 775303) Death is for us a great transformation and, according to the law of creation, should be a
('12', 381, 3, 28, 775393) 1 Full of darkness
('12', 382, 0, 1, 775412) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 383
('12', 382, 1, 2, 775453) noble one.
('12', 382, 1, 3, 775464) It is our duty to strive for this lofty kind of health.
('12', 382, 1, 4, 775520) How such health can be gained and preserved, we shall inquire hereafter.
('12', 382, 2, 5, 775593) [From Gujarati]

('12', 382, 4, 7, 775635) 267. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('12', 382, 5, 8, 775669) PHOENIX, Thursday [January 23, 1913]
('12', 382, 6, 9, 775706) MY DEAR LOWER HOUSE,
('12', 382, 7, 10, 775727) My heart yearns often to write long letters to you, but I am obliged to deny myself the pleasure.
('12', 382, 7, 11, 775825) Such is the life here.
('12', 382, 7, 12, 775848) From 4.45 a.m.
('12', 382, 7, 13, 775863) to 10 p.m., I do not think I waste a single moment in talk.
('12', 382, 7, 14, 775923) I see no visitors except on Sundays.
('12', 382, 7, 15, 775960) But even Sunday is no free day with me.
('12', 382, 7, 16, 776000) On no other terms could the new scheme be worked here effectively.
('12', 382, 7, 17, 776067) My meal never now takes more than 15 minutes.
('12', 382, 7, 18, 776113) Between 11 and 12, bathing and dinner are finished.
('12', 382, 7, 19, 776165) Boys do no washing of pots now.
('12', 382, 7, 20, 776197) Miss West alone does it and she is at the school at the stroke of 12.30 p.m.
('12', 382, 7, 21, 776274) I do little personal correspondence now.
('12', 382, 7, 22, 776315) Even my London letters are only a few lines.
('12', 382, 7, 23, 776360) Thus do I cope with the day’s programme but only barely so.
('12', 382, 7, 24, 776420) The tension does not irritate me.
('12', 382, 7, 25, 776454) It gives me greater pleasure.
('12', 382, 7, 26, 776484) How I wish you could stand this life.
('12', 382, 7, 27, 776522) But I fear it is too much for you, at any rate at this stage.
('12', 382, 7, 28, 776584) How long I shall stand it remains to be seen.
('12', 382, 7, 29, 776630) But you will come and see things for yourself.
('12', 382, 7, 30, 776677) Meantime you are comparing notes and collecting your thoughts and yourself.
('12', 382, 7, 31, 776753) I know that you will not allow your head to guide you but your heart.
('12', 382, 7, 32, 776823) I suggest your putting the wagon and the mules at an auction sale as also everything else not required there.
('12', 382, 7, 33, 776933) Your books I am keeping as they are in their cases.
('12', 382, 7, 34, 776985) Only those tools which I require myself I have taken out and not the others.
('12', 382, 7, 35, 777062) I am just now on my trial.
('12', 382, 7, 36, 777089) The Government have rejected two of the names given by us of educated entrants.
('12', 382, 7, 37, 777169) This is a matter of principle and I have told them that passive resistance will be revived if they reject our nominees 1 .
('12', 382, 7, 38, 777292) So I might any moment have to abandon work here which is moulding me and those who are with me.
('12', 382, 7, 39, 777388) Secondly, I have as a matter of principle boycotted the Congress as I
('12', 382, 8, 40, 777458) 1 Vide “Does it Mean Passive Resistance?”, 18 1 1913.

('12', 383, 3, 15, 778174) 268. NONE TOO SOON
('12', 383, 4, 16, 778193) We publish elsewhere the report printed in a recent issue of the Times of Natal to the effect that the Union Government have decided to abolish the £3 tax exacted annually from time expired indentured Indians, their wives, and their children.
('12', 383, 4, 17, 778436) The news, if true, is a welcome relief, though it has come none too soon.
('12', 383, 4, 18, 778510) It was high time that the people of South Africa had washed their hands clean of this blood money.
('12', 383, 4, 19, 778609) We call it blood money after full deliberation.
('12', 383, 4, 20, 778657) A tax collected from a poor man, his wife, and his children, manifestly for the purpose of driving him and his family from a country for which he and his had slaved for five years, or driving him into a further term of slavery cannot be fittingly described by any other name.
('12', 383, 4, 21, 778933) When the abolition of the tax is an accomplished fact, the day should be observed as one of rejoicing by the Indian community, throughout South Africa, in that it will give relief to thousands of our dumb countrymen.
('12', 383, 4, 22, 779150) The credit will be Mr. Gokhale’s of this hateful impost is abolished this year.
('12', 383, 5, 23, 779230) Indian Opinion, 25 1 1913
('12', 383, 6, 24, 779256) 269. THE LICENSING QUESTION
('12', 383, 7, 25, 779284) A very significant reference appears in the address of the President of the Natal Municipal Association, at the annual meeting of that body at Utretcht, on the 20th instant.
('12', 383, 7, 26, 779458) We are informed that the
('12', 384, 0, 1, 779483) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 385
('12', 384, 1, 2, 779524) Financial Relations Bill, which was dropped in the last session of the Union Parliament, is to be reintroduced, with certain modifications, this session, and that its objects are, briefly, to transfer to Provincial Councils the revenue derived from dealers’ licences and the right to legislate, in regard thereto, “which means that, if the Bill passes in its present form the control of the licences will be placed in the hands of the Provincial Councils”.
('12', 384, 1, 3, 779981) If the effect of the Bill is to take from municipalities the control of trading licences, it will undoubtedly be a matter upon which the Indian community are to be congratulated.
('12', 384, 1, 4, 780160) If it means that the control of licences is to be transferred from the Union Government to the Provincial Councils, undoubtedly the result will be most injurious to the interest of the community.
('12', 384, 1, 5, 780356) We feel that the Bill has not received that consideration and criticism which it ought to have at the hands of the Indian public, and it is very much to be feared that it is in conflict with Section 147 of the South Africa Act, which provides that “the control and administration of matters specially or differentially affecting Asiatics throughout the Union shall vest in the Governor General in Council”, that is to say, the Union Parliament and not the Provincial Councils.
('12', 384, 1, 6, 780833) So far as Natal is concerned, it is notorious that widespread hopes of adding a still further burden to those already borne by the Indian population are entertained as a result of the adoption by the Provincial Council of Mr. G. H. Hulett’s resolution 1, in 1911, as an act of revenge for the stoppage of the importation of indentured labour from India.
('12', 384, 1, 7, 781187) There is no doubt that the question of trading licences was in the mind of the Imperial Government when they insisted upon the inclusion in the South Africa Act of the safeguards provided by Section 147. But if this Bill passes in the form that, we understand, it is to be brought forward, those safeguards will be rudely brushed aside, and since we are told on the authority of Imperial Ministers, that the King’s power of veto is little else than a sham and a delusion and its enunciation in the Royal instructions a mere diplomatic blind, it follows that Indian trading rights will be given an even more precarious character than hitherto, and that they will be speedily extinguished, unless Indians take up the challenge and offer a vigorous protest.
('12', 384, 2, 8, 781942) Indian Opinion, 25 1 1913
('12', 384, 3, 9, 781968) 1 Vide 11th footnote of “Memorial to Secretary of State for Colonies”, 15 5 1911.

('12', 386, 1, 2, 783896) 272. “CAN WE THUS ENSURE THE COUNTRY’S PROGRESS?”
('12', 386, 2, 3, 783946) This line is from a well known poem.
('12', 386, 2, 4, 783983) It came to mind when we read the following paragraph from Gujarati Panch:
('12', 386, 3, 5, 784057) Shrimant Sardar Balvantrai Bhai Saheb Scindia has set apart a sum of two lakh rupees from which to grant a monthly allowance of Rs. 125 to each Vaishnava who renounces the world and retires into vanavasa 1. Shrimant Sardar has donated this money in the fulness of his heart.
('12', 386, 3, 6, 784332) It is true that some worthy Vaishnavas take to vanavasa.
('12', 386, 3, 7, 784389) To enjoy vanavasa—to embrace mendicancy 2—is a lofty state.
('12', 386, 3, 8, 784449) However, holding out the inducement of a monthly allowance to a vanavasi 3 is tantamount to a betrayal [of him].
('12', 386, 3, 9, 784562) Vanavasa and money are mutually opposed.
('12', 386, 3, 10, 784603) It is our guess that Shrimant Sardar must have set apart this fund for the benefit of the vanavasi’s relations.
('12', 386, 3, 11, 784715) Even that, to my way of thinking, is faulty.
('12', 386, 3, 12, 784760) A vanavasi places no reliance on society for the maintenance of his family.
('12', 386, 3, 13, 784836) He commits his children to the Almighty.
('12', 386, 3, 14, 784877) If he takes out [as it were] an insurance policy thus taking man’s help for his wife and children, he cannot be deemed to have taken to vanavasa.
('12', 386, 3, 15, 785023) Moreover, one does not calculate so before adopting fakiri or vanavasa.
('12', 386, 3, 16, 785095) When the power seizes him, no one in the world can stop him.
('12', 386, 3, 17, 785156) There is a great likelihood of Shrimant Sardar’s [proferred] help promoting fraud.
('12', 386, 3, 18, 785239) Many who are Vaishnavas in name only will come forward to adopt vanavasa, and their families will draw a monthly allowance of Rs. 125 each.
('12', 386, 3, 19, 785379) It can perhaps be argued that these allowances will be granted each month only after proper scrutiny.
('12', 386, 3, 20, 785481) To this, our reply is that the family of a genuine vanavasi will not submit to scrutiny.
('12', 386, 3, 21, 785570) The true vanavasi will not himself give “notice”.
('12', 386, 3, 22, 785620) Such endowments are tantamount to fraud in the name of religion.
('12', 386, 3, 23, 785685) It is not by thus manufacturing vanavasis or patriots that [the cause of] the country can be advanced.
('12', 386, 3, 24, 785788) History records no instance of any country having progressed in this manner.

('12', 387, 2, 3, 786249) 2. OUR BODY
('12', 387, 3, 4, 786261) Earth and water, sky, fire and air
('12', 387, 4, 5, 786296) The play of these five elements, they call the Universe.
('12', 387, 5, 6, 786353) An almost full description of the human body is contained in this verse.
('12', 387, 5, 7, 786426) It says that the sport of Nature or her Creator with the five elements—earth, water, sky, light and air—which he mingles, is what we know by the name of the Universe.
('12', 387, 5, 8, 786593) From the substance of which this Universe is made has been fashioned this figure of clay which we call our body.
('12', 387, 5, 9, 786706) We have a saying among us, “as within the body so in the Universe” 1 and, “as with oneself, so with the country”.
('12', 387, 5, 10, 786820) If we remember this clue [to the mystery of the Universe] we shall certainly see that clean earth, pure water, fresh air and open space and bright sunshine are essential for the preservation of the body, and that we need not fear any of these elements.
('12', 387, 5, 11, 787073) In fact, illness follows when the body becomes comparatively deficient even in one of these.
('12', 387, 6, 12, 787166) It is imperative that we know at least this much about our body, but this knowledge is not adequate for our subject.
('12', 387, 7, 13, 787283) The body is made up of skin, bone, flesh and blood.
('12', 387, 7, 14, 787335) The skeleton provides the principal support for the body and it is that which enables us to stand upright and walk.
('12', 387, 7, 15, 787451) The bones protect the delicate parts of the body, the skull protects the brain and the ribs, the heart and the lungs.
('12', 387, 7, 16, 787569) There are 238 bones in the body by the doctors’ reckoning.
('12', 387, 7, 17, 787628) We can all see that a bone is hard outside, but it is not so inside; the inside is soft and hollow.
('12', 387, 7, 18, 787728) The joint where one bone is joined to another is covered with cartilage which is taken to be soft bone.
('12', 387, 8, 19, 787832) Our teeth, too, are bones.
('12', 387, 8, 20, 787859) During childhood, the milk teeth first appear and these fall out.
('12', 387, 8, 21, 787925) Then permanent teeth appear, which, once they drop out, do not grow again.
('12', 387, 8, 22, 788000) Milk teeth begin appearing between the ages of six and eight months and have almost all of them appeared by the time the child is bout two years old.
('12', 387, 8, 23, 788150) Permanent teeth begin to appear after the age of five and they have all grown by the time he is
('12', 387, 9, 24, 788246) 1 The saying is, “ ”.
('12', 388, 0, 1, 788268) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 389
('12', 388, 1, 2, 788309) between seventeen and twenty five.
('12', 388, 1, 3, 788344) The molars appear last of all.
('12', 388, 2, 4, 788375) If we feel our skin, we will find a number of knobs of flesh underneath at many places.
('12', 388, 2, 5, 788463) These are called muscles.
('12', 388, 2, 6, 788489) Our nerves get work out of them.
('12', 388, 2, 7, 788522) It is because of our muscles that we can open and close our hands, work our jaws and blink.
('12', 388, 2, 8, 788614) All these actions are performed with the aid of muscles.
('12', 388, 3, 9, 788671) Complete information about the body lies outside the scope of these chapters.
('12', 388, 3, 10, 788749) The writer himself does not possess this knowledge.
('12', 388, 3, 11, 788801) Only facts necessary for our purpose will be set out here.
('12', 388, 3, 12, 788860) Having, therefore, grasped the foregoing facts, we go on to the main parts of the body.
('12', 388, 3, 13, 788948) Among these, the stomach is the most important.
('12', 388, 3, 14, 788996) If the stomach were to slacken even for a moment, all our limbs would languish.
('12', 388, 3, 15, 789076) Even the most ferocious beast will not have the capacity to endure the strain which we subject the stomach to.
('12', 388, 3, 16, 789187) Its function is to digest food and nourish the body with the food so assimilated.
('12', 388, 3, 17, 789269) What the engine is to machinery, the stomach is to man.
('12', 388, 3, 18, 789325) This organ is to the left, beneath the ribs.
('12', 388, 3, 19, 789370) Having passed through many processes within it, the food is then broken down into different fluids and their [nutritive] element extracted, the remaining portion being expelled from the intestines as excreta.
('12', 388, 3, 20, 789579) Above the stomach is the left lobe of the liver.
('12', 388, 3, 21, 789628) To the left of the stomach is the spleen.
('12', 388, 3, 22, 789670) The liver is to the right beneath the ribs.
('12', 388, 3, 23, 789714) Its function is to purify the blood and produce bile which is needed for the digestive process.
('12', 388, 4, 24, 789810) Behind the ribs, in the hollow of the chest, are [located] other useful organs—the heart and the lungs.
('12', 388, 4, 25, 789914) The sac containing the heart is to the left, between the two lungs.
('12', 388, 4, 26, 789982) There are altogether 24 bones in the chest including both those to the left and to the right.
('12', 388, 4, 27, 790076) The heart pulsates between the fifth and the sixth ribs.
('12', 388, 4, 28, 790133) We have tow lungs, the left and the right, which consist of bronchial tubes.
('12', 388, 4, 29, 790210) These are filled with air and purify the blood.
('12', 388, 4, 30, 790258) Air reaches the lungs through the wind pipe.
('12', 388, 4, 31, 790303) This air must pass through the nostrils.
('12', 388, 4, 32, 790344) Air which thus passes through the nostrils is warmed before it reaches the lungs.
('12', 388, 4, 33, 790426) Many people, who are ignorant of the fact, breathe through the mouth and so do themselves harm.
('12', 388, 4, 34, 790522) The mouth is for eating, etc.
('12', 388, 4, 35, 790552) Air must be inhaled only through the nose.
('12', 388, 5, 36, 790595) We have briefly examined the structure of the body and got
('12', 389, 0, 1, 790654) 390 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 389, 1, 2, 790696) some idea of its important parts.
('12', 389, 1, 3, 790730) Now we shall examine the fluid— blood—on which the functioning of our body depends.
('12', 389, 1, 4, 790814) Blood provides us with nourishment.
('12', 389, 1, 5, 790850) It separates the nutritive part of the food, expels the useless products—excreta—and maintains the body at a constant temperature.
('12', 389, 1, 6, 790981) It flows continuously through veins and arteries.
('12', 389, 1, 7, 791031) It is to this flow that the pulse beat is due.
('12', 389, 1, 8, 791078) In a young and healthy person the pulse beats about 75 times a minute.
('12', 389, 1, 9, 791149) A child’s pulse is more rapid and that of an aged person slower.
('12', 389, 2, 10, 791214) The most important agent that keeps the blood pure is air.
('12', 389, 2, 11, 791273) The blood which enters the lungs, having circulated through the body, has become useless as it now contains poisonous substances.
('12', 389, 2, 12, 791403) The air inhaled into the lungs absorbs these toxic substances and passes on the oxygen it contains to the blood stream.
('12', 389, 2, 13, 791523) This process goes on constantly.
('12', 389, 2, 14, 791556) The inhaled air, laden with the poisons from the blood, then comes out and the blood, having taken up the oxygen, circulates through the arteries over the entire body.
('12', 389, 2, 15, 791724) One can imagine the extent to which the exhaled breath is impure.
('12', 389, 2, 16, 791790) Air has such tremendous effect on our bodies that it will be necessary to consider the subject in some detail in a separate chapter.

('12', 390, 2, 3, 792036) [PHOENIX, ] Post Vad 4 [January 26, 1913] 1
('12', 390, 3, 4, 792080) HARILAL, Medh has had a letter is which his father gives news of your failure.
('12', 390, 3, 5, 792159) You should have written to me.
('12', 390, 3, 6, 792190) I have not felt disappointed over your failure.
('12', 390, 3, 7, 792238) Since you have resolved to pass that examination, go on working for it again.
('12', 390, 3, 8, 792316) Send me your question papers.
('12', 390, 3, 9, 792346) You must have preserved them.
('12', 390, 3, 10, 792376) Let me know in which subject you failed.
('12', 390, 3, 11, 792417) I read in Mumbai Samachar 2 that you were present at the Gokhale meeting.
('12', 390, 3, 12, 792491) Give me your impressions of it.
('12', 390, 3, 13, 792523) I am arranging to go there in six months.
('12', 390, 3, 14, 792565) I should certainly be able to go if a law satisfying to our demands is passed; so it appears.
('12', 390, 3, 15, 792659) I have therefore settled in Phoenix.
('12', 390, 3, 16, 792696) I don’t wish to stir out from here for five months.
('12', 390, 3, 17, 792748) There are in all 30 children to be taught, including those in Phoenix.
('12', 390, 3, 18, 792819) 3 Jekibehn, Miss West, one Patel named Maganbhai 4, Kashi and I do the teaching.
('12', 390, 3, 19, 792900) I get up at 4.45 in the morning and wake up the children at five.
('12', 390, 3, 20, 792966) The press hands, the schoolchildren and I do farming from 6 to 8. Between 8 and 8.30, the students and the press hands have breakfast.
('12', 390, 3, 21, 793101) At 8.30, all the press hands return to the land and work there until 11. I take the children to the school, where they are taught to read and write from 8.30 to 10.30. From 10.30 to 11, again, they learn farm work.
('12', 390, 3, 22, 793316) Between 11 and 12.30, people bathe and eat.
('12', 390, 3, 23, 793360) From 12.30 to 4.30, work in the press where the older boys train for two hours; the last two hours [are spent on] reading and writing in the school.
('12', 390, 3, 24, 793509) I cannot at all look after the school in the afternoons.
('12', 390, 3, 25, 793566) I may be able to do so, I think, when things settle down a bit.
('12', 390, 4, 26, 793630) 1 The meeting referred to in paragraph 3 was convened by the Sheriff of Bom bay on December 14, 1912 to welcome Gokhale on his return from South Africa.

('12', 391, 5, 12, 794494) PHOENIX Friday [January 31, 1913]
('12', 391, 6, 13, 794528) MY DEAR LOWER HOUSE,
('12', 391, 7, 14, 794549) We are planting banana plants.
('12', 391, 7, 15, 794580) Sam was superintending.
('12', 391, 7, 16, 794604) His holes were not in a line.
('12', 391, 7, 17, 794634) He asked me if it would matter.
('12', 391, 7, 18, 794666) I said ‘no’ so far as I was concerned but that if you were here, you would certainly insist on the holes being in a line.
('12', 391, 7, 19, 794788) The next row of holes was straight.
('12', 391, 7, 20, 794824) I mention the incident to tell you how near you are to me in all I am doing.
('12', 391, 7, 21, 794901) I think of you continually during all the gardening operations and often wish you were near to advise me.
('12', 391, 7, 22, 795007) I relate the incident also to show how we two would have acted in the matter.
('12', 391, 7, 23, 795085) I knew the holes were wrong and allowed them to be proceeded with.
('12', 391, 7, 24, 795152) You would never have allowed it.
('12', 391, 7, 25, 795185) You would have had the wrong holes filled in.
('12', 391, 7, 26, 795231) I do not attach any permanent value to this work.
('12', 391, 7, 27, 795281) To me it is useful only in so far as it trains those who are engaged in it.
('12', 391, 7, 28, 795357) The work itself is being continually done and undone.
('12', 391, 7, 29, 795411) One man builds, another destroys and rebuilds according to his notions of rightness.
('12', 391, 7, 30, 795496) Who is right?
('12', 391, 7, 31, 795510) Who knows?
('12', 391, 7, 32, 795521) But we do know when we act to our souls’ profit and when we do not.
('12', 391, 7, 33, 795589) And that is all that matters on this earth.
('12', 391, 7, 34, 795633) It would certainly be a great thing if you would walk with Medh and Desai.
('12', 391, 7, 35, 795708) Do if you can.
('12', 391, 7, 36, 795723) No, I do not work in the knowledge that I am always to be in it.
('12', 391, 7, 37, 795788) On the contrary, here I am preparing for my withdrawal.
('12', 391, 7, 38, 795844) It is highly likely that some of the programme here you would like very well.

('12', 392, 4, 10, 796353) 276. A CORRECTION
('12', 392, 5, 11, 796371) In our issue of the 18th ultimo we referred to the recently published rules regarding the Natal schools, and we stated that the rules were framed for the first time prohibiting the entry of Indian children into the Government Schools not specially set apart for them.
('12', 392, 5, 12, 796639) Our attention has, however, been drawn to the fact that similar rules were framed some time ago and that we commented already upon them at the time.
('12', 392, 5, 13, 796788) We regret that we should have inferred from the rules in question that the authorities had added a new grievance to the heavy list already existing.
('12', 392, 5, 14, 796937) The wrong is none the less a serious one because it has existed for some time.
('12', 392, 5, 15, 797016) The Provincial Government might have taken the opportunity, seeing that they were recasting the rules, of removing the defect instead of perpetuating it.
('12', 392, 5, 16, 797170) Our attention has also been drawn to the fact that a hasty reader might conclude, from our remarks that Indian children in Natal could not receive education in the Government schools beyond the 4th Standard.
('12', 392, 5, 17, 797378) The friend to whom we are indebted for the caution points out that what was formerly the Higher Grade Indian School at Durban provides for the education of Indian children up to the 6th Standard.
('12', 392, 5, 18, 797574) This we knew perfectly well.
('12', 392, 5, 19, 797603) But we mentioned that Indian children could not, in effect, receive more than elementary education.
('12', 392, 5, 20, 797703) And the late Higher Grade School, whose name was always a misnomer, gives no more than elementary education.
('12', 392, 5, 21, 797812) The 6th Standard of that school is the 6th Standard of an elementary school, and hardly equal to the 4th Standard of a High School in India.
('12', 392, 5, 22, 797953) This school affords no scope for a lad who wishes to matriculate at the Cape University.
('12', 392, 5, 23, 798042) He may not be admitted to the ordinary High Schools or the Natal University College.
('12', 392, 5, 24, 798127) He must take private tuition.
('12', 393, 0, 1, 798157) 394 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 393, 1, 2, 798199) This is a handicap of which the community justly complains.
('12', 393, 1, 3, 798259) Mr. Merriman, the other day, suggested, at the opening of a Muslim school in Cape Town, that the true solution of the colour question was education.
('12', 393, 1, 4, 798408) Quite so.
('12', 393, 1, 5, 798418) But the Government of the Union puts every obstacle in the way of Coloured children, whether Natives or Asiatics.
('12', 393, 2, 6, 798532) Indian Opinion, 1 2 1913

('12', 393, 4, 10, 799017) 1 In General Hertzog’s estimation, evidently, Natives and Asiatics should be classed together.

('12', 393, 4, 17, 799570) He is still a powerful force in South African politics.
('12', 393, 4, 18, 799626) He apparently represents the extreme wing of the anti Asiatic party that would be satisfied with nothing less than our complete segregation and national humiliation.

('12', 394, 3, 9, 801414) 278. GERMISTON INDIANS
('12', 394, 4, 10, 801437) It appears from [a report in] the East Rand Express that the Indians in the Germiston Location will have to shift to a new Location by the end of February.
('12', 394, 4, 11, 801593) The Natives have all left.
('12', 394, 4, 12, 801620) The Municipality has paid them £1,500 by way of compensation.
('12', 394, 4, 13, 801682) The Indians have not shifted yet, though the Municipality is agreeable to paying them up to £700. Our friend the Express states that the Indians are not entitled to any such compensation.
('12', 394, 4, 14, 801870) If the Municipality pays it, it will be an act of grace and a matter of policy.
('12', 394, 4, 15, 801950) The idea is not to the liking of the Express.It argues that, if it is to be paid as a matter of policy, the cost should be borne by the Transvaal Government.
('12', 394, 4, 16, 802108) The Municipality is then welcome to accept a share of the cost if it want to.
('12', 394, 4, 17, 802186) The truth is that, whatever the Municipality pays, it will not be an act of grace, but it will be paid out of fear—fear of satyagraha, the London Committee and of the Imperial Government.
('12', 394, 4, 18, 802374) Suppose the slumbering Indians wake up!
('12', 394, 4, 19, 802414) Suppose Lord Ampthill discredits the Germiston Municipality in public!
('12', 394, 4, 20, 802485) Suppose the Imperial Government finds fault with it!
('12', 394, 4, 21, 802538) Any one of these fears the Municipality could face out; but it is meek in the face of them all [together].

('12', 394, 7, 24, 802686) 279. GENERAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT HEALTH [ V]
('12', 394, 9, 25, 802727) We have seen something of the structure of the body and have learnt that it requires three kinds of nourishment: air, water and food.
('12', 395, 0, 1, 802861) 396 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 395, 1, 2, 802903) Of these, air is the most essential.
('12', 395, 1, 3, 802940) Consequently, Nature has provided it to such extent that we can have it at no cost.
('12', 395, 1, 4, 803024) But modern civilization has put a price even on air.
('12', 395, 1, 5, 803077) In these times, one has to go off to distant places to take the air, and this costs money.
('12', 395, 1, 6, 803168) It is at Matheran that residents of Bombay can get fresh air and only then does their health improve.
('12', 395, 1, 7, 803270) In Bombay itself, if one can live on Malabar Hill, the air is much better.
('12', 395, 1, 8, 803345) But one must have money to do this.
('12', 395, 1, 9, 803381) If Durbanites want fresh air, they have to go to live in Berea.
('12', 395, 1, 10, 803445) That again means expense.
('12', 395, 1, 11, 803471) It would not, therefore, be quite true to say in modern times that “air is free”.
('12', 395, 1, 12, 803553) Whether air is free or has to be paid for, we cannot carry on without it for a moment.
('12', 395, 1, 13, 803640) We have seen that blood circulates through the entire body, is purified after returning to the lungs and flows out again.
('12', 395, 1, 14, 803762) This goes on all day and all night.
('12', 395, 1, 15, 803798) Every time we breathe out, we expel fouled air and, when we breathe in, we obtain from the air without, oxygen with which to purify the blood.
('12', 395, 1, 16, 803941) This respiration con tinues every moment and the life of our body depends upon it.
('12', 395, 1, 17, 804024) When we die of drowning, it only means we are unable to inhale oxygen and exhale foul air.
('12', 395, 1, 18, 804115) A pearl diver puts on a diving suit before he goes down into the water and obtains air from a tube [one end of] which remains above the water level.
('12', 395, 1, 19, 804264) It is because of it that he can remain under water for a long time.
('12', 395, 1, 20, 804332) Some doctors have conducted experiments which have esta blished that, if a person is kept without air for five minutes, the life giving breath leaves the body.
('12', 395, 1, 21, 804492) At times a baby [lying] close to its mother dies of suffocation.
('12', 395, 1, 22, 804557) This happens because the mouth and nose are smothered, and the baby gets no fresh air.
('12', 395, 1, 23, 804644) We see from all this that air is the most necessary nourishment for us, one that can be had without the asking.
('12', 395, 1, 24, 804756) We get food and water, only by asking for or seeking them, but air, we take in involuntarily.
('12', 395, 1, 25, 804850) Just as we hesitate to take foul water or food, so ought we to in the case of foul air.
('12', 395, 1, 26, 804938) In fact we do not take in unwholesome food or polluted water in the same quantities as we do in case of foul air.
('12', 395, 1, 27, 805052) The revulsion comes from the seeing.
('12', 395, 1, 28, 805089) [For] we worship idols.
('12', 395, 1, 29, 805113) 1 Air cannot be seen with the naked eye.
('12', 395, 1, 30, 805154) We therefore have no idea of how much foul air we take in.
('12', 395, 1, 31, 805213) We hesitate to eat food touched by another; we would think twice before drinking water which another has tasted
('12', 395, 2, 32, 805325) 1 That is, we believe only in good or evil that is visible.
('12', 396, 0, 1, 805385) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 397
('12', 396, 1, 2, 805426) before us.
('12', 396, 1, 3, 805437) Even if we felt no aversion 1 within us [towards filth or ugliness], we would never take the vomit of another.
('12', 396, 1, 4, 805548) If vomit is put even before one famine stricken, he would die rather than eat it.
('12', 396, 1, 5, 805630) But we all inhale, without revulsion, the air “spewed” by another—that is, exhaled by him.
('12', 396, 1, 6, 805721) According to the rules of hygiene, spewed air is just as bad as spewed food.
('12', 396, 1, 7, 805798) It has been proved that, if air exhaled by a man is introduced into the lungs of another, the latter dies instantaneously; so poisonous it is.
('12', 396, 1, 8, 805941) Yet people sitting of sleeping cooped up in a small room inhale, all the time, air which is as impure.
('12', 396, 1, 9, 806044) Fortunately, air is constantly in a state of movement and agitation and diffuses rapidly.
('12', 396, 1, 10, 806134) Moreover, it can enter through the smallest of pores.
('12', 396, 1, 11, 806188) Consequently, even as we are huddled in a room and fouling the air inside, some fresh air comes through a clearance in the door or chinks in the roof.
('12', 396, 1, 12, 806339) It is not wholly “spewed” air, therefore, that we [they] breathe.
('12', 396, 1, 13, 806405) The air exhaled by us is constantly being purified.
('12', 396, 1, 14, 806457) When we breathe the air inside us out into the open, the foul air diffuses ins tantly into the atmosphere, and Nature thus maintains the [required] quantity of pure air.
('12', 396, 1, 15, 806627) The atmosphere extends over a large area, enveloping this small earth.
('12', 396, 1, 16, 806698) We can now see why so many people are ailing and emaciated.
('12', 396, 1, 17, 806758) There is no doubt that bad air is the cause of more than 99 per cent.
('12', 396, 1, 18, 806828) of diseases.
('12', 396, 1, 19, 806841) Tuberculosis, fever and many diseases termed infectious are all caused by the foul air we inhale.
('12', 396, 1, 20, 806939) The first, the easiest and the last means of ending them is to have fresh air, purest of the pure.
('12', 396, 1, 21, 807038) There is no other, vaidya or hakim, that can match it.
('12', 396, 1, 22, 807093) Tuberculosis is a sign of rotting lungs, foul air being the cause.
('12', 396, 1, 23, 807160) Just as an engine is damaged through being fed with bad coal, so are our lungs by foul air.
('12', 396, 1, 24, 807252) Hence, modern doctors who understand [this] will invariably advise tuber culosis patients, as the first step in the treatment, to spend all the 24 hours in the open.
('12', 396, 1, 25, 807418) All other remedies take effect after this, but none will work without it.

('12', 399, 3, 7, 812122) 282. TWO IMMIGRATION CASES
('12', 399, 4, 8, 812149) Mr. Justice Broome has given judgment in two immigration cases.
('12', 399, 4, 9, 812213) They both deserve to be known.
('12', 399, 4, 10, 812244) In one case the father has complained that he had suffered a loss because the official had thrown his son out [of the country] without inquiry.
('12', 399, 4, 11, 812388) He had filed a suit for compensation and had also pleaded that he might be allowed to produce his son [in court].
('12', 399, 4, 12, 812502) The [claim of the] boy [to stay in the country] was rejected by the official.
('12', 399, 4, 13, 812580) The father then secured an interdict from the Supreme Court to stay his son’s being sent back to India.
('12', 399, 4, 14, 812684) Meanwhile, additional evidence was produced before the official, but he did not accept it.
('12', 399, 4, 15, 812775) The official then took legal steps to have the body deported.
('12', 399, 4, 16, 812837) The case was adjourned so that a summons could be issued.
('12', 399, 4, 17, 812895) Meanwhile the official changed his mind.
('12', 399, 4, 18, 812936) Assuming he had the [necessary] authority, he deported the boy without issuing a summons and obtaining the order of a court.
('12', 399, 4, 19, 813061) The father’s conten tion was that the official had no such authority.
('12', 399, 4, 20, 813131) The Court has rejected this contention and ruled that the official is empowered to deport anyone without the consent of the court.
('12', 399, 4, 21, 813262) This ruling will have fearful consequences.
('12', 399, 4, 22, 813306) Such are the tyrannical powers vested in the official that, if he chooses, he can extinguish the rights of every Indian [in the country].
('12', 399, 4, 23, 813444) The second case was for the refund of the deposit money of £100. 1 The Court has ruled that, if the deposit was made because of the Immigration Act, [the decision] to refund it or not lay within the discretion of the Government.
('12', 399, 4, 24, 813673) It can be refunded if the right of the person in respect of whom it was tendered is established, and for confiscating the money so deposited, the Government needs no order from the Court.
('12', 399, 4, 25, 813861) Arguing thus, the Court has dismissed the second case
('12', 399, 5, 26, 813915) 1 Wherever an Asiatic immigrant, appealing against the decision of an immigration official, wanted to have his domiciliary right tested by a court of law, he had to deposit this sum.
('12', 400, 0, 1, 814098) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 401
('12', 400, 1, 2, 814139) too; the Court has only said that where a deposit is made in good faith, the amount should be refunded on compassionate grounds.
('12', 400, 1, 3, 814268) The consequences of both these cases are fearful.
('12', 400, 1, 4, 814318) There has been a considerable accretion of official power, and a situation has come about in which Indians might stop coming to this land out of sheer fright.
('12', 400, 1, 5, 814477) It is our duty to wage a vigorous campaign against this.

('12', 402, 3, 11, 819867) 285. GENERAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT HEALTH [ VI]
('12', 402, 4, 12, 819909) We consume air not only with the lungs, but some portion of it is also taken in through the skin.
('12', 402, 4, 13, 820007) On the skin, there are pores, minute and innumerable, through which we draw air.
('12', 402, 4, 14, 820088) Everybody ought to know how a thing so essential may be kept clean.
('12', 402, 4, 15, 820156) Indeed, as soon as a child’s understanding is adequate, he should be taught about the importance of air.
('12', 402, 4, 16, 820261) If the readers of these chapters perform this easy but important task and, having acquired some general knowledge about air, live according to it, pass on the knowledge to their children and make them act in accordance, I shall regard myself as having fulfilled my task.
('12', 402, 4, 17, 820532) Latrines, Open spaces, narrow lanes [dirtied through misuse] and urinals, where these are separate, are the principal agencies for defilement of air.
('12', 402, 4, 18, 820682) Few are aware of the harm that can be caused by the filth from latrines.
('12', 402, 4, 19, 820755) When a cat or dog defecates, it generally paws a hole and, having defecated into it, covers the faeces over with earth.
('12', 402, 4, 20, 820875) Where modern water closets do not exist, this method ought to be followed.
('12', 402, 4, 21, 820950) We should keep a pail full of dry earth or ash in our latrines.
('12', 402, 4, 22, 821014) Every time the latrine is used, earth or ash should be sprinkled over the faeces so as to cover them over completely.
('12', 402, 4, 23, 821132) This will stop the smell, and it cannot then happen that flies and winged insects, having sat on the filth, come in contact with our bodies.
('12', 402, 4, 24, 821273) One whose nose has not become defective or inured to stench can easily realize how much foul odour, filthkept uncovered can spread.
('12', 402, 4, 25, 821405) If filth from a latrine were mixed in our food in our presence, we should be sick.
('12', 402, 4, 26, 821488) But there is not an iota of difference between air laden with the
('12', 403, 0, 1, 821554) 404 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 403, 1, 2, 821596) stench from a latrine and food mixed with faeces.
('12', 403, 1, 3, 821646) If there is, it is only that the latter is visible to our naked eye, while the former is not.
('12', 403, 1, 4, 821740) Seats, etc., in closets should be kept absolutely clean.
('12', 403, 1, 5, 821797) We are ashamed to do this kind of work ourselves, or fret at having to do it, instead of which we should feel disgust at having to use dirty latrines.
('12', 403, 1, 6, 821948) Why should we not ourselves clean up the filth excreted by our own body, which we make another person take away?
('12', 403, 1, 7, 822061) There is absolutely nothing bad about doing this work oneself; having learnt this for ourselves, we must teach it to our children as well.
('12', 403, 1, 8, 822200) When the pail is full, the contents should be thrown into a pit, a foot or two deep, and should be well covered over with earth.
('12', 403, 1, 9, 822329) If one is in the habit of going to the fields to defecate, one should go far from where people live.
('12', 403, 1, 10, 822430) There, one should dig a shallow pit with a spade to get one’s business over with and should fully cover the faeces with the earth dug.
('12', 403, 1, 11, 822565) We urinate any and everywhere and this fouls the air; it is a habit that must be wholly given up.
('12', 403, 1, 12, 822663) Where no special place is available for urination, we should go far from where people live; having made water on dry ground, we should sprinkle the spot with earth.
('12', 403, 1, 13, 822828) There are forceful reasons, however, why excreta should not be buried too deep.
('12', 403, 1, 14, 822908) One is that the heat of the sun cannot then do its work and the second that it may affect the neighbouring springs.
('12', 403, 1, 15, 823024) We spit on the carpet, on the floor, in the courtyard and where soever we can.
('12', 403, 1, 16, 823103) Spittle is often poisonous.
('12', 403, 1, 17, 823131) The sputum of a tubercular patient is extremely dangerous.
('12', 403, 1, 18, 823190) Germs rising from it get into the air inhaled by others and do great harm.
('12', 403, 1, 19, 823265) Over and above that, the house is dirtied, but that is another matter.
('12', 403, 1, 20, 823336) In this regard our duty is not to spit any and everywhere inside the house, but to keep a spittoon.
('12', 403, 1, 21, 823436) Outdoors, one should spit, if one has to, on dry ground where there is plenty of dust.
('12', 403, 1, 22, 823523) The sputum will mix with the dry earth and the damage will be less.
('12', 403, 1, 23, 823591) Some doctors are of the opinion that tubercular patients should spit only into receptacles containing germicide.
('12', 403, 1, 24, 823704) Even if a patient spits onto the dust on dry ground, the germs in his sputum are not destroyed.
('12', 403, 1, 25, 823800) This dust carrying the germs rises into the atmosphere and infects others.
('12', 403, 1, 26, 823875) Whether this opinion is right or wrong, we can at least learn this much from it: spitting any and everywhere is a dirty and injurious habit.
('12', 403, 1, 27, 824016) Some people are in the habit of throwing food, refuse and peelings, etc., all over.
('12', 403, 1, 28, 824100) If this garbage was buried in the ground near the surface, it would not foul the air; also it would in due course make
('12', 404, 0, 1, 824219) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 405
('12', 404, 1, 2, 824260) useful manure.
('12', 404, 1, 3, 824275) One should never throw out perishables.
('12', 404, 1, 4, 824315) It has been found from experience that these suggestions are easily put into practice, once they are understood.
('12', 404, 1, 5, 824428) We have seen how air is fouled through our bad habits and how this can be stopped.
('12', 404, 1, 6, 824511) We shall now consider how it should be inhaled.

('12', 405, 6, 17, 827305) The return of Mr. Gokhale to India after his triumphant tour in South Africa has brought the Indian question of South Africa to the front as perhaps it has not been before except during Mr. Polak’s stay in India.
('12', 405, 6, 18, 827518) But the public in India, during Mr. Polak’s stay there was invariably sympathetic and uncritical.
('12', 405, 6, 19, 827616) This in a way was a drawback.
('12', 405, 6, 20, 827646) Mr. Gokhale’s landing in Bombay led, on the one hand, to the unique demonstration there as described by the Times correspondent, and to criticism of Mr. Gokhale’s work, on the other.
('12', 405, 6, 21, 827829) The criticism, in our humble opinion, was hasty and ill conceived.
('12', 405, 6, 22, 827896) What Mr. Gokhale never did was imputed to him, and the very compromise, which was
('12', 405, 7, 23, 827978) 1 South Africa British Indian Committee, London
('12', 406, 0, 1, 828026) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 407
('12', 406, 1, 2, 828067) universally approved two years ago, was now condemned, because Mr. Gokhale had, on local examination, confirmed his original attitude towards it.
('12', 406, 1, 3, 828213) Mr. Gokhale, therefore, immediately upon landing, had to enter into a defence of his own action and the part Mr. Gandhi had played in the compromise.
('12', 406, 1, 4, 828363) 1 Mr. Gokhale’s defence was, as was only to be expected, convincing.
('12', 406, 1, 5, 828432) He returned to the subject at Poona, where, too, a great demonstration of welcome was held.
('12', 406, 1, 6, 828524) But the most crushing reply to this critics was made by Mr. Gokhale at Bankipore, 2
('12', 406, 2, 7, 828608) where he held the Congress audience spellbound for more than an hour.
('12', 406, 2, 8, 828678) The result of the discussion is that the very papers that either themselves adversely criticized Mr. Gokhale’s South African achiev ement, or allowed their regular correspondents to offer irresponsible and ill informed criticism, have veered round, acknowledged their mistake, and admitted that Mr. Gokhale was right, that he had not surrendered a single principle, and that he had dealt with the problem in a calm, statesmanlike, and patriotic spirit, as he alone could do.
('12', 406, 2, 9, 829153) He said or did nothing new, but he did the same thing that was done by the local Indians in his own original manner, and threw the weight of his great influence and prestige in our favour.
('12', 406, 2, 10, 829342) He did not speak or act for India, because he was not its accredited agent, and yet he spoke unofficially both for India and, indeed, the Empire.
('12', 406, 2, 11, 829488) For Mr. Gokhale, in spite of his critics, remains the idol of his people, and commands the respect of the Empire as no other living Indian does.
('12', 406, 2, 12, 829633) We hope to be able shortly to reproduce Mr. Gokhale’s speech at the Congress, and an epitome of the criticism, adverse and otherwise.
('12', 406, 2, 13, 829767) The ferment created by Mr. Gokhale’s visit to South Africa and his return has done good in that the reacceptance of the compromise by the majority of his critics will, being now informed, add greater weight to any further agitation that may go on in India in our favour.
('12', 406, 2, 14, 830038) And, Heaven knows, we want all the assistance still from the Motherland that she can give us!
('12', 406, 2, 15, 830132) We are but at the fringe of our troubles.

('12', 407, 4, 11, 831699) 289. GENERAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT HEALTH [ VII]
('12', 407, 5, 12, 831742) We saw in the previous chapter that the correct way of inhaling air is through the nose—not the mouth; few really know how to breathe correctly.
('12', 407, 5, 13, 831887) Many people breathe through the mouth.
('12', 407, 5, 14, 831926) This habit is injurious.
('12', 407, 5, 15, 831951) If very cold air is inhaled through the mouth, one catches a cold and the voice drops.
('12', 407, 5, 16, 832038) Dust particles in the air enter the lungs of one who breathes through the mouth and they often do much damage.
('12', 407, 5, 17, 832149) One immediately experiences this at first hand in a large city like London.
('12', 407, 5, 18, 832225) Thanks to the large number of chimneys, frequent “fogs”—yellow mists—form in that city in November.
('12', 407, 5, 19, 832325) Minute black particles are suspended in the fog.
('12', 407, 5, 20, 832374) They will be found in the sputum of one who inhales air laden with this dust.
('12', 407, 5, 21, 832452) To avoid this happening, some women, who are not accus tomed to breathing through the nose, tie a gauze mask over their mouths.
('12', 407, 5, 22, 832580) This gauze serves as a kind of strainer.
('12', 407, 5, 23, 832621) The air passing through it is cleared.
('12', 407, 5, 24, 832660) If this mask is examined after use, these particles are seen.
('12', 407, 5, 25, 832722) God has placed a similar filter in our nose.
('12', 407, 5, 26, 832767) Air breathed in through the nose reaches the lungs only after it has been cleansed.
('12', 407, 5, 27, 832851) Moreover, this air goes down after it has been warmed.
('12', 407, 5, 28, 832906) Keeping these
('12', 408, 0, 1, 832920) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 409
('12', 408, 1, 2, 832961) facts in mind, everyone should learn to breathe in only through the nose.
('12', 408, 1, 3, 833035) This is no difficult matter.
('12', 408, 1, 4, 833064) When we are not talking, the mouth should be kept shut.
('12', 408, 1, 5, 833120) Those who have got into the habit of leaving their mouths open should sleep at night with a bandage over the mouth.
('12', 408, 1, 6, 833236) Breathing then will necessarily be through the nose.
('12', 408, 1, 7, 833289) One should also take about 20 deep breaths through the nose, morning and evening, standing in the open.
('12', 408, 1, 8, 833393) By so doing the habit of breathing through the nose is formed.
('12', 408, 1, 9, 833456) Even if a healthy person who is accustomed to breathing through the nose does this, his chest will become strong and broad.
('12', 408, 1, 10, 833580) This experiment should be tried by everyone.
('12', 408, 1, 11, 833625) One should measure one’s chest before commencing this experiment and again a month later.
('12', 408, 1, 12, 833715) One will find that the chest has become appreciably broader even in so short a period.
('12', 408, 1, 13, 833802) Sandow and others get people to exercise with dumb bells, and the principle underlying it is the same.
('12', 408, 1, 14, 833905) Exercising briskly with dumb bells makes one breathe hard and deep.
('12', 408, 1, 15, 833973) And this makes the chest broad and strong.
('12', 408, 1, 16, 834016) Together with the knowledge of how to breathe, it is also necessary to develop the habit of inhaling fresh air day and night.
('12', 408, 1, 17, 834142) Our normal custom is to remain confined in our house or shop by day, and at night to sleep in a room that is like a safe.
('12', 408, 1, 18, 834264) If the room has doors and windows, we shut them.
('12', 408, 1, 19, 834313) This habit must be strongly deprecated.
('12', 408, 1, 20, 834353) It is imperative that we inhale pure air for as long as possible, especially while sleeping.
('12', 408, 1, 21, 834446) Everyone who can manage to do so should accordingly sleep in an open veranda or on the terrace, outside the house or on the balcony.
('12', 408, 1, 22, 834579) Those who do not have the good fortune to be able to do this should keep as many doors and windows open as possible.
('12', 408, 1, 23, 834696) There is no need to fight shy of air, which is our staple diet twenty four hours of the day.
('12', 408, 1, 24, 834789) The notion that the fresh or raw air of morning causes illness is a mere superstition.
('12', 408, 1, 25, 834876) It is possible that one who has spoiled his lungs through bad habits may contract a cold by sudden contact with fresh air, but one should not be afraid of this cold.
('12', 408, 1, 26, 835042) In Europe, at various places, they have now put up, for persons suffering from tuberculosis, spacious buildings, which admit plenty of fresh air.
('12', 408, 1, 27, 835188) The chief cause of the pestilence of plague in our own country is our bad habit of fouling the air and inhaling this defiled air.
('12', 408, 1, 28, 835318) That even the most delicate of persons can only benefit from fresh air is a certain truth.
('12', 408, 1, 29, 835409) If we learn not to foul the atmosphere and to take
('12', 409, 0, 1, 835460) 410 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 409, 1, 2, 835502) in only fresh air, we will, without any effort on our part, be spared many diseases, and the charge of slovenliness made against us in lands such as South Africa will to some extent be obviated.
('12', 409, 1, 3, 835697) Just as it is needful to sleep in the open, so it is not to cover one’s face during sleep.
('12', 409, 1, 4, 835788) It is the habit of many Indians to sleep with their faces covered.
('12', 409, 1, 5, 835855) By so doing, we inhale the foul air we have exhaled.
('12', 409, 1, 6, 835908) Air is a thing that finds its way through the smallest of passages.
('12', 409, 1, 7, 835976) However we muffle ourselves, some air does get in.
('12', 409, 1, 8, 836027) If this did not happen, we would die of asphyxiation whenever we sleep covered right up to the head.
('12', 409, 1, 9, 836128) But this does not happen, since some air from without, with oxygen in it, does enter; however that is not enough.
('12', 409, 1, 10, 836242) If one feels cold in the head, one can cover it separately as with a Balaclava cap, leaving the nose uncovered.
('12', 409, 1, 11, 836354) However cold it may be, one should never sleep with the nose covered.
('12', 409, 1, 12, 836424) Air and light are so closely connected that a word or two must be said about light in this chapter itself.
('12', 409, 1, 13, 836531) As we cannot live without air, so we cannot do without light.
('12', 409, 1, 14, 836593) Hell is conceived as absence of light.
('12', 409, 1, 15, 836632) Where there is no light, the air is always unwholesome.
('12', 409, 1, 16, 836688) When we enter a dark room, we are bound to become aware of the smell.
('12', 409, 1, 17, 836758) We cannot use our eyes in the dark; and this proves that we are born to live in the light.
('12', 409, 1, 18, 836849) The darkness that Nature has thought necessary for us, she has given us by creating the comfort giving night.
('12', 409, 1, 19, 836959) Many people have got into the habit of sitting or sleeping, on the hottest of days, in cellar like rooms, having shut out light and air.
('12', 409, 1, 20, 837096) Those who live without air and light look weak and lustreless.
('12', 409, 1, 21, 837159) In Europe nowadays, some doctors cure their patients by prescribing plenty of light and fresh air.
('12', 409, 1, 22, 837258) It is not only the face that they expose to light and air; the patient is almost stripped and they then bring fresh air and light to play on the skin all over the body.
('12', 409, 1, 23, 837427) Hundreds of persons are cured by this treatment.
('12', 409, 1, 24, 837476) In order to allow light and air to enter and leave freely, the windows of the house should be kept open day and night.
('12', 409, 1, 25, 837595) On reading this, people will wonder how it is that, if light and air are so necessary, many who remain confined to their rooms do not suffer any harm.
('12', 409, 1, 26, 837746) It must be said that those who entertain this doubt have not thought about the matter.
('12', 409, 1, 27, 837833) Our subject is not how to exist anyhow, but how to live, if possible, in perfect health.
('12', 409, 1, 28, 837922) It has been conclusively proved that, where people get insufficient air and light, they are unwell all the time.
('12', 409, 1, 29, 838035) City dwellers are more delicate
('12', 410, 0, 1, 838067) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 411
('12', 410, 1, 2, 838108) than village folk because they get less light and air.
('12', 410, 1, 3, 838163) Among our people in Durban, diseases such as tuberculosis are prevalent and the Medical Officer ascribes it to the fact that we live in such conditions that we either cannot get or do not take in fresh air.
('12', 410, 1, 4, 838370) The subject of air and light has so close a relation to good health that one should pay great attention to understanding it.
('12', 410, 1, 5, 838495) [From Gujarati]

('12', 410, 7, 32, 839783) 291. GOHKALE IN INDIA
('12', 410, 8, 33, 839805) Mr. Gokhale has made three noteworthy speeches in India and reports of these along with comments have reached us.
('12', 410, 8, 34, 839919) The speeches
('12', 411, 0, 1, 839932) 412 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 411, 1, 2, 839974) were made in Bombay, in Poona and at the Congress at Bankipore.
('12', 411, 1, 3, 840038) The speech at the Congress has been considered the best.
('12', 411, 1, 4, 840095) It lasted, they say, an hour and was listened to with rapt attention by the audience; such great effect did it have.
('12', 411, 1, 5, 840212) As soon as Mr. Gokhale landed at Bombay, he found two groups.
('12', 411, 1, 6, 840274) One, headed by Sir Pherozeshah 1, considered that Mr. Gokhale had returned after having given away Indians’ rights.
('12', 411, 1, 7, 840390) He had not done right [they argued] to assent to the settlement arrived at through Mr. Gandhi.
('12', 411, 1, 8, 840485) One writer even went to the extent of remarking that the money sent to South Africa had all been wasted.
('12', 411, 1, 9, 840590) This group was of the view that Gokhale should not only have secured Indians’ legal rights to enter South Africa but should also have asked permission for unlimited numbers—[indeed] for any Indian who may wish to do so.
('12', 411, 1, 10, 840810) It made no difference to this group that, in case such freedom was denied, all the Indians might have to quit.
('12', 411, 1, 11, 840921) That this group is a very small one is shown by the meetings that Gokhale addressed in Bombay and Poona and at the Congress for, at these, no one came forward to oppose him.
('12', 411, 1, 12, 841095) However, a paper like The Bengalee was misled by this group.
('12', 411, 1, 13, 841156) After Mr. Gokhale’s Congress speech, newspapers which had earlier made adverse comments showed regret and said that they had written under a misconception.
('12', 411, 1, 14, 841312) 2 Speaking at the Congress, Mr. Gokhale has explained [his case ] so well that nothing can now be said against his action.
('12', 411, 1, 15, 841435) What is more, it should now be conceded that what he did was best.
('12', 411, 1, 16, 841502) We think that it has been all to the good that there was difference of opinion in India and that Mr. Gokhale’s action had
('12', 411, 2, 17, 841624) 1 Sir Pherozeshah Merwahnji Mehta; “uncrowned king” of Bombay who “roared like a lion in law courts”; was associated with the Congress since its inception and presided over its sixth session at Calcutta in 1890; elected President of the 24th Session of the Congress (in 1991) but resigned dramatically six days before assumption of office; did much committee work for the Congress, particularly in connection with the protest against the Public Service Commission recommendations in 1892; member of the 1894 deputation to Lord Elgin; in 1896, met Gandhiji for the first time “as a loving father would meet his grown up son” and helped him to call a public meeting in Bombay which both of them addressed; in 1901, advised Gandhiji against going to South Africa; first sceptical of satyagraha because he thought that nothing could be done for Indians abroad unless the country was free, but declared at a Bombay meeting in 1914 that “his blood boiled at the thought of these women lying in jails”.
('12', 411, 2, 18, 842620) 2 Vide “Mr. Gokhale at the National Congress”, 4 1 1913 and “Gokhale’s Speech in India”, 4 1 1913
('12', 412, 0, 1, 842718) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 413
('12', 412, 1, 2, 842759) been criticized.
('12', 412, 1, 3, 842776) This gave rise to a great debate all over the country on our problem, which led to a better understanding of the true signifi cance of our campaign.
('12', 412, 1, 4, 842925) Those who had so far had only a superficial understanding now began to go deeper into the matter.

('12', 412, 3, 14, 843646) Indian Opinion, 22 2 1913
('12', 412, 4, 15, 843672) 292. GENERAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT HEALTH [ VIII]
('12', 412, 5, 16, 843716) 4. WATER
('12', 412, 6, 17, 843725) We have seen earlier that air is food.
('12', 412, 6, 18, 843764) The same is true of water.
('12', 412, 6, 19, 843791) Air enjoys the first position, and water comes second.
('12', 412, 6, 20, 843846) Without air man can survive only for a few minutes, whereas he can live without water for hours, even for days on end, depending on the country.
('12', 412, 6, 21, 843991) Even so, it is certain that one cannot subsist without water for as long as one can without food.
('12', 412, 6, 22, 844089) If, however, a person can have water, he can live for many days without food.
('12', 412, 6, 23, 844167) Water makes up more than 70 per cent.
('12', 412, 6, 24, 844205) of our body.
('12', 412, 6, 25, 844218) Without water, it is believed, the body would weigh 8 to 12 lbs.
('12', 412, 6, 26, 844283) In all that we eat, there is more or less water.
('12', 412, 6, 27, 844332) Yet we take proportionately little care of a thing which, for us, is very important.
('12', 412, 6, 28, 844417) Diseases like the plague beset us because of our carelessness in the mater of air.
('12', 412, 6, 29, 844500) Similar results follow from our carelessness regarding water.
('12', 412, 6, 30, 844562) Typhoid often breaks out among troops in battle and the cause, it has been proved, is polluted water, because on the front soldiers have to drink whatever water they can get.
('12', 412, 6, 31, 844737) Typhoid breaks out also among those who live in cities, and the cause is mostly bad water.
('12', 412, 6, 32, 844828) Drinking bad water often gives rise to diseases like stone.
('12', 412, 6, 33, 844888) There are two causes for contamination of water—one, that the
('12', 413, 0, 1, 844950) 414 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 413, 1, 2, 844992) water is found in places where it cannot remain pure, and two, that we sully the water.
('12', 413, 1, 3, 845080) We ought not to drink water which is stores in or comes from a dirty place, and for the most part, we do not; but we do not hesitate to drink water which has been polluted by us through neglect.
('12', 413, 1, 4, 845275) For instance, we throw whatever we like into a river and then proceed to use that very water for drinking and washing.
('12', 413, 1, 5, 845394) The rule is that one should never drink water from the place where one bathes.
('12', 413, 1, 6, 845473) River water should be drawn from a spot up stream where no one bathes.
('12', 413, 1, 7, 845544) In every village, therefore, the river should be divided into two sections—the lower section for bathing and washing and the upper for drinking.
('12', 413, 1, 8, 845689) When an army camps in the vicinity of a river, the direction of the river flow is ascertained and a flag put up [at a given spot] on the bank.
('12', 413, 1, 9, 845832) Anyone who bathes in a place higher up is punished.
('12', 413, 1, 10, 845884) Where, in our country, these arrangements do not exist, careful women dig pits in the river bed and take water from these; this practice is very wholesome as the water gets filtered as it passes through the sand.
('12', 413, 1, 11, 846097) Well water is sometimes dangerous to drink.
('12', 413, 1, 12, 846141) In shallow wells, the liquid from the excreta absorbed into the surrounding ground seeps in and pollutes the water.
('12', 413, 1, 13, 846257) Sometimes dead birds fall into them; often birds build their nests within.
('12', 413, 1, 14, 846332) Moreover, if there is no masonry round the well [at the top], dirt from the feet of persons drawing water falls into the well and fouls the water.
('12', 413, 1, 15, 846479) It is therefore necessary to employ the utmost care in using well water for drinking.
('12', 413, 1, 16, 846565) Water stored in tanks is oftentimes bad.
('12', 413, 1, 17, 846606) To prevent deterioration of such water, the tanks should be cleaned from time to time and kept covered; the roof and other places from where [drinking] water comes should be kept clean.
('12', 413, 1, 18, 846792) Few, however, make the effort to maintain such cleanliness.
('12', 413, 1, 19, 846852) The golden rule is therefore to rid the water of impurities to the extent possible; to boil it for half an hour; to let it stand for a time; to pour it into another vessel without disturbing the water and then to drink it only after straining it through thick, clean cloth into a third vessel.
('12', 413, 1, 20, 847146) One who does this is, however, not released from his duty towards others.
('12', 413, 1, 21, 847220) Water which is maintained for public use is in the nature of property which jointly belongs to him and to all others living in the locality.
('12', 413, 1, 22, 847361) He is obliged to use it like a trustee.
('12', 413, 1, 23, 847401) He must, therefore, do nothing which might foul the water in any way.
('12', 413, 1, 24, 847471) He must never foul a river or well.
('12', 413, 1, 25, 847507) He must not bathe or wash clothes near any source of drinking water or defecate in the vicinity.
('12', 413, 1, 26, 847604) He may not cremate dead bodies near by or throw the ashes into the water.
('12', 413, 1, 27, 847678) Even after taking these precautions, we do not get water that is
('12', 414, 0, 1, 847743) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 415
('12', 414, 1, 2, 847784) perfectly pure.
('12', 414, 1, 3, 847800) It contains a certain amount of salts and, occasionally, rotten vegetable matter.
('12', 414, 1, 4, 847882) Rain water is regarded as the purest of all, but before it reaches us the dust particles, etc., in the atmosphere get mixed with it.
('12', 414, 1, 5, 848015) Absolutely pure water has a different effect on the body.
('12', 414, 1, 6, 848073) Knowing this, certain doctors prescribe distilled water for their patients.
('12', 414, 1, 7, 848149) This water is made by boiling water into steam and cooling the latter.
('12', 414, 1, 8, 848220) Anyone suffering from constipation may, if he chooses, have first hand proof of the efficacy of distilled water.
('12', 414, 1, 9, 848333) Such water is sold by all chemists.
('12', 414, 1, 10, 848369) A book has recently been published on the subject of distilled water and its uses.
('12', 414, 1, 11, 848452) The writer believes that a large number of diseases can be cured by the use of water so processed.
('12', 414, 1, 12, 848551) This is an exaggeration, but it is not improbable that absolutely pure water has considerable effect on the body.
('12', 414, 1, 13, 848665) Not everyone knows that water is of two kinds, hard and soft; but the fact is noteworthy.
('12', 414, 1, 14, 848755) Hard water is that in which soap does not readily lather but remains insoluble.
('12', 414, 1, 15, 848835) This means that the water contains salts in large quantities.
('12', 414, 1, 16, 848897) It is difficult to use soap with hard water, as it is with brackish water.
('12', 414, 1, 17, 848972) With hard water, cooking too is difficult and, for the same reason, drinking it should, and does, make it difficult for us to digest our food.
('12', 414, 1, 18, 849115) Hard water always tastes brackish whereas soft water is either sweet or tasteless.
('12', 414, 1, 19, 849198) Some believe that, as the substances dissolved in hard water are nutritive, its use is beneficial, but we generally find that soft water is the right one to use.
('12', 414, 1, 20, 849360) Rain is Nature’s purest form of water.
('12', 414, 1, 21, 849399) It is of course soft and all agree it is good to use.
('12', 414, 1, 22, 849453) If hard water is boiled on a chula for half an hour, it becomes soft.
('12', 414, 1, 23, 849523) After it is taken off the fire, it should be processed as described earlier.
('12', 414, 1, 24, 849600) When to drink water and how much—the question sometimes arises.
('12', 414, 1, 25, 849664) The simple answer to this is that water should be drunk when one feels thirsty and enough to quench one’s thirst.
('12', 414, 1, 26, 849778) There is nothing wrong in drinking water during or after a meal.
('12', 414, 1, 27, 849843) Those who drink in the course of a meal should, however, remember that water is not to be drunk for washing down the food.
('12', 414, 1, 28, 849966) If food does not go down by itself, that is either because it has not been properly chewed or because the stomach does not need it.
('12', 414, 1, 29, 850098) In fact, it is not—and it should not be—generally necessary to drink water.
('12', 414, 1, 30, 850174) Just as our bodies consist of over 70 per cent.
('12', 414, 1, 31, 850222) of water, so does our food.
('12', 414, 1, 32, 850250) In some foods, the proportion of water far exceeds 70 per cent.
('12', 414, 1, 33, 850314) There is no food that is wholly devoid of water.
('12', 414, 1, 34, 850363) Furthermore,
('12', 415, 0, 1, 850376) 416 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 415, 1, 2, 850418) much water is used in cooking.
('12', 415, 1, 3, 850449) Why then does one feel thirsty?
('12', 415, 1, 4, 850481) A complete answer to this question can be had only by reference to the constituents of our diet.
('12', 415, 1, 5, 850578) Here, it may be simply said that those whose diet does not contain things like spices and chillies, which create an unnatural thirst, need only a little water.
('12', 415, 1, 6, 850738) Those whose diet consists mainly of fresh fruit will seldom want to drink water by itself.
('12', 415, 1, 7, 850829) If a person is constantly thirsty without reason, we may take it that he suffers from something or the other.
('12', 415, 1, 8, 850939) One notices that some people drink water indiscriminately, having superficially observed others doing so without any apparent ill effects.
('12', 415, 1, 9, 851078) The answer that was given to a similar question in the chapter on air applies here also.
('12', 415, 1, 10, 851167) Moreover, the blood in our body possesses such wonderful properties that it destroys a number of toxins itself.
('12', 415, 1, 11, 851279) But a fine sword is damaged if not burnished after use, and so with blood.
('12', 415, 1, 12, 851354) If we get blood to do the work of a watchman, but do not look after it, it is not surprising that its power is sapped and finally lost altogether.
('12', 415, 1, 13, 851501) Thus, if one always drinks bad water, the blood will in the end certainly stop doing its work.

('12', 415, 6, 18, 851701) MY DEAR LOWER HOUSE,
('12', 415, 7, 19, 851722) Your letter calls for a long reply.
('12', 415, 7, 20, 851758) I see that you are very happy.
('12', 415, 7, 21, 851789) The remedy is not in Palestine, not in studies in London.
('12', 415, 7, 22, 851847) It lies in two things: either in applying yourself entirely to your office and studying whilst in practice or in your living with me and coming to India.
('12', 415, 7, 23, 852001) The first is hardly feasible for you as you are; the second is, as you yourself say, the course for you but it is hard.
('12', 415, 7, 24, 852121) There’s the rub.
('12', 415, 7, 25, 852138) You want to avoid difficulties and yet do the right thing.
('12', 415, 7, 26, 852197) The two things are inconsistent.
('12', 415, 7, 27, 852230) You would study in London.
('12', 415, 7, 28, 852257) That is an easy life and pleasant.
('12', 415, 7, 29, 852292) No worry of office.

('12', 415, 7, 31, 852450) It won’t do.
('12', 415, 7, 32, 852463) You have to see happiness in unhappiness and feel that life is made up of wordly miseries which rightly understood hammer us into shape.
('12', 415, 7, 33, 852600) You cannot

('12', 416, 1, 20, 853765) You are acted upon by what is good in others.
