('12', 417, 6, 15, 855283) 295. JOHANNESBURG SCHOOL
('12', 417, 7, 16, 855308) It was only recently that this school was started, but there seems to be trouble already.
('12', 417, 7, 17, 855398) Everyone has been under the impression that Tamil and Gujarati will be taught during school hours.
('12', 417, 7, 18, 855497) We now hear that Tamil can only be taught outside school hours, which means it cannot be taught at all.
('12', 417, 7, 19, 855601) If the Government does that, that will be a great injustice.
('12', 417, 7, 20, 855662) In a talk with member of the School Board, Mr. Gokhale was given a clear promise that the Government would arrange for the teaching of any Indian Language if there was a considerable number of students of that Language [group] in the school.
('12', 417, 7, 21, 855904) Tamil is an important Indian Language.
('12', 417, 7, 22, 855943) A fair number of boys who know that language have joined the school.
('12', 417, 7, 23, 856012) It is the Government’s duty to give these boys a fair knowledge of that Language.
('12', 417, 7, 24, 856094) The new Committee that has been set up would do well to agitate in this regard.
('12', 417, 7, 25, 856174) Justice will not be difficult to get.
('12', 417, 7, 26, 856212) When children
('12', 417, 8, 27, 856226) 1 Following the death of Clement, addressee’s son
('12', 418, 0, 1, 856276) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 419
('12', 418, 1, 2, 856317) are not taught through their mother tongue, they only acquire a parrot like knowledge.
('12', 418, 1, 3, 856404) A boy studying in a Government Indian school, where the teacher did not know the mother tongue of the pupil, had been taught the English word for popat [i.e., parrot], but he did not know that the word denoted popat in Gujarati.

('12', 418, 4, 13, 857203) 296. GENERAL KNOWLEDGE ABOUT HEALTH [ IX]
('12', 418, 5, 14, 857245) 5. DIET
('12', 418, 6, 15, 857253) Air, water and food constitute our nourishment.
('12', 418, 6, 16, 857301) But as a rule we look upon food alone as nourishment, and by food we only mean food grains.
('12', 418, 6, 17, 857393) We will not believe that a person lives on food unless he eats wheat and rice.
('12', 418, 6, 18, 857472) The truth is that air is the principal form of nourishment.
('12', 418, 6, 19, 857532) We have seen that we just cannot exist without it, also that we are taking in this essential form of nourishment every moment, whether we are aware of it or not.
('12', 418, 6, 20, 857694) Water comes next in importance to air but before food, and so nature has seen to it that this also is more readily available than food.
('12', 418, 6, 21, 857830) Food occupies the third and last place.
('12', 418, 6, 22, 857870) Food is unite a complicated subject to write on.
('12', 418, 6, 23, 857919) There is much difference of opinion regarding what food to take and when.
('12', 418, 6, 24, 857993) Habits differ from nation to nation.
('12', 418, 6, 25, 858030) The same item of food affects different individuals differently.
('12', 418, 6, 26, 858095) It is difficult, even impossible, to be dogmatic in this matter.
('12', 418, 6, 27, 858160) In certain parts of the world men kill human beings and eat their flesh ; for them it is food.
('12', 418, 6, 28, 858255) There are also some who eat excreta.
('12', 418, 6, 29, 858292) That is food for them.
('12', 418, 6, 30, 858315) Some live entirely on milk; for them milk is food.
('12', 418, 6, 31, 858366) Others, again, live on fruit and for them that is food.
('12', 418, 6, 32, 858422) In this chapter the term “food” covers all these
('12', 419, 0, 1, 858471) 420 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 419, 1, 2, 858513) things.
('12', 419, 1, 3, 858521) Although it is difficult to lay down what food should be eaten, it is necessary for each one to come to some decision for himself.
('12', 419, 1, 4, 858652) It is of course superfluous to observe that the body cannot function without food.
('12', 419, 1, 5, 858735) We are ready to suffer innumerable hardships, even commit sins, in order to obtain food.
('12', 419, 1, 6, 858824) Under these circumstances it is necessary to inquire into the purpose of taking food.
('12', 419, 1, 7, 858910) We shall then be able to determine what food we should take.
('12', 419, 1, 8, 858971) All will agree that out of every 100,000 persons 99,999 eat merely to please their palate, even if they fall ill in consequence.
('12', 419, 1, 9, 859100) Some take a laxative every day in order to be able to eat well, or some powder to aid digestion.
('12', 419, 1, 10, 859197) Some, having gorged an enormous meal with great relish, vomit it out and are ready again for other delicacies.
('12', 419, 1, 11, 859308) Some eat large quantities and then miss a couple of meals.
('12', 419, 1, 12, 859367) Some die of thoughtless overeating.
('12', 419, 1, 13, 859403) The author has himself come across all these types.
('12', 419, 1, 14, 859455) There has been such a transformation in his own life that he can now laugh at many of his past follies and is ashamed of some others.
('12', 419, 1, 15, 859589) There was a time when the author would drink tea in the morning, have breakfast two or three hours later, a regular meal at one p.m., then tea at about three o’clock and a full meal between 6 and 7 in the evening.
('12', 419, 1, 16, 859803) His condition in those days was pitiable indeed.
('12', 419, 1, 17, 859852) He used to get oedema.
('12', 419, 1, 18, 859875) A medicine bottle was always at his side.
('12', 419, 1, 19, 859917) He would often have a laxative in order to be able to eat, and afterwards a dose from another bottle by way of tonic, as a matter of routine.
('12', 419, 1, 20, 860059) He feels that he now has three times the energy for work that he then had, although he must be said to be no longer in his prime.
('12', 419, 1, 21, 860189) Such a life is indeed to be pitied, and is if we go deeper into the matter, low, sinful and despicable.
('12', 419, 1, 22, 860293) Man is not born merely to eat, nor does he live merely for the sake of eating.
('12', 419, 1, 23, 860372) He is born in order to know his Maker and he lives to this end.
('12', 419, 1, 24, 860436) This cannot be done unless one keeps one’s body alive and the latter cannot exist without food.
('12', 419, 1, 25, 860532) This is why food is a necessity.
('12', 419, 1, 26, 860565) This is the ideal attitude and it will do for those who believe in God.
('12', 419, 1, 27, 860637) But even the atheist will admit that one must eat with due regard to one’s health and with the object of keeping the body fit.
('12', 419, 1, 28, 860764) Consider beasts and birds.
('12', 419, 1, 29, 860791) Cattle do not eat for the satisfaction of the palate, nor do they eat like gluttons.
('12', 419, 1, 30, 860876) They eat when they are hungry—and just enough to satisfy that hunger.
('12', 419, 1, 31, 860946) They do not cook their food.
('12', 419, 1, 32, 860975) They take their portion from that which Nature proffers to them.
('12', 419, 1, 33, 861040) Then, is man born to pander to his palate?
('12', 419, 1, 34, 861083) Is he alone fated to be always ill?
('12', 419, 1, 35, 861119) Among the animals which are not domesticated, there is
('12', 420, 0, 1, 861174) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 421
('12', 420, 1, 2, 861215) no starvation; they have no rich and poor, nor is there one group that eats ten times in a day and another that can scarcely eat even once.
('12', 420, 1, 3, 861355) All these distinctions are to be found only in our species, yet we regard ourselves as superior in intelligence to animals.
('12', 420, 1, 4, 861479) It is, however, evident from all this, that if we make our stomach our God and spend our lives in its worship, we must surely be inferior to them.
('12', 420, 1, 5, 861626) If we think carefully, we shall discover that the root cause of the many evil things that we do, such as lying, pleasure hunting, perjury, theft and so on, is our failure to restrain the craving of our palate.
('12', 420, 1, 6, 861836) If we could keep it under control, we would find it easy enough to rid ourselves of the other cravings.
('12', 420, 1, 7, 861940) In spite of our knowing this, we fail to regard over eating or taking too much pleasure in food as a sin.
('12', 420, 1, 8, 862046) If we steal or fornicate or tell a lie, others regard us with contempt.
('12', 420, 1, 9, 862118) Among books on ethical subjects, many fine ones have been written on lying, stealing, adultery, etc., but there is no book about the kind of person who cannot control his palate.
('12', 420, 1, 10, 862297) This subject is not, as a matter of fact, considered as falling under ethics.
('12', 420, 1, 11, 862375) The reason for this is that we are, all of us, in the same boat.
('12', 420, 1, 12, 862440) How will the pot call the kettle black?
('12', 420, 1, 13, 862480) Even our great men do not appear to have succeeded in mastering the desire for tasty food.
('12', 420, 1, 14, 862571) Consequently, indulging one’s palate has never been considered to be wrong.
('12', 420, 1, 15, 862647) The most that books recommend is that, in order to control the senses, it is desirable to limit the amount of food eaten.
('12', 420, 1, 16, 862769) But it has never been said that the pampering of our palate makes us prone to other weaknesses as well.
('12', 420, 1, 17, 862873) Thieves, cheats and sensual men are shunned by respectable people.
('12', 420, 1, 18, 862940) But these same respectable people must be indulging in pleasures of the palate hundreds of times more varied than those of ordinary men and women.
('12', 420, 1, 19, 863087) A man’s gentlemanliness is supposed to consists in the richness of his meals.
('12', 420, 1, 20, 863165) Thus, just as in a thieves’ settlement stealing would not be a sin, so we, being all of us slaves of the palate, do not frown upon such slavery or even notice it.
('12', 420, 1, 21, 863328) On the contrary, we are happy with it.
('12', 420, 1, 22, 863367) At a wedding we give feasts to minister to the pleasures of the palate, our own and those of others.
('12', 420, 1, 23, 863468) Some give dinners at funerals, too.
('12', 420, 1, 24, 863504) On festival days, there must be sweets.
('12', 420, 1, 25, 863544) When a guest comes, tasty dishes must be prepared.
('12', 420, 1, 26, 863595) Not to invite neighbours and friends to partake of meals and not to go to them for the same purpose is frowned upon as grossly unsocial conduct.
('12', 420, 1, 27, 863740) Unless we press the invited guest to overeat, we are considered to be extremely stingy.
('12', 420, 1, 28, 863828) On every holiday, we feel bound to prepare special dishes.
('12', 420, 1, 29, 863887) On Sundays, we seem to think that we have the right to eat till we are sick.
('12', 421, 0, 1, 863964) 422 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 421, 1, 2, 864006) What is, therefore, in the nature of a great fault has been transformed by us into an essential social obligation.
('12', 421, 1, 3, 864121) The serving of meals is accompanied with numerous formalities of hypocritical nature, so that our slavery, our animality is completely hidden from ourselves.
('12', 421, 1, 4, 864279) How shall we free ourselves from this darkness?
('12', 421, 1, 5, 864327) This problem lies beyond the scope of simple hygiene.
('12', 421, 1, 6, 864381) We can, therefore, only pose it and leave it there; it must be considered, however, to the extent that it bears on the problem of health.
('12', 421, 1, 7, 864519) Let us now look at the subject from another angle.
('12', 421, 1, 8, 864570) It appears to be a universal law that the food needed by living creatures, whether human or animal, is provided by Nature from day to day.
('12', 421, 1, 9, 864709) There is nothing strange in this.
('12', 421, 1, 10, 864743) In Nature’s kingdom no insurance is required.
('12', 421, 1, 11, 864789) No one is found remiss in his duty, none sleeps, no one is lazy.
('12', 421, 1, 12, 864854) The water wheel of her processes is in perpetual motion without so much as a moment’s pause.
('12', 421, 1, 13, 864947) And so Nature does not have to lay by a store for a year or even for a day.
('12', 421, 1, 14, 865023) By this inexorable law are we governed, whether we wish it or no.
('12', 421, 1, 15, 865089) If we understand and abide by it, not a single family will have to starve even for a day.
('12', 421, 1, 16, 865179) Now, it is obvious that, if just sufficient food is produced every day and if one person eats more than his share—eats more than he needs, there is bound to be a shortage to that extent, and, therefore, insufficient food for another.
('12', 421, 1, 17, 865413) This is the simple explanation why large numbers of people have to go without food.
('12', 421, 1, 18, 865497) In God’s creation, in the kitchens of thousands of kings and hundreds of thousands of rich men, food is prepared that is far in excess of what they and their servants need.
('12', 421, 1, 19, 865670) This excess has been taken out of the mouths of others.
('12', 421, 1, 20, 865726) Will not these others then go hungry?
('12', 421, 1, 21, 865764) If two wells are served the same current of water, and if this current carries just sufficient water for the two, it is quite plain that an excess of flow into one will mean shortage for the other.
('12', 421, 1, 22, 865962) If this rule is correct—a rule which is not a figment of the author’s imagination but one which has been propounded by highly intelligent men—it means that, whatever we eat after our hunger has been satisfied is stolen food.
('12', 421, 1, 23, 866187) Akha 1, the goldsmith, has truly sung: “Like unto unprocessed mercury swallowed in place of food is wealth stolen from another.” Whatever we eat for the sake of its taste alone is to be paid for by the body through toxic reactions, either visible or invisible; we lose our
('12', 421, 2, 24, 866460) 1 A Gujarati poet of the 17th century
('12', 422, 0, 1, 866498) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 423
('12', 422, 1, 2, 866539) health to that extent and suffer.
('12', 422, 1, 3, 866573) After this discussion, it will be easier for us to consider what and when to eat.

('12', 422, 5, 12, 867542) But it is the experience of my Association that Indians with unsupported claims do not, as rule, come, and that those who do come are not detained, but sent away by the vessels that bring them.

('12', 424, 2, 3, 870785) Unrevised PHOENIX, Wednesday night [March 5, 1913]
('12', 424, 3, 4, 870836) MY DEAR LOWER HOUSE,
('12', 424, 4, 5, 870857) Your letter calls for a prompt reply.
('12', 424, 4, 6, 870895) You are in a self searching mood and are therefore hypercritical of yourself.
('12', 424, 4, 7, 870973) I do not mind it at all if you make good use of this self examination.
('12', 424, 4, 8, 871044) But it has its limits.
('12', 424, 4, 9, 871067) Carried too far, it makes one morbid and sometimes leads to loss of mental balance.
('12', 424, 4, 10, 871151) If you have wasted 42 years then do not waste the 43rd.
('12', 424, 4, 11, 871207) Let the past be a beaconlight.
('12', 424, 4, 12, 871238) But you seem to have become prostrate before the enormity of your own wickedness and so almost seem to wish to remain in it.
('12', 424, 4, 13, 871363) But why all this imputation of vice and weakness to yourself?
('12', 424, 4, 14, 871425) Are your contemporaries stronger and better?
('12', 424, 4, 15, 871470) I deny.
('12', 424, 4, 16, 871478) They are more amenable to the voice of Satan than you are.
('12', 424, 4, 17, 871537) Have you wasted your life in that you have overcome ten thousand temptations and succumbed to the ten thousand and first?
('12', 424, 4, 18, 871659) By all means avoid now the second mistake after the ten thousand and first and take courage from the fact that you had strength to resist ten thousand attacks.
('12', 424, 4, 19, 871819) Find out the cause for the stray mistake made and you will certainly avoid it.
('12', 424, 4, 20, 871898) The true remedy is to compel yourself into ceaseless activity.
('12', 424, 4, 21, 871961) Refuse to believe that you are weak and you will be strong.
('12', 424, 4, 22, 872021) Believe continuously that you are wicked and you will sink.
('12', 424, 4, 23, 872081) Have you never done a good turn to anybody?
('12', 424, 4, 24, 872125) Have you never given a helping hand to a stranger?
('12', 424, 4, 25, 872176) Have you never denied yourself pleasure of life?
('12', 424, 4, 26, 872225) Why do you attract Mrs. Mayo to yourself or Maude!
('12', 424, 4, 27, 872276) Why do you gain the ear of Liddle when others fail?
('12', 424, 4, 28, 872328) Why have you been often saved against yourself?
('12', 424, 4, 29, 872376) I do not suggest that you may pat yourself on the back for these things.
('12', 424, 4, 30, 872449) But you must use these good points to enable you to go forward.
('12', 424, 4, 31, 872513) A man in the midst of plague stricken patients gets frightened and has the plague himself.
('12', 424, 4, 32, 872604) You imagine yourself to be in the midst of plague stricken companions conjured up by your imagination and may well end by getting the plague yourself.
('12', 424, 4, 33, 872755) Why not think that these companions are passing phantoms that will disappear before the other healthy thought companions you may create for yourself.
('12', 424, 4, 34, 872905) And after all, this heart searching is a species of subtle pride.
('12', 424, 4, 35, 872971) At the bottom, there is a desire to shine, to be considered, rather than be, good.
('12', 424, 4, 36, 873054) If this is not true, you
('12', 425, 0, 1, 873079) 426 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 425, 1, 2, 873121) know yourself that you are good because you try to avoid evil.
('12', 425, 1, 3, 873184) The world, however, knows only your failures.
('12', 425, 1, 4, 873230) Are you pining to show the world your successes?
('12', 425, 1, 5, 873279) If you are, you are on the wrong track.
('12', 425, 1, 6, 873319) But I know that you are not consciously pining.
('12', 425, 1, 7, 873367) I do know, however, that you are desirous of showing to yourself service.
('12', 425, 1, 8, 873441) But why desire so?
('12', 425, 1, 9, 873460) The only legitimate desire we can have is to perfect ourselves.
('12', 425, 1, 10, 873524) If we keep that as our goal, we shall never despond, we shall never weaken; we shall ever go forward and never go mad.
('12', 425, 1, 11, 873643) You are made for this better state.
('12', 425, 1, 12, 873679) For Heaven’s sake do not unmake yourself by thinking evil of yourself as you have the knack of doing when the mood comes on you.

('12', 433, 2, 3, 889677) APPENDIX I
('12', 433, 3, 4, 889688) SUMMARY OF THE PROTECTOR’S REPORT
('12', 433, 4, 5, 889722) The Report of the Protector of Indian Immigrants for the year 1910 shows that considerably more than double the number of men, women and children were introduced into Natal under the indenture system during 1910 than in the previous year, the figures being 5,858 and 2,487 respectively.
('12', 433, 4, 6, 890009) There were sixteen deaths during the voyage, which, says the Protector, “is considerably above the average, and was largely occasioned by the number (eight) who died on the s.s.Umhloti’s sixth voyage from Madras.” It will be remembered that the Umhloti was the boat on which the outbreak of “spotted fever” occurred.
('12', 433, 4, 7, 890326) Some light may be thrown on the outbreak when we read what the Protector says: “The Surgeon Superintendent informed me that several of the children were embarked in a very weak state, and this had to be, or a considerable number of Indians would have had to be kept back.” So we see that the agents were so anxious to get off a large shipment that they were prepared to run the risk of sickness and death on the voyage, and, as it happened, an outbreak of a serious disease.
('12', 433, 4, 8, 890801) We are also informed that there were several deaths among the Indians of this shipment after landing including eight from cerebro spinal meningitis or “spotted fever”.
('12', 433, 4, 9, 890969) There were 14 deaths during the year from this disease.
('12', 433, 4, 10, 891025) We venture to think that the Protector’s reply to our enquiries at the time, that “there was no need for any alarm”, that “a few had died” and that “it was expected that the disease had run its course”, was hardly a sufficient one in view of the above facts.
('12', 433, 5, 11, 891284) 1 Some deaths due to “spotted fever” were reported among a batch of indentured Indians (intended especially for Sir Liege Hulett’s estate) on board s.s.
('12', 433, 5, 12, 891437) Umhloti which reached Durban in September, 1910. Official information being unavailable, Indian Opinion wrote on September 22 to the Protector of Indian Immigrants, Polkinghorne, seeking confirmation of the report.
('12', 433, 5, 13, 891652) Replying on September 24, Polkinghorne admitted that “a few” deaths had occurred but assured that there was “no need for any alarm”.
('12', 433, 5, 14, 891785) The Editor wrote again enquiring about the number of those dead, affected or detained owing to the disease.
('12', 433, 5, 15, 891893) In reply, Polkinghorne referred him to a Natal Mercury news report.
('12', 433, 5, 16, 891961) Indian Opinion of October 1 commented strongly on this reply, at which the Protector declined to give any further information to the Editor.
('12', 433, 5, 17, 892102) On October 26, the Natal Indian Congress wrote to Polkinghorne who said he would supply the desired information provided they did not publish it in Indian Opinion.
('12', 433, 5, 18, 892266) The Congress wrote to him on October 31 saying that, as the matter was a public one, they would certainly hand over Polkinghorne’s reply to the Press and that Indian Opinion could not be prevented from taking a “copy from the local dailies”; vide “Indentured Indians’ Plight”, 1 10 1910 and Indian Opinion, 1 10 1910 & 19 11 1910.
('12', 434, 0, 1, 892597) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 435
('12', 434, 1, 2, 892638) There were 1,955 deaths during the year, being an increase of 268 on the previous year.
('12', 434, 1, 3, 892726) The Chief causes of death were diarrhoea 249, tuberculosis of the lungs 189, bronchitis 133, and pneumonia 283. There were 24 suicides, being a decrease of 10 on the previous year.
('12', 434, 1, 4, 892907) Why there should be even 24, which is a very high figure, remains a mystery which the Protector does not enlighten us upon.
('12', 434, 1, 5, 893031) The high figures for diarrhoea, tuberculosis, and pneumonia call for attention from those in authority.
('12', 434, 1, 6, 893135) The very high death rate of 22.15 amongst free Indians is explained by the fact that all children of indentured parents are classed as “free”.
('12', 434, 1, 7, 893278) The death rate of Indian Children (noted in last year’s report as being so exceptionally low, 6.56) has this year risen to 23.33. The weather conditions of the latter half of the year, the Protector thinks, may probably account to some extent for this increase.
('12', 434, 1, 8, 893540) We are not aware that the weather conditions were so severe as to make [for] such a huge increase in the death rate.
('12', 434, 1, 9, 893657) Seeing that the heavy death rate among children was “under consideration”, we should have thought the Protector would have been able to give some substantial reason for this excessive death rate.
('12', 434, 2, 10, 893853) There is a distinct indication that wages are on the increase, says the Protector.
('12', 434, 2, 11, 893936) This, of course, applies only to re indentured Indians.
('12', 434, 2, 12, 893992) There was no indication that the rate of wages of first indentured men would be increased.
('12', 434, 2, 13, 894083) Consequently there were applications for 15,114 more men.
('12', 434, 2, 14, 894141) The Protector anticipates that, owing to the increase in the percentage of those re indenturing, there will probably be at the end of 1911 as many men under indenture as there have been for the last two years.
('12', 434, 2, 15, 894351) It is possible that this may be found to be the case, as, apart from the increase in wages offered, the £3 tax still remains as a compelling force upon them to give up their liberty.
('12', 434, 2, 16, 894534) We are glad to note that, in the opinion of the Protector, “employers generally are now more careful in the management of their Indians, and are more willing to dismiss overseers and sirdars for wrongful conduct towards the Indians, and less inclined to screen them than in years gone by.” This is satisfactory as far as it goes, and we have, no doubt, to thank for this very largely the efforts of those who have endeavoured to give publicity to the evils of the indenture system.
('12', 434, 2, 17, 895016) The question of overwork still remains unsettled to the satisfaction of the Protector.
('12', 434, 2, 18, 895103) This is due in a measure, he thinks, to the inherent difficulty of settling what is a fair task.
('12', 434, 2, 19, 895200) He might have added that the task system is altogether unfair.
('12', 434, 2, 20, 895263) What we have seen is that whilst a strong man or woman cutting cane finishes the set task early in the afternoon, the weaker ones have to work until dark night.
('12', 434, 2, 21, 895424) And in the work of filling carts, the question of finishing the task depends largely on the number of carts and the distance to travel.
('12', 434, 2, 22, 895560) Even if every other condition was satisfactory, the task system would make life a burden to many an indentured Indian.
('12', 434, 2, 23, 895679) It can easily be imagined that those who fail to finish their task fall under the displeasure of the managers and sirdars, and where ill treatment is complained of, the task system will invariably be found to be the cause.
('12', 434, 3, 24, 895902) The Deputy Protector, in his report, says that a number of deserving women have been relieved of the payment of the annual £3 licence under Act 17 of 1895, and he understands that women generally are not unduly pressed for payment.
('12', 435, 0, 1, 896134) 436 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 435, 1, 2, 896176) Protector adds that 485 women have been granted exemption passes by the Magistrates.
('12', 435, 1, 3, 896261) Surely it must be evident that, whatever this figure represents, women should not be asked to pay it at all.
('12', 435, 1, 4, 896370) It is bad enough that men should have to pay for the privilege of remaining as free men in a country which they have done so much to build up, but for women and girls over the age of thirteen to be taxed to such an extent to monstrous.
('12', 435, 1, 5, 896606) We know of several cases in which the Magistrates have refused to grant exemption certificates to Indian women.
('12', 435, 1, 6, 896718) Why should such a matter be placed at the mercy of a Magistrate?
('12', 435, 1, 7, 896783) At Verulam, the Magistrate wisely exercises a wide discretion, exempting all women claiming exemption; but at Stanger the Magistrate has scarcely exempted a single poor woman of his district.
('12', 435, 2, 8, 896975) This year has seen the stoppage of further supplies of indentured Indians from India, and for this we are thankful.
('12', 435, 2, 9, 897091) We believe that the resident Indian population will benefit by the action of the Indian Government.
('12', 435, 2, 10, 897191) The Natal Mercury thinks that, now that Indian immigration is stopped, the European population will increase at a greater ratio than the Indian, as in the one case there will be the open door to immigrants, and in the other it will be closed.
('12', 435, 2, 11, 897434) Whether that will be so or not remains to be seen, but, there it will now be no excuse whatever for persecuting the resident indian population.
('12', 435, 2, 12, 897578) They are here for good or ill, and it depends very largely on the European community what the future will be.
('12', 435, 2, 13, 897688) If South Africans act up to the traditions of the British Empire, there is no reason to fear but that all sections will find room in this country.
('12', 435, 2, 14, 897835) For ourselves we shall not rest until the identure system in abolished, We believe in freedom for all.
('12', 435, 2, 15, 897938) We want to see the Indian community of South Africa a free and happy people, and this can never be, so long as there are thousands of men, women and children living in what, even under the best conditions, can only be described as semi slavery.

('12', 436, 6, 13, 899508) LORD CREWE’S SPEECH ON INDIANS IN DOMINIONS AT IMPERIAL CONFERENCE
('12', 436, 7, 14, 899575) LONDON, June 19, 1911
('12', 436, 9, 15, 899597) The Imperial Conference met in London on June 19, 1911 with Rt.
('12', 436, 9, 16, 899661) Hon’ble L. Harcourt, Secretary of State fore the Colonies, in the chair, Gen.
('12', 436, 9, 17, 899739) L. Botha (Prime Minister of the Union), F. S. Malan (Minister of Education) and Sir David de Villier Graaff ( Minister of Public Works, Posts and Telegraphs) attended on behalf of the Union of South Africa.
('12', 436, 9, 18, 899946) A memorandum about the problem of Indian subjects of the Empire in the Colonies was also circulated.
('12', 436, 10, 19, 900047) The agenda for discussion included a resolution by the New Zealand Prime Minister who sought to confine Coloured races to their zones and later changed his resolution to deal with rights of self governing Colonies “with wider legislative powers” in respect of British and foreign shipping.
('12', 436, 11, 20, 900337) The proceedings of the Conference began with some general remarks by the Earl of Crewe, Secretary of State for India, on Indians within the Dominions.
('12', 436, 11, 21, 900488) Extracts from his speech are given below:
('12', 436, 12, 22, 900530) if there was any question which seemed to threaten not merely the well being, but the actual existence, of the Empire as an Empire, it was this difficulty between the white races and the Native races, because I ventured to point out, as between the Dominions and the Mother Country there could be no question, whether it was a question of commerce or a question of defence or any other of the questions which we now discuss, which could not be solved by good will and by good sense on both sides .
('12', 436, 12, 23, 901028) I understand that this memorandum which I have before me has been circulated to all the members of the Conference, and those who have read it will recognize that it
('12', 436, 13, 24, 901193) 1 Two words illegible here
('12', 437, 0, 1, 901220) 438 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 437, 1, 2, 901262) deals both with the general principles of the question, and also with special instances of difficulty which have arisen in the various Dominions with regard either to the ingress of Indians or to the treatment of Indians when they are there .
('12', 437, 2, 3, 901505) Now I desire to say first, that I fully recognize—as His Majesty’s Government fully recognize—two fact: the first is, that as the Empire is constituted, the idea that it is possible to have an absolutely free interchange between all individuals who are subjects of the Crown—that is to say, that every subject of the king whoever he may be or wherever he may live has a natural right to travel or still more two settle in any part of the Empire—is a view which we fully admit, and I fully admit, as representing the India Office, to be one which cannot be maintained.
('12', 437, 2, 4, 902073) As the Empire is constituted it is still impossible that we can have a free coming and going of all the subjects of the King throughout all parts of the Empire.
('12', 437, 2, 5, 902234) Or to put the thing in another way, nobody can attempt to dispute the right of the self governing Dominions to decide to themselves whom, in each case, they will admit as citizens of their respective Dominions.
('12', 437, 3, 6, 902445) That is one of the facts which on behalf of His Majesty’s Government I fully recognize.
('12', 437, 3, 7, 902533) I also recognize this—that we are or may be easily prone in this country to underrate the difficulties which confront the Dominions in this matter, because we are not troubled to any extent by a similar problem here.
('12', 437, 3, 8, 902750) It so happens that there never has been any influx of Coloured races into this country on a scale which has awakened any of the difficulties, which, as I well know, confront you gentlemen in the different self governing Dominions .
('12', 437, 4, 9, 902982) Many have now abandoned, for instance, the theory that labour can be regulated simply by the conditions of supply and demand.
('12', 437, 4, 10, 903108) There are many nowadays, too, who have abandoned the theory that the remuneration of labour need necessarily stand in any very close relation to the value of the work done, and that being so, it is clear that the rivalry of cheap labour such as may be introduced from India seems a greater hardship than it did in the days of a harsher political economy which was generally accepted .
('12', 437, 4, 11, 903493) during the greater part of the nineteenth century .
('12', 437, 4, 12, 903545) we are certainly approaching, if we have not already arrived at, the time when organized labour will seriously object to the importation of any kind of lower paid labour, whatever its colour and whatever its nationality, if it is of a competitive character.
('12', 437, 4, 13, 903803) This is one of the main difficulties, indeed, which is connected with this question ofIndian immigration .
('12', 437, 4, 14, 903910) But as to the existence of the colour difficulty in its crudest form there can, of course, be no question whatever.
('12', 437, 5, 15, 904026) It is one of those prejudices or beliefs which become stronger as people become more educated and more generally superior, and in this respect it differs from most of the easy and foolish prejudices which are held against the Native races.
('12', 437, 5, 16, 904266) I am disposed to go so far as to say that in most respects the less a white man has individually to be proud of, the prouder he is apt to be of his whiteness, and the more he considers himself .
('12', 437, 6, 17, 904461) among the observations made by Mr. Chamberlain in his address to the
('12', 438, 0, 1, 904530) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 439
('12', 438, 1, 2, 904571) Conference in 1897. Those word are, if I may venture to say so, well worth weighing.
('12', 438, 1, 3, 904656) I will not attempt to enlarge upon or in any way to develop what Mr. Chamberlain there so admirably said.
('12', 438, 1, 4, 904762) I might, however, venture perhaps to remind you that, on the point of the national claims of Indians grounded on their past history .
('12', 438, 1, 5, 904896) this at any rate is not a moment when we desire to ignore those considerations, The ceremony of Thursday next, to which we are all looking forward, depends to a great extent for its meaning upon the long line of British sovereigns, through the Stuart, Tudor, and Plantagenet dynastics back to the time of the Norman Conquest and dim ages of the Saxon monarchy’; and yet there are to be found in India those whose pride of descent is no less well founded and no less real than that of the King of England himself.
('12', 438, 1, 6, 905409) Then, again, as regards history we must never forget that not merely has India produced a great number of remarkable men both in the public service, and, to go back further, notable in ancient literature, but that she is most closely linked to a great number of the most famous men of our own race—statesmen, soldiers and others.
('12', 438, 1, 7, 905739) Now, of course, these considerations do not appeal to everybody .
('12', 438, 1, 8, 905805) If “A man’s man for a’ that” is to be our motto, the claim of a large number of Indians is a real and solid claim indeed.
('12', 438, 1, 9, 905927) Whether we value intellectual culture, whether—apart from questions of creed—we value the religious mind, whether we value that remarkable devotion to and understanding of the things which are not seen which is so exceptionally deep in India and which, I think, appeals to many people in these harder and material days, whether, again, we value simple intellectual force, uncertain in its exercise in some directions I admit, but which in others produces as keen and fine an instrument as you can find in any part of the world—whether we value all of those things or any of them it is undoubtedly the fact that India and Indians can establish a high and real claim for our consideration, apart from all others.
('12', 438, 2, 10, 906638) India must admit the main postulates with which I opened those observations, that is to say the undoubted liberty of the self governing Dominions to lay down the rules of their own citizenship, and I can say cheerfully on behalf of the India Office and the Government of India that we will always do our best to explain to the people of India how the position stands in this matter.
('12', 438, 2, 11, 907021) We will not encourage India in any way to develop what, as circumstances are, can only be called extravagant claims for entrance into the self governing Dominions, and we will do our best to explain to them what the conditions of the Empire really are .
('12', 438, 2, 12, 907275) all sections and shades of Indian Opinion .
('12', 438, 2, 13, 907319) combine when it is a question of Indian disability in any part of the British Empire.
('12', 438, 2, 14, 907405) It cannot be denied that this difficulty is a very real asset, and a valuable asset in India to those who are opposed to our rule there .
('12', 438, 2, 15, 907543) If, they ask, Indians are to suffer from disabilities in various part of the Empire, what good in the British connection at all?
('12', 438, 2, 16, 907672) I may point out also that the growing tendency to apply principles of self government to India adds greatly to the complication and difficulty of the matter, because when a legislative council, as always possibly may happen, takes occasion to make a particular protest against some legislation or some administrative act on the part of the Government of a Dominion, It becomes .
('12', 438, 2, 17, 908051) a far more serious matter than if a mere uninformed
('12', 439, 0, 1, 908103) 440 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 439, 1, 2, 908145) grumble .
('12', 439, 1, 3, 908155) is heard.
('12', 439, 2, 4, 908165) On the other side, as regards the protection of those who are already domiciled there, some, I may remind you, have been there for a very long time indeed.
('12', 439, 2, 5, 908321) There is at any rate one of the Dominions in which Orientals have been domiciled for some 200 years.
('12', 439, 3, 6, 908422) The difficulty, of course, does not arise, I know very well, from the views or prejudices of Ministers themselves, but it cannot always be easy for them to impress upon their subordinates, quite subordinate officials who are probably imbued with a very strong anti colour prejudice, the importance which we attach, and which those who have to do with India and know India always attach—to what may seem small matters of this kind.
('12', 439, 3, 7, 908853) however close the connection and however perfect the understanding between the Mother Country and the self governing Dominions, we are not a united Empire unless that understanding spreads to some considerable extent also to that vast part of the Empire of which, of course, India is the most prominent division, but which also includes all the Crown Colonies which are inhabited by the various Native races .
('12', 439, 3, 8, 909263) it is a distinct misfortune and a derogation from the unity of the Empire if the Mother Country continually finds itself implicated in difficulties between various parts of the Empire.
('12', 439, 4, 9, 909448) I do not pretend, as I repeat once more, that the question is really a soluble one in the full sense—I do not think it is—but I am quite certain that if the Dominions will agree all thorough to show an accommodating and friendly spirit towards India, .
('12', 439, 4, 10, 909701) the best public opinion in India will recognize your efforts .
('12', 439, 5, 11, 909764) India Opinion, 14 10 1911 & 21 10 1911
('12', 439, 7, 12, 909803) INDIA OFFICE MEMORANDUM FOR IMPERIAL CONFERENCE
('12', 439, 8, 13, 909851) INDIA OFFICE, June, 1911
('12', 439, 9, 14, 909876) The general principles which His Majesty’s Government desired to maintain in regard to the relations between His Majesty’s Indian subjects and the self governing Dominions were thus stated by Mr. Chamberlain in the course of his address to the Conference of Colonial Premiers in 1897:
('12', 439, 10, 15, 910161) “We quite sympathize with the determination of the white inhabitants of the Colonies which are in comparatively close proximity to millions and hundreds of millions of Asiatics that there shall not be an influx of people alien in civilization, alien in religion, alien in customs, whose influx, moreover, would most seriously interfere with the legitimate rights of the existing labour population.
('12', 439, 10, 16, 910559) An immigration of that kind must, I quite understand, in the interest of the Colonies, be prevented at all hazards, and we shall not offer any opposition to the proposals intended with that object, but we ask you also to bear in mind the traditions of the Empire, which makes no distinction in favour of, or against, race and colour; and to
('12', 440, 0, 1, 910900) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 441
('12', 440, 1, 2, 910941) exclude, by reason of their colour, or by reason of their race, all Her Majesty’s Indian subjects, or even all Asiatics, would be an act so offensive to those peoples that it would be most painful, I am quite certain, to Her Majesty to have to sanction it.
('12', 440, 1, 3, 911198) Consider what has been brought to your notice during your visit to this country.
('12', 440, 1, 4, 911279) The United Kingdom owns as its brightest and greatest dependency, that enormous Empire of India, with 300,000,000 of subjects, who are as loyal to the Crown as your are yourselves, and among them there are hundreds and thousands of men who are every whit as civilized as we are ourselves, who are, if that is anything, better born in the sense that they have older traditions and older families, who are men of wealth, men of cultivation, men of distinguished valour, men who have brought whole armies and placed them at the service of the Queen, and have in times of great difficulty and trouble, such, for instance, as on the occasion of the Indian Mutiny, saved the Empire by their loyalty.
('12', 440, 1, 5, 911973) I say you, who have seen all this, cannot be willing to put upon those men a slight, which, I think, is absolutely unnecessary for your purpose, and which would be calculated to provoke ill feeling, discontent, irritation, and would be most unpalatable to the feeling not only of Her Majesty the Queen but of all her people.
('12', 440, 2, 6, 912298) What I venture to think you have to deal with is the character of the immigration.
('12', 440, 2, 7, 912381) It is not because a man is of different colour from ourselves that he is necessarily an undesirable immigrant, but it is because he is dirty, or he is immoral, or he is a pauper, or he has some other objection which can be defined in an Act of Parliament, and by which the exclusion can be managed with regard to all those whom you really desire to exclude.
('12', 440, 2, 8, 912739) Well, gentlemen, this is matter, I am sure, for friendly consultation between us.
('12', 440, 2, 9, 912821) As I have said, the Colony of Natal has arrived at an arrangement which is absolutely satisfactory to them, I believe, and remember they have, if possible, an even greater interest than you, because they are closer to the immigration which has already begun there on a very large scale, and they adopted legislation which they believe will give them all that they want, and to which the objection I have taken does not apply, which does not come in conflict with this sentiment, I am sure, you share with us; and I hope, therefore, that during your visit it may be possible for us to arrange a form of words which will avoid hurting the feelings of any of Her Majesty’s subjects, while at the same time it would amply protect the Australian Colonies against any invasion of the class to which they would justly object.”
('12', 440, 3, 10, 913641) The position of India in the British Empire was again emphasized by Mr. Asquith at the Colonial Conference of 1907, when he said: “We should never, under any conceivable circumstances, accept here a preference granted to us only in respect of goods carried in ships in which the whole of our fellow subjects in India were not allowed to serve.
('12', 440, 3, 11, 913985) We could not possible accede to that, and everybody here would say we would rather have no preference limited by such condition as that.”
('12', 441, 0, 1, 914123) 442 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 441, 1, 2, 914165) PARTICULAR DIFFICULTIES
('12', 441, 2, 3, 914189) It is unnecessary to recapitulate the course of events since 1897, but the forms in which Asiatic questions have arisen in the self governing Colonies may be briefly indicated.
('12', 441, 4, 4, 914366) In Natal, which alone imported Indian labour, the resident Indian population was increased by a large influx of collies who, at the end of their indentures, remained in the Colony subject to special taxation, and by a small “free” immigration of persons who were able to pass the education test imposed by the Immigration Act.
('12', 441, 4, 5, 914693) Difficulties arose about traders’ licences, municipal franchise, and the education of Indian children, and these were accentuated by the passing in 1908 by the Natal Parliament of two Bills which were reserved and have not come into operation, one to bring to an end the issue of new trading licences to Asiatics,t he other to prohibit after a certain time, the holding of trading licences by Asiatics.
('12', 441, 4, 6, 915096) In 1909, however, the Dealers’ Licenses Act of 1897 was so amended as to allow an appeal to the Supreme Court on the renewal of existing licences, though not on their transfer or on the issue of new licences.
('12', 441, 5, 7, 915305) TRANSVAAL
('12', 441, 6, 8, 915315) In the Transvaal, which most of the resident Indians had left during the War, acute difficulties were caused by an influx of Indians after annexation and by doubts as to the exact effect of some of the laws and regulations of the South African Republic.
('12', 441, 6, 9, 915569) Under the Peace Preservation Ordinance permits to Asiatics to enter the Colony were granted only to persons who had resided before the War.
('12', 441, 6, 10, 915709) This provision was stereotyped by the Asiatic Law Amendment Act of 1907, passed immediately after the grant of responsible government, and, although the Immigrants’ Restriction Act of the same year was in form modelled on the Natal Act, the effect of the two Acts read together was that no Asiatic, however well educated, could claim as a right to enter the Colony unless he could prove that he was before the War a bona fide resident.
('12', 441, 6, 11, 916145) This position, which had no parallel in any other part of the Empire, was, with great reluctance, accepted by His Majesty’s Government.
('12', 441, 6, 12, 916281) The stringent provisions for proof of the identity of lawful residents, though declared by the Transvaal Government to be necessitated by the trade in forged documents, gave rise to an acute and bitter controversy, which was allayed only for a few months by an amending Act of 1908. On the one hand the Indians deliberately adopted a policy of passive resistance to the law; on the other hand some of the incidents of imprisonment and deportation of Indians awoke in India itself a feeling of indignation the sincerity and the importance of which were very imperfectly appreciated in South Africa.
('12', 442, 0, 1, 916879) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 443
('12', 442, 1, 2, 916920) CAPE OF GOOD HOPE AND ORANGE FREE STATE
('12', 442, 2, 3, 916960) In Cape Colony, which allowed the entry only of Indians who could pass an education test, and in the Orange Free State, where an Asiatic question had never arisen, nothing had recently happened which calls for notice, except for one or two complaints that old residents who went back to India on a temporary permit were refused readmission to Cape Colony on technical grounds, which caused hardship.
('12', 442, 3, 4, 917360) UNION OF SOUTH AFRICA
('12', 442, 4, 5, 917382) Under the Act of Union matters differentially affecting Asiatics were reserved for the Union Government.
('12', 442, 4, 6, 917487) The Union Government introduced an Immigration Bill in the recent session of Parliament which aimed at a final settlement of the question.
('12', 442, 4, 7, 917626) The Bill was withdrawn at the end of the session, but it is understood that the subject will again be taken up.
('12', 442, 4, 8, 917738) Meanwhile, a provisional settlement has been arranged by the Union Government which has led to the abandonment of the passive resistance movement.
('12', 442, 4, 9, 917885) The stoppage of indentured emigration from India to Natal has now prevented the further recruitment of the uneducated classes of Indians within the Union.
('12', 442, 4, 10, 918040) Thus, in South Africa, the problem henceforth will practically be that of the government of a resident Asiatic population, considerable in numbers only in Natal .
('12', 442, 5, 11, 918203) QUESTIONS OF POLICY
('12', 442, 6, 12, 918223) The foregoing summary shows that the question of Indian immigration affects the several Dominions in different ways and in varying degrees.
('12', 442, 6, 13, 918363) But the question may be said to fall under three heads:
('12', 442, 7, 14, 918419) (1) The entry of new immigrants.
('12', 442, 8, 15, 918452) (2) The status and condition of Indians who have been allowed to enter.
('12', 442, 9, 16, 918524) (3) The employment of Indians on ships in colonial waters.
('12', 442, 10, 17, 918583) (1) ENTRY OF IMMIGRANTS
('12', 442, 11, 18, 918607) His Majesty’s Government fully accept the principle that each of the Dominions must be allowed to decide for itself what elements it desires to accept in its population.
('12', 442, 11, 19, 918777) The extreme contention urged by some Indians, thought not by those who speak with responsibility, that membership of the British Empire shall entitle any British subject to resides where he chooses, is disposed of by acknowledged political facts.
('12', 442, 11, 20, 919024) At the same time it is of great importance to recognize that subjects of the King, however different in physique, customs, and religion, from the European races, are not aliens.
('12', 442, 11, 21, 919202) It is not sufficiently realized that, for purely local reasons, the Dominions have adopted a policy which puts Asiatic British subjects on the same footing as alien Asiatics.
('12', 442, 11, 22, 919377) In fact, for reasons noted above, the Dominion of Canada is more rigorous towards British Indian than towards Japanese immigration.
('12', 442, 11, 23, 919509) A second important fact, generally overlooked, is that some parts of the British Empire have adopted, towards Asiatic British subjects a policy of exclusion which foreign nations
('12', 443, 0, 1, 919688) 444 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 443, 1, 2, 919730) have found unnecessary.
('12', 443, 1, 3, 919754) It is of course the case that the tropical and sub tropical possessions of European Powers correspond in climate and conditions to the British Crown colonies, and do not reproduce those local conditions which account for the immigration policy of the Dominions.
('12', 443, 1, 4, 920016) None the less, it is a striking fact that British Indians are allowed by foreign countries privileges denied to them by the Dominions.
('12', 443, 2, 5, 920151) It is useless to attempt to veil the fact that the policy of building up new nations of European blood within the empire the absolutely incompatible with the idea that every British subject, whatever his race, shall have free right of ingress to any part of the Empire.
('12', 443, 2, 6, 920421) This being so, all that His Majesty’s Government is entitled to ask is that the immigration policy of the Dominions shall be so framed and expressed as to avoid wanton injury to the self respect of non European British subjects.
('12', 443, 2, 7, 920650) The policy of basing exclusion upon an educational, not a racial, criterion, meets this requirement, although, in its application to individual cases, it admits of being administered so as to exclude Indians on racial grounds.
('12', 443, 2, 8, 920877) Other methods of restricting immigration, without in statutory terms differentiating against a particular race, find place in the Canadian law, which gives power (1) to exclude immigrants deemed unsuited to local climate or requirements, or immigrants of any specified class, occupation, or character; (2) to require immigrants to be in possession of a certain minimum sum of money.
('12', 443, 3, 9, 921260) It will not be disputed that each of the Dominions is under the strongest moral obligation to take no isolated action which would involve the Empire in war with a foreign power.
('12', 443, 3, 10, 921438) But it does not appear to have been thoroughly considered that each Dominion owes responsibility to the rest of the Empire for ensuring that its domestic policy shall not unnecessarily create embarrassment in the administration of India.
('12', 443, 3, 11, 921676) It is difficult for statesmen who have seen Indians represented only by manual labourers and petty traders to realize the importance to the Empire as a whole of country with some three hundred million inhabitants, possessing ancient civilizations of a very high order, which has furnished and furnishes some of the finest military material in the world to the Imperial forces, and which offers the fullest opportunities to financial and commercial enterprise.
('12', 443, 3, 12, 922136) It is difficult to convey to those who do not know India the intense and natural resentment felt by veterans of the Indian Army, who have seen active service and won medals under the British flag, and who have been treated by their British officers with the consideration and courtesy to which their character entitles them, when (as has actually happened) they find themselves described as “coolies”, and treated with contemptuous severity in parts of the British Empire.
('12', 443, 3, 13, 922609) Matters like this are, of course, very largely beyond the power of any Government to control, but popular misunderstandings are such a fruitful source of mischief that it seems worth while to put on record the grave fact that a radically false conception of the real position of India is undoubtedly rife in many parts of the Empire .
('12', 443, 4, 14, 922944) The immigration difficulty, however, has on the whole been met by a series of statues which succeed in preventing Asiatic influx without the use of deferential or insulting language.
('12', 443, 4, 15, 923127) It is accepted that the Dominion shall not admit as
('12', 444, 0, 1, 923179) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 445
('12', 444, 1, 2, 923220) permanent residents people whole mode of life is inconsistent with their own political and social ideals.
('12', 444, 2, 3, 923326) But the admission of temporary visitors, to which this objection does not apply, has not yet been satisfactorily settled.
('12', 444, 2, 4, 923448) If the question were not grave, it would be seen to be ludicrous that regulations framed with an eye to coolies should affect ruling princes who are in subordinate alliance with His Majesty, and have placed their troops at his disposal, members of the Privy Council of the Empire, or gentlemen who have the honour to be His Majesty’s own Aides de Camp.
('12', 444, 2, 5, 923801) It is of course true that no person of such distinguished position would in fact be turned back if he visited one of the Dominions.
('12', 444, 2, 6, 923933) But these Indian gentlemen are known to entertain very strongly the feeling that, while they can move freely in the best society of any European capital, they could not set foot in some of the Dominions without undergoing vexatious catechisms from petty officials.
('12', 444, 2, 7, 924198) At the same time the highest posts in the Imperial services in India are open to subjects of His Majesty from the Dominions.
('12', 444, 3, 8, 924323) The efforts of the British Government to create and foster a sense of citizenship in India have, within the last few years, undoubtedly been hampered by the feeling of soreness caused by the general attitude of the Dominions toward the peoples of India.
('12', 444, 3, 9, 924577) The loyalty of the great mass of Indians to the Throne is a very conspicuous fact, and it is noteworthy that this feeling is sincerely entertained by many Indian critics of the details of British administration.
('12', 444, 3, 10, 924789) The recent constitutional changes have given the people of the country increased association with the Government, and have at the same time afforded Indians grater opportunities of bringing to the direct notice of Government their views on the wider question of the place of India in the Empire.
('12', 444, 3, 11, 925085) The gravity of the friction between Indians and the Dominions lies in this, that on the Colonial question, and on that alone, are united the seditious agitators and the absolutely loyal representatives of moderate Indian Opinion.
('12', 444, 3, 12, 925315) The Government of India, while appreciating the Colonial point of view, cannot, and do not, which to dissociate themselves from general feeling of disappointment at the unwillingness of the Dominions to recognize that Indians are entitled to consideration.
('12', 444, 3, 13, 925572) Many highly educated and well bred Indians have natural and laudable desire to see other parts of the Empire, but at present are deterred from visiting the Dominions.
('12', 444, 3, 14, 925739) It is earnestly hoped by His Majesty’s Government that the measures necessary to prevent such an influx of the lower classes of Indians as would modify the population of the Dominions and create grave internal difficulties will not be extended to visitors of good social rank, merchants of sound commercial position who have interests outside India, or students who have attained to University standing.
('12', 444, 4, 15, 926143) (2) THE STATUS OF INDIANS RESIDENT IN THE DOMINIONS
('12', 444, 5, 16, 926195) It is in South Africa alone that there is any large resident Indian population, and it existence here is in the main due to the deliberate importation by Natal (inaugurated under Crown Colony but continued under Responsible Government) of contract Indian labour.
('12', 444, 5, 17, 926458) In Canada and Australia Indian immigrants have been
('12', 445, 0, 1, 926510) 446 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 445, 1, 2, 926552) comparatively few in number and have come on their own commercial business.
('12', 445, 1, 3, 926628) But in South Africa—apart from the entry of some representatives of those Indian traders who have for centuries past done business on the east coast of tropical Africa—the Indian element is, in origin due to the action of Government undertaken at the instance and in the interests of a very important section of the European population of Natal.
('12', 445, 2, 4, 926974) So far, then, as an Indian population exists, the Dominions can do much to allay unrest in India by abstaining from any administrative policy which could be represented as showing an intention to expel them, or to reduce them to a position of degradation.
('12', 445, 2, 5, 927230) In South Africa Indians compete chiefly with European traders—often with a low class of Europeans of alien origin,—while in British Columbia they are in competition with white workmen.
('12', 445, 2, 6, 927415) It is thus inevitable that from time to time this economic rivalry should lead to friction.
('12', 445, 2, 7, 927507) But the treatment of Indian traders by municipal authorities in Natal has at times been flagrantly unfair, and even now security for permanence of trading rights is given, by means of Appeal to the Supreme Court against licensing boards, only to individuals who already possess trading licences.
('12', 445, 2, 8, 927803) The transfer of existing, or the grant of new, licences, is entirely in the hands of municipal authorities.
('12', 445, 2, 9, 927911) Certain schemes of legislation in Natal, and of administrative measures in the Transvaal, have caused much apprehension among Indians, and it is to be hoped that, when the union has satisfied itself that safeguards against unlimited Asiatic immigration have been provided, it will be possible to treat resident Indians generously.
('12', 445, 3, 10, 928242) Any system of generous treatment may be held to involve:
('12', 445, 4, 11, 928299) (1) avoidance of any measures calculated to take away the means of livelihood from respectable traders by vexatious regulations;
('12', 445, 5, 12, 928428) (2) restriction of sanitary measures to cover real sanitary needs, and regulations adequate to prevent the use of such measures as an indirect means of disturbing Indian residents;
('12', 445, 6, 13, 928609) (3) the grant of educational facilities, which, of course, need not lead to the admission of Asiatic and European children into mixed primary schools;
('12', 445, 7, 14, 928760) (4) a determination not to utilize immigration laws to banish lawful residents by means of legal quibbles, or to break up domiciled families, or to refuse temporary admission on visiting permit to relatives whose presence is urgently required by resident Indians.
('12', 445, 7, 15, 929024) (Such an incident as the refusal of a permit to a son to attend to funeral of his father, which is alleged to have occurred in British Columbia, would create very bitter feeling amongst a people who attach supreme importance to funeral rites.)
('12', 445, 8, 16, 929268) It is practically certain that there will never be any large Indian population in Canada, Australia, or New Zealand, the Dominions in which the aboriginal population is small, and in some cases decreasing, and which will, in the ordinary
('12', 446, 0, 1, 929506) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 447
('12', 446, 1, 2, 929547) course of events, be, for all practical purposes, purely European.
('12', 446, 1, 3, 929614) But in South Africa not only does the Native population so enormously outnumber the whites that unskilled labour will probably always remain in Native hands, but a small Asiatic element has existed for nearly two centuries.
('12', 446, 1, 4, 929838) Cape Colony has found it possible to govern without friction and to utilize the “Malays” imported by the Dutch East India Company, who are Mahomedan in religion and distinctive in their social habits.
('12', 446, 1, 5, 930039) They have established a position as fishermen, drivers, and petty agriculturists.
('12', 446, 1, 6, 930121) It cannot be maintained that South Africa can accommodate only white and black, and has no place for the brown races.
('12', 446, 1, 7, 930239) For although in a comparatively recently colonized area, such as the territories of the two former republics, this might be argued, Cape Colony affords an example of a large element, consisting not only of the “Malays”, but of the “Coloured people”, which is intermediate in civilization and habits between the Native Africans and the Europeans.
('12', 446, 1, 8, 930585) There is no intention to minimize the difficulties caused by the presence of an intermediate element, whether of mixed blood or purely Asiatic.
('12', 446, 1, 9, 930729) But it is believed the equitable administration can prevent these difficulties from becoming dangers.
('12', 446, 2, 10, 930831) (3) THE EMPLOYMENT OF INDIANS IN SHIPS IN COLONIAL WATERS
('12', 446, 3, 11, 930889) It is unnecessary to add to what is said on this point in the historical summary, where the serious disabilities which the New Zealand Shipping Bill of 910 would impose on Indian seamen are pointed out.
('12', 446, 4, 12, 931092) Indian Opinion, 9 9 1911, 16 9 1911, 23 9 1911 & 30 9 1911
('12', 446, 5, 13, 931151) APPENDIX IV
('12', 446, 6, 14, 931163) UNION MINISTERS’ MINUTES ON IMMIGRANTS’ RESTRICTION BILL (1912)
('12', 446, 8, 15, 931227) In the course of conversation this morning General Smuts referred to the draft Immigration Bill.
('12', 446, 8, 16, 931324) I asked him what would be the position, under Clause 28, of one of the limited number of educated Indians to be admitted into the Union under the dictation test if he wished to enter the Free State.
('12', 446, 8, 17, 931523) The Minister said there would be no restriction upon his entry into the Free State or into any other Province, and the only special disabilities to which he would be subjected would be the prohibition to acquire fixed property, or to engage in commerce or farming in the Free State, as set forth in Sub clause 2 of Clause 28. According to what General Smuts said, there would be nothing to prevent him from establishing himself as a doctor except the absence of sufficient number of his compatriots to make professional practice lucrative.
('12', 446, 8, 18, 932063) The rest
('12', 446, 9, 19, 932072) 1 This is a report by the Private Secretary to the Governor General based on a discussion he had with Smuts.
('12', 446, 9, 20, 932181) It was forwarded by Gladstone to the Colonial Office on October 28, 1911.
('12', 447, 0, 1, 932255) 448 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 447, 1, 2, 932297) of Chapter 33 of the Orange Free State Law Book was not being repealed, but its provisions, with the exception of Article 7 and 8, would be practically inoperative so far as the Indians admitted under the dictation test were concerned, as their status and rights were protected under the draft Bill.
('12', 447, 1, 3, 932597) I asked the Minister whether he did not anticipate strong protests from Mr. Gandhi and his followers in regard to the specific retention of Articles 7 and 8. He said that Mr. Gandhi would raise no objection so long as the right of entry into the Free State were secured, as it was under the draft Bill.
('12', 447, 1, 4, 932900) I did not anticipate such a sanguine reply, but I conclude from the confidence with which General Smuts spoke that he has been in communication with Mr. Gandhi and has satisfied himself on this point He appeared to be convinced that the Bill, so far as it went, would be acceptable to the Indian community in this country.
('12', 447, 1, 5, 933223) As regards the attitude of the Orange Free State members, General Smuts recognized that Sub clause 2 of Clause 28 did not go so far as they would desire.
('12', 447, 1, 6, 933377) Their wish would be to prevent any Indian from entering their Province, and time would show whether they would prove intractable.
('12', 447, 1, 7, 933507) He hoped that they would be reasonable enough to appreciate that it would be intolerable if they endeavoured to wreck the Bill because it did not meet all their aspirations in every particular, and he considered that he had a strong argument in his armoury in that there was no absolute bar upon the entry of Indians into the Province under the present law, as the grant or refusal of permission in each case was left to the exercise of ministerial discretion, and there was nothing to prevent a Minister from admitting an unlimited number of Asiatics into the Free State if he saw fit, subject always to the statutory bar in regard to their owning fixed property, or their engaging in commerce or farming.
('12', 447, 1, 8, 934214) He seemed to think that, if this circumstance were brought home to them, their attitude might not improbably undergo some modification.
('12', 447, 1, 9, 934350) I may add that I have reason to believe that the draft of Sub clause 2 was specially submitted to General Hertzog, and that he did not take exception to its terms.
('12', 447, 2, 10, 934514) 2. I mentioned that I had failed to observe in the draft Bill any provision for giving effect to the Minister’s undertaking in his correspondence with Mr. Gandhi that provision should be made for the registration of passive resisters who, but for their passive resistance, would previously have been entitled to registration.
('12', 447, 2, 11, 934840) This point, it will be remembered, was alluded to in Paragraph 15 of Lord Gladstone’s despatch Confidential (2) of the 23rd October, General Smuts replied that it had been found that no special legislation was required for the purpose of carrying out this pledge, and that certificates of registration were now in fact being granted.
('12', 447, 3, 12, 935174) 3. As regards the dictation test, General Smuts volunteered the statement that he was considering the expediency of adopting the Australian model in its entirety and of providing that the subject of the test should be restricted to European languages.
('12', 447, 3, 13, 935426) He thought there would be no difficulty in scheduling a list of European languages, and he would be prepared to include Yiddish in the list as the overwhelming majority of white immigrants at present were of the Jewish race.
('12', 447, 4, 14, 935651) 4. He said that he was very hopeful of passing the Bill into law during the next session, and would use every endeavour in that behalf, as it was of the greatest
('12', 448, 0, 1, 935813) VOL. 12: 15 JULY, 1911 8 MARCH, 1913 449
('12', 448, 1, 2, 935854) importance that the immigration question should be regularized and settled.
('12', 448, 1, 3, 935930) The emphasis with which he spoke is the more satisfactory as a few months ago there were indications suggesting the possibility of some slackening of interest in the subject.
('12', 448, 2, 4, 936105) 1 engage in productive industry.
('12', 448, 2, 5, 936138) It will be noted that his observation on the general question of white immigration differ considerably, both in tone and in intention, from the public utterances of at least one of his colleagues.
('12', 448, 3, 6, 936335) 6. As regards the Asiatic question in the Transvaal, he expressed himself as gravely concerned by the interpretation placed by the Divisional Court upon Section 77 and 130 of the Gold Law, to which reference was made in Lord Gladstone’s despatch No.
('12', 448, 3, 7, 936585) 917 of the 23rd instant.
('12', 448, 3, 8, 936610) He considered that the decision was bad in law but he did not propose to interfere with it.
('12', 448, 3, 9, 936702) Its effect he understood to be that wherever a right to let Stands to Asiatics had existed in mining areas, outside of townships, prior to the passing of the Act, that right could still be exercised.
('12', 448, 3, 10, 936902) The result would be that a large number of Asiatic stores would spring up all over the reef, that the white trader would be crowded out, and that a considerable impetus would be given to the illicit traffic in gold and liquor in which Asiatics were prone to indulge.
('12', 448, 3, 11, 937169) He thought that further legislation might be necessary, and a solution, to which he inclined, both in regard to this particular difficulty and to the general question of Asiatic trading in the Transvaal, might have to be found in the introduction of a licensing system resembling that of Natal.
('12', 448, 3, 12, 937464) It will be remembered that the contemplation of some such expedient was indicated by Ministers in their Minute No.
('12', 448, 3, 13, 937579) 1028 of the 2nd September, which was transmitted to the Secretary of State with Lord Gladstone’s despatch No.
('12', 448, 3, 14, 937689) 737 of the 4th idem.
('12', 448, 3, 15, 937710) The scheme in General Smuts’ mind appears to be the introduction of an universal system of licensing of all businesses in the Transvaal by the local authorities, without any explicit discrimination against Asiatics, and subject to the preservation of existing rights and to an appeal to some central authority with a view to obviating the infliction of undue hardship.
('12', 448, 3, 16, 938079) He has evidently not yet come to a definite conclusion on the subject, and he appreciates that any such proposals would encounter formidable opposition in several quarters.
('12', 448, 3, 17, 938252) He said, however, that he was strongly impressed with the necessity of taking some action to check what he described as the alarming development of Asiatic trading in this Province; and that, of course, would be the practical effect of the introduction of a licensing system, however free from racial differentiation it might be in form.
('12', 448, 3, 18, 938590) The white trader, he asserted, could not exist side by side with Asiatic competition.
('12', 448, 3, 19, 938676) He quite recognized that the business methods of white trader did not entitle them to very much sympathy, as they had taken as unreasonable advantage of their opportunities and were inclined to charge excessive profits.
('12', 448, 3, 20, 938896) But however that might be, he was not prepared to face the alternative of the whole retail trade of the country falling into Asiatic hands.
('12', 448, 3, 21, 939036) As between the two evils of the undesirable business methods of white traders on the one hand, and the unlimited extension of Asiatic trading on the other,
('12', 448, 4, 22, 939192) 1 A page is missing here.
('12', 449, 0, 1, 939218) 450 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('12', 449, 1, 2, 939260) he could not hesitate to choose the former, unless he wished to stultify his ideal of South Africa as a white man’s country.
('12', 449, 1, 3, 939385) The tone of his remarks left no doubt in my mind that he was giving the question serious attention, not merely as a subject for theoretical consideration, but with a view to effective action, and it would, I fear, be idle to hope that it will be allowed to remain to abeyance.

('12', 451, 2, 2, 944270) January 6, 1912 With reference to His Excellency the Governor General’s Minutes Nos.
('12', 451, 2, 3, 944355) 15/234 and 15/235 of the 18th ultimo on the subject of the draft Immigration Bill, Ministers have the honour to state that they have given careful consideration to the further points which have been raised by the Secretary of State for the Colonies and the Secretary of State for India.
('12', 451, 2, 4, 944642) With regard to the recent settlement with the passive resisters, Ministers do not anticipate that any difficulty will occur in connection with the validation of certificates which have been issued to Indians in terms of that settlement.
('12', 451, 2, 5, 944879) The Indian leaders themselves do not ask for such legislation, and in Ministers’ opinion no question is likely to arise with any future Government of the Union, as the certificates in question are limited in number which will all have been issued in the space of a short time, and it would be impracticable, even if it were legal and possible, for any Government to recall or to refuse to recognize any such certificate which had been officially issued.
('12', 451, 2, 6, 945333) Clause 5(g): Both under the law in South Africa and under the practice in the past polygamous marriages have not been recognized, and Ministers are unable to provide any facilities in the draft Bill which would have the effect of altering the present position in South Africa.
('12', 451, 3, 7, 945610) Clauses 5(h): The Indian leaders, to whom the draft Bill has been shown, have raised no objection to Clause 5(h) in its present form, but should it appear, during the passage of the measure through Parliament, that opposition exists to the use of the word “white”, Ministers will be prepared to consider the question of an amendment.
('12', 451, 4, 8, 945944) Clauses 6 and 7: Ministers desire to state that the interpretation placed on these Clauses by the Secretary of State for the Colonies is the correct one.
('12', 451, 5, 9, 946098) Clauses 7 and 28(2): The leaders of the Indian community have raised no objection to the reference to Chapter XXXIII, but have, on the contrary, intimated that the Clause as drafted appears to afford a satisfactory solution of the difficulties which have been experienced in this matter.
('12', 451, 5, 10, 946386) Ministers desire, however, to add that the question whether it will be possible to carry the Section as it is at present drafted depends very largely on the attitude of the members of Parliament from the Orange Free State, who are most strongly against any relaxation of the provisions of the Chapter in question.
